webTitle: BBC unveils secret weapon in ratings war: South Melbourne

fields.headline: BBC unveils secret weapon in ratings war: South Melbourne
fields.trailText: She can be a cruel mistress, football. One minute she has you walking on air, the next you have to look at the camera and say: "Join us again on Tuesday when we'll have the whole of Manchester United versus South Melbourne live on BBC1 and BBC Choice." I have rarely seen Gary Lineker looking more melancholy. By my reckoning, Gary Neville owes the BBC about six million viewers.
fields.body:
She can be a cruel mistress, football. One minute she has you walking on air, the next you have to look at the camera and say: "Join us again on Tuesday when we'll have the whole of Manchester United versus South Melbourne live on BBC1 and BBC Choice." I have rarely seen Gary Lineker looking more melancholy. By my reckoning, Gary Neville owes the BBC about six million viewers.

It is entirely possible, of course, that by the time this column appears, the BBC will have rethought its live coverage of the World Club Championship to avert the wrath of angry licence payers denied their nightly fix of cookery and holiday programmes by a meaningless football match, but my view is that having spent £12m of our money the BBC should plough on with the blanket coverage.

Having been liberated over the Christmas holiday from the need to follow televised sport, I have been able to watch some of the other programmes the BBC spends our money on and not all of them, it may startle you to learn, are terrific, not even the few in which Mr Dale Winton does not figure (nothing against Dale, whom I have always admired for refusing to let the absence of any discernible talent hamper his career progress; it's just that he is a little over- exposed at present).

Viewing figures for the United match tomorrow will clearly be, to borrow Sir Les Patterson's colourful phrase, lower than a snake's armpit, but as BBC Sport is at pains to point out, the World Club Championship has a significance beyond anything that happens on the pitch, as a marker signalling the BBC's commitment to live sport.

It is also hoped the compe tition will attract new viewers to the BBC's digital channel BBC Choice, with all its exciting interactive possibilities.

Without wishing to rain on anybody's hi-tech parade, I watched a fair bit of BBC Choice's coverage of the Real Madrid-Al Nassr match, and both United games, and I have to say the exciting and innovative interactive element - and forgive me if I am being too technical - seemed to be as follows: you could phone them up.

Since most other media outlets had already given over most of their airtime to non-stop round-the-clock discussion of David Beckham's sending off/undergarments (I know this, because I was invited to appear on BBC News 24, so pretty well everybody else in Britain must already have had their say), this particular innovation failed to have me cooing with wonder.

For United v Necaxa, BBC Choice not only gave us the expert views of Mark Owen, formerly of the popular singing group Take That, but also something called the CommCam, which was a rear view of commentators Angus Loughran and Mark Lawrenson watching the match in front of a backdrop of Copacabana beach.

Though I have nothing against Loughran, who once tipped me two horses which, if they didn't actually win, lost far more convincingly than my own selections would have, I was not terribly taken with the prospect of staring at the back of his head for a couple of hours, particularly as he had only the same view of the game as I had on BBC1.

This post-modern experience of watching somebody watching the match is borrowed from Sky's Gillette Soccer Saturday where, if you are so inclined, instead of following a match on Radio 5 Live through the eyes of skilled professional reporters and Stuart Hall you can watch George Best and Clive Allen looking at a screen and telling you what they can see. At least it doesn't cost Sky very much, though.

BBC Choice might just as well have followed the idea through to its logical conclusion and put a camera in my living room, so they could watch me watching them watch the match. They might have caught my wife saying, "Can we switch it over?"

I obliged, by switching to BBC1, mainly to see if Barry Davies could come up with any new pronounciations of Solskjaer, and also in the hope that it might be raining in Rio.

"We all had our reservations about this tournament," Lineker said to his experts Alan Hansen and Steve Bruce, "but the nearer we get to kick-off, the more interest in the competition has grown." Sure. I might have been more enthusiastic about it myself, had it been the epi logue to a day spent drinking coconut milk on Copacabana beach, watching the locals demonstrate how a thong should be worn.

I wonder if John Motson felt as I did, because he was at Tranmere's Prenton Park while his colleagues were sunning themselves in Brazil. Has he upset someone in the BBC? When Davies said, "As the humidity increases, the mosquitoes arrive," I had visions of Motty sitting at home in his sheepskin jacket with a bag of Mintoes, leaping from his seat shouting, "Yes!" On the other hand, maybe he just couldn't make it to Brazil.

He was missed. I thought Davies was a little below par, spotting the United penalty and Yorke's yellow card after I did - and I was looking over Angus Loughran's left shoulder. Still, the consolation for Motty is that, like me, he can watch the West Ham-Villa replay on Sky tomorrow, while Barry Davies tries to whip up interest in the most pointless evening's television since Hale and Pace's last series.

fields.headline: Second Division round-up
fields.trailText: Colchester's Lua-Lua is on song in a nine-goal thriller, Millwall miss their chance to gain ground, and Chesterfield win at last.
fields.body:
Lomano Lua-Lua scored a minute from time as mid-table Colchester United hit back from 3-1 down to beat third-placed Bristol Rovers 5-4 at Layer Road.

Jason Roberts took his season's tally to 18 with goals in each half for Rovers and, although Steve McGavin pulled one back, Jamie Cureton's penalty put the visitors further ahead. But Colchester scored three in four minutes, McGavin with a second and two from Karl Duguid, to go 4-3 up. Cureton then missed a penalty and, although Nathan Ellington did make it 4-4, Lua-Lua secured the points.

Fourth-placed Millwall missed a chance to close on the leading group as they had to settle for a 1-1 draw at home to Wycombe.

Sean Devine gave Wanderers the lead in the 13th minute with his 18th goal of the season, and though Neil Harris equalised before the interval Millwall could not break down the visitors, who had Jason Cousins sent off for a second bookable offence after 62 minutes.

Chesterfield ended a run of 23 games without a win when David Reeves' shot three minutes into stoppage time gave them a 1-0 victory over Brentford and lifted them off the bottom. Kyle Lightbourne hit a late winner for Stoke in a 2-1 win over visiting Luton, who had Matthew Taylor sent off.

Mark Stein's 10th goal of the season put Bournemouth ahead two minutes into the second half but Gary Owers salvaged a draw for visiting Notts County 20 minutes from time.

fields.headline: European round-up
fields.trailText: The Argentine striker Hernan Crespo scored a last-minute equaliser as nine- man Parma held Juventus to a 1-1 draw yesterday, allowing Lazio to go top with a 3-1 victory over Bologna at the Olympic Stadium.
fields.body:
The Argentine striker Hernan Crespo scored a last-minute equaliser as nine- man Parma held Juventus to a 1-1 draw yesterday, allowing Lazio to go top with a 3-1 victory over Bologna at the Olympic Stadium.

Juve, despite their poor finishing, had looked like coasting to victory after Alessandro del Piero converted a 69th-minute penalty and Parma had Stefano Torrisi and Dino Baggio sent off in rapid succession.

Instead Crespo's 12th goal of the season allowed Lazio to mark their centenary by regaining the top spot which they had lost five days ago with defeat at Venezia.

Pavel Nedved and the new signing Fabrizio Ravanelli scored Lazio's second and third goals but not before Kennet Andersson had threatened to spoil his former club's party by equalising Marcelo Salas's first-half opener.

"Unfortunately we're not playing well and that's why it was vital to win today," said the Lazio coach Sven-Goran Eriksson. Lazio lead Serie A with 34 points, one ahead of Juve and three in front of Parma.

Elsewhere Udinese thrashed Perugia 5-0 and Cristiano Lucarelli's seventh goal of the season for Lecce condemned Torino to their sixth straight defeat. Bottom-of-the-table Cagliari won their first match of the season, 3-0 at home to their fellow strugglers Piacenza.

In Spain Rivaldo made a dramatic return for Barcelona yesterday, the Brazilian popping up in the final minute to seal a 2-0 win over Celta Vigo that lifted the Catalans to second in the Spanish league.

Rivaldo, who sat out two games after a row over tactics with the coach Louis van Gaal, came on as a second-half substitute with his side leading 1-0 through Luis Figo's goal after two minutes.

Barcelona are now four points behind the leaders Deportivo La Coruna, held to a goalless draw at Espanyol on Saturday. A Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink penalty was enough to secure victory for Atletico Madrid over Real Mallorca.

fields.headline: Third Division round-up
fields.trailText: Swansea move into top spot at Rotherham's expense as three see red at Barnet.
fields.body:
Swansea City moved into top spot by coming from behind to beat Hartlepool 2-1 and in the process equal a club record of eight successive wins.

Gary Jones put the visitors in front before the interval but Steve Watkin and Jason Smith replied in the second half to match the achievement of the team of 39 years ago.

Rotherham slipped from first to third as Halifax< Town pulled off a 1-0 away win, Lee Potter's 73rd-minute diving header securing the points.

Three men were shown the red card at Underhill where Barnet moved into second place with a 2-1 home win over Southend. Martin Carruthers of the vistors and Gary Heald were sent off after Mark Arber's opener for Barnet had been nullified by Heald's own-goal. Southend's Mark Tinkler was then dismissed for a second bookable offence but Daniel Brown had already secured the win for Barnet.

Hull were two up at home to Peterborough but lost 3-2 through a last-minute goal from Andy Clarke, his second of the game. City led through David Brown and a John Eyre penalty before Clarke hit his first after 63 minutes and Richard Scott levelled it with 15 minutes remaining.

Leyton Orient won 3-1 at Exeter City , who reacted by sacking the manager Peter Fox yesterday. Steve Watts got the visitors under way, Gary Alexander equalised but Dean Smith and Iyseden Christie tied it up for the Os.

webTitle: Welfare could claim Killie tie as Caley Thistle land Celtic

fields.headline: Welfare could claim Killie tie as Caley Thistle land Celtic
fields.trailText: A nail-biting week lies ahead for the East of Scotland club Whitehill Welfare. On Tuesday, they will learn whether their application to join the Scottish Football League has been successful; four days later they will attempt to earn themselves a lucrative Tennents Cup third-round tie at Kilmarnock by beating Alloa, with whom they drew 2-2 on Saturday.
fields.body:
A nail-biting week lies ahead for the East of Scotland club Whitehill Welfare. On Tuesday, they will learn whether their application to join the Scottish Football League has been successful; four days later they will attempt to earn themselves a lucrative Tennents Cup third-round tie at Kilmarnock by beating Alloa, with whom they drew 2-2 on Saturday.

"The Alloa players will be getting stick at work all week for failing to beat us," said their manager Mike Lawson."I'm sure that will make them more determined but the most important thing for us this week is entry into the league. If it were based purely on the strength of our team I'm sure we would get in. But that is not the case, so even if we don't get in, we will keep working and hope to get our chance."

Inverness Caley Thistle manager Steve Paterson is thrilled at the prospect of facing Celtic in their third-round tie at Parkhead in front of a probable 60,000 fans.

"I know we can't try to set the pace of the game," he said. "But it's in my nature to try and get in among the opposition. It should be a great experience for my players, one they should remember for the rest of their lives."

webTitle: Ferguson puts brave face on Rio meltdown

fields.headline: Ferguson puts brave face on Rio meltdown
fields.standfirst: Romario 24 26, Edmundo 43 | Butt 81
fields.trailText: As each Vasco goal went in, Manchester United's rivals at home must have choked on their pints. What was supposed to be a gruelling nightmare for Sir Alex Ferguson's team is turning into a pleasant winter break. Leeds and Arsenal ought to campaign to get them back into the FA Cup.
fields.body:
As each Vasco goal went in, Manchester United's rivals at home must have choked on their pints. What was supposed to be a gruelling nightmare for Sir Alex Ferguson's team is turning into a pleasant winter break. Leeds and Arsenal ought to campaign to get them back into the FA Cup.

Make no mistake, United are bitterly disappointed. They enjoyed becoming the world's best club in Tokyo six weeks ago; now that title has gone. But yesterday Ferguson was praising rather than cursing this competition he once hated, describing his squad's experience here as "brilliant".

United will field their fringe players against South Melbourne tomorrow and, even if they reach Friday's third-place play-off, the intensity has gone. Tired for Arsenal on January 24 or the rest of the season? More chance, surely, of John Aldridge becoming the new Carol Vorderman.

"It's been brilliant, tremendous," said Ferguson. "We have had quality training, the climate's good, what more could you ask?" One of the league games United missed is even being squeezed into a vacant Cup weekend.

The 22 children from local favelas who visited United's training site yesterday did not seem too concerned that their hosts were no longer the best team in the world. They juggled balls with players, posed for photographs and wore their United T-shirts and caps with pride. Perhaps Ferguson's words had convinced them.

"I think we were the best team in the tournament," he said. "Definitely. But if you make mistakes at this level then you've no one to blame but yourselves. We cut our own throats." On Saturday night it seemed Gary Neville had taken the charm offensive too far.

Thankfully United have repaired the initial damage off the pitch but it is their image on it which now bemuses Brazilians. Vasco fans are hardly complaining but they could not believe how poorly the champions of Europe played. The downbeat second-half atmosphere showed what an anticlimax it was.

"It was not the Manchester United I know," said the former Brazil coach Mario Zagallo. "I went to Tokyo to see them and I have seen them in England and this was a completely different team. I expected a better level of football from them. There was something wrong with United. We could see that as soon as they walked on the field. They were wilting in the heat and feeling it very badly."

Jordi Cruyff said afterwards that United would beat Vasco four- or five-nil in England. But the weather was not the true root of their downfall. Mistakes by Neville are as rare as woolly hats on Copacabana beach at this time of year. Yet he made two errors in two minutes to hand Romario his goals. Edmundo's brilliance fin ished it off. United can hardly say they were not warned of those two.

"Two unacceptable mistakes" was how Neville described it. "Contrary to what people may believe, we had come here to win this tournament," he added. "With the two mistakes I made I didn't really give the team a chance. You can't give those guys opportunities."

Even third place could be beyond United now, though it would mean nothing to them in any case. To qualify for the play-off they must beat South Melbourne and hope Vasco defeat Necaxa. Then goal difference would decide whether United or the Mexicans progress. At the moment United's is worse by four.

Undoubtedly United will try. Their youngsters will want to impress and the setting will help, even if the stands are empty. As Ferguson said: "Ninety per cent of players in the world have never played in the Maracana . . . The younger players can share the experience."

How much Saturday's experience hurt United was clear. "For me personally it was like a World Cup," Mark Bosnich said, "because I rarely get this opportunity to play on a world stage." The captain Roy Keane said the players had made "a massive effort".

The shame was that Vasco did not need a massive effort for their win. They looked nervy and United had appeared comfortable until Neville lost his head. First his loose back-pass enabled Edmundo to provide Romario with No1. Then an attempt to chest a ball back to Bosnich allowed the 33-year-old in again.

"Sometimes, when you make mistakes like that, it's better to be punished," Neville said. "It's a kick up the backside. My job is to defend. I should be clearing balls, not trying to chest them back to the keeper."

Vasco's coach Antonio Lopes deserves some credit. He said the videos he watched of United, including the game in Fiorentina no doubt, taught him to watch for back-passes and look to beat the offside trap. Edmundo needed neither for his superb strike.

After spinning past Mikael Silvestre he stretched to beat Bosnich and broke into celebrations which were almost as impressive. Under his strip was a T-shirt bearing the words "king of light" and a picture of a child. The boy was Rafael Barcelar, a Vasco fan who died of meningitis last week aged five. "The boy's wish before he died was to see Vasco beat Manchester United," Edmundo said. "The beauty of the goal is dedicated to him."

United might have scored more than just Nicky Butt's late tap-in in the second half. But, as Denis Irwin said: "If we had pushed them they might have moved up a gear."

The dream at Old Trafford of starting this millennium as they ended the last, as the best team in the world, is dead. But United will surely not look back on this trip with regret.

 Antonio Lopes has warned his Vasco players not to get carried away as they prepare for their match against Necaxa tomorrow. "More than ever it is necessary to wear the sandals of humility and not let the win over United go to our heads," Lopes said. Their full-back Jorginho has been ruled out of the rest of the tournament with a thigh strain.

Vasco fans are hardly complaining but they could not believe how poorly the champions of Europe played. The downbeat second-half atmosphere showed what an anticlimax it was. "It was not the Manchester United I know," said the former Brazil coach Mario Zagallo. "I went to Tokyo to see them and I have seen them in England and this was a completely different team. I expected a better level of football from them. There was something wrong with United. We could see that as soon as they walked on the field. They were wilting in the heat and feeling it very badly." Jordi Cruyff said afterwards that United would beat Vasco four- or five-nil in England. But the weather was not the true root of their downfall. Mistakes by Neville are as rare as woolly hats on Copacabana beach at this time of year. Yet he made two errors in two minutes to hand Romario his goals. Edmundo's brilliance fin ished it off. United can hardly say they were not warned of those two. "Two unacceptable mistakes" was how Neville described it. "Contrary to what people may believe, we had come here to win this tournament," he added. "With the two mistakes I made I didn't really give the team a chance. You can't give those guys opportunities." Even third place could be beyond United now, though it would mean nothing to them in any case. To qualify for the play-off they must beat South Melbourne and hope Vasco defeat Necaxa. Then goal difference would decide whether United or the Mexicans progress. At the moment United's is worse by four. Undoubtedly United will try. Their youngsters will want to impress and the setting will help, even if the stands are empty. As Ferguson said: "Ninety per cent of players in the world have never played in the Maracana . . . The younger players can share the experience." How much Saturday's experience hurt United was clear. "For me personally it was like a World Cup," Mark Bosnich said, "because I rarely get this opportunity to play on a world stage." The captain Roy Keane said the players had made "a massive effort". The shame was that Vasco did not need a massive effort for their win. They looked nervy and United had appeared comfortable until Neville lost his head. First his loose back-pass enabled Edmundo to provide Romario with No1. Then an attempt to chest a ball back to Bosnich allowed the 33-year-old in again. "Sometimes, when you make mistakes like that, it's better to be punished," Neville said. "It's a kick up the backside. My job is to defend. I should be clearing balls, not trying to chest them back to the keeper." Vasco's coach Antonio Lopes deserves some credit. He said the videos he watched of United, including the game in Fiorentina no doubt, taught him to watch for back-passes and look to beat the offside trap. Edmundo needed neither for his superb strike. After spinning past Mikael Silvestre he stretched to beat Bosnich and broke into celebrations which were almost as impressive. Under his strip was a T-shirt bearing the words "king of light" and a picture of a child. The boy was Rafael Barcelar, a Vasco fan who died of meningitis last week aged five. "The boy's wish before he died was to see Vasco beat Manchester United," Edmundo said. "The beauty of the goal is dedicated to him." United might have scored more than just Nicky Butt's late tap-in in the second half. But, as Denis Irwin said: "If we had pushed them they might have moved up a gear." The dream at Old Trafford of starting this millennium as they ended the last, as the best team in the world, is dead. But United will surely not look back on this trip with regret.  Antonio Lopes has warned his Vasco players not to get carried away as they prepare for their match against Necaxa tomorrow. "More than ever it is necessary to wear the sandals of humility and not let the win over United go to our heads," Lopes said. Their full-back Jorginho has been ruled out of the rest of the tournament with a thigh strain.

webTitle: Southgate in striking form to pre-empt penalties

fields.headline: Southgate in striking form to pre-empt penalties
fields.trailText: West Ham United had better watch out. Not only is Gareth Southgate threatening to hand over the penalty-taking duties to his team-mates but his third goal in two games from open play means he may even settle tomorrow night's re-run Worthington Cup tie before it ever gets to the shoot-out stage.
fields.body:
West Ham United had better watch out. Not only is Gareth Southgate threatening to hand over the penalty-taking duties to his team-mates but his third goal in two games from open play means he may even settle tomorrow night's re-run Worthington Cup tie before it ever gets to the shoot-out stage.

"I'm always available to take penalties but it might sometimes be wiser to say to someone else, 'You have a crack,'" the Aston Villa captain acknowledged on Saturday. "Penalties are not my forte, as you know."

Maybe not, but goalscoring presently is. As the only Villa player to have found the back of the net in the last 180 minutes Southgate can claim sole responsibility for upsetting the Premiership leaders Leeds United and now for knocking Southampton out of the FA Cup.

This was a tepid match that warmed up only when Southgate displayed his customary opportunism in the 20th minute. After Claus Lundekvam had been booked for pulling back Julian Joachim on the left, Paul Merson swung in the free-kick, Ian Taylor headed the ball back across the six-yard line and South gate stooped to conquer.

The watching England coach Kevin Keegan must have been impressed. No defender in the country is playing as well as Southgate and he easily snuffed out the threat of the reborn Kevin Davies, who was coming off a run of three goals in three games. That is something that gave Southgate as much satisfaction as scoring.

"It's pleasing that we made a lot of chances and should have won easily but we also limited them to only a few opportunities," he pointed out with professional relish.

Not that Southampton posed much of a threat. This was a spiritless show by the Saints, who had beaten Ipswich away in the last round, and it hardly bodes well for their annual battle against relegation. Jones is clearly having difficulty motivating his players and he looks like a man at his wits' end.

"It doesn't matter what team you put out, they have to go out and perform and today we couldn't even make a pass over five yards," he said after David James in the Villa goal did not have a save to make. "We never really got them turned, our forward line was non-existent and you can't perform at the highest level when only three players are doing the business." .

John Gregory' problems are mundane in comparison but perturbing none the less. Southgates' success in front of goal tells its own story about the lack of bite from Villa' forwards and, with Dion Dublin out for the rest of the season with a damaged neck, the manager said he was considering shopping for a striker.

"Southgate is getting into the penalty box to score, which wasn't possibly the case before. But I'd like to see the strikers score, I must say, it does worry me," Gregory said. He refused to mention the C-word but it seems the forgotten Stan Collymore is now a target for the German club Bayer Leverkusen.

Villa have reached a crucial part of their season. They are on a mini run of 10 points from 12 in the league and the talk now is of a Uefa Cup place, most probably through one of the cup competitions, magnifying considerably the importance of tomorrow night's visit to Upton Park in a quarter-final being replayed because West Ham fielded an ineligible player the first time round.

That night Southgate missed the crucial penalty in the shoot-out; now he aims to settle things in advance of extra-time. "The miss is past history," he said. "We're looking forward to going there and winning the game."

fields.headline: Second bite for Wolves
fields.trailText: Even the Luddites among us are grudgingly accepting that the case for referees to be aided by television replays is becoming overwhelming. Though that alone might not have been sufficient to avoid the dreadful error at Tranmere, here a "third eye" similar to that employed in cricket Tests would have helped ensure Wednesday's progress to the fifth round.
fields.body:
Even the Luddites among us are grudgingly accepting that the case for referees to be aided by television replays is becoming overwhelming. Though that alone might not have been sufficient to avoid the dreadful error at Tranmere, here a "third eye" similar to that employed in cricket Tests would have helped ensure Wednesday's progress to the fifth round.

On this occasion the controversy surrounded a linesman who was providing a third eye. Unfortunately the assistant referee Trevor Massey's view was impeded by a goalmouth scramble 40 yards away and he was incorrect when he signalled that Steve Sedgley's header had crossed the line. None of the Wolves players had claimed that it had.

It was no less than Wolves deserved for a stirring second-half fight-back but it was hard not to sympathise with the Premiership's whipping boys, whose manager Danny Wilson asked: "How can a linesman, 40 yards away with 20 bodies in front of him, make that sort of decision? I find it unbelievable, particularly when Wolves haven't even claimed for it."

Perhaps the most alarming aspect of the affair for Wednesday was the almost Corinthian grace with which they accepted their fate. Aside from the goalkeeper Pavel Srnicek's appeal at the final whistle there was no dissent, merely the casual air of resignation with which their players have begun to accept their fruitless travails in the Premiership.

There is nothing wrong with being magnanimous but it is hard to imagine Manchester United or the Leeds team of the early 70s being so accepting of such an injustice. Srnicek, who appeared to have clawed the ball to safety after it hit the post, later shrugged: "That is typical of our luck this season."

Also typical of Wednesday this season was the fact that they performed adequately for only 20 minutes. The Swedish midfielder Niclas Alexandersson opened the scoring with an adroit finish for a deserved ninth-minute lead but, after chances were missed by Ian Nolan and Gerald Sibon, Wednesday went into their shells and almost invited the 68th-minute flash point which levelled the tie.

Wolves had been coming closer and closer, thanks mainly to Wednesday's tendency to concede set pieces in dangerous positions, and Sedgley's header, from a well worked corner routine, gave them the equaliser they merited, even if the circumstances were controversial.

"I thought we deserved the draw, for sure," said Colin Lee, the Wolves manager.

"We're delighted to take them back to Molineux, but we've still got a hard tie ahead of us."

webTitle: Scallywags have Chelsea looking to the bench

fields.headline: Scallywags have Chelsea looking to the bench
fields.trailText: Tore Andre Flo must have wished after one of this season's most freakish Premiership games that his celebrated role as a substitute with the goal touch had never come to an end. Chris Sutton, his striking partner, must dread that, as long as he remains at Chelsea, a decent part will never materialise at all.
fields.body:
Tore Andre Flo must have wished after one of this season's most freakish Premiership games that his celebrated role as a substitute with the goal touch had never come to an end. Chris Sutton, his striking partner, must dread that, as long as he remains at Chelsea, a decent part will never materialise at all.

Chelsea squandered more than 30 chances against a Bradford side that, for all their vigour and persistence, were repeatedly left bemused and befuddled.

Flo's distress at failing to mastermind a Chelsea victory arose from a mountain of missed opportunities, which brought to mind a phrase almost made famous by Magnus Magnusson: "I've started but I can't finish." Four chances went begging in the first 15 minutes and, after that, only the obsessive statisticians kept counting.

For Sutton came a greater torment: the realisation that, even on an extraordinary day like this, he had failed to make an impact. Largely innocuous, he was substituted for Gianfranco Zola midway through the second half and, if there had ever been a day when he might have been expected to score six and put his Chelsea misery behind him, this was it.

In terms of entertainment it was marvellous stuff but in essence this was a fluke result that told us what we already knew.

Bradford, to adopt the phrase used by their manager Paul Jewell, are "a bunch of scallywags" who may survive through their spirit. Chelsea again left Gianluca Vialli dismissing his side's Premiership chances with an air of courteous incredulity.

While Vialli maintains his composure, the same cannot be said of some of his players. What can one conclude from the actions of players who respond to a team-mate's missed chance by gesturing to the bench with irritation? Who are they trying to kid?

As Chelsea repeatedly failed to equalise Lee Mills' 59-second goal for Bradford, their frustration mounted. Gustavo Poyet's failure to convert two good opportunities early in the second half caused first Dan Petrescu, then Albert Ferrer, to fling their arms towards the bench in disbelief. What were they indicating? Bring Gianfranco on? Come out of retirement, Gianluca?

Petrescu, forever elusive in a free-ranging midfield role, finally claimed that equaliser 13 minutes into the second half. Roberto Di Matteo, who had been on the field only a few seconds, won possession in midfield and slid through a pass for Petrescu to tear beyond the defensive cover and beat Matthew Clarke.

When Zola did at last come on to replace Sutton there was every indication that a second Chelsea substitution would also prove influential. Twice in the last 10 minutes it almost did but Clarke, by now, was thoroughly warmed up after a succession of comfortable saves.

Bradford, roused by the equaliser, shrugged off their defensive impotence and counter-attacked with the spirit of a side that has now gone six games unbeaten at Valley Parade. Mills spurned two decent chances and Neil Redfearn's headed goal was disallowed for offside. They might have stolen it. Vialli can be grateful that Chelsea at least escaped the final ignominy.

webTitle: England miss a trick for Centurion

fields.headline: England miss a trick for Centurion
fields.trailText: St George's Park was eerily empty yesterday. No brass band chugging out its renditions of It's A Heartache and Delilah, no television and the merest scattering of spectators sprawled on the grass bank at the Duck Pond End, soaking up the sun. It was Sunday in Port Elizabeth and, on the most sensational azure summer's day, the population had better things to do.
fields.body:
St George's Park was eerily empty yesterday. No brass band chugging out its renditions of It's A Heartache and Delilah, no television and the merest scattering of spectators sprawled on the grass bank at the Duck Pond End, soaking up the sun. It was Sunday in Port Elizabeth and, on the most sensational azure summer's day, the population had better things to do.

That was a sentiment shared by the big guns in the England team. The tourists are here to play a South African Invitation side, at sea level whereas the Test on Friday is at altitude, over three rather than four days in what must rank as one of the most meaningless matches played by an England side on tour in recent years.

Who at the England and Wales Cricket Board is responsible for approving such schedules? Does he consult those who are going into the front line?

To show how much the tourists think of the fixture, anyone who is anyone in the England Test team, with the exception of those - Michael Vaughan and Alan Mullally - who have spent too much time sidelined to be able to justify three days with their feet up, was omitted and instead England fielded members of the one-day squad.

And as the Cadbury's Flake on top of this particular ice-cream, Graeme Hick rather than Vaughan - a successful Under-19 and A-team leader and, genuinely, a prospective successor one day to Nasser Hussain - was pronounced captain on the spurious premise that he is the most experienced player. New management or not, England's capacity for the occasional foray into crassness remains untrammelled.

Those who struggled long and hard through the heat and humidity of the back-to-back Tests over the festive season deserve their time out to recharge before Centurion. No quibble there: the captain must be drained mentally never mind physically, Michael Atherton's back will always remain a concern, all of the pace bowlers were on their knees after Cape Town and Alec Stewart has bobbed up and down behind the stumps for days on end and done a magnificent job.

But there is, as Hussain put it, a bloody important Test match coming up and, Vaughan aside, there are two batsmen, Mark Butcher and Chris Adams, who have scarcely scored a run in the series. Even if Darren Maddy comes into the Test side, either Butcher or Adams will have to play and should have been in the side for this game, should indeed have been beating the door down to play. But perhaps the England management will draft in Hick, say, or Vikram Solanki for the Test, which would mean reneging on their assertion that they would select exclusively from the original touring party.

The makeshift side got themselves back in the game well enough after the Invitation side's opener Rudi Steyn, who played three Tests and a single one-day international five years ago, had threatened to score a century in the two hours before lunch.

In little more than an hour he had made 52 of the 62 for one scored, and by the interval had hit 10 fours and three sixes (two off Alex Tudor and one from Graeme Swann) in his 90. After lunch, however, England, through Mark Ealham's diligence in particular, pegged him back and eventually he holed out to fine leg for 93.

This match being reminiscent of the old county championship, the Invitation XI declared their first innings at 253 for seven, with three wickets for Tudor and a brace apiece for Mullally, who had not bowled in a match since the Saturday of the Wanderers Test six weeks ago, and Ealham, leaving England 20 minutes to bat in which time Maddy and Nick Knight scored 16 and survived comfortably enough.

Mullally later said that he was "raring to go" after his rib injury. "I'd like another spell out there in this game, but I wouldn't be too concerned if that didn't happen," he added. "I've bowled 20 overs here which has got the cobwebs out, and it's just a matter of ticking over now."

Someone will fill his boots today, probably Hick (although the book would be closed on that one), but in the great scheme of things it will matter not a jot.

webTitle: Radio just in time for England batting collapse

fields.headline: Radio just in time for England batting collapse
fields.trailText: Australia's radio pioneers tuned in to cricket just in time to record an England batting collapse.
fields.body:
During the Newlands Test last week - and quite a few more of recent lamenting memory - as Mark Nicholas's ball-by-ball Talk Radio commentating team described the helter-skelter of England wickets falling in a bunch, at the same time as breathlessly ensuring their ruddy office-rental sponsor received its money's worth of mentions, you might have wondered what it was like in the supposed golden ages of long ago, pre-sponsorship, when England batsmen stayed magisterially at the crease for day upon day under the sweltering suns of Empire.

A nice anniversary shows, in fact, that nothing much has changed. The humiliation in Cape Town coincided, almost to the day, with the 75th birthday of ball-by-ball broadcast cricket commentary and, wouldn't you know, a dreadful England batting collapse of almost modern proportions.

The Ashes Test in Sydney on England's 1924-25 tour, led by Arthur Gilligan, was played over seven days, with a break for Christmas Day, at the end of December 1924. The city's local 2BL wireless station had one of its cricket-loving reporters, one Hyam Marks, sitting inside the SCG's famous scoreboard alongside the venerable former Australian batsman Clem Hill. At irregular times through the match, the two of them described "occasional passages of continuous play" to listeners.

The first Test match wicket to fall, simultaneous to being described on air, was the opener Warren Bardsley's, caught by Frank Woolley off Tich Freeman for 21 in Australia's first innings of 450 (Collins 114, Ponsford 110, Tate six for 130).

England went in. Uncannily it was virtually a prophecy of what was to come on cricket broadcasting's 75th anniversary. In Cape Town last week, as the millennium dawned, England's first innings proceeded from an opening partnership of 115 between Mark Butcher and Michael Atherton to 213 for three before the last seven wickets collapsed for 45 and, everything frenziedly described on Talk Radio, 258 all out.

In Sydney three-quarters of a century before, Jack Hobbs and Herbert Sutcliffe put on 157 for the opening stand, after which Patsy Hendren (74 not out) steered them to 202 for three before watching at the other end as the last seven folded in a heap for 72 (Hearne 7, Woolley 0, Sandham 7, Chapman 13, Tate 7, Gilligan 1, Freeman 0, Strudwick 6) and all out 298. And all described live on Sydney's 2BL wireless station. Nothing new under those Empire suns.

Australia won that auspicious first Test by 193 runs and when they disdainfully wrapped up the series by 4-1 back at the SCG in March the wireless experiment was suc cessfully repeated. This time it was advertised as "commentary and scores". Later that year, when the Australia v The Rest Test Trial match (before selection of the 1926 side to tour England) was held in Sydney, the wireless transmission was trumpeted as "unique ball-by-ball commentary".

This time it was the city's 2FC channel which did the honours, the intrepid broadcasters this time being Len Watt, a news reporter and Sydney grade cricketer, and the soon-to-be celebrated radio pioneer HP Williams, who was to become the first general manager and luminary of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. This time they worked at ground level on a trestle table almost behind the bowler's arm on the boundary line under the famous Hill.

So Australians were very much the groundbreakers at cricket broadcasting. In Britain the fledgling BBC first attempted a live cricket commentary in May 1927 - Essex v the New Zealanders at Leyton - but it was deemed to be far too deadly dull, transmitting none of the excitement nor immediacy of the Twickenham rugby international or Wembley Cup final which they had covered live for the first time earlier that year.

Meanwhile, Sydney's HP Williams had studio-bound commentators receiving snap cables describing each delivery for Australia's Test matches abroad, and after each over they would colour in the bare facts with descriptive inventions as-if live, along with "canned" sound effects for applause and pencils tapping microphones for the impression of willow on leather.

T here had long been, of course, newsreel film of sports events, and many flickering clips survive. Feature documentary films, too, of championship boxing matches. The first live radio coverage of a boxing match was transmitted by landline into six New York cinemas in 1921, when Jack Dempsey fought the Frenchman Georges Carpentier in New Jersey. (Baseball match descriptions began similarly in private "closed circuit" pay-to-listen theatres.)

But it wasn't until all of six years later, in September 1927, that a championship boxing match was heard live by a general audience - when 82 radio stations "nationwide" transmitted the second fight between Dempsey and Gene Tunney from Chicago. "the referee is counting . . . three, four . . . Carpentier no effort to rise . . . five, six . . . he's sunk to the mat . . . nine, ten . . . The fight is over! Jack Dempsey remains world champ!" Not bad, Major, for a historic, culture-setting first.

fields.headline: Faith in the future
fields.standfirst: Despite the series defeat, there were enough success stories in South Africa for England's cricketers to return with cautious optimism and confidence in some names for the future
fields.trailText: Despite the series defeat, there were enough success stories in South Africa for England's cricketers to return with cautious optimism and confidence in some names for the future.
fields.body:
The end, when it came, was swift, as if a dam had burst. England had left Johannesburg six weeks ago beaten in the first Test but unbowed, and confident in their capacity to compete on an equal footing given good pitches, fitness and an even share of the luck.

And they did, they competed so well in Port Elizabeth that were it not for some indifferent umpiring they might have won the match, as indeed they might also have done in the debilitating heat and humidity of Durban. Yet they could not find the killer punch, the one telling blow that would floor the South African team, and by the time Cape Town was reached the chance, we now know, had been lost. There, in the shadow of Table Mountain, England crumbled.

It is precisely 13 years ago today that England, under Mike Gatting, began the final Test match of their successful Ashes tour, and the record abroad in the interim has been dismal. Fifty-eight matches have been played since that trip, in 14 series plus a couple of one-off matches, and only nine of them have been won, four of them in New Zealand who were beaten in the 1991-92 series and again five years later.

In the eight full series of five or more matches, not once have England come within a sniff of winning, and the last time they went into the final match of such a series even with the rubber still undecided was in the Caribbean six years ago. Brian Lara put any ambitions firmly in their place with his triple century.

So to come to South Africa this winter, with an inexperienced side under the stewardship of a new captain and coach, and expect (as opposed to hope) that they might win was fanciful. This is an immensely powerful South African side with a depth in batting unparalleled in Test history. They are playing at home, where since their readmission they have won 20 of 37 matches, losing only five. Only the Australians, and that in a close and withering contest, have beaten them in a series.

Sense of purpose

Putting things in context, then, Nasser Hussain's team have acquitted themselves well, gaining respect for their spirit, sense of purpose, togetherness and tenacity. Certainly they were undeserving of the nasty, not to say deeply insensitive assertion of a tabloid newspaper that the team should be incarcerated on Robben Island. In fact, they would do well to remember that Nelson Mandela was sustained in part during his imprisonment by his capacity to take the long-term view. Hussain and Duncan Fletcher came to South Africa wanting to win the series, but above all they wanted to see progress being made towards a more stable and consistent England in the future.

Selection was geared accordingly, and not as a reaction to the knee-jerk demands for new players that followed last summer's disastrous series against New Zealand.

"When I came into the job," Hussain has said, "we had tried the top six for quite a while and it wasn't working. It was felt that this tour had to be a watershed." So familiar faces such as Graham Thorpe (by his own choice), Mark Ramprakash and Graeme Hick were missing and new ones - Michael Vaughan, Chris Adams, Darren Maddy - brought in. Of the batsmen, only Vaughan has been a success, and he only partially since he has yet to score a half-century. But he looks the part, is clearly temperamentally suited to Test cricket, has good technique and will be around now for a while. Had Hick and Ramprakash been selected (and they may yet get back into the side) Vaughan would not have had the opportunity to state his credentials.

Fletcher and Hussain have already forged a profitable alliance, one that is respected by the players. The captain has his finger on the pulse and clearly has within him not just a sound cricket brain but a streak of ruthlessness. He presents himself to the media as articulate, thoughtful and deeply passionate. Fletcher is understated, a world away from the frenetic tenure of David Lloyd. Efficiency would be his watchword and he knows precisely where he would like England to be heading and on what timescale.

He fully acknowledges the huge task his side faced out here and therefore has managed to keep a sense of perspective. Progress, he says, is up to schedule and perhaps even ahead, despite the fourth Test. If there are casualties - Adams looks likeliest and probably Mark Butcher too - then they have been given the freedom to play in their own way, confident that they would be given a run. They have been allowed every chance. Out of it already Vaughan has been identified as someone in whom to invest, but so too have Chris Silverwood and Andy Flintoff. That, Fletcher would say, is not a bad way to begin replacing the fabric of the side, and Andrew Caddick and Hussain himself have cemented their roles as England's key bowler and batsman.

There is an argument which says that, with the series already lost, the rebuilding should start now; that Hussain's ruthlessness should be demonstrated with the swift introduction of Vikram Solanki, for example. Fletcher and the captain, however, have said they will not be looking outside the original tour party for this week's final Test at Centurion.

"It would be divisive at this stage," says Fletcher, and he has a point. In addition, he notes, there is not much to be learned in one game and didn't it take Herschelle Gibbs and Jacques Kallis time to learn the ropes at Test level? The management are prepared to back their judgment and the capacity of players to absorb lessons and respond accordingly.

The real business starts when they return home, and Fletcher knows that the job of lifting the side to the competitive and technical levels enjoyed by the Australians and South Africa will be monumental. He is keen to explore the mental side of players as well as their technical ability.

"You have to look at that aspect," he says. "I have been involved with Gary Kirsten for years and someone once asked me whether he would make it as a Test player. I said that technically I wasn't sure but that mentally he was tough and if you have that inner strength there is no limit to what can be achieved."

However, Fletcher will be hampered by a county system which encourages mediocrity and then expects players to switch to international cricket without losing a beat, and by a massive international programme which precludes him watching domestic cricket to any great extent.

He will be obstructed too in his search by the appalling standard of pitches on which young cricketers in their formative years and seasoned pros alike are compelled to play. Fletcher cites Gibbs and Kallis once more as players whose game has been honed on true surfaces and stresses the need for bowlers to be able to develop variety, allied to patience, in order to compete on proper Test pitches.

The England and Wales Cricket Board is going some way in trying to eradicate poor pitches by the introduction next season of a "flying squad" who can get to a ground at a moment's notice. However, it could legislate as well (and this goes for the International Cricket Council too) by placing the responsibility for assessing a pitch in the hands of the umpires (or match referee) and giving them the power to award choice of innings to the visiting team if it is substandard. The Wanderers would have made an interesting test case.

Perhaps the biggest steps will be the awarding of central board contracts and the establishment of an academy to augment those operated by the regional boards. Contracts should not be handed out as grace and favour to old lags but as a means of maintaining standards and control, particularly over those on the way up. Flintoff, for example, would benefit, as would Alex Tudor or Steve Harmison.

Finishing school

The formation of an academy will not in itself be the panacea that many would like to think. The version that works so well in Australia, run by Rodney Marsh, is not a sausage factory where ordinary cricketers go in and emerge as internationals. Rather it is a finishing school. Players who go there are already quality youngsters with a track record. Marsh simply knocks off the rough edges, instilling a sense of values, an understanding of their heritage, a respect rather than the typical English contempt for the past, and both mental and physical discipline. The ECB must take this as its model.

But it will all take time. There is, as Fletcher and Hussain say again and again, no quick fix. We have been too bad for too long for the solution to emerge overnight. They have made a start, though, and if Vaughan, Flintoff and Silverwood become mainstays of the side over the next six years, this tour will not have been in vain.

webTitle: Youth at the helm until it goes under

fields.headline: Youth at the helm until it goes under
fields.trailText: Two years ago, the defeat of the England Test side in the West Indies was tempered by victory in the World Youth Cup. Have faith in a brighter future, we were told. Today, we again seek out indications of better times ahead: England's senior side have lost in South Africa, but the U19 side which begins its defence of the World Cup crown in Sri Lanka tomorrow is widely regarded as the team to beat.
fields.body:
Two years ago, the defeat of the England Test side in the West Indies was tempered by victory in the World Youth Cup. Have faith in a brighter future, we were told. Today, we again seek out indications of better times ahead: England's senior side have lost in South Africa, but the U19 side which begins its defence of the World Cup crown in Sri Lanka tomorrow is widely regarded as the team to beat.

Tim Boon, the England U19 coach, even has the rare luxury of pronouncing in Colombo: "We are not merely here to defend the World Cup but to retain it, without every other Test nations sniggering into their Lion lager." This upbeat mood could not exist at senior level, and has not existed for the past 20 years. When David Lloyd, then England's senior coach, spoke encouragingly of winning the World Cup on home soil last summer, the cynical reactions of disbelief left him cursing English sport's capacity for negativity.

But such negativity is understandable. English team sport is failing to compete and English cricket is failing most of all. If England persistently shine at U19 level - even regularly outdoing the Australians, who all the evidence tells us have a tougher sporting upbringing than we do - then a few years later, the rot invariably sets in.

The chief culprit is widely regarded as county cricket. Many young players, given to believe at age-group level that they are stars of the future, become frustrated by a lack of opportunity. Even those immediately promoted can quickly find ambition deadened on an exhausting county circuit, where an overcrowded fixture list is maintained for the benefit of a few thousand elderly spectators.

There remains hope that England's last World Youth Cup winners can reverse the trend. Paul Franks, at Nottinghamshire, has proved himself a combative all-rounder, qualities re-emphasised on this winter's England A tour in New Zealand. Chris Schofield's leg-spin is observed with relish not just within Lancashire. Robert Key's batting is highly regarded at Kent, and might have brought him an A tour ahead of Durham's Michael Gough.

But, for all that, county cricket breeds complacency, and hinders development. Fast bowlers can virtually arrange their operation for a stress fracture in advance because of the excessive strains placed on developing bodies. Batting techniques are undermined by English cricket's persistent failure to produce consistent pitches of even bounce, where skill will out.

Two years ago, Owais Shah was a media item, the A level student taking time off studies to bring England glory. That is worth recalling in a week when David Blunkett has envisaged an educational future in which schools may remain open until 10pm. For youth sport, such a future will spell chaos.

Shah, in any case, has faltered, just as the much-touted Ben Hollioake before him. Shah was one of several Middlesex players criticised by the Australian batsman, Justin Langer, for a slack attitude towards maximising their talent. Hollioake even claimed that he is "uncoachable". It is a comment that would invite derision in Australia, but in England, boredom, fatigue and conceit are an ever-present danger.

County cricket has at least been browbeaten into action. Next season, the championship splits into two divisions, with promotion and relegation. The transfer system will quicken, whatever the resistance, and in five years, perhaps less, a first division elite will possess the cream of the cricketing talent.

But problems remain. The collapse of cricket in state schools maintains an over-reliance on the private schools, and on fast-tracking players identified at an early age. Alex Loudon, Kent's England U19 captain, has deserved his accolades. But his background is cliched: Eton College and England age-group cricket from U14 level onwards.

English club cricket, although slowly awakening to its responsibilities, cannot fill the breach. The elite leagues introduced by the England and Wales Cricket Board will remain a nonsense until the best players play in them.

A governing body with any guts and innovation would immediately enforce a pyramid system of club cricket, with free movement throughout all leagues, demand proper coaching and youth development, and blacklist all league clubs who failed to comply.

Boon has experience of Sri Lankan conditions, having played for Colombo CC in 1983. He must know that for England to repeat, in the humidity of Sri Lanka, their victory in South Africa two years ago would be an achievement against the odds.

England's U19s can do nothing more than win and, if they do, they deserve us to glory in any success, even if we believe it means little. Their opening match tomorrow, against one of the seven non-Test nations, pits them against America. Imagine if cricket really caught on in the United States. Nobody would rest until a cricket pitch had been laid in every state school in Britain.

England squad

Alex Loudon (Kent, capt)
James Adams (Hampshire)

Ian Bell (Warwicks, left)

Michael Carberry (Surrey)

John Maunders (Middx)

Gary Pratt (Durham)

Justin Bishop (Essex)

David Harrison (Glam)

Tim Murtagh (Surrey)

Tim Phillips (Essex)

Nick Warren (Warwicks)

Graeme Bridge (Durham)

Ian Pattison (Durham)

Mark Wallace (Glam, w-k)

Schedule

Group matches
Jan 11 England v Americas Jan 13 England v West Indies Jan 15 England v Zimbabwe (all matches in Colombo)

Super League phase
Jan 18 - Jan 22

Semi-finals
Jan 24 (Galle and Colombo)

Final
Jan 28 (Colombo)

That is worth recalling in a week when David Blunkett has envisaged an educational future in which schools may remain open until 10pm. For youth sport, such a future will spell chaos. Shah, in any case, has faltered, just as the much-touted Ben Hollioake before him. Shah was one of several Middlesex players criticised by the Australian batsman, Justin Langer, for a slack attitude towards maximising their talent. Hollioake even claimed that he is "uncoachable". It is a comment that would invite derision in Australia, but in England, boredom, fatigue and conceit are an ever-present danger. County cricket has at least been browbeaten into action. Next season, the championship splits into two divisions, with promotion and relegation. The transfer system will quicken, whatever the resistance, and in five years, perhaps less, a first division elite will possess the cream of the cricketing talent. But problems remain. The collapse of cricket in state schools maintains an over-reliance on the private schools, and on fast-tracking players identified at an early age. Alex Loudon, Kent's England U19 captain, has deserved his accolades. But his background is cliched: Eton College and England age-group cricket from U14 level onwards. English club cricket, although slowly awakening to its responsibilities, cannot fill the breach. The elite leagues introduced by the England and Wales Cricket Board will remain a nonsense until the best players play in them. A governing body with any guts and innovation would immediately enforce a pyramid system of club cricket, with free movement throughout all leagues, demand proper coaching and youth development, and blacklist all league clubs who failed to comply. Boon has experience of Sri Lankan conditions, having played for Colombo CC in 1983. He must know that for England to repeat, in the humidity of Sri Lanka, their victory in South Africa two years ago would be an achievement against the odds. England's U19s can do nothing more than win and, if they do, they deserve us to glory in any success, even if we believe it means little. Their opening match tomorrow, against one of the seven non-Test nations, pits them against America. Imagine if cricket really caught on in the United States. Nobody would rest until a cricket pitch had been laid in every state school in Britain. fields.headline: United stave off inevitable
fields.trailText: Glamour, glory and heroics may be associated with the FA Cup, but for two struggling Second Division clubs such as these there is only one thing that counts: money.
fields.body:
Glamour, glory and heroics may be associated with the FA Cup, but for two struggling Second Division clubs such as these there is only one thing that counts: money.

Cut behind the smiles and relief of Cambridge, a team who had not tasted victory on their travels for nine months, and the harsh reality is that it was absolutely vital they won.

A bumper pay day in the fifth round and they can stave off the transfer of one or both of their match-winning strike force of Martin Butler and Trevor Benjamin.

Their manager Roy McFarland knows it will be only a temporary reprieve, but he also knows it might just be long enough to save their increasingly precarious Second Division skins.

So Cambridge were laughing all the way to the bank. Wrexham on the other hand were left bemoaning a result that turns the spotlight back on their poor league form - they have not won for 16 games - and they know they probably need to buy to pull themselves clear of the relegation zone.

A lucrative Cup run would possibly have done the trick. But, as their manager Brian Flynn is all too aware, football very rarely gives you what you want or need. "After we beat Middlesbrough I was a hero, now some fans want me out," he said. "You'll have to ask the chairman whether my job is under threat.

"We are prepared for a long hard battle. Unfortunately we haven't got a spare million to go out and improve our squad. Cambridge's two strikers are probably worth that and I wish we could afford players like them."

Benjamin put Cambridge ahead with a diving header and Butler regained the lead from a 52nd-minute free-kick after Karl Connolly's looping header had equalised. It was an excellent display of finishing by Cambridge and one which Wrexham, who hit the woodwork three times, need quickly to emulate.

"There has been interest in Butler and Benjamin from Premiership clubs," said McFarland. "I don't want to lose them but this club is losing half a million pounds a season and one of the ways we survive is by selling players.

"It is inevitable that someone will offer the money we are prepared to sell them for."

webTitle: Time Warner and AOL to merge

fields.headline: Time Warner and AOL to merge
fields.trailText: Time Warner, the world's biggest media corporation, and America Online, the world's leading online service provider, today announced a $250bn merger that will combine traditional and new media into one gargantuan enterprise.
fields.body:
Time Warner, the world's biggest media corporation, and America Online, the world's leading online service provider, today announced a $250bn merger that will combine traditional and new media into one gargantuan enterprise.

With its film, cable, TV and publishing assets, Time Warner is already a titan in traditional media. By merging with America Online, Time Warner is seeking to leverage those assets for the next phase in the communications revolution as the internet becomes the dominant mode of disseminating information.

America Online chairman and chief executive Steve Case is expected to be named chairman of the merged company, while Time Warner's chairman and chief executive Gerald Levin will be chief executive, according to Dow Jones.

."This is an historic moment in which new media has truly come of age," Mr Case said.

Dow Jones reports that AOL shareholders are likely to hold a majority stake in the merged company of just over 50%. Based in Dulles, Virginia, AOL currently has a market capitalisation of about $164 billion, roughly twice the $83 billion of New York-based Time Warner, but the deal's terms are unlikely to value AOL as highly.

The merger comes at a time when traditional media, including newspapers, are positioning themselves for a proliferation of outlets. In a recent sign of the convergence of old and new media, Rupert Murdoch recently acknowledged the importance of the internet and announced a major push by his media companies into the area.

In the coming year, customers will be able to get information via mobile phones that have access to the internet, putting more pressure on traditional media companies to explore new ways of getting their information across to people. Conversely, internet companies are looking to put entertainment and other content on their websites to attract customers.

Shares in UK media groups Granada Group Plc and Pearson Plc rose sharply on news of the imminent merger announcement from the US. Granada shares - also lifted by renewed talk of a possible demerger following the company's statement on Friday that it may bid for one of its UK media rivals - gained 55-1/2 pence or 9.5% in early morning trading. Pearson was up 133p or 7.8% at 1,834p.

The two were among the leading gainers in the FTSE 100 index, along with Reed International Plc, up 23-1/2p or 5.3%.

Inevitably, there will be questions as to whether Time Warner-AOL will be an unwieldy giant. Time Warner already is a massive empire composed of Warner Bros, its Hollywood studio, a big music business, a publishing arm, Time magazine, the CNN cable news network, a TV network and cable systems. The company is frequently subject to feuds within its various business units. Time Warner is also expanding into the telephone business.

Time Warner also has been trying to build so-called hubs on the internet that focus on entertainment and news and created a high-speed internet service called Road Runner. Last month it set up a $500 million fund to invest in digital media, giving it access to technology in such areas as electronic commerce and interactive television.

"This is a defining event for Time Warner and America Online as well as a pivotal moment in the unfolding of the internet age," said Time Warner President Richard Parsons.

Once considered a bit of a joke because of delays and glitches in its service, AOL has become a powerful internet presence with over 20m internet customers. It overcame teething problems when subscriber demand overwhelmed services; now its flat monthly fee for unlimited access is the accepted business model for online services. Last year, it solidified its status as the world's leading online provider, when it purchased Netscape, the pioneering internet browser company.

AOL has been buying web-based services during the past few years to expand beyond its proprietary online service to compete with Yahoo! Inc. and others that offer web services for free. Last month AOL bought MapQuest.com for about $1bn to link online mapping with its entertainment and advertising services.

fields.headline: Keep up
fields.standfirst: Missed what the top analysts are saying   about our digital future? Catch up here
fields.trailText: Missed what the top analysts are saying about our digital future? Catch up here
fields.body:
Steve Outing, Stop the Presses column at www.mediainfo.com "The most difficult task for many traditionally trained publishers is to embrace the notion of setting free the content they pay to produce. The 20th-century model was to produce news content of such quality that consumers will buy your newspaper or visit your website rather than the competition's. The 21st century model is to get your content and brand name everywhere, so that consumers as they navigate the diverse online media environment will see your content even though they may never pick up your newspaper or magazine or visit your website."

Morgan Cartwright, online manager of Contra Costa Newspapers, replying (on the same site) to forecasts in Outing's previous column that newspaper groups would increasingly merge their traditional and online operations: "Fact is, most of the larger newspaper groups are moving in the opposite direction. One reason for this is the growing salary gap that makes it difficult or impossible to retain folks with web experience unless you pay them more, and give them stock options. You can't have one editor getting options and a high salary sitting next to a print person making much less. "[Also] online has become so competitive, so fast-evolving, so complex, that it simply doesn't work to ask a newspaper management team to build this new business while trying to grow the existing print business. Even if they had the time, would they have the expertise? Online is a very different business than selling printed newspapers. And it becomes more different every day."

Michael Wolff, www.newyorkmag.com "I predict that Amazon.com will be the Atari of the Internet. In 1982, at the dawn of the personal-computer revolution, Atari was as iconic and as admired and as economically significant as Amazon is at this moment. And then it wasn't. It was out of business. The first time I opened Amazon to its familiar depersonalized personalized greeting and got offered a power tool, I knew what my prediction was."

James Leadbetter, www.theStandard.com "Ever since the Commerce Department began focusing on the 'digital divide', the issue has been discussed largely as a racial gap. For good reason: it's undeniable that there's a net-access chasm between whites and most non-white populations. But some close to the data say that the digital divide is not a racial divide at all. 'I've been looking at these numbers since 1998,' says Idil Cakim, an analyst for a New York Net research firm, 'and I've determined that income is the controlling factor for internet access.' According to Cakim's research, there is essentially no digital divide among the wealthiest Americans of any race."

fields.headline: Waging global war
fields.standfirst: As US net expansion reaches saturation point, news websites are spending millions targeting the rest of the world to ensure instant recognition and future profits. Bob Eggington reports
fields.trailText: As US net expansion reaches saturation point, news websites are spending millions targeting the rest of the world to ensure instant recognition and future profits. Bob Eggington reports
fields.body:
Suppose the Daily Beast were to start its own global news website. It would be a surefire winner, right? After all, the internet is creating huge new business opportunities and billions of pounds in revenue - and news websites are among the fastest-growing, most popular categories in the business. The money would just come rolling in, right? Up to a point, Lord Copper.

There is no doubt the internet is creating massive wealth. A study by the University of Texas put the value of internet-related business in the US last year at $300bn, and rising. But where is the money going? At this relatively early stage of the industry's existence it is going, mostly, to the people who provide the technology: the infrastructure providers (Cisco and Sun), the telecoms companies (Bell, ATT and BT), the major internet service providers (AOL) and software businesses (Microsoft).

Where it is not going is to the websites themselves - at least, not in sufficient quantities to make a profit for very many of them. The vast majority are losing money. And the big news websites, with their large staffs and relatively small revenues, are recording some of the biggest losses, despite the fact that some are now beginning to raise significant revenues.

The internet world is one in which a company's true financial picture is seldom disclosed. Spin and speculation are rife, but hard facts are rare. An honourable exception was ABCNews.com, the third largest of the American news sites, which published a loss of $21.5m in its first year of operation (1997/98).

It was hailed for its candour - but the publicity hurt. This year the parent Disney Corporation has chosen not to give ABC's individual figures. Instead these are included in overall losses for the group's internet operations of more than $1bn.

CNN, which also does not give individual financial information about its internet activities, said its news site made a small profit last year - its fourth year in existence. But, it added, it would not expect to make a profit next year because the money would be ploughed into global expansion.

All the other large news organisations are making similar decisions: the argument is not about how to make money from the web - but how to spend it. Their concern is not about how to increase revenue (though they are all trying to do that) - it is about how to establish themselves in the minds of users as the website of choice for following the news.

They are spending heavily to achieve the dominant positions in the global news market. Then, when profitability finally arrives, they will be the ones to benefit.

Attention has begun to shift to the "global market" because growth in internet usage in the US is at last beginning to slow down. One research firm, Cyber Dialogue, reported that the US internet population grew by just 13% in 1999, compared to 58% in 1998. This is seen as the inevitable result of a market reaching maturity.

It also means that the big areas of growth in the years to come will be outside North America. Europe, South America and Asia have become important target markets.

The relatively mature US market has shown that there is only room for a limited number of big news sites. CNN and MSNBC got off to flying starts and have remained the big players. ABC News and Fox have achieved some success but CBS, who entered last, have found it almost impossible to make any impact.

So how many big global news sites can prosper? Two? Four? Six? Well, despite the immature, incoherent and largely abstract nature of the "global market", there are already three: CNN, Yahoo News and my own site, BBC News Online. All three have mature global strategies and significant numbers of users around the world.

Yahoo is slightly different from CNN and the BBC, in that it is a "news aggregator" and not a primary source in its own right. It acquires news content from various agencies, newspapers and other organisations and pulls it all together. This makes its news look a bit odd sometimes to professional observers, but the wired public does not seem to mind. Yahoo has become a major news brand in its own right.

Yahoo is also one of the few big websites that is making money - and it is ploughing much of it back into expansion around the world. Yahoo currently has 21 international news sites in three continents, all offering news. MSNBC, the joint-venture between Microsoft and NBC, is trying hard to repeat its US success on a global level. But it has the same problem confronting all three of the main US television networks: a shortage of content.

Since the news networks came into play on Wall Street in the 80s, cost-cutting has led them to close news bureaux and reduce foreign coverage to a fraction of what it was. MSNBC's response has been to enter into a partnership with the Washington Post and Newsweek to share their content.

Merril Brown, editor in chief of MSNBC, says: "We will get world-class content from the Post and Newsweek. The Washington Post will have access to our multimedia and Newsweek will have a new home on the web. We'll cover some big events together, create special internet and television projects and deal with the complexities of foreign coverage in ways that will substantially improve the editorial capabilities of all involved."

How this partnership will work between two companies that are essentially competitive in the same internet space remains to be seen. But the Washington Post has not given up its own plans to offer an authoritative global news site.

An internal memo to the editorial staff from one of the company's senior executives said: "Multimedia, the integration of audio clips, streaming video, live interactive chat and other media into core journalistic text, may be the killer application that news publishers have been groping toward.

"Think about how these tools can be applied to the very best of what the WP [Washington Post] does every day. We need to push past (our competitors) by combining our deep, credible, personality-filled, wide-ranging journalism with the new tools of search, personalisation and multimedia that have caused these other sites to grow."

A new global news site is expected soon from late internet convert Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation. A News Corporation executive says: "The news site will have to have access to all of the news material created by all the News Corporation companies. This won't be easy in the the highly federal structure of News Corp, in which all the different newspapers and TV operations guard their independence fiercely. But we will have to co-operate with each other because we recognise that a news site needs all the elements: text from the newspapers, and audio and video from the broadcasting bits of the empire."

A big debate is now going on within News Corporation over who is to make the site, and what it will be called. One camp wants to launch the site under the banner of the Times, a historic news brand which would have some recognition among the global audience. But Foxnews.com in the US is already up and running with a rolling-news culture and access to audio and video - elements which are seen to be vital if the new site is to be competitive.

But how will all these sites make money? Gerry McGovern, the internet analyst and founder of the web consultancy Nua, says: "The internet is inherently a publishing environment. However, three things differentiate it from more traditional publishing environments. Firstly, because the internet has not fully penetrated many markets and demographics, it is still quite costly to create new content for it. To be viable means repositioning as much already created content as possible.

"Secondly, traditional news media are very focused on 'today's news'. The internet is inherently an archive environment and those who create logical, easily searchable content archives will achieve new revenue sources. Thirdly, the internet is inherently a participatory environment. Leveraging users so that they become content creators through chat, reviews, etc, must be fully exploited."

Despite the fact that nobody knows how or when it will happen, there is agreement that websites will one day make money. And when it comes, news websites will be among the big money-spinners. These two key assumptions have become a sort of received web wisdom - a rare beast in an industry characterised by madcap growth, tiny revenues, no agreed standards and fierce controversy over the future. But the hype artists and the gloom merchants, as well as the careful analysts, all agree that "content sites", like news, do have a future, and a rich one at that.

 Bob Eggington is editor of BBC Online
