A new global news site is expected soon from late internet convert Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation. A News Corporation executive says: "The news site will have to have access to all of the news material created by all the News Corporation companies. This won't be easy in the the highly federal structure of News Corp, in which all the different newspapers and TV operations guard their independence fiercely. But we will have to co-operate with each other because we recognise that a news site needs all the elements: text from the newspapers, and audio and video from the broadcasting bits of the empire." A big debate is now going on within News Corporation over who is to make the site, and what it will be called. One camp wants to launch the site under the banner of the Times, a historic news brand which would have some recognition among the global audience. But Foxnews.com in the US is already up and running with a rolling-news culture and access to audio and video - elements which are seen to be vital if the new site is to be competitive. But how will all these sites make money? Gerry McGovern, the internet analyst and founder of the web consultancy Nua, says: "The internet is inherently a publishing environment. However, three things differentiate it from more traditional publishing environments. Firstly, because the internet has not fully penetrated many markets and demographics, it is still quite costly to create new content for it. To be viable means repositioning as much already created content as possible. "Secondly, traditional news media are very focused on 'today's news'. The internet is inherently an archive environment and those who create logical, easily searchable content archives will achieve new revenue sources. Thirdly, the internet is inherently a participatory environment. Leveraging users so that they become content creators through chat, reviews, etc, must be fully exploited." Despite the fact that nobody knows how or when it will happen, there is agreement that websites will one day make money. And when it comes, news websites will be among the big money-spinners. These two key assumptions have become a sort of received web wisdom - a rare beast in an industry characterised by madcap growth, tiny revenues, no agreed standards and fierce controversy over the future. But the hype artists and the gloom merchants, as well as the careful analysts, all agree that "content sites", like news, do have a future, and a rich one at that.  Bob Eggington is editor of BBC Online

webTitle: Desktop icons, No 1: The Qwerty keyboard

fields.headline: Desktop icons, No 1: The Qwerty keyboard
fields.trailText: It is beautifully nonsensical, a model of inefficiency. And yet almost anyone who has ever typed a letter, sent an email or logged on to a computer has had to work around its delightful idiosyncrasies.
fields.body:
It is beautifully nonsensical, a model of inefficiency. And yet almost anyone who has ever typed a letter, sent an email or logged on to a computer has had to work around its delightful idiosyncrasies.

Named after the layout of its first five letters, the Qwerty keyboard is 126 years old, and seems entirely illogical. But despite countless upstart attempts to dislodge it, this curious arrangement of letters has retained its position of absolute cultural dominance.

'Twas not ever thus. When Christopher Latham Scholes made his first "type-writer" in 1868, the letters were arranged alphabetically in two rows. Nobody in backwoods Milwaukee had yet dreamed up the concept of touch-typing - the preferred method was the two-fingered "find and peck" technique still favoured by bosses around the world - but even at snail-like speeds the up-striking "typebars" had a tendency to jam. Scholes redesigned the layout, separating common pairs such as T and H, and conveniently allowing salesmen to master a speedy fluency in typing the machine's name - all the letters of the word "typewriter" occur in the top row of the keyboard.

But like any hegemonic belief system, Qwerty has its dissidents. A small but passionate caucus favours the rival Dvorak keyboard, designed in 1932 by an American university professor. All logic suggests that Dvorak is by far the better system. Its "home" (middle) row AOEUIDHTNS uses the five vowels and the five most common consonants, leading to a far more natural typing rhythm. Professor Dvorak estimated that a typical day's typing on a Qwerty keyboard required the fingers to travel 16-20 miles; with his system, he claimed, the figure is one mile. None of which has had any notable effect on Qwerty's absolute supremacy. Like imperial weights, driving on the left and the monarchy, things would be probably be a lot simpler if the system were abolished and replaced by something logical. But isn't efficiency dull?

fields.headline: The sec's files
fields.trailText: Are you ready for the new world of work?
fields.body:
 Brave New Workplace

Are you ready for the new world of work? Most of us are not, according to management guru Tom Peters, who believes that 90% of white collar jobs will disappear or change beyond recognition in the next ten years. And faced with a revolution, Peters has done what any good management guru would do and started a movement. Called Work Matters! it aims to help people to understand the challenges ahead and to prepare for them. The website at www.tompeters.com explains the theory behind the movement and invites discussion on ways to cope with the workplace changes.

 Tips to get ahead

New research from Royal Mail's special delivery team has found that half of all secretaries are now empowered to make business decisions, and one in ten hold the purse-strings in the office. The general trend is towards increased responsibility for support staff - 40% of those surveyed said they have to do less and less typing and dictation, and now have more responsibility. The team has produced a guide full of tips for secretaries on how to get ahead at work, available free by writing to Smart Moves Guide, 22 Endell Street, London WC2H 9AD.

 It's in the badge

In the fine tradition of innovations you didn't know you needed until you discovered them, ID badge manufacturer IDentilam has launched its Conference Card Caddie, designed to transport delegates' badges to business conferences without them becoming disorganised. A lightweight plastic case with removable trays, the Card Caddie holds up to 112 badges in ordered rows. It can be customised with your company's logo, and comes in seven colours. For details, contact IDentilam on 01293 854700.

 Overseas info

As business becomes increasingly global, staff who want to work abroad are more valuable than ever to international organisations. But the way such mobile workers want to be rewarded is changing - it is no longer enough for companies to offer a good pay packet and then leave their employees to get on with their foreign posting. According to the Institute of Personnel and Development, today's international workers are looking for recognition of a good work/life balance, and need motivation and career management even though they are working at a distance. The institute has produced a guide on reward packages for international workers. The IPD Guide on International Reward and Recognition by Stephen J Perkins and Chris Hendry costs £7.50. Tel: 01752 202301.

Compiled by Penny Cottee, editor of Executive PA magazine Freda Gardiner's final Sec's Lives column appeared on December 13

fields.headline: The low down: Workplace bullying
fields.trailText: Bullying in the office is something we deplore in the abstract but often condone on a day-to-day basis. Call bullying "creative tension" and suddenly it becomes acceptable - nobody wants to speak out against creativity.
fields.body:
Bullying in the office is something we deplore in the abstract but often condone on a day-to-day basis. Call bullying "creative tension" and suddenly it becomes acceptable - nobody wants to speak out against creativity.

What makes adult bullying nasty is that it is a "top-down" process. Inevitable comparisons with the school playground don't really hold water, because the big kid who steals your child's Pokemon cards doesn't pay their salary. Grown-up bullying may be less to do with a rogue individual and more to do with the culture of an entire organisation.

At the British psychological society's occupational psychology conference last week, Iain Coyne of the University of Hull suggested that the correct way to control organisational bullying was to concentrate on the victims.

Coyne and his colleagues have identified a personality profile of the typical employee likely to be bullied. Using personality tests they discovered the potential victim is likely to be "anxious, unstable, introverted and conscientious."

This is not to suggest that nature obligingly turns out victims as fodder for an office-based "survival of the fittest". The personality may well be a product of the environment - put bluntly, the victims are likely to be over-careful because they will get shouted at if they get something wrong.

This may be effective in the short-term but it is a cruel and depressing way to get things done. The personality profile, Coyne suggests, can be used to identify employees who should be treated in a different way, perhaps through a mentoring scheme or assertiveness training.

Although the emphasis is on the victims, Coyne says it is a "two-pronged" approach. It also benefits the organisation - managers have a freer hand with their "creative tension" with less risk of ending up before an industrial tribunal.

fields.headline: Met 'not equipped' to solve murders
fields.trailText:
Britain's biggest police force was criticised today for its failings in murder
investigations, in a damning report highlighting undermanned and overworked
squads.
fields.body:
Britain's biggest police force was criticised today for its failings in murder investigations, in a damning report highlighting undermanned and overworked squads.

The report found that senior investigators at the Metropolitan police were regularly forced to juggle 12 murder cases, with fewer resources than were given to their counterparts in provincial forces.

Officers throughout the Met said they did not believe that investigating murder was a priority for the force, which has a murder solution rate of 84% compared with an average of 92% nationwide.

Some complained that senior officers were indifferent to the problems they faced, coupled with "unacceptably low staffing levels" within murder squads, according to the report by Her Majesty's inspectorate of constabulary. It found "too many staff working under pressures which are avoidable and cannot be justified".

One senior detective told the inspection team: "The Met is not equipped to investigate lengthy murder inquiries."

The report found there was a common perception among staff that chief officers had little understanding of what was involved in a murder investigation. It concluded: "If the MPS is to improve on its performance in respect of murder detection there must be an increase of staff allocated to murder investigation."

Senior investigators told inspectors that they were at times carrying "excessively high" workloads, with one saying he was looking into 14 murder offences.

The report said: "Her Majesty's Inspector ... is concerned that an SIO may be tempted to focus time and resources on new 'easy to solve' cases at the expense of longer running cases."

However, it commended officers' work in training in murder scene attendance and investigation and said the majority of staff demonstrated a commitment "of which the MPS can be proud".

The study was ordered by home secretary Jack Straw after the Stephen Lawrence report last year and looked into the investigation of murders and the force's community and race relations policy.

However, the report did find considerable improvements in the Met's race relations policy and practice.

Considerable efforts have been made to improve services to London's ethnic minority communities. Although more thought needs to be given to a pan-London strategy, the inspection judged that stop and search initiatives had been well-managed.

Much more effort is needed to attract and retain ethnic minority staff, but the work of the racial and violent crime task force was highly praised.

The inspector, Dan Crompton, said that he was confident that further improvements would have made by the beginning of 2001.

Home office minister Charles Clarke said he was concerned at the finding by inspectors that officers did not see murder investigations as a key priority.

The report said: "There is more to be done in securing the hearts and minds of non-specialist police officers. A pervasive feeling exists among some staff that what is seen as special treatment for the victims of racist attacks can only be delivered by prejudicing service to the wider community.

"Until officers and staff understand the impact of hate crime because of skin colour or cultural difference, securing the appropriate initial response to victims will remain an unfulfilled challenge."

But it said the internal culture within the force had improved despite the low level of officers from ethnic backgrounds.

Senior officers at the Met said its murder clear-up rate should not be compared to provincial forces but instead judged against other major capital cities. The Met's clear-up rate is higher than Paris at 75%, Dublin at 74%, Amsterdam at 70% and Washington DC at 44%, according to figures collected by Scotland Yard.

The report said it could not be proved that the Met was a special case but found that its relatively low detection rate was down to low resources rather than the competence or expertise of officers.

webTitle: Tranmere tie will not be replayed

fields.headline: Tranmere tie will not be replayed
fields.trailText: FA Challenge Cup committee decide that the FA Cup fourth round tie between Tranmere and Sunderland will not be replayed. Saturday's result stands and there will be no appeal against the ruling.
fields.byline: By Football Unlimited staff and agencies
fields.body:
FA Challenge Cup committee decide that the FA Cup fourth round tie between Tranmere and Sunderland will not be replayed. Saturday's result stands and there will be no appeal against the ruling.

The Challenge Cup committee decided that Tranmere had not "knowingly and deliberately distorted the outcome of the game".

Spokesman Adrian Bevington added: "What happened on Saturday clearly relates to the laws of the game rather than competition rules.

"Their conclusion was that Tranmere did not knowingly and deliberately distort the course of the game in its final minutes. The result of the game will stand.

"Referees and match officials are under considerable pressure, not least in high profile cup ties. Their decisions on the laws of the game are final and for the good of the game they have to be accepted."

"The FA's referee committee has been asked to give urgent consideration to the events which took place at Prenton Park last Saturday."

Referee Rob Harris dismissed Tranmere defender Clint Hill late in Saturday's match for a second bookable offence and when the First Division side introduced Stephen Frail as a substitute they failed to take Andy Parkinson off immediately.

Harris allowed play to restart and Frail helped defend a Sunderland free-kick, challenging Jody Craddock for the ball, before the substitution mistake was noticed and Parkinson left the field.

After the match Sunderland boss Peter Reid acknowledged there had been a breach of the rules and Tranmere manager John Aldridge was quick to lay the blame at the feet of Harris and fourth official David Unsworth.

webTitle: Rebel attacks take toll on Russia

fields.headline: Rebel attacks take toll on Russia
fields.trailText:
Russian forces today battled to hold on to two key towns under heavy attack from
Chechen rebels as Moscow admitted to the heaviest losses in a single day since the current campaign began.
fields.body:
Russian forces today battled to hold on to two key towns under heavy attack from Chechen rebels as Moscow admitted to the heaviest losses in a single day since the current campaign began.

With its offensive to take Chechnya stalled, the Russian military has been forced on the defensive in recent days. Chechen rebels launched attacks yesterday to take the towns of Argun and Shali, which were captured last month by Russian forces.

An interior ministry spokesman said today that rebels killed 26 Russian soldiers and wounded 30 during the last 24 hours. Russia has claimed for weeks that its losses are no more than one or two a day, despite persistent reports by soldiers in Chechnya that casualties are much higher.

Russian defence minister Igor Sergeyev said that a temporary lull in bombing of the capital Grozny for Orthodox Christmas was over. But Russian forces did not stop ground operations around Grozny despite the weekend lull.

After steadily retreating over the last few months, the rebels have gone on the offensive in the past week in Grozny and other parts of Chechnya.

Russian commanders said their troops had gained the upper hand in Argun and Shali after rebel attacks, but reports from the area said fighting was still raging for the two towns.

Military leader Viktor Kazantsev claimed that Russian forces have pushed back a force of 300 rebels who attacked Argun, located nine miles east of Grozny. "The federal troops are in full control of the situation within the town," Kazantsev said. He said federal troops were "mopping up" Argun, an indication that scattered groups of rebels were still putting up resistance in the area.

Chechen forces rejected the Russian claims, insisting that they were in control of Argun. Acting president Vladimir Putin "will beg us for peace," said Salanbek Aduyev, a rebel leader.

Kazantsev said Russian troops had the upper hand in Shali, located 12 miles south-east of Grozny. But military sources told the ITAR-Tass news agency that there was still heavy fighting in the town.

The Interfax news agency also reported that federal troops were surrounded in the local administration building in Shali, and that well-protected gunmen were firing on them from nearby buildings.

Despite the latest attacks against them, general Kazantsev said today that the Russian offensive would end in two months. Russian commanders have made similar claims several times, but the military does not currently appear close to a final victory in Chechnya.

webTitle: Met lent stopped car to Lawrence

fields.headline: Met lent stopped car to Lawrence
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The father of the murdered teenager Stephen Lawrence was driving a car loaned to him by the Metropolitan police when he was stopped by officers investigating a robbery, it was revealed last night.
fields.body:
The father of the murdered teenager Stephen Lawrence was driving a car loaned to him by the Metropolitan police when he was stopped by officers investigating a robbery, it was revealed last night.

Neville Lawrence was stopped and interviewed for 20 minutes in St John's Wood, north London, in the early hours of December 27, by two officers called to the robbery which had taken place a few hours earlier.

The car had been provided by Scotland Yard for security reasons, a source confirmed yesterday.

Mr Lawrence, who was in the car with his cousin, has lodged a formal complaint both into the handling of the investigation and their questioning about the robbery and details of the car and its contents.

The Met has also ordered its own inquiry into the incident which happened when Mr Lawrence and his cousin were stopped on the Lisson Grove estate, in Paddington, west London, just before 1am after visiting friends. They were not searched and after being in terviewed were allowed to continue their journey.

The police complaints authority is expected to study the legal basis for the officers' demand to know what was in the vehicle and allegations that Mr Lawrence clearly stated the police liaison officer who dealt with him as a protected witness would answer any questions about the car.

Scotland Yard frequently provides cars for security reasons to people they feel require the facility to avoid being traced. Officers can swap plates or cars on demand if it is felt security could be compromised.

A Met source added that the car had been hired specifically for Mr Lawrence and that other provisions had been made to tighten up security at his home and on his telephone line.

In December Mr Lawrence and his estranged wife, Doreen, issued writs against 42 officers involved in investigating the murder of their son whose killers are still free.

Last night a spokesman for the Metropolitan police refused to comment formally on any security arrangements regarding Mr Lawrence.

In December Mr Lawrence and his estranged wife, Doreen, issued writs against 42 officers involved in investigating the murder of their son whose killers are still free. Last night a spokesman for the Metropolitan police refused to comment formally on any security arrangements regarding Mr Lawrence.

fields.headline: Other replayed games
fields.trailText:
Manchester City v Luton (FA Cup, 1961)
Denis Law had scored all six goals as Manchester City moved into a 6-2 lead at Luton in the fourth round of the FA Cup, only for the match to be abandoned due to fog with 10 minutes remaining. Luton won the replay 2-1 and Law had his goals removed from the record books.
fields.body:
Manchester City v Luton (FA Cup, 1961)
Denis Law had scored all six goals as Manchester City moved into a 6-2 lead at Luton in the fourth round of the FA Cup, only for the match to be abandoned due to fog with 10 minutes remaining. Luton won the replay 2-1 and Law had his goals removed from the record books.

Newcastle v Nottingham Forest (FA Cup, 1974)

Forest were leading 3-1 when Newcastle fans staged a pitch invasion. After the game resumed, the Magpies came back to win 4-3, only for the Football Association to order a replay on neutral ground. After a 0-0 draw at Goodison Park, Newcastle finally won the second replay 1-0 and eventually went on to lose to Liverpool in the final.

Leeds v Stuttgart (European Cup, 1992)
Leeds thought they were out of the Uefa Cup despite winning the second leg of the tie 4-1 at Elland Road. Stuttgart scored the vital away goal, but it turned out that they had also broken Uefa regulations by fielding four foreign players instead of the permitted three. Swiss international Adrian Knup came on as a substitute, and it was three minutes until Italian Maurizio Gaudino was taken off. The replay was played at a neutral ground - the Nou Camp - and Leeds won 2-1.

Arsenal v Sheffield United (FA Cup, 1999)
After an injury to an Arsenal player, Sheffield United sportingly kicked the ball into touch. When the Gunners tried to return the ball, new signing Kanu, looking to make a good impression, intercepted and created the winning goal in a 2-1 victory. Gunners boss Arsene Wenger claimed that Kanu was not aware of the custom of returning the ball, and both teams agreed to replay the match. Again, Arsenal won 2-1.

Farnham v Herne Bay (FA Cup, 1999)

Herne Bay used four substitutes in their FA Cup qualifying match victory earlier this season. Their chairman realised the mistake and went straight to the FA, who ordered the game to be replayed, this time at Farnham. The game went to a second replay, but eventually Herne Bay ran out 2-1 winners.

West Ham v Aston Villa (Worthington Cup, 1999)

Manny Omoyimni came on for seven minutes in this Worthington Cup tie, but had already played in an earlier round of the competition whilst on loan to Gillingham. The Hammers went on to win the match on penalties, but the FA ordered the tie to be replayed.

webTitle: How Coronation Street threatened Good Friday deal

fields.headline: How Coronation Street threatened Good Friday deal
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: A row over the rights to screen Britain's top soap, Coronation Street, was parachuted into the Irish peace talks, according to minutes of an Anglo-Irish ministerial meeting released to the Guardian.
fields.body:
A row over the rights to screen Britain's top soap, Coronation Street, was parachuted into the Irish peace talks, according to minutes of an Anglo-Irish ministerial meeting released to the Guardian.

The culture secretary, Chris Smith, had to fight to stop the dispute between Ulster TV and Ireland's main state station from souring the Good Friday agreement.

The bizarre sideshow to the agreement is revealed in minutes of a meeting in Dublin last June between Mr Smith and his Irish counterpart, Sheila de Valera, granddaughter of Ireland's former president Eamon de Valera. They have been released to the Guardian under the Irish freedom of information act. The British documents are banned from public view until 2030.

The row broke out when Radio Telefis Eirrean (RTE) decided to build a transmitter which would beam the soap into 70% of homes in Northern Ireland compared with its usual 30% - threatening the dominance of the Belfast-based Ulster TV. Furious UTV executives protested to Dublin because RTE would be poaching their own Coronation Street viewers by transmitting the soap at the same time.

Briefing notes for the meeting suggest that the angry UTV executives could be mollified by a provision in Ireland's broadcasting bill giving Ulster broadcasters new digital wavebands in the republic.

Her civil servants then briefed her that the only way to solve the transmission row might be to get a joint "exchange of letters" with Mr Smith to bring back "a climate of confidence in the British broadcasters and officials".

Minutes of the meeting revealed that Mr Smith was happy to sort out the soap war. They say: "The secretary of state agreed we were 'nearly there' and that this matter was quite relevant to the Good Friday agreement. He was happy to ensure that all necessary steps are taken - RTE services will soon be available to some 70%... of the North."

Friends of Mr Smith confirm that the deal was part of a wider agreement that everyone - north and south - should have the greatest possible choice of programmes.

fields.headline: Straw attacks woolly liberals
fields.standfirst: Straw attacks lawyers and 'liberals'
fields.trailText: Jack Straw will this week attack the "knee jerk" hostility of fellow lawyers and the hypocrisy of "Hampstead liberals", who condemn his plans to curb the right to trial by jury but urge him to override legal procedures when the accused is someone of whom they disapprove - such as the suspected Nazi war criminal Konrad Kalejs.
fields.body:
Jack Straw will this week attack the "knee jerk" hostility of fellow lawyers and the hypocrisy of "Hampstead liberals", who condemn his plans to curb the right to trial by jury but urge him to override legal procedures when the accused is someone of whom they disapprove - such as the suspected Nazi war criminal Konrad Kalejs.

In a hard-hitting speech defending his new criminal justice (mode of trial) bill, the home secretary will argue that lawyers always resist reforms and that his own plans to make the criminal justice system more "effective and fair" are modest compared with those of his widely admired Labour predecessor, Roy Jenkins.

Mr Straw will cite recent demands to detain rather than deport the Latvian-born Mr Kalejs to justify his attack. "There is disdain for Hampstead liberalism, because there is hypocrisy at its core. Part of what I am doing in this speech is to show that there is great inconsistency - as there has been in the last week."

But he will also register similar contempt for the attacks made by some "woolly minded" critics of his package of measures to curb anti-social behaviour. He admits that barely a dozen such orders have been taken out so far, but insists they are "restraining behaviour which was otherwise not restrained" in tough neighbourhoods where his critics do not live.

"I have also got disdain for the fact that under the cloak of liberalism, though I think it is woolly-minded liberalism, they take no account of the situation of those who are less favoured than they. Those who are criticising some changes we have made are immune from - and absolutely refuse to acknowledge - the extent of the harassment that people endure on rundown estates."

Addressing the Institute for Public Policy Research, a left-leaning thinktank, in London on Thursday, he will not only mention the Kalejs case but also that of the murdered teenager Stephen Lawrence. He will contrast the "defining cases" of the 1970s and 1980s, miscarriages of justice which saw the Guildford Four and Birmingham Six wrongly convicted, with their 1990s equivalent.

"I will be suggesting that the defining case in the 1990s will be the Stephen Lawrence case, where the issue was not someone who was innocent and found guilty, but the opposite failing: the system's failure to secure a charge and conviction in respect of whoever it was who murdered a black teenager."

The innocent must be protected, but the guilty must also be caught, he will suggest.

If enacted, the new jury law will deny defendants the automatic right to opt for jury trial in crown court in such cases as theft and burglary. It is seen by some lawyers as too pro-prosecution and has been condemned by both the Bar Council and the Law Society.

Despite the uproar, Mr Straw, whose reform has the backing of the lord chief justice, will argue that the present system is open to costly and time-consuming abuse. It also backfires, producing higher sentences for those convicted after pleading not guilty in a crown court trial than they would have received from magistrates.

"What barristers say publicly and what is said in private are two very different things. Most people I know at the bar know there is a racket going on, with persistent criminals who know how to play the system," he said in a Guardian interview which will outrage many lawyers.

Unrepentant, the home secretary accuses his own profession of "a detachment, an unwillingness to engage seriously in a debate about modernising the judicial system", to help protect the innocent and ensure that it deals more effectively with the guilty.

But the uproar about Konrad Kalejs underlines the importance of getting the right balance, he will say.

"There is a powerful sense of ambiguity, particularly among people on the left, about how you deal with crime and criminals. Generally their approach is one which is, above all, concerned about the rights of defendants. But when it comes to particular crimes and suspects there is a reaction which some people have shown in the past two weeks. It's almost as if they are demanding a 'guilty as charged bill'. Certainly they demand that normal process should be abandoned," Mr Straw said.

"For example, the Liberal Democrat spokesman demanded that I use my powers to detain Kalejs. If I was to publish a white paper saying that in future home secretaries ought to have powers to detain people on suspicion - it's called internment, by the way - and the Liberal Democrat spokesman signed up to it, there would be a hue and cry. Quite right, yet they do not recognise there is any inconsistency in this approach."

webTitle: 'Fair and effective' Straw lays down the law

fields.headline: 'Fair and effective' Straw lays down the law
fields.standfirst: Home secretary maintains his scepticism on proportional representation and is ready for a fight with Hampstead liberalsProportional representation: special report
fields.trailText: After a rough week in one of the toughest jobs in government, a home secretary needs all the friends he can get. But Jack Straw loves nothing better than picking a friendly quarrel with natural allies on the progressive wing of politics.
fields.body:
After a rough week in one of the toughest jobs in government, a home secretary needs all the friends he can get. But Jack Straw loves nothing better than picking a friendly quarrel with natural allies on the progressive wing of politics.

Mr Straw is preparing a speech on crime and liberty, to be delivered in London on Thursday, and has "just discovered a wonderful quotation from Helena Kennedy", the New Labour QC and peer.

"She talks about the knee jerk response of most lawyers, especially those with progressive attitudes, to resist any change that might affect the position of a defendant," he reports with glee.

That is the nub of his defence against lawyers who are attacking his plans to curb the right to jury trial.

He is going on the offensive, in sharp contrast to his refusal to be drawn into the controversy over HM inspectorate of constabulary's critical report on the Metropolitan police's handling of racial crime until after it is published today.

But during a relaxed interview, Straw cheerfully picks another fight with "Hampstead liberals" and their hypocrisy over crimes they rarely suffer themselves.

As for Liberal Democrats with whom Mr Straw sits on Tony Blair's joint consultative committee (JCC), they are guilty of the above offences, as well as of over-selling the merits of electoral reform.

Now that Britain has started introducing proportional representation (PR) "people can see that 'fair votes' will lead to very unfair elections", sniffs the cabinet's most vocal PR-sceptic.

So Labour supporters who rejected PR in the party's leaked consultation exercise were right? "I think the evidence pretty accurately reflects the mood throughout the party towards PR. I always thought it would once people moved from the general to the particular. It's easy to make an argument against first-past-the post and say we should have something better."

The home secretary is careful to give formal endorsement for PR voting systems adopted for Scottish and Welsh devolution. "It's the system we all supported, it's the one that is there," he said.

But, without saying as much he is evidently dismayed with the results so far, squabbles in Edinburgh and a minority Labour regime in Cardiff. "You ask me why the mood in the party has hardened against PR. The answer is that people no longer have to look at it in the crystal ball, they can read it in the book," he said. Experience in Scotland and Wales "had not delivered the step-change in political culture that advocates of PR have often wished".

That sounds a premature verdict from a politician who remains convinced that many of the changes he is promoting in the criminal justice system will not catch on right away. Anti-social behaviour orders, for instance, will take a long time to bed down because "there is a strong view in the criminal justice system, as elsewhere in British public life, that nothing should ever be done for the first time".

On PR, however, Mr Straw is adamant. When he strays on to party funding (another of the high profile home office reforms this session), he is quick to blame Helmut Kohl's prob lems in Germany on the list system of PR voting whereby political elites never lose their seats as Michael Portillo did under the "sudden death arrangements" of first-past-the-post voting.

"Whether they are in office or not [in Germany] they are always in power. That is the problem with PR. Politics in Britain is much cleaner than on the continent, partly because we do not have a swirling political elite and expensive state funding."

Being the kind of politician who sleeps soundly at night, the home secretary does not stay in harsh mood for long. He boasts that he has backed substantial increases in state funds for both Tories (from £1.53m to £3.38m) and Liberal Democrats (£0.3m to £1.08m).

"I am in favour of fair funding of opposition parties and have sought in government to put into practice things which I thought were unfair in opposition."

As for the joint sessions pioneered by Mr Blair and Paddy Ashdown, Mr Straw has attended all of them. "There are still differences of emphasis between me and some of my Liberal Democrat friends on the issue of PR.

"But I am in favour of cooperation with the Liberal Democrats on issues where we are in broad agreement, what Vernon Bogdanor called the 'popular front of the mind."

Whether defending the controversial asylum act which comes into force in October or his refusal to outlaw indirect racism in the race relations (amendment) bill, Mr Straw always relies on a mixture of lightly-worn principle, pragmatism and his native optimism.

Asked if his disdain for liberalism makes him illiberal he replies with laughter. "No, no. Fair and effective is what I would say." Later he stressed that effective is not the same as efficient. "Efficient is a narrower concept. Being effective is about outcomes. Being efficient is about process."

Very New Labour. Jack Straw is on message.

 Mr Straw has warned that the English are "potentially very aggressive, very violent" and will increasingly articulate their Englishness following devolution.

Speaking as part of a BBC Radio 4 series about what it means to be British, to be broadcast today, Mr Straw said the English had used their "propensity to violence" to "subjugate Ireland, Wales and Scotland". He added: "I think as we move into this new century, people's sense of Englishness will become more articulated and that's partly because of the mirror that devolution provides us with and because we're becoming more European at the same time."

What the minister said

On the Met: "Where you have a major inquiry of that kind (Stephen Lawrence) it is bound to produce a short-term shock ... But I am convinced that good has already flowed from the process and will produce better, more effective policing in London."

On anti-social behaviour orders: "I am disappointed about the take-up and we are working to improve advice to local authorities and police about how they should be used ... Where they have been granted people on the ground have found they are very successful."

On freedom of information bill: "Where ministers refuse to accept the recommendation of the tribunal to make a disclosure the minister himself is responsible to parliament for that decision. That seems to me to be the right process."

On human rights act: "It will be seen in retrospect as the most significant change from the legal aspect last century."

webTitle: Me and my motor - Larry Lamb

fields.headline: Me and my motor - Larry Lamb
fields.trailText: What are you driving?
fields.body:
What are you driving?

Grey Ford Sierra Ghia estate.

What does that say about you?

Very good question.

What do you like about it?

It's extremely reliable, capacious and powerful.

Why did you buy it?

It was purchased from a friend for those reasons.

What kind of driver are you?

Hard but not speedy.

Any bad habits?

Absolutely none, your honour!

Any driving test tales?

It took three goes - all pretty straightforward.

What was your first car?

1938 Morris 8 tourer.

Have you ever crashed or got a speeding ticket?

Many crashes in my early years - one or two quite serious. I've only ever got speeding tickets when I'm driving in mountains.

Have you ever experienced road rage (either passively or actively)?

Yes - both ways. I had to stop an irate young man and get out of my car and demand that he hit me - he didn't.

What do you use your car for?

I've virtually rebuilt a house and two flats with its assistance.

What sort of state is your car in (inside or out)?

Generally rough, but mechanically it's always kept in good order.

What's in the boot/glove compartment?

Emergency supplies, ropes, boots, water, umbrella, toilet paper and rubbish.

Have you ever had sex in a car?

Many times. My very first, in fact, in the back seat of a borrowed Vauxhall 9. Not very satisfactory but subsequently things got better. It's not my preferred territory.

What music do you listen to on the road?

All and everything.

What would be your dream car?

Blue Bentley Continental circa 1985.

Who is your dream passenger?

The person who was taking me to pick up my winnings in cash from the lottery.

Larry Lamb is appearing in Anna Weiss at the Whitehall Theatre in London.

I've virtually rebuilt a house and two flats with its assistance. What sort of state is your car in (inside or out)? Generally rough, but mechanically it's always kept in good order. What's in the boot/glove compartment? Emergency supplies, ropes, boots, water, umbrella, toilet paper and rubbish. Have you ever had sex in a car? Many times. My very first, in fact, in the back seat of a borrowed Vauxhall 9. Not very satisfactory but subsequently things got better. It's not my preferred territory. What music do you listen to on the road? All and everything. What would be your dream car? Blue Bentley Continental circa 1985. Who is your dream passenger? The person who was taking me to pick up my winnings in cash from the lottery. Larry Lamb is appearing in Anna Weiss at the Whitehall Theatre in London.

fields.standfirst: Elvis painted one gold, Liberace plastered piano keys over his. But today's pop idols drive mundane off-the-peg Mercedes and Toyotas.  Michael Booth  recalls when cars were as flamboyant as the stars

fields.body:
"Ford Ka Helps Billie's Driving Ambition!" "All Saints Choose Chart-Topping Jeep Grand Cherokee!" "Slade to Tour With Ford Minibus!" Manufacturers are always eager to tell us about their latest sponsorship hook up with the pop star of the moment (and Slade). But standing amid the throng watching All Saints collect the keys to their new wheels at last year's Motor Show, I couldn't help but wonder whether a glorified mini-van was appropriate transport for a group of supposedly cool and foxy international pop stars. And All Saints aren't the only sell-outs.

Take a look at the cars most pop stars drive, or are driven in, these days and, with the exception of Ferrari fan Chris Rea (who I'm not sure counts anyway) and Prodigy's Keith Flint, who drives a monster of a TVR, mundanity rules. Hang around outside the Brits and you'll see that the Mercedes S-Class, or worse the Toyota Previa (for second-string boy bands), are the standard pop star transport.

Maybe today's artists can ill-afford to be seen endorsing fossil fuel-burning extravagance, as Jay Kay has found to his cost when pilloried for his conflicting environmentalism and a penchant for 12mpg Lamborghinis. Whatever, things were certainly different in the 50s and 60s, when no artist would venture out in anything less than a fur-trimmed Roller with gold-plated hub caps. The best of these fabulous vehicles can still be seen in two extraordinary car museums, one at the Liberace Foundation in Las Vegas, the other at Elvis's home, Graceland, in Memphis.

Automobiles may have been at least partly to blame for Elvis's slothful ballooning, but he still loved them. "The first car I ever bought was the most beautiful I've ever seen," Elvis once said. "It was secondhand, but I parked it outside my hotel the day I got it and stayed up all night just looking at it. The next day it caught fire and blew up on the road."

I suspect it may have been suicide. The car knew what he would have done to it had it lived. The first new car he bought, soon after his first string of hits on the Sun record label, was a 1956 Cadillac. According to legend, Elvis went into the showroom clutching a pound of grapes and squeezed the fruit on to the bonnet of the demonstrator. "That's the colour I want my Cadillac, thangyouverrymuch," he said. It was the only known instance of Elvis wasting food.

That Cadillac is the first car you see as your eyes adjust to the reverently dimmed light inside the museum. The rest of the collection is arranged in a horseshoe around a re-creation of a drive-in movie theatre. Filmgoers watch selected car moments from Elvis's movies on a continuous loop, while parked in authentic 1957 Chevrolet seats.

The collection is by no means complete - Elvis's legendary gold Caddy is on display at the Country Music Hall of Fame in Nashville and other Elvis-mobiles are often advertised on the internet. As his wealth snowballed he began buying new cars, each of which he would personalise with the same good taste that judged the living room ceiling to be an appropriate place to lay shag pile. Cadillacs, Jeeps and Harley Davidson motorbikes abound throughout the rest of the museum, each with either a spangly silver or a bilious pink paint job to mark them as the property of the King. Occasionally Elvis inadvertently allowed good taste to obscure his better judgment and bought a European machine. But even then he either chose a dud (his black Ferrari 308 GT4 is about as desirable in Ferrari circles as rust), or irretrievably disfigured his purchase with an ill-advised piece of customising (as with the vile blue leather in his Rolls-Royce Silver Cloud).

Elvis didn't reach his zenith until the 70s, and neither did his cars. I didn't know whether to laugh or cry when I reached the half way stage of the tour and the centre piece of the exhibition: a brace of Stutz Blackhawks.

Even in standard trim Stutz Blackhawks are ostentatious. The first one ever made was originally ordered for Frank Sinatra in 1971; Elvis charmed it from the dealer for $26,500 (Sinatra's response is not recorded). Frustratingly, an assistant wrecked that car while on his way to wash it shortly after Elvis took delivery (it was later repaired). Undeterred, the King bought another of the Pontiac-engined monsters and had its interior plated with 18-carat gold. Both are on display at Graceland.

As if Elvis's cars hadn't suffered enough, he even tried to murder one of them. As is the custom with highly strung, mid-engined Italian supercars, Elvis's rare and beautiful De Tomaso Pantera refused to start one morning. Instead of calling a breakdown service, as you or I might, he simply pulled out his gun and shot it.

By the standards of what Wladziu Valentino Liberace did to his cars, Elvis's Pantera got off lightly. Las Vegas's Liberace Car Gallery is possibly the only car museum that could rival Elvis's for chintz and chutzpah. I took a cab there from the Strip and found, alongside the world's biggest rhinestone and more dodgy candelabra than Bermondsey market, numerous customised classics.

Take the priceless Rolls-Royce Phantom V Landau, smothered in tiny mirror tiles etched with a design of galloping horses. Beside it in the low-rise museum compound, ranged appropriately around a parking lot, sits a matching Baldwin grand piano. Or Liberace's Excalibur, a British confection based loosely (and I mean loosely) on the legendary Mercedes SSK. This one is covered from head to fender in Australian rhinestones (his favourite semi-precious rock).

Liberace, at one time the highest-paid musician in the world, didn't own a car until he was 30, when he bought an Oldsmobile 88 convertible - chosen because a piano has 88 keys. But once he bought that he was hooked, and embarked on an automotive spending spree untrammelled by notions of taste or restraint. As with Elvis, but sadly not today's off-the-peg stars, Liberace didn't stop once he'd bought a car. Even his more mundane machinery would be decorated with a piano key motif, or bedecked with his trademark candelabra. But Liberace's greatest automotive crime was that the only mileage his grand and costly cars accrued was in carrying their owner on and off stage to the applause of a sea of blue rinses.

As you wander around the rest of the collection, you cast incredulous eyes over a Rolls-Royce Silver Cloud with a striking red, white and blue colour scheme, in honour of America's bicentennial; a bastardised Beetle - "Volks-Royce" - part Roller, part VW; a customised London cab (Liberace was a committed Anglophile - or "insufferable snob" as they are known in the US); a 1964 Cadillac with diamond-studded candelabra, a bar with sterling silver cups depicting winners of the Kentucky Derby, and a TV and stereo; as well as dozens more motoring atrocities. As far as I'm concerned, it more than warrants its title of "Nevada's third most popular tourist attraction".

One man whose name crops up in both museums is George Barris, fabled customiser and creator of the original Batmobile. Barris painted Elvis's gold Cadillac, and also plastered Liberace's 1954 Eldorado with a chrome piano key design and used candelabra as (hardly pedestrian-friendly) bonnet ornaments.

It could be that today's pop stars need a man like Barris to pep up their garages. He could decorate Morrissey's Porsche with a fibreglass quiff; the Sterophonics' car could be swathed in sheepskin; or maybe Liam Gallagher would like a large pair of bushy eyebrows atop the windscreen of his Bristol.

I suspect my fantasies may all be in vain. Elvis and Liberace existed in an era more tolerant of such gaudy glamour. Perhaps, on reflection, it's best that way.

Graceland, Elvis Presley Boulevard, Memphis (001 901 332 3322); The Liberace Car Gallery, 1775, East Tropicana, Las Vegas, Nevada 89119 (001 702 798 5595)

fields.headline: Test drive  Fiat Punto
fields.trailText: At its launch, the new Fiat Punto lost its spirit. Or at least its spirito: the ad campaign for the new model traded the wry wit of the "Spirito di Punto" series for a dollop of American cheese. And hey, if those elephants, giraffes and ostriches didn't make you laugh, there was a fat man, too!
fields.body:
At its launch, the new Fiat Punto lost its spirit. Or at least its spirito: the ad campaign for the new model traded the wry wit of the "Spirito di Punto" series for a dollop of American cheese. And hey, if those elephants, giraffes and ostriches didn't make you laugh, there was a fat man, too!

Thankfully, the car's image projectors are now back on track with a new series of boy v girl dialogues, to which the obvious subtext is that Fiat's best-ever seller is the essence of cute. Few will disagree; if you thought the original was a nice-looking duckling (Ford evidently did, given the styling tribute that is the Focus) it's fair to say that Punto II is a fanciable swan.

Like size-10 stilettos, five-door hatchbacks can look clumsy, but Punto's proud haunches are so confidently styled that, in this case, the five-door manages to be chic. Check the bold, pointy tail lights and clever kicked-out boot; like a little Dolce and Gabbana number, it looks trim from every angle. Blessed with a flatter, more pert posterior, the three-door car looks even tidier. Punto's face now shows more character; the headlamps are complex, all-in-one clusters and they glare with the kind of insect-like cool you'd expect from a BMW.

Inside, there's enough room for at least half an average Italian family. The stereo sits logically on a pronounced bump atop the dash, but visibility is excellent for most of 360 degrees. The seats are comfy and big on side support; they encourage you to assume an uprightish stance, but that's entirely suitable for this car's roadgoing nature.

Fiat braved a potential caseful of jokes by staging Punto II's launch in a remote corner of western Sicily. Brimming with pride, the mayor of the labyrinthine mountain-top town of Erice threw his streets open to visiting journalists. Studying the map carefully, I charged my JTD 1.9 diesel test car the wrong way down a generous alleyway, being forced to retrace my tracks after a swift 58-point turn. Still, the manoeuvre was invaluable: it showed how well the new "City" button works - you push it in and the steering goes light as an air steward's handshake. It also showed how dint-resistant the car is - when I finally managed to detach the rear quarter panel from the street corner, the metalwork obediently popped back into place, showing hardly a scratch.

Once through the city walls, the JTD took to the hairpins like a supercharged sherpa. In fact, it showed such brio that it upstaged both the 1.2 litre 16-valve and the alleged Sporting version, the latter producing so little torque in second that, as I overtook a lorry, I fully expected the words "To be continued!" to flash across the windscreen.

By now, I was starting to conceive my Punto dream-team - a creation with all the rev-lust of the JTD, all the toned handling of the Sporting and all the composure of the 1.2 ELX. Silly me, I had yet to drive the prime Punto, the HGT. This 1.8 insists and thrives on a good hard thrashing, clings to tarmac like heavily chewed gum and, at high speed, sails on with all the solid grace of a Golf GTi.

Superminis face tough work to earn family car status, but the new Punto keeps Fiat in the field - a marked improvement on a car which has been Europe's best seller since 1997. Fiat's decision to kick off prices at £7,995 makes the car not quite as lean as the cheapest 1.3 Encore-badged Ford Fiesta. However, despite the revisions to the latter, Punto II has image and driveability that place it leagues ahead.

webTitle: We Can Work It Out, I'm A Loser and Drive My Car

fields.headline: We Can Work It Out, I'm A Loser and Drive My Car
fields.trailText: NOBODY DOESN'T DO IT BETTER
fields.body:
NOBODY DOESN'T DO IT BETTER

By the time you read this, Tranmere will have learnt the consequence of breaking the footballing rules in their FA Cup tie with Sunderland on Saturday. At the time of writing however, the FA are still undecided as to how to deal with the dismissal of Clint Hill - which turned into a substitution when the fourth official got the numbers on his electronic board wrong. Some might say that the FA haven't reached a decision because they don't have a clue what they're doing.

But not the Fiver. The Fiver understands that the real reason the FA have postponed the announcement of Tranmere's fate today is because they are simply overwhelmed with possible solutions. Knowing the game's governing body as we do (ie: not very well) we can think of at least three possible ways in which they may choose to resolve the situation. And that's off the top of our heads.

1) Seeing as Hill was sent off in the 89th minute, simply replay the last minute of the game. This would mean another bumper box office for Prenton Park and provide officials with only 60 seconds (plus stoppage time) in which to make a mistake.

2) Arrange a competition between Peter Reid and John Aldridge to see who can make the most acerbic post-match comment. Whoever criticises the referee in the most underhand manner wins.

3) Let the result stand, as the contentious last-minute free kick was only heading onto the head of Jody Craddock, and, on behalf of the confused official, offer a donation to charity. No, scratch that, it's a stupid suggestion.

BRAZIL NUTS

According to the head of the FA's World Cup team, Manchester United's participation in the World Club Championshop has helped England's 2006 bid no end. Said Alec (coincidence, we think not) McGivan today: "I think United's participation has helped enormously." If helping enormously means forcing the Casualty franchise out of its usual slots for two of the worst United performances of recent times, then the Fiver couldn't agree more.

The World Cup bid has, of course, been constantly trumpeted as the main reason for United ducking out of the FA Cup (or British Club Cup Tournament of Kings if Sepp Blatter was in charge). So it is interesting to hear exactly how McGivan thinks the FA has gained from United's week of kickin' and a-losin'.

"I think that this is the first time most of the players have had the chance to play in South America and if you are a professional footballer, that's a great experience to have," was one bonus. As was the fact that, over the weekend, David Beckham played keepy-up with some kids. United's initial aloofness "may have upset a few people," reasons McGivan, "but this week when things are relaxed [ie: too late] they have done things with street kids." Heart warming.

But what did Mr Blatter make of it all? "I have had suspicions today and yesterday that Sepp Blatter is thrilled by United's being here," said McGivan rather unconvincingly. "I think he's very pleased by their attitude and the way in which they have accepted defeat and yet are still keen participants." Which, with regards to our World Cup prospects, amounts to a small amount of bugger all. Rumours are already abroad that Blatter instead wants England to host the Championshop in a couple of years. A privilege it would surely be churlish to pass up.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I won't speak to Ferguson again if I can help it because there are only so many cheeks you can turn." - Jim Leighton, cross with the account in Alex Ferguson's autobiography of how he was dropped for the 1990 FA Cup final replay, opens himself up to all sorts of buttock-related comedy.

THERE'S ONLY TWO DAMIAN TAYLORS

It's been a good day for Ipswich defender Gary Croft, as he's been let out of the can after serving one month of a four-month sentence. Croft had been banged up for driving his car while already disqualified and, upon being pulled over by an officer of the law, telling anyone who would listen that his name was Damian Taylor. Which amounts to perverting the course of justice, the saucy liar.

You'd have assumed Croft's first act as a free man would be to nip into the nearest shop to buy 20 snouts, a pint of milk and a paper, but the ex-Blackburn defender instead chose to issue a statement which thanked Ipswich for "their compassion" while he was doing bird. "I would like to say how delighted I am to be back amongst my colleagues at Ipswich Town, a club whose support for me during these turbulent times has been boundless," he smarmed.

"I have received hundreds of encouraging letters and cards reiterating to me how badly I have erred," continued a contrite Croft, "but also assuring me that there is a road to recovery." The Fiver just hopes he takes the bus when he goes down it.

Incidentally, now he's out of the jug, Croft has to wear an Aitkenesque electronic tag for the next couple of months. Ipswich have requested that he be allowed to remove the tag for matches, but the Fiver hopes the authorities consider this carefully. Our friend Filthy Nigel, who runs the Ipswich branch of Very Video, rang to tell us that someone has just rented out a copy of Escape To Victory under the name Mr Damian D'amian. Of course, we're drawing no conclusions and suggesting nothing.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Speculation that George Weah could be on his way to the Premiership heightened today after AC Milan admitted he is unsettled at the club. Vice-president Adriano Galliani told the official Milan website that the Liberian striker is unhappy at sitting on the bench at the San Siro, and that "if Weah should decide to leave, he will not be able to play for any other Italian team as the club has no intention of helping the opposition". Leeds United have already been linked with a move for the former World Player of the Year.

Newcastle have taken Paraguay's 19-year-old midfielder Diego Gavila on trial. "We wanted to have a look at him because we have heard he is a bit special. He is a possible star in the making," Newcastle boss Bobby Robson told the Express.

Rangers are believed to be interesting in signing occasional Chelsea full back Bernard Lambourde.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Martin O'Neill will lodge a complaint with referees chief Philip Don over the "harsh" sending-off of Darren Eadie during Leicester's FA Cup tie with Arsenal. O'Neill said: "I will be giving Philip Don a call to point out what I consider to be a very harsh decision relating to Darren Eadie. The decision was ludicrous."

Manchester United have named a youthful team for their final World Club championshop game against South Melbourne tomorrow. The team, captained by Andy Cole for the first time, will be: Van der Gouw, P Neville, Berg, Wallwork, Higginbotham, Greening, Cruyff, Wilson, Fortune, Cole, Solskjaer.

Celtic striker Harald Brattbakk has joined FC Copenhagen in a £650,000 deal.

Dunfermline have agreed a fee for Rangers midfielder Ian Ferguson. The deal is dependent on a medical and terms.

Dundee United striker Steven Thompson has signed a two-year extension to his contract which will keep him at Tannadice until 2003.

Greenock Morton boss Billy Stark has left the Cappielow club, less than 48 hours after a 6-2 league defeat at Inverness Caledonian Thistle. Youth team boss Peter Weir will take temporary charge.

fields.bodyText: NOBODY DOESN'T DO IT BETTER By the time you read this, Tranmere will have learnt the consequence of breaking the footballing rules in their FA Cup tie with Sunderland on Saturday. At the time of writing however, the FA are still undecided as to how to deal with the dismissal of Clint Hill - which turned into a substitution when the fourth official got the numbers on his electronic board wrong. Some might say that the FA haven't reached a decision because they don't have a clue what they're doing. But not the Fiver. The Fiver understands that the real reason the FA have postponed the announcement of Tranmere's fate today is because they are simply overwhelmed with possible solutions. Knowing the game's governing body as we do (ie: not very well) we can think of at least three possible ways in which they may choose to resolve the situation. And that's off the top of our heads. 1) Seeing as Hill was sent off in the 89th minute, simply replay the last minute of the game. This would mean another bumper box office for Prenton Park and provide officials with only 60 seconds (plus stoppage time) in which to make a mistake. 2) Arrange a competition between Peter Reid and John Aldridge to see who can make the most acerbic post-match comment. Whoever criticises the referee in the most underhand manner wins. 3) Let the result stand, as the contentious last-minute free kick was only heading onto the head of Jody Craddock, and, on behalf of the confused official, offer a donation to charity. No, scratch that, it's a stupid suggestion. BRAZIL NUTS According to the head of the FA's World Cup team, Manchester United's participation in the World Club Championshop has helped England's 2006 bid no end. Said Alec (coincidence, we think not) McGivan today: "I think United's participation has helped enormously." If helping enormously means forcing the Casualty franchise out of its usual slots for two of the worst United performances of recent times, then the Fiver couldn't agree more. The World Cup bid has, of course, been constantly trumpeted as the main reason for United ducking out of the FA Cup (or British Club Cup Tournament of Kings if Sepp Blatter was in charge). So it is interesting to hear exactly how McGivan thinks the FA has gained from United's week of kickin' and a-losin'. "I think that this is the first time most of the players have had the chance to play in South America and if you are a professional footballer, that's a great experience to have," was one bonus. As was the fact that, over the weekend, David Beckham played keepy-up with some kids. United's initial aloofness "may have upset a few people," reasons McGivan, "but this week when things are relaxed [ie: too late] they have done things with street kids." Heart warming. But what did Mr Blatter make of it all? "I have had suspicions today and yesterday that Sepp Blatter is thrilled by United's being here," said McGivan rather unconvincingly. "I think he's very pleased by their attitude and the way in which they have accepted defeat and yet are still keen participants." Which, with regards to our World Cup prospects, amounts to a small amount of bugger all. Rumours are already abroad that Blatter instead wants England to host the Championshop in a couple of years. A privilege it would surely be churlish to pass up. QUOTE OF THE DAY "I won't speak to Ferguson again if I can help it because there are only so many cheeks you can turn." - Jim Leighton, cross with the account in Alex Ferguson's autobiography of how he was dropped for the 1990 FA Cup final replay, opens himself up to all sorts of buttock-related comedy. THERE'S ONLY TWO DAMIAN TAYLORS It's been a good day for Ipswich defender Gary Croft, as he's been let out of the can after serving one month of a four-month sentence. Croft had been banged up for driving his car while already disqualified and, upon being pulled over by an officer of the law, telling anyone who would listen that his name was Damian Taylor. Which amounts to perverting the course of justice, the saucy liar. You'd have assumed Croft's first act as a free man would be to nip into the nearest shop to buy 20 snouts, a pint of milk and a paper, but the ex-Blackburn defender instead chose to issue a statement which thanked Ipswich for "their compassion" while he was doing bird. "I would like to say how delighted I am to be back amongst my colleagues at Ipswich Town, a club whose support for me during these turbulent times has been boundless," he smarmed. "I have received hundreds of encouraging letters and cards reiterating to me how badly I have erred," continued a contrite Croft, "but also assuring me that there is a road to recovery." The Fiver just hopes he takes the bus when he goes down it. Incidentally, now he's out of the jug, Croft has to wear an Aitkenesque electronic tag for the next couple of months. Ipswich have requested that he be allowed to remove the tag for matches, but the Fiver hopes the authorities consider this carefully. Our friend Filthy Nigel, who runs the Ipswich branch of Very Video, rang to tell us that someone has just rented out a copy of Escape To Victory under the name Mr Damian D'amian. Of course, we're drawing no conclusions and suggesting nothing. THE RUMOUR MILL Speculation that George Weah could be on his way to the Premiership heightened today after AC Milan admitted he is unsettled at the club. Vice-president Adriano Galliani told the official Milan website that the Liberian striker is unhappy at sitting on the bench at the San Siro, and that "if Weah should decide to leave, he will not be able to play for any other Italian team as the club has no intention of helping the opposition". fields.headline: Stressed worker wins record payment
fields.standfirst:
Unison
Worcestershire county council
fields.trailText: A record damages payout of £203,000 was made today to a former gypsy site warden forced to retire from work because of stress.
fields.body:
A record damages payout of £203,000 was made today to a former gypsy site warden forced to retire from work because of stress.

Father of four Randy Ingram, who lives in a caravan himself, blamed his employers for undermining his job, which led to a series of physical and verbal assaults on him by gypsies.

He was shot at and suffered other abuse, forcing him to retire from his £8,700-a-year job on grounds of ill-health in 1997.

He has never worked since and now has to attend hospital twice a week for therapy and takes up to 17 tablets a day.

Mr Ingram managed gypsy sites for Wychavon district council for two years until the work was transferred to Hereford and Worcester county council in 1995.

He took over responsibility for other sites, including one at Lower Heath, near Kidderminster, which had a history of problems.

Wardens accused the county council of failing to support their work, leading to a loss of their authority on the sites.

At a press conference in Birmingham, where the out-of-court settlement was agreed, Mr Ingram said: "I liked the job I did but the support wasn't there from my employers.

"I am part of the gypsy community, I have always lived in a caravan and I shall not be changing my lifestyle.

"The council has a lot to answer for, they have made me very ill with stress and depression and my home life has suffered as a result."

Peter Fennell, regional officer of Mr Ingram's union, Unison, said that when steps were taken to evict anti-social families from sites, or refuse entry to other known troublemakers, the decisions taken by the wardens were over-ruled by council managers.

"The council appeared to take the side of the gypsies. They were not prepared to take sufficient strong action against the troublesome families. This was very difficult for the wardens."

Mr Fennell said that of the ten wardens employed by the council, seven had been off work with stress and one had left permanently on ill health grounds, receiving a compensation payment of £14,500. Dave Prentis, deputy general secretary of Unison, said the case was one of the most extreme examples of stress the union had dealt with.

Chris Carter, head of planning at Worcestershire county council, which dealt with the claim as a result of local government changes, said procedures had been improved since the authority was formed two years ago, and more support was now given to gypsy liaison staff.

Today's settlement was the third high-profile stress case brought by Unison.

In 1994, social worker John Walker was awarded an out-of-court settlement of £175,000 against Northumberland County Council and last year housing officer Beverley Lancaster was awarded damages of around £65,000 by a judge after Birmingham City admitted liability for personal injury caused by stress.

 Recent figures showed that unions took 783 legal cases against employers for stress-related illness last year, 70% up on the previous 12 months.
