fields.headline: 'What next? A piece about how to construct a gas chamber?'
fields.standfirst: Lad mag FHM thought it was on to another winner when it published its student special full of irreverent features on suicide. But the families of two students used as case studies thought otherwise. And so did the Press Complaints Commission, the Samaritans, two universities and the magazine's sponsors.  Kamal Ahmed  reports
fields.trailText: Lad mag FHM thought it was on to another winner when it published its student special full of irreverent features on suicide. But the families of two students used as case studies thought otherwise. And so did the Press Complaints Commission, the Samaritans, two universities and the magazine's sponsors.
fields.body:
You would hardly notice it on a map. The small farm is tucked away in the folds of Worcestershire, sitting on a narrow country lane on the outskirts of the Middle of Nowhere. It has been the home for close on 30 years of Peter and Charmian Gibson.

Mr and Mrs Gibson live a rural life, he's a design engineer who works from home, she's an administrator for an e-commerce association based in the nearby village. They are quiet, private people who suffered the type of tragedy last June that no parent should have to suffer. Their son, Robert, took his own life. He had just completed a fine art degree at Southampton institute. He was awarded a first.

The Gibsons never asked FHM magazine to come barging into their lives last October, raking up their grief. They never asked FHM magazine to trivialise the death of their son or make a joke of its cause. They never asked to go into battle with an editor, Anthony Noguera - a battle which ultimately included Oxford university, the National Union of Students, the Samaritans and the Press Complaints Commission. But FHM came ploughing into Lench Farm anyway, wielding arrogance and ignorance and decided that as far as it was concerned the Gibsons were merely a sideshow in a much larger affair. Getting "the kids" to talk about suicide.

Drive 350 miles north from the Gibsons' farm and you come to the Edinburgh home of Angela and Kerry Napuk. Their daughter, Sarah, took her own life in April 1997. They didn't ask FHM magazine to trivialise the death or make a joke of its cause, either. But FHM just shrugged and got on with what it does best, irreverent, sarcastic coverage of any subject, however sensitive, in the name of the lad's mag revolution.

The Gibsons, the Napuks and three other families' children appeared in a special edition of FHM magazine that was distributed to universities across Britain at the start of the new academic year last autumn. In the free student guide were a series of articles on suicide entitled Straight to Hell, followed by an exclamation mark to give another little twist. Their tone astonished many and has raised serious questions both about the way the media cover such delicate subjects and about magazines that consider themselves outside the normal ethical controls of the media world.

Oxford university, Southampton institute and the National Union of Students all condemned the "grossly offensive" reporting. The Gibsons and the Napuks also lodged a formal complaint with the Press Complaints Commission, saying that the articles broke the code of practice. The commission has now agreed that FHM was involved in a "serious breach" of its code on intrusion into grief. It said the articles were "gratuitously humorous".

"The article was written in a humorous style and included examples of students who had committed suicide, tips on how to kill yourself and advice from a counsellor on how to prevent student suicide," the adjudication said.

"The commission agreed with the magazine that suicide is a matter of public interest and noted that the style of the piece was clearly intended for a particular audience of young people. However one of the key features of the code of practice is the way in which it seeks to protect particularly vulnerable groups of people, including those who are suffering at times of grief and shock.

"In this case, the commission noted that the complainants' children had died relatively recently - in one case only a few months prior to publication - and the magazine should have taken every care strictly to abide by the terms of the code which requires sensitivity in such circumstances. It had not done so, and instead of due sensitivity had treated their deaths in a gratuitously humorous manner."

The attitude of Straight to Hell was clear from the start. "The rest of the world might think you have it easy, but some students prefer suicide to another term of cider, exams and Red Dwarf . . ." the articles began, before detailing five "case studies" including those of Robert Gibson and Sarah Napuk. The tone was jokey: under a picture of a man, all clown tears and mock contrition, was the line: No one heard Tim's cry for help. And more. The magazine, sponsored by Pizza Hut, which has since said it is reviewing its relationship with FHM, gave a "how to" guide to different suicide methods. "Gun? Rope? Cyanide? Suicide may be the easy way out but that doesn't mean that it is simple to get right. So try these methods for size." It went on to detail, in comic tones, hanging, "bullet through the head", overdose and jumping.

"A pistol in the mouth is quick and easy, but remember to leave the safety catch off," the magazine said. "For maximum wall art effect use a shot gun like Ernest Hemingway, pulling the trigger by tugging on a piece of string."

And there was more. "How to construct a baffling suicide note", "isn't it better to go down the bar and have a beer" and an effectiveness rating for each suicide method.

When the magazine was published in October, all hell broke loose. Oxford university, at which two of the deaths mentioned in the articles took place, withdrew the magazine. Alex Coren, the deputy head of Oxford university's counselling service, who had given an interview to FHM about the causes of suicide, felt that he had been duped into appearing to give tacit approval to the magazine.

"Like the rest of us at the university he believes this is not a subject to be dealt with by sarcasm," an Oxford university spokeswoman said at the time. Oxford Brookes university also withdrew the guide. The NUS admitted it had "made a mistake" by allowing its commercial arm, NUS Services Ltd, to distribute the guide. A week later it announced that it was banning the magazine from all student unions and that FHM, along with other lads' magazines such as Loaded, would now be thoroughly vetted before any agreement about distribution was made in the future.

"I cannot find any good journalistic reason for the article," said Dr Roger Brown, the principal of Southampton institute. "There is no public interest. What next? A jokey piece about how to construct a gas chamber?" Every week there are 12 deaths by suicide in the university student age bracket.

Brown wrote to Noguera. "I believe the article is irresponsible and shows an unacceptable disregard for the personal grief of the students' family and friends. To write about these tragic events in such a flippant style can only add unnecessary pain."

"It was absolute filth, the worst type of gutter journalism," said Peter Gibson. "This was distributed to young people, many of whom are away from home for the first time, and they might be lonely and insecure and here is a magazine that is producing this stuff to get new readers."

The Napuks were similarly angered and distressed by the coverage. "How anyone can think that this is a suitable subject for satire is beyond me," Mr Napuk said.

The two families also wrote to the magazine demanding some answers. "We are protesting in the strongest possible terms that the reports of the students' deaths were used to illustrate an issue of great gravity in a crass and callous way," Mr and Mrs Gibson wrote. "We consider that it is a vile abuse of journalistic licence. As our son only died five months ago the wounds are very fresh."

Noguera wrote back to the Gibsons. He started with an apology, saying that the magazine had "no right to intrude upon your grief".

Then came the defence. "The article was designed as a deterrent and a warning to students, written in a language and style that they understand," he wrote. "Much of the discussion around this piece has taken the actual article wildly out of context and misrepresented much of what was in it.

"Of course we were not encouraging students to kill themselves. I must ask you to accept that whether you like FHM or not we know a lot about communicating with young people, especially men. You may not have appreciated the tone of the piece - and I fully appreciate that - but the majority of the target audience saw it for what it was. The piece sought to point out the horror and waste of suicide, specifically by citing case studies."

Noguera pointed out that FHM had been "commended on many occasions" for writing about difficult subjects that are often ignored. He said that features on young men and leukaemia and testicular cancer had been particularly well received.

"We have done more to persuade men to talk about their problems, both medical and psychological, than anybody," he said. "We communicate with men in a language and tone that they understand. It may seem insensitive and irreverent to you but it is by far the most effective way of getting the message across to our readers."

The Samaritans has taken a close interest in the FHM publication. It knows it needs such magazines to get to one of the most vulnerable suicide groups, young men. Does such an irreverent take on suicide work? "Young men do find it very difficult to articulate their emotions," says Simon Armson, chief executive of the Samaritans. "If you can do anything to help then that is to be welcomed. The concern is over the means by which that is done. We have to be very careful indeed about trivialising the issue, it is a question of balance. FHM did not get the balance correct, it ran the risk of causing damage to those people who are already in a vulnerable state."

Emap Metro, the publishers of FHM, is concerned about the bad publicity that may build when news of the adjudication becomes widely known. The NUS is likely to discuss banning the publication from its shop sites at its national conference at Easter. At a time when the lads' mag circulation bubble appears to be on the verge of bursting, such a move could be commercially damaging.

In an attempt to spike any guns that may be massing, Philip Thomas, the managing director of FHM, also wrote to the Gibsons. "That the tone and style of this recent piece overstepped the mark is an indication of the difficulties we face in covering these topics in the right manner," he said. "I am truly sorry to have caused you distress and I know that everyone at FHM feels the same. Please accept my sincere apologies." Paul Keenan, the managing director of Emap, also wrote to the chairman of the PCC, Lord Wakeham, saying that he "deeply regretted" the articles. He said last week that FHM had "learnt some hard lessons".

The Gibsons, who point out that FHM has been criticised before for its treatment of issues of mental health, and the Napuks are not convinced that the apologies amount to very much. "I want to challenge them to make a proper, public apology to all of those affected," Mr Gibson said. All FHM is duty bound to publish is the adjudication itself, which is likely to appear in the March issue of the magazine. It remains to be seen whether it will go further than that and run a personal message from the editor.

"There should be lessons here for all the media," Mr Napuk said. "The invasion into ordinary people's privacy has gone far too far. The excesses are sheer lunacy. In Sweden only [covering] the suicide of public figures is permissible, anyone who violates that rule is fined. What do we get here for such a pathetic piece of reporting? A slap on the wrist."
Research by Nicola Norton

Oxford Brookes university also withdrew the guide. The NUS admitted it had "made a mistake" by allowing its commercial arm, NUS Services Ltd, to distribute the guide. A week later it announced that it was banning the magazine from all student unions and that FHM, along with other lads' magazines such as Loaded, would now be thoroughly vetted before any agreement about distribution was made in the future. "I cannot find any good journalistic reason for the article," said Dr Roger Brown, the principal of Southampton institute. "There is no public interest. What next? A jokey piece about how to construct a gas chamber?" Every week there are 12 deaths by suicide in the university student age bracket. Brown wrote to Noguera. "I believe the article is irresponsible and shows an unacceptable disregard for the personal grief of the students' family and friends. To write about these tragic events in such a flippant style can only add unnecessary pain." "It was absolute filth, the worst type of gutter journalism," said Peter Gibson. "This was distributed to young people, many of whom are away from home for the first time, and they might be lonely and insecure and here is a magazine that is producing this stuff to get new readers." The Napuks were similarly angered and distressed by the coverage. "How anyone can think that this is a suitable subject for satire is beyond me," Mr Napuk said. The two families also wrote to the magazine demanding some answers. "We are protesting in the strongest possible terms that the reports of the students' deaths were used to illustrate an issue of great gravity in a crass and callous way," Mr and Mrs Gibson wrote. "We consider that it is a vile abuse of journalistic licence. As our son only died five months ago the wounds are very fresh." Noguera wrote back to the Gibsons. He started with an apology, saying that the magazine had "no right to intrude upon your grief". Then came the defence. "The article was designed as a deterrent and a warning to students, written in a language and style that they understand," he wrote. "Much of the discussion around this piece has taken the actual article wildly out of context and misrepresented much of what was in it. "Of course we were not encouraging students to kill themselves. I must ask you to accept that whether you like FHM or not we know a lot about communicating with young people, especially men. You may not have appreciated the tone of the piece - and I fully appreciate that - but the majority of the target audience saw it for what it was. The piece sought to point out the horror and waste of suicide, specifically by citing case studies." Noguera pointed out that FHM had been "commended on many occasions" for writing about difficult subjects that are often ignored. He said that features on young men and leukaemia and testicular cancer had been particularly well received. "We have done more to persuade men to talk about their problems, both medical and psychological, than anybody," he said. "We communicate with men in a language and tone that they understand. It may seem insensitive and irreverent to you but it is by far the most effective way of getting the message across to our readers." The Samaritans has taken a close interest in the FHM publication. It knows it needs such magazines to get to one of the most vulnerable suicide groups, young men. Does such an irreverent take on suicide work? "Young men do find it very difficult to articulate their emotions," says Simon Armson, chief executive of the Samaritans. "If you can do anything to help then that is to be welcomed. The concern is over the means by which that is done. We have to be very careful indeed about trivialising the issue, it is a question of balance. FHM did not get the balance correct, it ran the risk of causing damage to those people who are already in a vulnerable state." Emap Metro, the publishers of FHM, is concerned about the bad publicity that may build when news of the adjudication becomes widely known. The NUS is likely to discuss banning the publication from its shop sites at its national conference at Easter. At a time when the lads' mag circulation bubble appears to be on the verge of bursting, such a move could be commercially damaging. In an attempt to spike any guns that may be massing, Philip Thomas, the managing director of FHM, also wrote to the Gibsons. "That the tone and style of this recent piece overstepped the mark is an indication of the difficulties we face in covering these topics in the right manner," he said. "I am truly sorry to have caused you distress and I know that everyone at FHM feels the same. Please accept my sincere apologies." Paul Keenan, the managing director of Emap, also wrote to the chairman of the PCC, Lord Wakeham, saying that he "deeply regretted" the articles. He said last week that FHM had "learnt some hard lessons". The Gibsons, who point out that FHM has been criticised before for its treatment of issues of mental health, and the Napuks are not convinced that the apologies amount to very much. "I want to challenge them to make a proper, public apology to all of those affected," Mr Gibson said. All FHM is duty bound to publish is the adjudication itself, which is likely to appear in the March issue of the magazine. It remains to be seen whether it will go further than that and run a personal message from the editor. "There should be lessons here for all the media," Mr Napuk said. "The invasion into ordinary people's privacy has gone far too far. The excesses are sheer lunacy. In Sweden only [covering] the suicide of public figures is permissible, anyone who violates that rule is fined. What do we get here for such a pathetic piece of reporting? A slap on the wrist." webTitle: Keeping a foot in the door

fields.headline: Keeping a foot in the door
fields.standfirst: There are ominous signs that investigative reporting is choking to death, says  Nick Davies, but there's still a chance to revive old skills
fields.trailText: There are ominous signs that investigative reporting is choking to death, says Nick Davies, but there's still a chance to revive old skills
fields.body:
Some of the country's best-known journalists are joining forces to teach a 48-hour crash course in investigative reporting. We plan to turn our own stories inside out to expose the techniques we use. David Leigh is going to unpack the saga of Jonathan Aitken; Paul Foot will look back at notorious miscarriages of justice; John Ware will talk about his work on the secret state in Northern Ireland; and I am going to explain how I spent almost 18 months investigating a murderous paedophile ring and never got a word into print.

It will all provide good anecdotes for the audience, but the aim is to achieve something more urgent. There are ominous signs that reporting skills are choking to death. If journalism had its own Chris Woodhead, sweeping through newsrooms with a black cloak and the power of inquisition, he would find plenty of brilliant and dedicated reporters, but he would also uncover a gathering sediment of incompetence.

We have to acknowledge at the outset that, on the face of it, there are monkeys peeling bananas who have more skills than any reporter needs. After all, what do reporters do? They ask one lot of people questions and tell another lot of people the answers. In theory, they might need shorthand and typing; in practice, newsrooms are littered with people who can't do either.

And yet it is precisely because reporting involves such a simple and commonplace exchange that the skills required are so peculiarly subtle and elusive. Take, for example, the simple business of persuading people to talk. Almost anyone with a story worth telling has a reason to withhold it, so when you turn up on the doorstep of the bent detective, or the parents whose child has just been murdered, or the MI5 officer whose colleagues are bending the law, you are confronted with a most intricate problem and, if the door opens, you will have between five and ten seconds to start to solve it and you are going to have to use some very unusual skills.

I had been blown off dozens of doorsteps like so much old litter before I even began to realise that there were techniques to deploy here, let alone discovered what they were. And the closer you look at the reporter's role, the more hidden skills you see.

There are technical skills involved in finding stories and all kinds of tricks to procure the sources you need to pursue them. There are old skills in exploiting public records; new ones such as using the internet as an investigative tool; grubby ones such as playing office politics to work on the story you want and get the space you need to run it. There are ethical questions, practical questions, such as staying safe or avoiding arrest or dealing with a leaks inquiry, and philosophical questions about truth and objectivity.

If you succeed in gathering your facts then, in this country, a whole set of devious skills is required to negotiate the road to publication, which is blocked by laws of libel and contempt and official secrecy, all of them preserved by governments and courts which profit from their protection. The good news is that, at least to some extent, there are ways round them.

The object is not simply to track down these skills but to preserve them in the face of extinction. We have described them as "investigative reporting" skills. That ought to be a nonsense, like saying that some water is special because it is wet. All reporting is supposed to be investigative. At the most mundane level, it means simply that reporters should not print information just because someone claims it is true. At its most powerful, it means that news is what someone somewhere is deliberately concealing, and the reporter is consciously and rightly subversive. As currently practised, however, the investigative skills of reporting are withering.

There are reporters in Fleet Street and the provincial press who have not spent a single day learning their trade, who recycle political spin and PR fiction simply because they couldn't find an angle in a five-cornered room. Worse than that, there are middle-ranking executives with no training who commission this stuff without realising that it is not journalism. There are Fleet Street editors who seriously think that an investigation consists of a particularly heavy lunch with Max Clifford, followed by a bout of creative writing in the company chequebook.

The symptoms of this decline go far beyond the puddles of dishonest pap that have soaked our tabloids for a generation. Look at the decline in the quality of the provincial press, or the spate of bogus documentaries in commercial television. Why would TV journalists suddenly start fabricating phoney stories? Part of the answer is that they don't have the skills to put together real ones.

The demand for investigative skill is being smothered by the creeping commercialism of our profession. Accountants have cut staff numbers so that those left no longer have the time to investigate their stories; marketing experts have rewritten news values so that it is now commonplace for news editors to demand a particular story in order to appeal to some new target group in the marketplace. Real investigation is expensive and risky. Separately, the supply of investigative skill has declined. The old union-enforced rule that all new recruits must be trained has collapsed with the demise of the closed shop. Now, the internet presents the prospect of unlimited unskilled journalism; the Monica Lewinsky tale provided a glimpse into a future of untested rumour recycled as news.

But it is not over yet. We hope all kinds of journalists, from first-term students to hardened veterans, will join us, along with anyone else who ever thought that real reporting is worth defending.

fields.headline: Howzat!
fields.standfirst: A year after taking over Talk Radio, Kelvin MacKenzie is facing poor listening figures, a battle with the BBC and a photographer hellbent on trying to make his nose look big. He tells  Maggie Brown  about success, failure - and why he's pinning his hopes on cricket
fields.trailText: A year after taking over Talk Radio, Kelvin MacKenzie is facing poor listening figures, a battle with the BBC and a photographer hellbent on trying to make his nose look big. He tells Maggie Brown about success, failure - and why he's pinning his hopes on cricket
fields.body:
Kelvin MacKenzie is clutching a red Talk Radio mug and roaring at the photographer. Britain's one-man PR machine is loving every moment. "Am I going to look handsome or not?" he shouts. "Come on. I know your tricks, you're not going to take one of those photos looking up my nose. At my age [he's 53] I'm not having all my double chins on display."

It's just over a year since the former Sun editor turned wannabe entrepreneur took over Talk Radio in a £24.7m deal. It remains the weakest national commercial station. After sacking almost every presenter he inherited, including Anna Raeburn, (just before Christmas - "she just didn't fit in") and suddenly throwing the South African test match at listeners, he was rewarded in November with a 17% drop in listeners, to 1.8m.

But, by way of two further deals, he has also added 16 local music stations to his radio empire: in Scotland, the north west around Manchester, and Wales. After a total £90m of spending, the renamed Wireless Company, backed by Rupert Murdoch who holds a 20% share, is vying to be the UK's fourth largest radio group.

Even though two of the three acquisitions are still losing money, to the tune of £5-6m annually, MacKenzie, acutely interested in riches, says he is planning to float it, offering some shares to the public later this year or in early 2001, City estimates suggest it might be worth around £200m.

Meanwhile, Talk's audience losses - 450,000 over the year from slots throughout the day - have privately delighted his sworn enemy, the BBC's Radio 5 Live, whose audiences MacKenzie is after. So is it time for a reckoning?

After the bluster has died away, MacKenzie, who bet his own capital on success, has something of an admission to make. "I've made some errors," he says. "We've done some good things, we've done some bad things. When I first came, I wish I had jammed a lot more sport in. From the day I arrived. Right? But when I came in first of all, I wanted to learn. It's all very well backing your hunches, but in terms of tens of millions of millions [of pounds] running on it, you tend to be cautious. And I wish I had gone down the sports route faster . . . but nothing is going to stop us now."

How long did it take for the penny to drop that Talk's future lay in football? "I don't know. I liked the sports phone-ins. And then competing with the BBC on news talk (his original plan) is a difficult beast, because it has so many resources and can send people to far-flung places."

MacKenzie's company is quitting its prestigious offices in Oxford Street, London, this week (something he said last year he wouldn't do) for the more anonymous Waterloo. The reason is more space at a cheaper rate.

He needs the extra space because he has set up Impact, a national advertising sales house, to pump national advertising into his local stations, the main route for cutting losses at a time when radio advertising, up 12% in 1999, is slated for further strong growth. This is run by one of MacKenzie's most rated employees, Tim Bleakley, who leads a sharp sales team in a conventional manner. MacKenzie has the sense to leave him alone.

So, you've been on a bit of a learning curve? "It's true. I'm no genius." You didn't crack L!ve TV either. "It was never going to work commercially. Never any possibility. Its base was too low. But it was great fun."

If Talk's long-term future is sport, then much hangs on negotiations later this year for the radio rights to the Premier League from 2001. The rights are currently with Radio 5 Live. "We'll bid, but won't get them, too expensive. Um . . . [there is a long pause . . . he sucks through his teeth]. That is the challenge, is it not? You have to decide if you wish to be a shareholder, get the opportunity to buy the shares this year. You decide." Which is a rather convoluted way of suggesting he will use money from a flotation to build up a war chest.

His staff say one of MacKenzie's problems as chief executive is that he has no one to keep him under control, and to filter the five good ideas from the 20 he throws out. "Good point. Um . . . you know that is absolutely true, my failing is that I have too many ideas. Literally, I do. I come in here in the morning and sit down with my colleagues and say, right, I had this fantastic idea in the night. I have to get up and write them down. I did that in newspapers too, I have to get up. I can see they have to work very hard, make sure their eyes don't loll. And they always say, 'Where are we going to get the money for that?' And I always say, 'The Lord will provide.'

"Anyway, it's better to have ideas than to have none. Go to any live wire company today and they will have more ideas than capital. The day they have more capital than ideas, fire the chief executive."

The question is whether things like test match cricket really work for Talk. England's play has hardly been magical. "It is pretty tough to just put cricket into the schedule after it has been elsewhere for so many years. But the signal is sport, and live sport, and live sport makes great radio. It's got a nice sound to it.

"What I was amazed about when I first came here [in November 1998] was that we completely changed the schedule and our audience didn't move. In the third quarter [July/September 1999] 17% of them said farewell. In the fourth quarter we're ending up with a completely different audience: younger, male, less hours. So suddenly the audience get it and start liking it."

The worry, however, is that with cricket dominating output since November 17, the audience could change yet again, and this time downwards. And young men, his target, also like to listen to FM radio, something which Talk cannot offer. "Yes, but they like sport," MacKenzie says.

Talk's coverage has, so far, won plaudits from listeners for the quality of its commentators - the controversial Geoff Boycott, Mark Nicholas, Chris Cowdrey and Bob Woolmer, the former South African coach. The radio industry is also impressed. "It has done him good," says a rival.

Talk put it together themselves without help from close allies Sky ("It's not rocket science") and MacKenzie denies there is any link, cooperation or cross promotion between Talk and Murdoch companies. He won't know until February 3 and the next set of ratings figures how the cricket performed in terms of audience. "If I had to bet, we'll get some people in, some people out. When the cricket ends, we go back to normal schedule." But he is certain of one thing - Talk's audience will be back over 2m.

"We'll do more cricket in the summer, four-day cricket, one-day games." There are those who wonder if MacKenzie, ever experimental, plans to spread sports coverage from Talk to his local stations.

"They're two different businesses. People shouldn't confuse music and speech. They are completely different. To run a 24-hour speech station is actually a much tougher proposition than running a music station."

The only possible exception is the under-unexploited franchise for Scot FM, which might get a MacKenzie-style revamp. But nothing will be done on the hoof. Meanwhile, his megaphone and highly personalised campaign against the BBC continues unabated. He really sees himself as a David against a Goliath, campaigning for the end of the licence fee: "They enjoy taking taxpayers' money then appropriating to themselves some kind of genius by knocking me out of the ring. And when I tried to explain this to the dimwits on the [culture, media and sport] select committee [investigating the digital licence fee] they honestly could not understand it. One woman said to me, 'What about society?' I had to control myself, I was going to say to her, 'Well actually my little lovely, it's not society losing all this money, it's me.' The BBC is like royalty. Their time is past, but nobody has told the old dears."

As for Greg Dyke and the BBC? "When I saw this great list of the good and the great wrestling for this position, it was beyond my thought processes why anyone would want to do it. John Birt has been a bloody great problem for me, I can't believe under Dyke it will be any easier."

MacKenzie looks positively pink with pleasure at the thought of extending the attack.

John Birt has been a bloody great problem for me, I can't believe under Dyke it will be any easier." MacKenzie looks positively pink with pleasure at the thought of extending the attack.

fields.headline: Come into my parlour
fields.standfirst: The world's most fashionable magazine company wants to make its web operation a must-hit.  Imogen O'Rorke  meets the woman hoping to entice a new breed of Vogue reader
fields.trailText: The world's most fashionable magazine company wants to make its web operation a must-hit. Imogen O'Rorke meets the woman hoping to entice a new breed of Vogue reader
fields.body:
Sue Douglas is posing for a photo-shoot in the black and white checked executive boardroom at Condé Nast, where she has recently been appointed director of a re-suited and re-booted new media department. The former editor of the Sunday Express and senior executive of the Barclay Brothers' newspaper empire is blending in rather well with her new surroundings - looking for all the world like the techno-empowered ABC1 modern woman she is trying to reach with the new Vogue.com, which launches in April.

New media chic has officially arrived at Vogue House. The little black dress and Tatler's little black book are about to be joined by the little black palm top with detachable mobile phone (Vogue's own brand).

Douglas does not have a new media background. She has had one of the most varied and well-recounted careers in journalism, serving as the inspiration for heroines of hack-soap fiction. She is perceived by former colleagues to be charming (lethally so), extremely capable and truculent, when pressed. After being pushed from the Sunday Express in 1996, she has turned her back on editing for consultancy roles.

When Jonathan Newhouse, chairman of Condé Nast International, offered Douglas the job on a consultancy basis, she told him she was "a technophobe". "But the internet is no longer dominated by City boys trying to make money and nerds," she says. Just look at how many women are using email now and mobile phones - what will happen when everybody starts logging on via their mobiles? "But it will never take over from other forms of publishing; it is just another medium."

A medium which, with a bit of imported old-world glamour and new-world commerce, could be extremely profitable. If Douglas can turn the flagging Condé Nast Online around, the Elysian fields of upmarket online publishing could be hers.

Apart from Vogue.com - which, after it is merged with the American site to form a global-style portal, promises to be as different from the rather parochial Vogue.co.uk as Popeye before and after spinach - there are six other titles to tackle: GQ, Tatler, Traveller, Vanity Fair, World of Interiors and, finally, Brides, to launch at the end of February.

Condé Nast poured money away down the black hole that was the early internet. It was one of the first publishers to brave it online as early as 1996, with a low-level presence to boost subscriptions and a staff of three, backed by Microsoft. Apprehensions about the unknown market - not least the common fear that they would lose readers if they could get it free on the net - stymied any great developments, but, even at subsistence, the site was costly to sustain.

Dan Conaghan, the first editor of Condé Nast Online, is now in charge of new business at New Media. With Nicholas Coleridge, the managing director, he sketched out on a piece of paper the idea for "the eighth magazine", an internet-exclusive brand which never came to fruition. "Condé Nast in the UK is choosing to focus on its main magazine brand and build a site around that brand," he says, fearing they run the risk of not having enough money to sustain their vision. "Condé Nast as a publisher is unique in not seeing an exit in raising capital from outside and always having to dig deeper in its own pockets."

Condé Nast reported an online revenue of £5m last year, an 83% increase in the number of banner adverts, and 10m page impressions. Advertisers are, apparently, "desperate" to get into the new brass-knobs-on Vogue.com. The upward trend is encouraging, but is it enough to justify a £3m revamp, including five new members of staff, and a new editor, Abigail Chisman?

New media analyst Rebecca Ulphe, from Fletcher research, believes the offensive has been "prompted by the recent launch of women's portals". The competition is not just from other publishing houses, but from internet service providers such as Freeserve, newspaper groups (Hollinger and Associated with Handbag.com, and Charlotte Street.com respectively), and even Microsoft Network. "If you told Condé Nast they would be competing with Miscrosoft a year ago they would have laughed," she says.

The biggest challenge Condé Nast faces is not that it is starting late, but that its current readers might not be geared up for e-commerce. Fewer than one third of British women who buy magazines use the internet. The vast majority of Vogue and GQ users are in the top income bracket, however, and one in three have bought something over the net. "They have a very good opportunity here," says Ulphe. "They know their niche and how valuable their readers are."

It will not be difficult to steal the editorial edge from the women's networks, which have been criticised for trying to be all things to all people. There will be no question of stretching the Condé Nast brands to include a wider audience, says Douglas. "The disadvantage for all these other pretenders is that nobody knows who they are. I mean, is it Charlotte Street or Berwick Street? At least we have the nuts and bolts in place."

Douglas is confident current readers will use Vogue.com, but hopes to attract a new generation of young women who might not buy the magazine but would surf the site and use the chat-room. With young audiences already so sophisticated, however, they need plenty of new attractions.

The first of these will arrive in February when London fashion week will be broadcast live from the site, as will New York and Paris. There will be daily fashion news (currently the most visited part of the site), and a glitterati events page - like an animated Hello!, where you can zero in on celebrities' facial blemishes - will follow. A virtual shopping assistant to guide users around the site is being discussed. A Vogue.com internet cafe will also be opening soon.

The next stage is Vogue email - users can define who they are by putting the name of the most famous fashion magazine in the world after their own - and (a long way off in internet terms, maybe six months) Vogue mobile phones. Customisation is the marketing mantra of the American Condénet, but brand extension is still a dirty word for many at Vogue House, so Douglas treads carefully.

"Condé Nast UK will not lose its British character or sophistication," says Douglas firmly. The American site is decidedly aimed at the shopping mall market with a dating agency, Swoon.com, a health and fitness brand called PHYS, and Epicurious, a food channel that has a lucrative television deal. "If our readers want that, they will have to click through to the American site." If masthead television - something Nicholas Coleridge was wary of 18 months ago - happens, it will happen through the site.

GQ is staying as it is online: a cursory presence with a gallery of gorgeous cover girls to surf through, and editorial content reduced to a teaser. Tatler will remain inimitably Tatler with lists of the best hotels, restaurants, A-list party-goers, upper-class crumpet: "the definitive Metropolitan guide".

There is some talk of an interactive TV partnership for Vanity Fair with Channel 4, and a deal has just been signed with the Wedding Channel in the US, who will have a 40% stake in Brides. Condé Nast Traveller's site is relatively advanced with inside track editorial and online booking already available. But, on the whole, the outlook is conservative.

E-commerce is an area Condé Nast is treating with caution. "Everyone has just jumped in at the deep end and publishers have tried to become retailers. Some have got their fingers burned," says Douglas (namely Elle, which is struggling to ship goods customers have ordered).

With Vogue.com, Douglas aims to close the 18-month evolutionary time lag that separates Europe and America. Joan Feeney, editorial director of Condénet, said at the launch of US Vogue.com in October: "The moment has finally arrived when the technology, the audience, the marketplace and the fashion world are ready and primed for a site like Vogue.com." The same could already apply to the British market.

"The atmosphere of excitement is tangible," says Douglas, thrilled to have discovered the hang-out of the New Media IT crowd is in the lobby bar of London's Claridges Hotel. There, the technorati drink cocktails, flash mobiles and talk web ventures with the conviction they will happen. Venture capital rather than editorial favours is the big game. "It's hilarious," says Douglas. "Just like the Groucho club used to be - the 80s all over again."

fields.headline: Look on the white side
fields.standfirst: This week Channel 4 launches a multicultural programme with a difference - it's about white people. Executive producer  Narinder Minhas  explains why we have to rethink our TV stereotypes
fields.trailText: This week Channel 4 launches a multicultural programme with a difference - it's about white people. Executive producer Narinder Minhas explains why we have to rethink our TV stereotypes
fields.body:
Across hours and hours of television output, "white" and "English" are words that are rarely heard. It's even rarer to see them together. And yet the white English are the biggest group in Britain, the silent majority. They have become a race that dare not speak its name. Could it be that in our politically correct culture we're ignoring the ethnic majority and actually not making enough programmes about how white people feel?

I wanted to send Darcus Howe around Britain in search of the White Tribe - a tribe lost and, in some cases, even ashamed to be English. But it took a long time to get the idea off the ground. Strangely, I was met with a mix of apathy and disbelief from commissioning editors: "Sorry, this isn't for me"; "Most of our programmes are about white people already"; "Isn't this just divisive - how can you regard whites as a race?"; and "Darcus who?" were typical responses.

Even amongst those broadcasters who could see that this was a fresh idea, there seemed to be a nervousness about commissioning a "black" series with a mainstream vision. They could see that there was a need for multicultural output but were locked into an old way of thinking. For them, multicultural meant programmes made by black people for black people about black subjects.

But one broadcaster did get it - Michael Jackson, chief executive of Channel 4. "At last a series about my people," he said ironically. He also liked the idea of an authored journey with Darcus - a man closely associated with the black cause, leaving his home territory of Brixton and going off to meet whites in trouble: the former panther meets "the enemy", armed this time with tea and sympathy.

White Tribe, for me, is a radical format. For centuries the white man has gone to the dark continent to investigate the strange rites and rituals of a black tribe. This time we've reversed that and sent a black man to England to meet its ethnic majority, the whites.

Our real intention was to re-define what multicultural television should be in the new century. There's no reason why multicultural programmes should focus only on people with dark skin and life in the ghettos. Rather, its real future lies in the opportunities it provides for fresh perspectives on subjects that are often the preserve of "whites". When did you last see three hours of primetime television on a significant issue fronted by a black man who is not a chef, stand-up comic or a footballer?

There's a wide range of subject areas that can be re-invented and re-vitalised by looking through the multicultural prism. In Love In Leeds, a series I made last year for Channel 4, we took a universal theme - love - and gave it a multicultural spin. By reversing conventional documentary casting, replacing the token black with a token white, we gave romance a new lick of paint with surprising results.

In White Tribe, Englishness gets the Darcus treatment. He argues that the English are lost, demoralised and even ashamed to admit who they are. He confronts a tribe that prefers vindaloo to fish and chips, chooses coffee rather than tea, but still blames the rest of the world for its slow demise. It's a world in which to be white and proud is a contradiction in terms. Even the future king looks like a wigger - a white nigger - with his baseball cap back to front.

One example reveals some of the difficulties of making this type of multicultural television. On one occasion we filmed Darcus moving cautiously through the grey, rundown streets of an Oldham housing estate, looking left and then right. He was the only black man for miles. This was a white space, do not disturb. Asian families have tried living here but have not lasted long.

Darcus was visibly shocked by the views of the residents who consider themselves an ethnic minority in a town where they make up 90% of the population: "Us whites are second-class citizens now"; "Get one family in, and before you know it the estate is over-run by them"; "It's a white estate, and it'll stay a white estate"; "We're supposed to be Great Britain, but all the great has gone".

These encounters are going to upset some people and - as someone who has suffered personally from racial violence - I thought a lot about whether to include them. The argument that we might be providing a platform for the far right was taken seriously, but was ultimately dismissed.

The reason? Well, I wanted to see whether it was possible for people in places like Oldham to be white and proud but not racist - after all, it is possible for me to be Asian and proud, and for Darcus to be black and proud. But sadly, there is a thin line between English nationalism and racism.

People struggle to describe their Englishness in positive terms. They often resort to negatives. Uncertain of themselves, they attack others. This is why we used the comments, to reveal that very point.

Personally, I don't see anything wrong with people on television describing their feelings about other ethnic groups, as long as they are challenged - though I draw the line at including contributors who seek to incite racial violence.

One woman interviewed by Darcus expressed support for the nail bomber who terrorised minorities in London last year. We had no qualms about removing her contribution.

But, in general, the sense of injustice felt by members of every community in Britain should be explored on television - and that includes white victims. It seems to me that we as programme-makers tend to exercise a kind of self-censorship when it comes to certain forms of racism, almost as if it's exclusively ethnic minorities who find themselves on the receiving end of a type of prejudice and discrimination.

As Darcus's journey shows, this country has been completely transformed by immigration and globalisation. We're no longer so sure who the victims are, what black and white means, and ultimately what it is to be English. We're in a state of flux, living in a pick-and-mix culture. In this new landscape, multicultural no longer needs to be dull and worthy or confined to ghetto subjects. We have to move it in to primetime. We're all multicultural now.

Narinder Minhas is joint head of programmes at Diverse Production, and executive producer of White Tribe which will be shown on Channel 4, Thursday, 9pm.

fields.headline: One track minds
fields.standfirst: As the first shots are fired in the battle to become top dog of a unified - and immensely lucrative - ITV,  Mathew Horsman  looks forward to a year of ego clashes, second-guessing and cloak-and-dagger deals
fields.trailText: As the first shots are fired in the battle to become top dog of a unified - and immensely lucrative - ITV, Mathew Horsman looks forward to a year of ego clashes, second-guessing and cloak-and-dagger deals
fields.body:
Hundreds of column inches were dedicated at the weekend to the news that Granada just might want to take part in the consolidation of ITV.

What a surprise! Granada's Gerry Robinson and Charles Allen have been telling anyone who will listen that the commercial logic of a single ITV was inescapable; and who better to run it than the key executives of Britain's most successful commercial terrestrial broadcaster, Granada?

But how much closer to the prize did the two men come on Friday, with their announcement that Granada is considering a bid for either Carlton or United? Not very. This was a matter of putting down a marker rather than making a real move on either target company. Granada wants to be seen as a contender for the mantle of ITV chief, and with it the £1.8bn in advertising revenues generated by the Channel 3 companies. But it is not yet ready to run risks by mounting a bid that faces huge regulatory obstacles.

The message was meant for a wide public, including the City, Whitehall, Westminster, the Office of Fair Trading and the head offices of Michael Green's Carlton and Lord Hollick's United News & Media. The daily newspapers, the Sundays, the Today programme, Channel 4 news - all the media outlets duly complied, giving Robinson and Allen huge publicity for essentially saying: "We'd like to have a go too, please."

The announcement was aimed at allowing Granada to recover from a virulent case of wrong-footedness. Last November, Carlton and United announced they intended to merge to form an £8bn media giant, controlling all the regional ITV licences south of Granada's Yorkshire (with the exception, of course, of Granada's London Weekend Television). That merger would go against the rules - specifically undertakings agreed five years ago, during an earlier frenzied round of ITV consolidation, that no single company would claim more than 25% of national advertising revenues. Carlton and United combined would represent at least 36%.

On another important regulatory measure - share of television audience - Carlton and United could just squeeze through, as they together would represent 14.9% of the national audience, compared to the ceiling of 15% (excluding their stakes in GMTV and Channel 5). Granada considered but rejected a similar move on one of its rivals, because it quite sensibly realised that any combination of Granada and another ITV giant would exceed the 15% rule, which can only be changed by a new Broadcasting Bill (due some time after 2001).

But once Carlton and United decided to mount a "bounce the regulator" campaign, Granada, fearful of becoming an ITV also-ran, was always going to have to react. It is now nearly inevitable that the OFT will recommend a reference to the Competition Commission. With Granada's intervention last week, the OFT will be considering a much broader set of issues, relating not just to a Carlton-Granada merger but to a combination involving Granada too.

The maths are simple. The combination of Granada and Carlton would exceed both limits comfortably. So would a merger of Granada and United. So what is Granada hoping to achieve? For a start, the OFT may relax the 25% rule as a result of its consideration of the Carlton-United merger. The regulator had already announced a review of the limits, on the grounds that the British broadcasting scene had changed radically since the ceiling was set in 1994. Pay-TV has grown rapidly, Channel 4 is taking a greater share of revenues and Channel 5 has been launched. A lifting of the ceiling might allow Granada to sell airtime for either Carlton or United (maybe even both). Granada could then simply rely on a third party to "own" a few licences (enough to bring Granada's ITV audience share to below 15%) until such time as a new Broadcasting Act is passed.

That is a messy compromise that would not fully unlock the premium that single ITV ownership (programming, sales, production, scheduling) offers. But at least it would improve the chances that Granada ends up, one day, with the big prize.

Granada could certainly afford to pay a premium for the more desirable of the two companies, Carlton, whose shares are trading at a significant discount to their fundamental value. A break-up bid might value Carlton at more than £8 a share, compared to the £6 or so implied by the terms of the Carlton-United merger. True, Granada would have a big problem owning both the weekday and weekend London licences. But it might sacrifice one or the other in the interim, hoping to put them together after the rules are changed.

A less compelling (but still logical) case could be made for a Granada-United combination, although United's share price already more or less accurately reflects that company's value. But either outcome is merely a transition stage toward answering the ultimate question: who gets ITV?

The next steps will be fascinating, not least because they will involve such vivid personalities, bristling with ego, tinged with arrogance. It is great fun not just because the consolidation process is of such huge importance to how British media evolve in the future. More than that, we get a front row seat when Messrs Robinson, Hollick and Green slug it out.

So what next? Within a few weeks, the OFT will determine whether the Carlton-United merger should be referred. Now that Granada's intentions have been registered with the regulator, the decision will be a broader and perhaps more prescriptive one.

Let's assume for the moment that the limit on airtime sales is lifted (or set at a much higher level: say 40%). That paves the way for Carlton and United to merge, but it also gives Granada an opening to bid for one or other of its two rivals. It would then have to sell off a few licences (or park them with a friendly third party) to keep within the Broadcasting Act. Thereafter, Granada could play a waiting game and emerge as ITV's single owner in a year or two.

But an "all clear" signal from the OFT has to be considered unlikely. Let's assume instead that the Competition Commission is asked to look at the whole issue. That means months of uncertainty and puts consolidation on hold. Thereafter, the Commission may well decide to loosen the rules, and the companies can sort out a midway point on the way to a single ITV.

A further possibility might be that the Commission instead decides that the status quo should be retained until a new Broadcasting Bill is presented in the next Parliament. Such a decision would frustrate all the ITV players but would at least ensure that everyone has a chance to lumber up to the starting line before the consolidation whistle is blown. And that's not to mention a bid from a wholly unexpected quarter for one or other of the ITV companies (from the Continent perhaps).

Confusion and uncertainty all round then! But full marks to Granada for turning its "assertion of interest" into the biggest media news of the year so far. Imagine the pages and pages we will have to read when a real bid gets tabled for real money, some time later this year. For make no mistake, a single ITV is the end destination. Getting there, it seems, will be a voyage wholly characteristic of the British media scene: feints, jousts, second-guessing, bids, counter-bids, spin doctoring and ego, ego, ego.

webTitle: Time for granny to snog the paper boy

fields.headline: Time for granny to snog the paper boy
fields.trailText: Not so very long ago, although an age in internet time, a national newspaper effectively gave up its business news coverage to a wire service. Fleet Street looked on the coupling of the Independent on Sunday and Bloomberg with a mixture of horror and schadenfreude, as a sign that the cash-strapped paper had finally given up.
fields.body:
Not so very long ago, although an age in internet time, a national newspaper effectively gave up its business news coverage to a wire service. Fleet Street looked on the coupling of the Independent on Sunday and Bloomberg with a mixture of horror and schadenfreude, as a sign that the cash-strapped paper had finally given up.

How times have changed. Now partnerships between rival news organisations are all the rage and it is the internet that has made them fashionable. And few are more in vogue than financial news partnerships designed to cash in on the worldwide obsession with one thing - making money.

Last week, the Financial Times announced a new European joint venture with Marketwatch.com, the US-based online financial news. Two months earlier, the New York Times set up a joint newsroom with TheStreet.com in the online news group's Wall Street headquarters.

The differences with the Independent on Sunday's 90s dalliance and these two online ventures are more instructive than any similarities. For a start, no one could argue that the New York Times or the FT are strapped for cash. Indeed, the FT is expected to relaunch its own website this week, after receiving a special £40m handout from Pearson, its parent company, to do so. Both newspaper groups also come from a current position of editorial strength, either from circulation increases or award-winning reports.

In spite of these strengths, however, both newspapers felt that they had a lot to gain from pairing up with organisations that have been around for less time than the average length of tenure for FT staff members.

Such changes underline, of course, how much the internet is changing the way newspapers do business. But the very real danger is that in the frenzy to be first, journalistic standards are not maintained. The consequences if they are not could be particularly worrying if associated with a stock tip branded by the FT.

Larry Kramer, chief executive of Marketwatch.com based in San Francisco, explains the current popularity for joint ventures by saying that his company and the FT "could both do it on our own . . . but if we join forces we can do it faster". The "it" is to become the leading online information source for the growing band of finan cially literate people around the world, a prize which is being fought over by organisations as diverse as Reuters and News Corporation.

The latest alliances do not just reflect the popularity of financial news in the internet age, however. They raise questions that are being faced by general news organisations in the US and elsewhere - witness several recent alliances including that between the Washington Post, MNSBC and NBC News.

For both the FT and the New York Times, the new ventures provide a stepping stone to a 24-hour, or at least real-time, news service as well as, potentially, a new set of readers. The central problem they face is how to benefit from the cross-promotion and global coverage of the new tie-ups without destroying the quality of the content they cherish. The FT alliance is perhaps the most far-reaching of the latest deals, although it is less likely to affect its core news operation.

FT-Marketwatch.com makes admirable business sense. The new site, aimed at the growing band of European investors, will be largely modelled on CBSMarketwatch.com, which has become one of America's most widely viewed financial websites. The site attracts upwards of 6m people a month and many of these are ordinary investors deterred by the lofty tone of the printed FT.

As part of the deal, the FT lends its name and some free advertising to an operation that will be largely managed by Marketwatch staff. In doing so, it seeks to allay fears over quality control by picking an online news organisation it trusts. Thom Calandra, a senior Marketwatch editor, is to move to London to head FT-Marketwatch.com and plans to appoint up to 50 new members of staff over the coming months.

The joint newsroom operated by the New York Times and TheStreet.com is a different animal. It already employs six reporters, who are overseen by a seasoned Times business editor. The copy produced by these journalists - about a dozen stories a day updated constantly - is used on NYT.com only. However, both parties believe these stories may eventually make it into the Old Grey Lady herself.

The relatively tentative steps are perhaps understandable for a venerable institution faced with the speed of change of the internet. As Dave Kansas, editor-in-chief of TheStreet.com, says: "The NYT is a deliberate organisation and we're going one step at a time. It's pretty radical that they have decided to partner with an upstart like us in the first place."

Some journalists may view such tentative couplings as unwholesome, a bit like granny snogging the newspaper boy. But for old media groups scared of being left behind, they offer the best way forward into a new age. As long as granny remembers to take the necessary precautions.

fields.headline: The dogma of dangled carrots
fields.trailText: Incentives really do work. Look at ITV. The reported £75,000 to £100,000 bonuses the Network Centre team stood to earn in 1999 were linked to performance in ITV's definition of peak-time. Why? Why not its total audience share? Cynics would say because total share is in long-term unstoppable decline, and the team can only be "incentivised" by offering them a realistic target.
fields.body:
Incentives really do work. Look at ITV. The reported £75,000 to £100,000 bonuses the Network Centre team stood to earn in 1999 were linked to performance in ITV's definition of peak-time. Why? Why not its total audience share? Cynics would say because total share is in long-term unstoppable decline, and the team can only be "incentivised" by offering them a realistic target.

So ITV created a definition of peak-time that excluded the awkward 6-7pm hour, and said it would increase its share within it, even at the expense of losing share off-peak. And so last year overall share duly dropped by 0.5% even as peak share rose by 1% (not quite the promised 1.2%).

A con? Or a good result? Advertisers are not fools. They clearly want bigger audiences in peak-time, even if shifting resources into achieving this is at the expense of viewership off-peak. Delivering mass volumes of people who see an advertisement at least once is ITV's unique selling proposition. Other channels can fill in the gaps, or build up multiple viewership of campaigns.

ITV was rewarded with a reported extra £100m of revenue last year as a result of this. Meanwhile, other channels picked up ratings points at times when ITV was competing less vigorously, and so also increased revenues. In business jargon: "win-win". Which is why I would echo Wilfred Pickles and say: "Give 'em the money, Mabel!"

Incentives can also work in the BBC. After a year of the governors and John Birt insisting that a nine-month handover to his successor was essential in an organisation as complex as the BBC, the simple device of a peerage seems enough to have induced his premature departure (presumably, a delay of the announcement until the summer's birthday honours would have so undermined the workings of the House of Lords that it was worth disrupting our national broadcaster to avoid it).

Curiously, the story announcing the early Birt bath concentrated on the impending cull of BBC management that Greg Dyke would swiftly undertake, to be followed by the exile of the consultants, the re-drawing of the Broadcast/Production split, the abandonment of bi-media ideology in News, etc. If the reward for getting so much so wrong is a barony, we must surely expect a Duke Dyke to be unveiled if Greg survives five years.

Even the centrepiece of the Birt DG-ship is unravelling: his digital strategy. Greg himself paid obeisance to the achievements of BBC Online when he was appointed. But it is perverse to judge the success of an organisation on 1% of its spending, and not the other 99%. Meanwhile, News 24 was given a drubbing by the Commons Culture Committee, and the BBC's most consistent supporters have had little good to say about BBC Choice.

The established wisdom is that the Commons Committee is made up of anti-BBC oddballs, with none odder than its outspoken chairman, Gerald Kaufman. Such an assumption does not survive a reading of the Committee's report. Even those of us who disagree with some of the Kaufman conclusions have to admit he is a master of detail and an enemy of humbug. He offers a simple and effective mechanism for implementing the free TV licence for over-75s. He ruthlessly demonstrates that the BBC's response to the Davies Report is substantially at odds with its (unpublished) evidence to Davies just a few months earlier. "Sketchy at best" is his damning summary of the BBC's claims for additional expenditure on new services. As for a much expanded role in the digital era and additional funding, the BBC had "singularly failed to make the case".

However, he has failed to spot the absurdities in the NERA Report commissioned by the commercial lobby, and so takes at face value its laughable predictions that a digital licence fee would significantly slow digital take-up and delay analogue switch-off. The million homes that have gone digital in the past six months have clearly not been deterred by the prospect of the Davies Report being implemented.

Kaufman's most effective argument against the digital licence fee is that the BBC's contribution to the digital proposition is too modest to justify a compulsory payment by digital households for its digital services. But he is equally adamant that no increase in the general licence fee should be authorised to fund the BBC's digital ambitions, and rejects any thought of re-opening the five-year licence settlement. He devastatingly cites the BBC's own statements - in support of the five-year deal, in opposition to a digital licence fee, in pledging digital services at no extra cost - to deflate its vision.

A muddled digital strategy, poorly implemented, is scarcely what John Birt would have chosen as his legacy. There is much to be applauded from his 13 years at the BBC. Even so, we should remember that incentives are used to persuade failed managers to leave as well as successful ones to continue. Just as well they work.

fields.headline: Flu runs over the NHS
fields.standfirst: The public needs to hold the health service management to account
fields.trailText:
Like buses, you wait ages for a case of flu and then they come
in droves, creating a situation which crowded, sophisticated and demanding
modern Britain is still struggling to learn to manage. The current Calvary
- pensioners on hospital trolleys and refrigerated lorries standing in for
morgues - is in real danger of becoming an annual fixture. Adjust your
calendars to add Hospital Chaos between New Year and St Valentine's Day.
fields.body:
Like buses, you wait ages for a case of flu and then they come in droves, creating a situation which crowded, sophisticated and demanding modern Britain is still struggling to learn to manage. The current Calvary - pensioners on hospital trolleys and refrigerated lorries standing in for morgues - is in real danger of becoming an annual fixture. Adjust your calendars to add Hospital Chaos between New Year and St Valentine's Day.

"If only..." an NHS manager might legitimately sigh. The sudden and unpredictable timing of the rush is management's underlying nightmare, especially in an organisation with minimal budget flexibility. Hospital accident and emergency departments have an exact parallel in council gritting and snowplough depots: unlike Alpine countries, we do not have blankets of snow every winter and cannot therefore justify the cost of salt mountains and machinery which would always guarantee passable roads.

Given its everyday burden of operations, casualties and longer-term care, the NHS cannot practically be geared to a level of intensive care provision which would guarantee everyone a place in a crisis like the present one. But there is something unacceptably arthritic in an organisation which reacts so slowly to red emergency flags; and the bickering lack of NHS unity in the face of challenge calls for a strong, publicly-administered enema.

It may be sod's law that the build-up to this year's epidemic coincided with Christmas and the New Year, when medical staff want and deserve extra time with their families. But the first public alarm bells were jangling before Christmas Eve, and private ones will have been ringing in the hospitals for at least a week before that. Prudent managers started cancelling operations and clearing the decks at once. Their foolish counterparts who crossed their fingers and hoped for the best need to be held to account by their governing NHS trusts.

That means politicians and the media checking that trust meetings (probably in March and April, when everything seems sunny again) do just that. Part of the NHS malaise is that the public has yet to take up the welcome increase in transparency of the health service. Meetings which were once private are now open; but neither journalists nor ordinary punters turn up.

We, the public, have another role as potential solvers of this problem. Anyone who has been to A&E in mid-crisis will have seen appalling examples of staff inertia and rampant 'Can't-you-see-we're-busy' syndrome. Consultants shroud-wave - currently spreading the impossible rumour that an ITC patient has been transferred in desperation to Paris - and no one admits responsibility for emptying out-of-order payphones in casualty.

What that situation needs is a healthy dose of Outsiders. In other words, us. New Labour could usefully consider extending the Board of Prison Visitors to hospitals, mobilising volunteer enthusiasm at little cost to remind the professionals what the S stands for in NHS.

Metropolitan moaners

Last summer we Northerners felt sore and resentful when three new attractions in Yorkshire ran into crisis simultaneously, because too few visitors were coming to see them. With the miraculous perception given only to columnists, London media opinion decided immediately that this was because the novelties - the Royal Armouries in Leeds, the Earth Centre near Doncaster and the National Centre for Popular Music in Sheffield - were in the wrong place, ie up north.

Well ha, ha. Guess which new attraction has visitor problems now? Not that the Dome won't overcome them; like the trio in Yorkshire, which concluded, rightly, that their exhibits needed re-thinking and re-marketing. I don't in the least want to vent any Northern spite at the great exhibition in Greenwich, which is high on my list of Year 2000 family treats.

But I do want to express amazement at London pundits' resilience. In all the Dome flak over the weekend, I found the imperishable comment (in a serious broadsheet's leading article) that the Dome is "in a remote area of London" - as ghastly and unvisitable, by implication, as the North. Metropolitanism of this sort - apparently unaware even of the Jubilee Line - is so tightly-focused that it must soon disappear up its own... well, frankly that's the best place for it.
fields.bodyText: Like buses, you wait ages for a case of flu and then they come in droves, creating a situation which crowded, sophisticated and demanding modern Britain is still struggling to learn to manage. The current Calvary - pensioners on hospital trolleys and refrigerated lorries standing in for morgues - is in real danger of becoming an annual fixture. Adjust your calendars to add Hospital Chaos between New Year and St Valentine's Day. "If only..." an NHS manager might legitimately sigh. The sudden and unpredictable timing of the rush is management's underlying nightmare, especially in an organisation with minimal budget flexibility. Hospital accident and emergency departments have an exact parallel in council gritting and snowplough depots: unlike Alpine countries, we do not have blankets of snow every winter and cannot therefore justify the cost of salt mountains and machinery which would always guarantee passable roads. Given its everyday burden of operations, casualties and longer-term care, the NHS cannot practically be geared to a level of intensive care provision which would guarantee everyone a place in a crisis like the present one. But there is something unacceptably arthritic in an organisation which reacts so slowly to red emergency flags; and the bickering lack of NHS unity in the face of challenge calls for a strong, publicly-administered enema. It may be sod's law that the build-up to this year's epidemic coincided with Christmas and the New Year, when medical staff want and deserve extra time with their families. But the first public alarm bells were jangling before Christmas Eve, and private ones will have been ringing in the hospitals for at least a week before that. Prudent managers started cancelling operations and clearing the decks at once. Their foolish counterparts who crossed their fingers and hoped for the best need to be held to account by their governing NHS trusts. That means politicians and the media checking that trust meetings (probably in March and April, when everything seems sunny again) do just that. Part of the NHS malaise is that the public has yet to take up the welcome increase in transparency of the health service. Meetings which were once private are now open; but neither journalists nor ordinary punters turn up. We, the public, have another role as potential solvers of this problem. Anyone who has been to A&E in mid-crisis will have seen appalling examples of staff inertia and rampant 'Can't-you-see-we're-busy' syndrome.
