fields.headline: The flu epidemic
fields.trailText: What is flu?
fields.body:
What is flu?

Influenza is defined by the Gray Laboratory's medical dictionary as "an acute viral infection involving the respiratory tract. It is marked by inflammation of the nasal mucosa, the pharynx and conjunctiva and by headache and severe, often generalised myalgia. Fever, chills and prostration are common." The incubation period is one to three days and the disease ordinarily lasts for three to ten days.

What are the symptoms?

Self-diagnosis of flu is difficult as its classic symptoms, a fever, a sore throat, a headache and aching joints, are often confused with a common cold. You can test whether you have the flu on the NHS Direct website.

Flu differs from a common cold in the way that its viral strains rapidly appear and affect large numbers of people. Flu usually involves these initial symptoms, along with a worsening of the sore throat and muscle pains.

How does it spread?

Flu viruses enter the body through the eyes, nose or mouth. Flu is usually spread from person to person via airborne droplets or respiratory fluids, especially coughing and sneezing.

Is it fatal?

Yes. Every year flu kills thousands, particularly the elderly. Healthy people tend not to die from flu, although they can if complications develop, such as pneumonia or blood poisoning.

What I do?

If you are suffering from flu symptoms, you should stay at home, keep warm (but not over-warm), take basic painkillers such as Paracetamol to relieve your temperature, and drink plenty of water or other fluid to prevent becoming dehydrated.

Antibiotics are not effective against the flu. If your illness lasts longer than the usual three to ten days, you should see your doctor. You should also get medical advice if you are at risk of developing complications. These tend to emerge if you are old, infirm, suffer from a chronic illness or respiratory disease, or have a reduced immunity, from HIV or undergoing chemotherapy for instance.

If you haven't suffered from the virus this year and are at risk from developing severe flu, you can get a vaccination, which provides providing immunity to flu infection. 9m people in Britain have been vaccinated this winter. You need the injection every year: the vaccine is updated annually because of flu's constant mutation into different viral forms.

What is the cure?

Flu can be prevented by vaccination, but there is no cure. Flu is categorised into types A, B and C. Every year or so there are minor "drifts" in the viral strains of flu. These changes are enough to make those who suffered from - and became immune to - the previous strain susceptible to the new one.

This occurs because each flu strain has different surface antigens - which are molecules of two proteins. A person's immune system produce antibodies to fight the invading virus. These are developed specifically to attack each antigen, so when a new flu strain emerges it can circumvent the existing armoury in the body's immune system.

Large changes in the makeup of flu type A occur every decade or so. These are called "antigenic shifts" and tend to result in large epidemics.

Is this bout of flu an epidemic?

An epidemic is defined by the online medical dictionary as "occurring suddenly in numbers clearly in excess of normal expectancy, said especially of infectious diseases but applied also to any disease, injury or other health related event occurring in such outbreaks."

The government says flu reaches epidemic proportions when 400 people per 100,000 are suffering from the virus. Last week, statistics gathered from doctors across the country showed that 144 people per 100,000 had the flu.

The government's chief medical officer professor Liam Donaldson has called the current outbreak the first "serious epidemic" for 10 years. He says the figures are an underestimate because thousands are bypassing their doctors and going to the pharmacist or using the government's new NHS Direct service.

The medical profession disagree. The British Medical Association chairman Dr Ian Bogle has denied the existence of an epidemic. Dr Douglas Fleming, the director of the Birmingham research unit which calculates the official flu figures, says that flu rates are actually "very similar to the figures from last year which were not epidemic".

This year's outbreak falls well short of previous epidemics. In the last official epidemic during the winter of 1989-90, 600 people per 1,000 fell ill and 26,000 people died. In 1918 there was a flu pandemic, an epidemic that affects a wide geographic area, which killed more than 20 million - more than died in the war that had just ended.

Called "Spanish" flu, it was said to come from China, although professor John Oxford, writing in today's Daily Mail, says new research suggests it originated in a British military base in northern France.

The current virus appears to be a minor mutation, rather than a major new shift. It is called "Sydney" flu, a mutated form of type A flu which emerged in Sydney two years ago. It has been suggested that Australian rugby supporters helped spread the virus in Britain this summer.

Why has the NHS been hit so hard?

There are 1,500 intensive care beds in NHS hospitals across the country. Yesterday, there were between 20 and 31 free.

The current outbreak of flu has hit the NHS because the population is ageing. A greater proportion of the population is now elderly people, who often require hospital treatment for severe flu, than during the last major epidemic in 1989/90.

The NHS confederation says that efficiency reforms over the last decade have reduced the number of spare beds in hospitals. Many regularly run their emergency wards 95% full. This compares with 75% or less 20 years ago, which gave hospitals greater capacity to deal with sudden increases in those requiring hospital beds.

webTitle: March from the old to the new

fields.headline: March from the old to the new
fields.trailText: Today's $250bn merger announcement between Time Warner and America Online provides the most dramatic proof yet of the breakdown of old and new media.
fields.body:
Today's $250bn merger announcement between Time Warner and America Online provides the most dramatic proof yet of the breakdown of old and new media.

For Time Warner, it has been a steady march from the traditional media of film and print new areas. Gerald Levin, the head of Time Warner brought CNN, the cable network into the Time Warner empire, seeking to cross-fertilise Time Warner's numerous publications with cable TV.

Once thought of a bloodless technophile, Mr Levin has emerged as an audacious dealmaker. In his latest venture, Mr Levin is seeking to catapult Time Warner well and truly into the internet age, tapping the internet expertise of a new media company like AOL to leverage his company's traditional media assets.

Other companies have been moving in this direction, notably Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation. Mr Murdoch became an internet convert towards the end of last year and now wants his company to be at the cutting edge of the internet. His number two, Peter Chernin, is less focused on the company's heart, its newspaper business, than on its fast-growing divisions such as entertainment and the internet.

Last month, Mr Chernin announced a $1bn alliance with Healtheon/WebMD, the online healthcare company. The deal signalled a new trend for traditional companies to leverage their huge marketing power to gain a stake in internet companies. Instead of accepting advertising fees from online groups desperate to increase brand awareness, media companies are demanding a stake in the company in return for space.

As another example of the sort of cross-pollination Mr Chernin has in mind, News Corp plans to start a religious website linked to its Zondervan publishing interests. Mr Chernin also expects TV Guide, the magazine partly owned by News Corp, to rival Yahoo and America Online as a valuable media brand.

Mr Levin has taken the process of convergence to another level altogether, by merging Time Warner with an internet company. Although AOL initially was ridiculed by internet purists, it has established itself as the dominant online service provider with 20m customers, and it boosted its internet credentials with its purchase last year of Netscape, which popularised the internet browser.

By merging operations, Time Warner will have access to AOL's large customer base, while Yahoo will have access to Time Warner's content, which includes films, TV programmes and publications ranging from Time and Sports Illustrated to People and Entertainment Weekly. While other companies such as News Corp were looking at alliances with internet entities, Time Warner has decided to go all the way by throwing its lot in with AOL.

This deal represents the second phase of mergers among media companies. In the first phase media companies merged with each other. Disney set the trend by buying the ABC television network, Viacom bought Paramount, the film studio, Time Warner hopped on the bandwagon and bought CNN. These media companies then entered into alliances with internet companies or formed internet subsidiaries. Now we have a marriage of a traditional media company with an internet company.

On paper, it looks like a sensible idea. Media companies have to position themselves for an era where people will get news not just from print, but from phones, interactive TVs and computers. They need the expertise of a Yahoo! to channel information to these various platforms. The internet companies, for their part, need content for their sites.

Mr Levin has always been a technology buff. He resisted the pressure to get rid of Time Warner's cable assets, which soaked up investment. Now they have become valuable as a way of delivering information. He led the drive for interactive TV, although the experiment fizzled, coming ahead of its time. Now the question is whether he is too far ahead in putting Time Warner and AOL together. Large companies, and the new entity will be a behemoth, are notoriously difficult to run, and the clash of cultures between two companies, has often been difficult to overcome.

fields.headline: Flu: bed shortage row deepens
fields.trailText: Ministers were last night digging in against mounting pressure to order an increase in hospital bed numbers, as the NHS battled to handle a flu outbreak now described by the chief medical officer as an epidemic.
fields.body:
Ministers were last night digging in against mounting pressure to order an increase in hospital bed numbers, as the NHS battled to handle a flu outbreak now described by the chief medical officer as an epidemic.

An investigation for the government is understood to have concluded that the health service has no general shortage of beds - even though hospitals the length of the country say they are struggling to cope.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, intends to publish the inquiry findings this month. He pointed out yesterday that many hospitals in the US, where there are relatively more beds, had been plunged into disarray by a parallel flu outbreak and were turning patients away.

As health workers voiced growing protests at conditions in the service - one consultant today uses the term "brutal beyond belief" in a letter to the Guardian - there was an angry reaction to the drawing of comparisons between the NHS and the American public health care system.

Stephen Thornton, chief executive of the NHS confederation, representing health authorities and trusts, said US "emergency rooms" were a sink system for those unable to afford private medical insurance. "That's ER," said Mr Thornton, referring to the TV series about a chaotic American public hospital. "Have we really reached the point where we are comparing the NHS with field hospitals?"

The confederation says the main reason for current prob lems is that there is too little slack in the system to be able to respond to a flu outbreak. As a result of relentless demands for greater efficiency, many hospitals run their emergency beds at 95% capacity, compared to 75% or less 20 years ago.

A recent study by York university health economists, funded by the department of health, found that hospitals risked periodic bed crises at anything over 90% capacity.

The number of acute care beds in English NHS hospitals dropped 16% in the 10 years to 1998 and, on some measures, is among the lowest in Europe. Most new hospitals being built under the private finance initiative provide for markedly fewer beds than the units they are replacing.

In response to concern at this trend, the bed numbers inquiry was ordered by Frank Dobson, Mr Milburn's predecessor, and was carried out by a team led by Clive Smee, the health department's chief economic adviser.

The inquiry report is believed to set out policy options ranging from a small increase in beds to further substantial cuts, provided corresponding investment is made in primary care services outside hospitals.

Mr Milburn, whose own family is flu-stricken, said the bug was "particularly nasty" and causing complications in patients admitted to hospital, requiring them to stay longer than normal. There was "real pressure" on intensive care facilities, but nobody was failing to get the care they needed. "Overwhelmingly, the NHS is coping tremendously well."

Amid signs of easing problems in some parts of Britain, availability of intensive care beds in England yesterday fluctuated between 20 and 31 - higher than on some days last week but still well below approved levels.

The health department continues to decline to call the flu outbreak an epidemic, as figures remain well below that official threshold: compared to epidemic levels of 400 cases in every 100,000 people, the latest published total is 144 and an interim indicator due today is not expected to exceed 200.

However, Liam Donaldson, the chief medical officer said the official count understates the true position, not least because people have been following government advice and not bothering their GP.

Professor Donaldson estimated that 300 people in every 100,000 had flu, which he said was of "epidemic proportions". He called it as the worst outbreak since 1989 when 26,000 people, mainly elderly, died.

fields.headline: Stylish Leeds bounce straight back
fields.standfirst: The full FA Cup treatment
fields.trailText: At least Manchester City's departure from the FA Cup this season, unlike the stiff-necked withdrawal of Manchester United, gave their followers a whiff of glory.
fields.body:
At least Manchester City's departure from the FA Cup this season, unlike the stiff-necked withdrawal of Manchester United, gave their followers a whiff of glory.

That was all it was. Eventually Leeds United's superior passing and movement saw the Premiership leaders through to the fifth round with a victory which, but for the agility of Nicky Weaver in the City goal, would have been comfortable to the point of indecent luxury.

Yet for the best part of half an hour there seemed little difference between City's view from the top of the Nationwide League and the vista at present enjoyed by David O'Leary's aspiring young side. In the first 20 minutes alone the teams shared four goals, with City twice holding the lead.

Maine Road must still have been hugging itself after watching Manchester United's decline and fall in Rio the night before. It was not as if defeat in the Cup represented the end of the world for a City team intent on reaching the Premier League next season. But yes terday's tie offered strong prima facie evidence that should Joe Royle's team win promotion they will struggle to survive. If Vasco da Gama had sailed through Sir Alex Ferguson's defence in the Maracana, there were times when the Spanish Armada could have drifted past City's cover.

Appearances, however, can be misleading and should Leeds visit City in the Premiership next season it is unlikely they will find Royle quite so generous in his team formation and tactics. Yesterday the City manager seemed to opt for a policy of win or bust; anything but a fixture-clogging replay.

So he was happy to play three against four in midfield in order to employ Mark Kennedy as an orthodox left-winger supporting the strikers, Shaun Goater and Paul Dickov. In fact Kennedy had an indifferent game but so enthusiastically did City attack Leeds at the start of the game that for a time the afternoon offered them the possibility of a notable victory.

The reality was that the longer the match progressed the more Leeds exploited the advantage of the extra man between the penalty areas. Lee Bowyer and Harry Kewell found space at will and once Leeds had gone ahead shortly before half-time the outcome was never in doubt.

Even Royle, not a manager accustomed to giving his team's conquerors excessive praise, readily admitted to the overall quality of Leeds's performance. "Over the last 12 months we've played Wimbledon, Derby and Southampton in the League Cup and I've told my players that none of the opposition would improve our side," he said, "but today Leeds were terrific."

Certainly Leeds needed the sustenance of an impressive FA Cup victory after league defeats against Arsenal and Aston Villa which, after their having had to play 10 games in 30 days, had raised doubts about the team's staying power.

O'Leary, whose consistent refusal to discard his manager's L-plates has become an anachronism, will be the last person to talk about a league and Cup double but after yesterday's win he left no doubt about what an appearance at Wembley would mean. "I've done nothing in management," he said, "and I'd be delighted to win the FA Cup. I think it's the greatest competition in the world."

After the opening 20 minutes yesterday Maine Road was inclined to agree. So long as City suggested they could match Leeds goal for goal the tie had the makings of a classic.

The opening was a combination of opportunism and misjudgment. fields.headline: Playing catch-up
fields.standfirst: Click here to read all the entries in the diary so far
fields.trailText:
Dec 18
East London: Combined Eastern Province/Border XI v England
We fielded first, one of the hottest days since we've been here, and I had a chance to show that I'm still on this tour. In general, I felt I bowled really well - the ball was coming out nicely, and getting down there at good pace. There were just three overs later on when the ball got very sticky and I couldn't grip it properly. Their captain Strydom was able to get hold of a few then. Still, even though I went for some runs I also picked up three wickets, which is my job.
fields.body:
Dec 18
East London: Combined Eastern Province/Border XI v England
We fielded first, one of the hottest days since we've been here, and I had a chance to show that I'm still on this tour. In general, I felt I bowled really well - the ball was coming out nicely, and getting down there at good pace. There were just three overs later on when the ball got very sticky and I couldn't grip it properly. Their captain Strydom was able to get hold of a few then. Still, even though I went for some runs I also picked up three wickets, which is my job.

Dec 25
We went down to Kingsmead to train at around 10.30am on Christmas Day. The nets were very soggy because of torrential rain so it was mostly indoors. Alan Mullally was having a fitness test in the car park - he was bowling from one end, then he decided to switch ends, said he wanted to come downwind.

Got back in time for Christmas lunch - nothing too extravagant, just food and a couple of drinks, and then everyone went about their business. It was an important game the next day, plus all the guys had their girlfriends and families staying with them. All the guys, that is, apart from Graeme Swann. We told him he's a loner, but he doesn't mind - he takes it all with a pinch of salt.

The system of having the wives and girlfriends out here for Christmas makes a lot of sense. They get some sun, we get a break from being with the other guys all the time, and everyone gets to catch up with each other. It can be hard to see them during the summer too, so it's very important that they get out to meet us over the winter.

Dec 26
Third Test, Durban
They announced the side on Christmas day, and I was left out again. It's hard because it's not like at home when you can go back to your county and get loads of wickets and you're in form again. I came on this tour without having played for ages because of my knee injury, then all of a sudden the Tests have started, and you haven't shown everyone what you can do.

Now I'm playing catch-up, particularly as Chris Silverwood has come in and done so well. I haven't bowled since East London, and I probably won't until after the fourth Test, which is a gap of nearly three weeks. It's been a disappointing tour so far for myself, because I expected to do much better, but it's one of these things you learn from. I'm big and bad and ugly enough to get on with it. If I get my chance, I just have to do something outstanding, throw my name back in the hat.

Back to the game, and Nasser's tremendous innings. It was very slow on the first day - I don't think I've seen a day as slow as that in my career - but the important thing to remember is that a Test match lasts five days. Everybody over here was saying "boring, boring England," and then Alec Stewart came in and suddenly we were creaming the ball to all parts.

Andrew Caddick bowled really well: he extracted more bounce than anyone, being about six foot ten. I'm not used to many people being taller than me, but he's massive. In the second innings, though, South Africa learned from their mistakes. Gary Kirsten is a rock, the Michael Atherton of the South African side, and he got stuck in. That's the way it goes: some things just don't happen twice.

A few people said that Darren Gough didn't bowl at his best, but they've got to remember that he's also coming back from injury: he missed the whole of last season apart from the World Cup. As he plays more games he's bowling a lot better, and the next five-for is just around the corner.

The pitches out here make it hard for fast bowlers, particularly with the Kookaburra ball. It seems to go flat after 20 overs, and you just have to persevere. Be a Shaun Pollock, say, where you hardly concede a run and build pressure that way. Unless the conditions are like they were at the Wanderers, you're not going to blast people out. You have to be disciplined: set split fields and wait till you get a wicket, then try and go bang-bang.

Dec 31
Vodafone laid on a New Year's party for us by the waterfront in Cape Town. There was a live band, and Lord MacLaurin and Tim Lamb showed off their moves on the dancefloor. Then we just got on the bus and went home. It was about one o'clock, so not a late one, because we had to train the next day.

Jan 2
Fourth Test, Cape Town
We started really well, but as Nass says, from 213 for 3 to 258 all out is not good enough. When we got a score like that on a flat wicket they were always going to come out and show us how to do it. Nass did get a little bit upset when he was given out in the second innings. Human error, that's all you can say. It's very difficult for umpires now, with all the cameras and third umpires and so on. Before, it was just a guy making a decision and people were fine with that. Like the Premiership managers are always saying, all we ask for is a bit of consistency.

I wasn't actually there at the end. There were quite a few 12th men, so we did shifts, and I left early in the afternoon on the final day. It wasn't too long before the guys were back at the hotel. I don't know what it was like in the dressing-room but I can tell you that they were desperately disappointed. Now we've got one more game to play, and we have to make sure we're in the right spirit for that.

Alex Tudor was talking to Simon Briggs

fields.headline: The best runaway scene
fields.standfirst: The Straight Story
fields.trailText: Iowa. Camping out for the night, Alvin Straight (Richard Farnsworth) watches a teenage hitchhiker as she hovers nearby.
fields.body:
Iowa. Camping out for the night, Alvin Straight (Richard Farnsworth) watches a teenage hitchhiker as she hovers nearby.

"I couldn't get a ride."

Alvin catches her eye.

"Hungry?"

"What you got?"

He holds up a hot dog roasting on a stick.

"Wieners."

"Wieners?"

"Wieners. Want to try one?"

He offers the girl the stick; uncertainly, she sits down and begins to eat.

She looks round at Alvin's rider-mower.

"What a heap of junk."

"Eat your dinner, missy."

They continue their meal in silence.

"So, how long you been on the road?"

"I've been travelling most of my life."

"Got a wife? A family?"

"My wife Francis delivered 14 babies. Seven of them made it. She died in '81. Where's your family?"

The girl shrugs.

"You're running away?"

A beat.

"How far along are you?"

"About a month."

"You didn't tell them?"

"No, no one knows. Not even my boyfriend."

"Well, they may be mad. But I don't think they're going to be mad enough to want to lose you. Or your little problem."

"I don't know about that."

Alvin leans back in his chair.

"Well, of course, neither do I. But a warm bed and a roof sounds a might better than eating a hot dog on a stick with an old geezer travelling on a lawn mower."

The girl bursts out laughing.

See also: Times Square, It Happened One Night, Carny

Don't see also: Beethoven

Pointless trivia: While at college, David Lynch shared a room with Peter Wolf, lead singer of the J Geils Band.

fields.headline: They're frying tonight
fields.standfirst: All the presidential hopefuls support the death penaltyThe US elections: special report
fields.trailText: American politicians do not have much talent for the comically mordant, but they sure know a good television jingle when they hear one. And "O Death where is thy sting-a-ling-a-ling" is perfect for expressing the depth of their philosophic reflection on a distinctive American institution: the electric chair.
fields.body:
"O Death, where is thy sting-

a-ling-a-ling

O Grave, thy victoree?

The bells of Hell go ting-

a-ling-a-ling

For you but not for me." - Anon

The time is ripe over here for a revival of the song the British Tommies liked to sing on the way to the trenches. American politicians do not have much talent for the comically mordant, but they sure know a good television jingle when they hear one. And "O Death where is thy sting-a-ling-a-ling" is perfect for expressing the depth of their philosophic reflection on a distinctive American institution: the electric chair.

The barbaric chair, it is true, is in disfavour. Most of the 38 states where the death penalty is legal use a lethal injection. Utah and Idaho offer the firing squad. Only Florida, Alabama, Georgia and Nebraska have been frying the convicted. The verb there may sound a little harsh, but it has been the reality of three botched executions in Florida, which has now decided that its 366 death-row inmates should die by the needle.

You might expect that on such an emotional and contentious issue as capital punishment there would be a vigorous division of opinion. A scintilla of reasonable doubt might be expected about the efficacy and justice of a punishment now rejected by 71 countries. Membership of the European Union is not open to any death penalty state.

But it is not so. Every single one of the 11 presidential hopefuls unquestioningly embraces the death penalty. The only difference between left and right is that the left is more ready to denounce the chair, and more ready to acknowledge that you are more likely to fry if you are poor or black, and to live if you can afford decent counsel. Al Gore is no different from Governor Bill Clinton, who rushed conspicuously home in the 1992 presidential campaign simply to preside over the execution of a murderer so mentally retarded he hid a piece of pie to eat when he came back from the death chamber.

Bill Bradley, who could have outflanked Al Gore on the liberal left, has proved himself only a weasel-mouth on the death penalty as well as campaign finance reform. The supposed leader of the political Christians,Gary Bauer, ran away from the opportunity to speak for the abolitionist Christian community, though in December Catholic and Jewish leaders jointly called for ending a punishment that "diminishes all of us".

The Republican rivals look with envy on the front runner, the "compassionate conservative" George W Bush, who is easily top of the executioner's league table. In his five years as governor of Texas, he has dispatched 111 men and Karla Fay Tucker, a repentant born-again Christian. He has also reduced the years-long gaps between sentence and execution, an idea his brother Jeb, governor of Florida, has just adopted.

None of the candidates is willing to discuss the implications of all this. They are scared by polls, notably a Gallup last February suggesting that seven out of 10 Americans want the death penalty for murder. All of them are haunted by the wan face of the 1988 Democratic candidate, Governor Michael Dukakis, whose opposition to the death penalty was viciously exploited by George Bush senior. Asked in a TV debate what he would do if his wife were raped and murdered, Dukakis went into wimp mode. He failed to express the natural outrage everyone would feel, giving the impression that abolitionists were soft on killers.

But Dukakis was a singularly inept candidate. And there are signs that American opinion can be changed. The Gallup poll last February reporting 71% for executions also noted that the support was the lowest in 13 years. Recently, more probing polls have found that a majority would give up the death penalty if they could be sure a life sentence would mean life, coupled with restitution for the victim's family. With these conditions, support for the death penalty drops to 41%.

Several influences seem to be at work: Americans are uneasy to find themselves entering the millennium arm in arm with the executioners of China, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia and Sudan; they worry about the wrongful convictions and the frenzy that has gubernatorial opponents competing for who can promise the most executions (last year 98 people were put to death, the highest number since 1976). And then there is Hollywood. Tom Hanks, the American hero who stormed Utah Beach in Saving Private Ryan, is now starring as a jailer in The Green Mile, forced to watch the execution of a lovable black man he knows to be innocent. Politicians resent Hollywood's intrusion. But who was it who said: ". . . We need leaders who believe that, if politics is the art of the possible, it is the role of a leader to expand the possibilities"? It was Bill Bradley, but he is no longer listening to himself.

webTitle: Rovers' fate may go way of fashion

fields.headline: Rovers' fate may go way of fashion
fields.standfirst: The full FA Cup treatment
fields.trailText: Any football club, large or small, waiting for an FA committee to decide their fate can never be sure whether reason, expediency or sheer mindboggling doublethink will rule the day.
fields.body:
Any football club, large or small, waiting for an FA committee to decide their fate can never be sure whether reason, expediency or sheer mindboggling doublethink will rule the day.

Last year, when the spirit of the law was breached in Arsenal's FA Cup match against Sheffield United, a replay was deemed right and proper. On this occasion the spirit of Tranmere's 1-0 victory over Premiership Sunderland might suggest the FA should let the result stand.

But replays have become the fashion and yesterday Adrian Bevington, one of the few FA spokesmen not in Brazil, made it clear that a second match was an option, even if his utterances amounted to little more than what Basil Fawlty famously called "a statement of the bleedin' obvious".

This morning the FA Challenge Cup committee will bend its mighty collective mind to the problem, and Tranmere will fear the worst. Clearly there was a breach of the rules in extra-time, with the referee Rob Harris, the fourth official David Unsworth and the Tranmere management all culpable to some degree.

John Aldridge, Tranmere's manager, unfortunately reacted rather like a recalcitrant schoolboy, claiming his club had done nothing wrong.

"If the officials can't do it right, it is nothing to do with our lads," he said. "It was the last minute of the game. They didn't score from the free-kick and they weren't going to win it anyway by that stage. But if they want to go through the back door that's up to Sunderland."

But the facts were that Clint Hill, having been sent off a minute from the end for a second bookable offence, was illegally replaced by Stephen Frail - the fourth official having erroneously displayed Hill's number on his electronic board, and not that of Andy Parkinson.

Kevin Sheedy, Aldridge's assistant, recognised the mistake immediately and desperately tried to catch the attention of Parkinson, but already what might have been a crucial free-kick had been taken - Sunderland's last effective chance of equalising - with Tranmere defending 11 men strong rather than 10.

fields.headline: Platt talks up next test
fields.standfirst: The full FA Cup treatment
fields.trailText: For a manager under pressure, a foolproof way to reduce expectations is to talk up his team's opponents. It is a lesson that David Platt has learnt quickly during his distinctly uncomfortable spell in charge of Nottingham Forest.
fields.body:
For a manager under pressure, a foolproof way to reduce expectations is to talk up his team's opponents. It is a lesson that David Platt has learnt quickly during his distinctly uncomfortable spell in charge of Nottingham Forest.

Having overcome Oxford in a thrilling FA Cup third-round replay on Saturday, Forest travel to Stamford Bridge on Wednesday week and Platt's effusive description of Chelsea's modest manager would have turned Gianluca Vialli a Tranmere shade of red.

As team-mates at Juventus they won the Uefa Cup in 1993 and they now come face to face for the first time as managers. If Vialli and his team live up to Platt's platitudes it will not be much of a contest.

"Luca is an absolute diamond, an exceptional person who has taken all the qualities he had as a player into management," Platt said. "He's honest, straightforward, practically astute; he's magnificent. Emotionally I think so much of him. He's an exceptional person who's always there for you."

It is a support that Platt has needed this season as Forest, 17th in the First Division with only three wins from 15 games prior to Saturday, have struggled to adjust to his rebuilding programme.

Yet, though Forest's best formation and their most effective personnel may still be unclear, Platt has finally instilled some confidence into the side. After Paul Powell gave Oxford the lead with a stunning run and finish, Forest scored three times in the final nine minutes to seal their place in the fourth round.

"We showed a great deal of character," Platt said. "Six weeks ago we would not have come back from going a goal down but there's now a lot more confidence in the side. Going to Chelsea will be a lucrative tie so it was important for the football club to be in the next round.

"It's also a great thing for the players to look forward to and will get the adrenalin pumping. I remember when I was a player at Aston Villa being drawn to Inter Milan in the Uefa Cup in October 1990 and the feeling that I had for two weeks afterwards.

"Even going into the league games there's a small part of your mind that's already thinking about that game. Our job this week is to take people's minds off Chelsea and to concentrate on Grimsby in the league on Saturday."

Indeed, survival must remain Platt's priority given Forest's parlous position, but if his players can show the same fighting spirit as here then relegation will surely be avoided.

Saturday's late revival started with a thunderous strike from Chris Bart-Williams which flew in off the post in the 81st minute. Two minutes later Dougie Freedman, who the Oxford players, fans and management were convinced was offside, was brought down by Pal Lundin, with Oxford's goalkeeper inevitably being shown the red card before Bart-Williams converted the penalty. In the 89th minute Alan Rogers scampered clear of Oxford's beleaguered defence to complete the comeback.

webTitle: Messiah Moyes given an easy ride

fields.headline: Messiah Moyes given an easy ride
fields.standfirst: The full FA Cup treatment
fields.trailText: For a team seemingly inventive and fluid enough to be on the point of turning their backs on the Second Division and restoring overdue status to Deepdale, it is perhaps odd to suggest that Preston's hottest property is their 36-year-old manager David Moyes.
fields.body:
For a team seemingly inventive and fluid enough to be on the point of turning their backs on the Second Division and restoring overdue status to Deepdale, it is perhaps odd to suggest that Preston's hottest property is their 36-year-old manager David Moyes.

In the nation's boot rooms, where elder statesmen make their considered assessments, Moyes's is the name they tout with increasing approval. They like the way he has ambitiously benefited from his managerial apprenticeship. At Preston, where he arrived six years ago as a dour, uncomplicated centre-half, he has gradually revealed organisational and tactical skills to complement an intelligent, self-possessed presence.

Preston are on a fine league run and it is hard to see them not going up. The Deepdale frisson, which had appeared to be destined to bittersweet nostalgia, has resurfaced. And yet the irony of Saturday's Cup win, putting them into the fifth round for the first time since 1966, cannot be lost on Moyes and his team.

Plymouth were beaten by two own-goals and a penalty. You could hardly ask for more. Preston were also slow starters, intent on taking a cautious look at this Devon side, generously described by Moyes as "one of the best in their division; I like the way they play".

The home team deserved something from the tie, if only a penalty when Colin Murdock bundled over Paul McGregor in the second half. Maybe McGregor did himself a disservice with the flourish attached to his fall.

There had been a valid enough spot-kick shortly before, at the other end. David Eyres - an opportunist raider disguising his nearly 36 years, who gave Plymouth the most trouble - burst through and was brought down by the keeper Jon Sheffield. Not much doubt about it; the only question was whether Sheffield would be sent off. He stayed on and Graham Alexander converted the penalty.

Wayne O'Sullivan had opened the scoring by heading into his own net after 39 minutes when trying to prevent Kurt Nogan from reaching Jon Macken's cross. Jon Beswetherick, at the near post, confusedly glanced a similar own-goal from Eyres' in-swinging corner in the 77th minute.

Argyle were chasing for most of the second half in any case. They defended competently but made virtually none of the progress their manager Kevin Hodges had hoped for down the wings. Their strikers really got nowhere against Murdock and Michael Jackson; the two best shots came from Chris Leadbitter, both from outside the area and one bringing a spectacular leaping save from Tepi Moilanen. Occasional lapses of judgment by Sheffield were offset by the way he instinctively kept out a stinging header from Macken.

Preston are not as yet a glamorous side, not perhaps the kind Devonians had hoped to watch at this stage of the competition. But they are a well drilled unit, with undoubted Old Trafford influence in the composition of a team their next opponents would be wise to respect.

fields.headline: Mariners fail to hold Fish
fields.standfirst: The full FA Cup treatment
fields.trailText: For a blissful few days Bolton can relax in a cup-tie atmosphere and forget the depression of league results that have dumped them in mid table.
fields.body:
For a blissful few days Bolton can relax in a cup-tie atmosphere and forget the depression of league results that have dumped them in mid table.

This victory takes them into the fifth round and on Wednesday they meet another of the First Division's cup specialists, Tranmere, in a Worthington Cup semi-final.

Bolton's hopes, though, of further success in the first leg at the Reebok have been hit by the enforced absence of the influential Mark Fish, who will be on cup duty of a different nature.

The centre-back must join South Africa's training camp for the African Nations Cup today, at a time when his international team-mate Quinton Fortune has been allowed to stay in Brazil with Manchester United.

Fish is unhappy at being denied the same latitude. "It's very disappointing and they've got to sort it out," he said. "I've talked with other European-based players and if our federation keep forcing us like this we'll act together. We'll just stay in Europe where our bread and butter is and not appear for our country. It will happen.

"My situation is ridiculous; it's only a training camp and they could have let me play against Tranmere."

Fish was a commanding figure as Bolton held on to a 2-0 lead in the face of spirited Grimsby attacking in the final 30 minutes. Lee Ashcroft hit the bar and Stacy Coldicott had a shot cleared off the line, but it was all too late for a side whose current league form is as poor as Bolton's.

The outstanding Eidur Gudjohnsen set up Bolton's victory with a 22-yard shot in the 33rd minute, followed by a clever run and cut-back for Bo Hansen to score the second nine minutes after the interval.

Gudjohnsen, who once scored goals alongside Ronaldo for PSV when they were both 17, also hit the bar with a header. Injury wrecked his career in the Netherlands but the 21-year-old Icelander's ability on the ball is impressive and he is adjusting to English demands. "There's no question about his quality, and his work-rate is starting to improve," said Sam Allardyce, Bolton's manager.

Defeat leaves the Mariners without a win in seven games but Alan Buckley praised his players: "They kept going and refused to lie down."

fields.headline: Leicester limit Gunners' options
fields.standfirst: The full FA Cup treatment
fields.trailText: Frustration upon frustration for Arsenal. First they were stymied by bureaucracy, then the referee and finally by Leicester.
fields.body:
Frustration upon frustration for Arsenal. First they were stymied by bureaucracy, then the referee and finally by Leicester.

Despite enjoying near total possession, Arsène Wenger's side had to watch helplessly as City's disciplined rearguard performance earned them the draw they came for, even shrugging off their reduction to 10 men for the final nine minutes when Darren Eadie was harshly sent off for a second yellow card.

But Arsenal's disappointment at having to replay on Wednesday week was compounded by the fact that among the 10 cautions administered by the over-fussy referee Mike Riley was one shown to Davor Suker for mild dissent. It leaves the Croatian suspended for the league game at Manchester United on January 24.

Given the absence of Nwankwo Kanu, on international duty for Nigeria in the African Nations Cup, and with Dennis Bergkamp still struggling with a calf injury, Arsenal face a striker shortage for a game that may decide their title chances.

Kanu has been the subject of quite a saga over the past few days, with the Nigerian Football Association insisting that the striker joins up with the squad ahead of the tournament which begins on January 22, and Arsenal insisting he play in yesterday's game.

On Saturday morning Kanu was about to fly home when the former Wimbledon striker John Fashanu, who now works as Nigeria's sporting ambassador, stepped in and persuaded the Nigerian High Commissioner to let Kanu play.

In the end official confirmation from the Nigerian FA of the climbdown had not arrived by the time Wenger needed to pick his team and Kanu started only on the bench.

Although Arsenal hope to have Bergkamp back for the Manchester United game, the Gunners' vice-chairman David Dein is attempting to get permission for Kanu to fly home and play for Arsenal between Nigeria's games - though, even then, he will not be available against United as his country's first match is a day earlier.

As it turned out, Kanu was nearly prevented from travelling to Africa by an awful studs-first, over-the-top tackle by Robbie Savage which nearly snapped his leg in two. "You can end a career like that," said Wenger afterwards.

That Savage received only a yellow card for the worst tackle of the game by far highlighted the inconsistencies of Riley, who first booked Eadie for an innocuous challenge on Fredrik Ljungberg, then issued a second when the player took the ball away instead of allowing a free-kick to be taken.

The shower of yellow cards added to the general untidiness. It was a hard-fought tie, hardly an example of the beautiful game, as Arsenal struggled to impose on Leicester the superiority one would expect from a team playing at home, sitting higher in the league and with history on their side.

Leicester last won here in 1973 and this season have already lost twice to Arsenal, most wretchedly last month when a palsied performance at Filbert Street saw the home side taken apart in a 3-0 defeat.

Determined to restore some honour, additionally so after taking one league point from the last 15, Leicester's approach was typically focused - and this despite the absence of Tim Flowers, Muzzy Izzet, Andy Impey, Steve Guppy and Tony Cottee, all injured.

Each time Arsenal broke forward there were at least two yellow-shirted Leicester players on hand to thwart the progress of the man on the ball. And, though Arsenal's best intentions were to pass their way towards the visitors' area, they found themselves spluttering forward instead.

Despite the bulk of possession Arsenal created only three worthwhile chances before the break and two after it. They came closest on 74 minutes but Pegguy Arphexad produced a great tip-over from Suker's side-foot shot on the run.

The absence of the lock-picking skills of Bergkamp and Marc Overmars through injury was never more noticeable. Even when Kanu came on as a 62nd-minute replacement for Stefan Malz, Arsenal still struggled although the traffic was so one-way that City's makeshift striker Matt Elliott never had a chance to add to his two goals against Everton, and the loss of Tony Adams through injury was never exploited.

Leicester will be hoping for more in Wednesday's Worthington Cup quarter-final at home to Fulham.

fields.headline: Francis rails at Styles
fields.standfirst: The full FA Cup treatment
fields.trailText: Gerry Francis should stick to defence. Prosecution is a problem for him.
fields.body:
Gerry Francis should stick to defence. Prosecution is a problem for him.

In the image of their young wing-back Paul Bruce, Queens Park Rangers contributed nothing positive to this game. Bruce kept crossing from nowhere to no one. QPR had five players booked and one sent off, conceded a penalty and had one shot on target all game. And that was mishit.

Francis blamed injuries, which have been unreasonable this season, and the refereeing of Rob Styles, which has not.

Styles has refereed two QPR games this season and Francis has had words with him after both. At Fulham in September, Styles did not give Rangers a free-kick for 37 minutes and then sent off Rob Steiner for diving. And at Charlton on Saturday the referee sent off Chris Plummer for an offence that failed to scandalise even the opposition fans and players.

"I didn't see a penalty," Francis said. "I don't think anyone else did. Certainly not their players, certainly not my players, certainly not the crowd."

But the referee had a good sight of it and so did the television audience. It got a little messy after Plummer interrupted Andy Hunt's attempt to spin by him, but nothing very untoward happened until the central defender grabbed the Charlton striker's shirt.

That was his second offence and it was punished by a penalty and a red card. Graham Stuart, who had been misfiring all game, blasted the penalty over the bar, but Charlton went ahead within a minute through Charlie MacDonald, with a first goal in his first start for the first team.

MacDonald, an 18-year-old from Elephant and Castle, recalled that Rangers offered him schoolboy forms three years ago when he played a game for their youth team. "I said I'd get back to them," he smiled.

He had been given a lesson by Darren Ward, a central defender Rangers have on loan from Watford, but the teenager had the last word. When Shaun Newton cut inside from the right, the striker anticipated a shot, slipped behind Ward and slotted the ball in at the near post.

MacDonald is only 5ft 9in but he is strong, he can evidently finish and he would appear to have the right attitude. He planned to celebrate his triumph by going home to rest and watch Match of the Day.

As he will have seen, the BBC got it right. This game was not worth much more than a couple of minutes' highlights and Francis's complaint would have been a waste of airtime.

In the image of their young wing-back Paul Bruce, Queens Park Rangers contributed nothing positive to this game. Bruce kept crossing from nowhere to no one. QPR had five players booked and one sent off, conceded a penalty and had one shot on target all game. And that was mishit. Francis blamed injuries, which have been unreasonable this season, and the refereeing of Rob Styles, which has not. Styles has refereed two QPR games this season and Francis has had words with him after both. At Fulham in September, Styles did not give Rangers a free-kick for 37 minutes and then sent off Rob Steiner for diving. And at Charlton on Saturday the referee sent off Chris Plummer for an offence that failed to scandalise even the opposition fans and players. "I didn't see a penalty," Francis said. "I don't think anyone else did. Certainly not their players, certainly not my players, certainly not the crowd." But the referee had a good sight of it and so did the television audience. It got a little messy after Plummer interrupted Andy Hunt's attempt to spin by him, but nothing very untoward happened until the central defender grabbed the Charlton striker's shirt. That was his second offence and it was punished by a penalty and a red card. Graham Stuart, who had been misfiring all game, blasted the penalty over the bar, but Charlton went ahead within a minute through Charlie MacDonald, with a first goal in his first start for the first team. MacDonald, an 18-year-old from Elephant and Castle, recalled that Rangers offered him schoolboy forms three years ago when he played a game for their youth team. "I said I'd get back to them," he smiled. He had been given a lesson by Darren Ward, a central defender Rangers have on loan from Watford, but the teenager had the last word. When Shaun Newton cut inside from the right, the striker anticipated a shot, slipped behind Ward and slotted the ball in at the near post. MacDonald is only 5ft 9in but he is strong, he can evidently finish and he would appear to have the right attitude. He planned to celebrate his triumph by going home to rest and watch Match of the Day. As he will have seen, the BBC got it right. This game was not worth much more than a couple of minutes' highlights and Francis's complaint would have been a waste of airtime.

fields.headline: Forget Copacabana - viva el Fulham
fields.standfirst: The full FA Cup treatment
fields.trailText: Who needs the crowded Copacabana when the bulk of 17,000 can cavort in Cup joy down by London's riverside? If the old competition's currency has been devalued by Manchester United's defection, then this was the other, gleaming side of the coin - like a sixpence shining in the dark.
fields.body:
Who needs the crowded Copacabana when the bulk of 17,000 can cavort in Cup joy down by London's riverside? If the old competition's currency has been devalued by Manchester United's defection, then this was the other, gleaming side of the coin - like a sixpence shining in the dark.

Fulham's home was a glorious timewarp on Saturday. The Cottage itself, that curious corner-piece of a ground, still features a wooden stand and pewter expanses of terracing. And the result was redolent of the club's better days, like that run to the FA Cup final all of 25 years ago. Something was in the air, or rather over the PA, which belted out the 1975 anthem Viva El Fulham with "Diddy" David Hamilton at the controls.

Enough of nostalgia. Paul Bracewell is a practical man, fashioning a modern team with the riches provided by Mohamed Al Fayed. Fulham's manager plotted a pragmatic path to what was a giantkilling in more than the footballing sense. Seldom can a side of such towering stature as Wimbledon have been so ruthlessly brought to earth.

A standing ovation and the man-of-the-match award went deservedly to Barry Hayles, whose unpredictability and confidence in his quick, clever feet mocked his modest background as a full-back supplementing his carpenter's wages with Willesden Hawkeye and Stevenage Borough until 2 years ago.

At 27, Hayles has to be a quick learner, although he is undergoing too many lessons in the disciplinary department. The striker's recent sending-off - his third of the season - means he misses three games, starting with Wednesday's visit to Leicester in the Worthington Cup.

That was a downbeat end to a glorious day and Bracewell caught the mood after praising a performance "as good as I've seen since I've been here". Within minutes Fulham's manager was deliberating on their priority: promotion to the Premiership. Manchester City next Sunday, as his players readily agreed, is a "massive game for us".

It did not stop Bracewell doing his revision on Wimbledon, just as he had equally effectively on Tottenham, who crumbled at the Cottage a month ago.

"We've done our homework and we got our tactics right," said Bracewell. "That's the first time I've played a back four and all the players there used their experience." As a result, Wimbledon's trademark tactic of high diagonal balls to the tall wide men, Carl Cort and Marcus Gayle, never prospered.

Equally important, Fulham won - as Bracewell put it - "the battle and then the war" in matching Wimbledon physically. "We ruffled them a bit early on, and not many teams do that," said Lee Clark gleefully.

Fulham fans have endured more than nine hours without one of their own scoring. But the Cup is governed by different forces and the only puzzle at the end was how the First Division side had not scored six. Neil Sullivan's defiance was only part of the answer.

Geoff Horsfield, Hayles's more vaunted partner, should have scored before the 22nd-minute breakthrough, engineered by Kevin Ball's thoughtful pass, Clark's perception and Hayles's pirouette and finished off by Wayne Collins's header. Wimbledon could not cope with Hayles three minutes later as he ran on to another Clark pass and unselfishly centred for Steve Finnan's tap-in.

Thirty-five minutes passed before a Wimbledon shot of note in a barren first-half performance condemned as "just awful" by a glum Egil Olsen.

Hayles, taunting the statuesque Hermann Hreidarsson, was the focal point of everything and should have finished with a hat-trick to complete his award-winning day. It scarcely mattered as the third, killing goal arrived 13 minutes from time to a roar that rolled down the Thames.

Clark cleverly supplied Horsfield, whose low cross was fumbled by Sullivan for Collins to bundle in - an untidy goal but one making a neat point about Wimbledon's defensive disorder in the face of an exuberant Fulham team only too pleased to progress in the absence of Manchester United and any other Premiership team not up for the Cup.

As Clark said of United's disdain, "I hope all the other clubs think the same. It'll give us more of a chance."

webTitle: Twisted love for Depp and Ricci

fields.headline: Twisted love for Depp and Ricci
fields.standfirst: Also today, Cate Blanchett in line for Hannibal, Michael Caine's literary turns,  Sandler's new movie 'violates every sense of human decency', in brief and the latest casting news
fields.trailText: Also today, Cate Blanchett in line for Hannibal, Michael Caine's literary turns, Sandler's new movie 'violates every sense of human decency', in brief and the latest casting news
fields.body:
Heads sure do roll in Sleepy Hollow, but they certainly aren't lost in love. Apart from the endless decapitations, Tim Burton's Hammer homage is also notable for the complete lack of onscreen chemistry between Johnny Depp and Christina Ricci.

One scene in which Depp confesses to Ricci that she has "bewitched" him is delivered with as much feeling as one would reserve for a pickled onion, but there is a reason why the pair - dubbed the 'gothic Tracy and Hepburn' give a whole new meaning to word 'sang-froid'.

At a recent press conference Depp said: "I met Christina when she was nine years old and when you have to regard that person you met at the age of nine as a love interest it's a little uncomfortableunsettling. Working on Sleepy Hollow we gradually allowed ourselves to get to the stage where it wasn't so...twisted."

Cate Blanchett in line for Hannibal

After a week of uncertainty and intense speculation, it seems certain that Hannibal, the sequel to The Silence of the Lambs, will definitely not star Jodie Foster. Studio executives had contemplated abandoning the project altogether when producer Dino De Laurentiis offered to pay back the $10 million spent by Universal on book and script costs, but it now seems likely the studio will go ahead with the film, and will make an offer to Cate Blanchett to play the female lead of FBI agent Clarice Starling. Sources say there is another actress on the short list, but won't reveal who she is.

Whether the star of Elizabeth would be able to fit in the project is another matter. She's just about to start work on Sam Raimi's The Gift with Keanu Reeves, and is also signed up for The Lord of the Rings trilogy.

Caine's literary turns

Screen veteran Michael Caine has been speaking about his latest role in Shiner, one of the many British gangland movies currently in production. But Caine refuted comparisons to Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels.

"It's a completely different kind of thing. It's a study in character," he said of the film, which is said to be loosely based on Shakespeare's King Lear. Caine plays boxing promoter and small-time gangster Billy "Shiner" Simpson, whose world crashes around him when his son Eddie (played by one-time Coronation Street heartthrob, Michael Marsden) loses an important bout. The film goes into production next week.

Caine will also soon be starring alongside Kate Winslet in Quills. He plays a 66-year-old doctor who marries a seventeen-year-old girl.

This fits happily into his screen preference for younger women. "I don't want a love scene with a woman who looks like me, for goodness' sake. I've always liked my women younger" he said last week (see our story).

Meanwhile, away from the bedroom, the actor has also revealed that he is writing a novel. "It's a thriller to amuse me, and I hope it will amuse other people, that's all. I've got to the end in a mad dash, now I've got to go back and do it properly," Caine said. Not least because the budding Frederick Forsyth has just discovered that he has killed one of his characters off twice.

Sandler's new movie 'violates every sense of human decency'

Adam Sandler executive producer of Deuce Bigalow: Male Gigolo has come in for criticism over the depiction of a woman suffering from Tourette Syndrome (an illness which can manifest itself through the uncontrollable use of expletives).

Judith Ungar, executive director of the US Tourette Syndrome Association, says the movie has prompted a record number of complaints from sufferers expressing hurt, dismay and outrage at the way in which the film pokes fun at the character. She says, "While it may not be against the law to ridicule people with disabilities, it certainly violates every sense of human decency. And it can only serve to further stigmatise the thousands of children and adults who must cope with having TS every day".

In brief

Robin Williams is to go online in a weekly comedy show from April. The madcap actor announced last week that he will host a weekly, web-based variety show called RobinWilliams@audible.com. The show, which will be written and performed by the actor and selected friends, will run for half an hour and be available exclusively online. Williams hopes the show will encourage his artistic peers "take control of their talent."

Catherine Zeta-Jones and Michael Douglas are to marry in Majorca. The couple will wed at Douglas's remote mountain villa on the Spanish resort island, a source close to the couple has revealed. "They want to keep the wedding private. Michael's estate in Majorca is perfect because it is so isolated," said the friend.

Casting couch

Anthony Minghella who was so impressed by Cate Blanchett's performance in his homoerotic thriller, The Talented Mr Ripley that he expanded her role, wants the Australian actress to star in his next project, Cold Mountain, a 19th century Civil War drama based on Charles Frazier's best-selling novel. But Blanchett will have to fight it out with Ripley co-star Gwyneth Paltrow who is also keen to play the woman who waits in her Blue Ridge Mountains' home for her lover to return from the Civil War.

 Helen Hunt is back on track to star in What Women Want with Mel Gibson. The actress recently dropped out of the project to star in Pay it Forward with Kevin Spacey, but is now hoping to do both projects.

 Freddie 'She's All That' Prinze Jr. is in talks to play the lead in Summer Catch. The actor would play a poor, baseball-playing small-town boy who tries to impress both the big leagues and a wealthy woman who spends her summer holiday in his Cape Cod town.

webTitle: Eraserheads go down to twin peaks

fields.headline: Eraserheads go down to twin peaks
fields.standfirst: The full FA Cup treatment
fields.trailText: It is a fair bet that David Lynch's latest film The Straight Story is showing at Neil Warnock's local cinema. With a depleted defence, the Sheffield United manager might have drawn inspiration from the tale of a man riding a lawnmower in a straight line; after all, Mr Straight had no tricky corners to negotiate. Unfortunately for Warnock the Blades had plenty.
fields.body:
It is a fair bet that David Lynch's latest film The Straight Story is showing at Neil Warnock's local cinema. With a depleted defence, the Sheffield United manager might have drawn inspiration from the tale of a man riding a lawnmower in a straight line; after all, Mr Straight had no tricky corners to negotiate. Unfortunately for Warnock the Blades had plenty.

"If corners hadn't been invented it would have been a very close game," he admitted after seeing his side panic throughout at set pieces on Saturday, gifting Newcastle safe passage into the fifth round. "We were hoping we wouldn't have to defend corners early on. In the end they got one at the start of each half. That's what did us."

Warnock and his opposite number Bobby Robson have both galvanised their squads to pull the two Uniteds away from the foot of their respective divisions. Indeed the visitors, unbeaten in seven games, could realistically harbour some thought of a Cup upset.

For Warnock, however, a combination of suspension, injury and his recent manager of the month award - the kiss of death for many a team's ambitions - contrived to settle the tie. His tallest defender, Shaun Murphy, was banned and when Nolberto Solano swung the first corner of the game into the area no one picked up Alan Shearer, who gleefully prodded the Geordies ahead.

"Murphy's the only height we've got. The two lads who were supposed to be marking can't man-mark," added Warnock. "We had two midgets marking Speed and one of their centre-halves. We were a disgrace at corners; they could have scored with every one they had."

Not that the early setback settled the tie. The Blades struck back with some quality during an evenly contested first half. When Jonathan Hunt swung a deep cross to the far post, there was Martin Smith to catch the ball on his left foot, advance a yard and lift it gracefully over the on-rushing Steve Harper from the acutest of angles. The scorer, as the visiting fans were quick to point out, was born in Sunderland.

Parity at the interval was no more than the Blades deserved. "They were equal to us in that first period, working hard and giving so much energy," said Robson. "But in the second half the pace and the power of my side told. Our fluency ensured we won the game."

Predictably, a corner was the visitors' undoing. Solano's centre was headed goalwards by Gary Speed on to Marcelino, making a nuisance of himself amid a clutch of defenders. And there was Nikolaos Dabizas to bundle the ball home.

This messy opening to the second half visibly drained the Blades' confidence and from then on the quality of Newcastle's goals reflected a previously negligible gulf. Even Alessandro Pistone, an idle onlooker for much of the first half, got involved; his burst to the byline and cut-back enabled Duncan Ferguson to rifle home the third. Kevin Gallacher's fourth, a crisp shot from Shearer's knock-down, was the icing on the Geordie cake.

"Pistone was nothing more than a defensive left-back in the first half," said Robson. "Once he got on his motorbike and got down the line he becomes a player again.

"He's got to ask himself whether he wants to be a top international footballer or what he was in the first half, which was not very much."

fields.headline: Chippo double but Burnley chipper
fields.standfirst: The full FA Cup treatment
fields.trailText: Whatever the controversies elsewhere, the Cup regained some gloss here. There was no upset, supposedly the lifeblood of romance, just a fine, open game as generous in skill and endeavour as it was of spirit. It was a match to restore faith after the miscast third round. It even had undisputed winners, undisputed goals and undisputed players on the field.
fields.body:
Whatever the controversies elsewhere, the Cup regained some gloss here. There was no upset, supposedly the lifeblood of romance, just a fine, open game as generous in skill and endeavour as it was of spirit. It was a match to restore faith after the miscast third round. It even had undisputed winners, undisputed goals and undisputed players on the field.

Not that the substitutions were conducted with aplomb. As the fourth official stood with Burnley's No15 Graham Branch, his board showed 8 and 31 for Coventry's attempt to get Noel Whelan on. Paul Cook, Burnley's No8, was almost off before the mistake was spotted. Later, when Paul Telfer (No12) was replaced, the board showed No2, who was not playing for either side. World Mathematics Year may have justification after all. Or perhaps it is time for a fifth official to monitor the fourth, or even a bench of them.

Such nonsense apart, the game flowed almost without fouls or injury. Stan Ternent, who has revived the Second Division side over the last 18 months, said beforehand: "We expect an open game, as they are all forward-looking players apart from the centre-backs. We'll see what we are made of."

They were made of such buoyant confidence in their ability and such determination to test it by meeting Coventry's challenge on the front foot that only their reluctance to do anything crude got them into serious trouble. Even then, thanks to Coventry's profligacy, they were, as Ternent put it, "bang in it for 70 minutes". After all they had won at Derby that way in the previous round.

Never did a head go down. Or, when it did, when some- thing failed to come off, one could almost see the player remembering where he was, casting off momentary disappointment and running off in relish of the next involvement. Or perhaps it was the thought of Ternent. He is a hard task-master. He said "enjoy"; they did him proud. "We didn't embarrass ourselves," he said in understated recognition.

It was a pity a poor clearance by Steve Davis, back at Burnley from Luton, led to the first goal, Youssef Chippo consummating a crisp exchange with Gary McAllister; the central defender is neat and unruffled as his snooker namesake. Coventry, having survived the next 20 seconds,needed an hour before Chippo got his second to make Whelan's third an irrelevance.

In that hour, according to Gordon Strachan, "we decided it was time to show our flicks and tricks; we tried to entertain and we got out of shape". It made for much fun.

Coventry's Moroccans have now joined the national squad for the African Nations Cup but they will be back for Saturday's game against Wimbledon. "The Moroccan authorities have been good to us," said Strachan. It reflected further the day's good nature. Strachan has never failed to reach the fifth round with Coventry but he must do without them until the sixth. He already has midfielders at full-back. Unless his defenders recover, more improvisation lies ahead.

But this was Burnley's day. When Coventry won the Cup in 1987 the Lan cashire club, founder members of the League, avoided going out of it with a last-day win. Now, like Preston, they are vying for a return to the First Division.

Of all league clubs Burnley boast the best local support per head of population. "You won't see any Manchester United shirts in Burnley," said a fan - nor, presumably No7 thongs.

fields.headline: Barmby cops Francis blast
fields.standfirst: The full FA Cup treatment
fields.trailText: In Manchester United's absence Everton have become this season's specialists at winning cup ties through late goals, and with the good fortune they enjoyed here they could go all the way to Wembley. That being so, Trevor Francis will feel doubly robbed.
fields.body:
In Manchester United's absence Everton have become this season's specialists at winning cup ties through late goals, and with the good fortune they enjoyed here they could go all the way to Wembley. That being so, Trevor Francis will feel doubly robbed.

In the previous round Nick Barmby had spared Everton extra-time embarrassment with a strike five minutes from the end against Exeter. On Saturday the scoring honours went to David Unsworth, but from Birmingham's perspective there was only one figure responsible for their downfall.

David Elleray escaped blame because, as Francis rightly pointed out, it has become an impossible task to adjudicate on the crucial tackles when so many players are prepared to speculate on the referee's generosity. Barmby protested his innocence, claiming he had been caught by Eddie Newton in winning the first of two penalties - and, to be fair to him, there was no immediate evidence of his nose growing longer.

But Francis's touchline view as Barmby went down with 15 minutes of a breathless second-half remaining was that his side had been the victims of a con job. He listened afterwards while his players voiced the same sentiment and then sought out the video monitor, which confirmed his initial impression. When he later bumped into Barmby outside the dressing rooms Francis did not mince words.

"He took a dive and I told him so," said the Birmingham manager. "What's more, he had done the same in the first half as well. Barmby had lost possession and there was absolutely no contact. It has become all too prevalent for players to fall over and it makes it so hard for referees."

Unsworth's second successful conversion following a tug by David Holdsworth on Kevin Campbell was deemed by Francis to be irrelevant. By then the damage had been done, Birmingham's initial vigour and their later determined resistance turned to waste by a dodgy decision. "I was taught by Brian Clough at Nottingham Forest to steer clear of controversy," Francis added, "but, when you have lost a match in that way, you are entitled to be angry."

Birmingham had already defeated Watford in the third round and removed Newcastle from the Worthington Cup and until midway through the first half they were Everton's superiors. Gary Rowett and Bryan Hughes both had chances to underline that dominance and failed by mere inches to find Paul Gerrard's goal.

It was only when Francis Jeffers discovered enough room 22 yards out to shudder a post that the Premiership side began to get on top. The first of Ian Bennett's many splendid saves foiled Campbell soon after. From that point Everton never looked back, though Walter Smith confessed he was confronting the possibility of a trip to St Andrews before Barmby auditioned for his equity card.

"Their goalkeeper was proving equal to everything we could throw at him and we began to think we might need to go to a replay," said Smith. "The way we improved in the second half was the most positive feature of the game for me."

fields.headline: Club business for Martin Bicknell
fields.standfirst: Each week we talk to a county pro about what he's doing in the close season. Surrey and former-England seamer Martin Bicknell is the latest to take the hotseat
fields.trailText: Martin Bicknell, who will be 31 on Friday, opens the bowling for Surrey. Last season he topped their wicket-taking list in the Championship with 71, and also scored 432 runs. He played two Tests for England, in 1993, and seven one-day internationals, in 1990-91
fields.body:
Martin Bicknell, who will be 31 on Friday, opens the bowling for Surrey. Last season he topped their wicket-taking list in the Championship with 71, and also scored 432 runs. He played two Tests for England, in 1993, and seven one-day internationals, in 1990-91

"I've been spending most of this winter setting up my own business, Martin Bicknell Golf. About 50% of the business is taken up with selling golf clubs to the general public, and 50% with providing branded clubs to businesses, football clubs, beneficiaries, that sort of thing. It is very exciting - golf is my second sport (I play with a handicap of five) and I've always wanted to get involved in it.

So far I've managed to get Sheffield Wednesday, Derby, Everton, West Ham and Liverpool football clubs on board plus a few businesses in London. And Adrian Aymes of Hampshire and Ian Austin of Lancashire are buying my clubs for their benefit seasons. I've had one golf day at The Oval for the public, and I'm having another one at George Abbot school in Guildford, on March 12, if anyone fancies coming along.

I'm working by myself at the moment but my aim is to get a cricketer from each county to set up their own franchise, much like I've done. I'm recruiting as I go along, though I don't know why Ð county cricketers are a very untrustworthy bunch.

I wasn't holding my breath for an England call-up - I don't do that any more. My England days are behind me. I think I've got about four more years in county cricket. Then I will have played 18 seasons so I'll be ready for something a bit different.

In previous seasons I've worked for the marketing department at Surrey, coached, gone abroad, set up my benefit; you never do the same thing two years running in cricket. Now I've got a little office at home, so I can spend a lot more time with my family, which is great - though I seem to spend much of that time being a taxi service for my daughters, who are five and three.

We haven't really had any set training with Surrey because most of our players are abroad Ð in Perth or Sydney. Ali Brown and I are about the only ones left. We all meet up again at the end of March and you're expected to be in a fit state, but most people are these days.

We had the normal round of parents and family over Christmas which was nice. (Nad Shahid was selling Christmas trees again but I didn't buy mine from him this year, because last year's one fell to pieces.) On New Year's Eve we got together with a big group of our old friends. It was a pretty big night.

It would be great to win the Championship again this year, and if everyone stays fit I think we stand a very good chance. My personal aims are always the same: to stay fit, play every game and take it from there. It will be weird to be without Darren [his elder brother, an opening batsman, who has just joined Nottinghamshire after 12 years with Surrey]. By a quirk of fate the first game we play against each other will be at Guildford, the club where we've played all our cricket. It will be quite a match."

Martin Bicknell was talking to Tanya Aldred
