fields.headline: Changing bugs beat flu vaccines
fields.standfirst: How mutating virus adapts to defeat nature and scienceMore about the NHS
fields.trailText: The greatest problem faced by doctors attempting to combat the flu virus is its ability to mutate to confound the body's immune system, making it almost impossible to predict what shape it will take each winter.
fields.body:
This year it is the Sydney strain carried, say some doctors, by Australian rugby fans visiting Britain for last year's World Cup, and responsible for the influenza epidemic that has exposed a shortage of NHS beds. Four months ago the medical profession was warning of a Hong Kong strain borne by pigs. Next year it could be Beijing B again.

The far-flung origins of these different strains and the diverse means by which they are transmitted illustrate the greatest problem faced by doctors attempting to combat the flu virus: its ability to mutate to confound the body's immune system make it almost impossible to predict what shape it will take each winter.

A nucleus of genetic material coated in protein, the virus has the ability to change its make-up to survive. While the body may have adapted an immune strategy to combat the flu that laid you low last winter, the chances are that come next winter the virus will have reinvented itself.

There is no cure for flu. The primary tool for reducing cases during the midwinter peak is vaccination - 9m jabs were given in Britain this winter. But flu's adaptability continually confounds vaccine manufacturers.

The flu cycle begins in the Far East, where the first cases of new strains are typically detected some six months before reaching Britain. In Hong Kong, Shanghai and other Far Eastern cities that have lent their name to outbreaks, densely populated areas with imperfect hygiene, where humans and animals live closely together, provide the breeding grounds for new strains.

As the virus passes from one species to another, from chicken or pig to human, it mutates, occasionally becoming lethal on a massive scale. In 1918 over 20m people died in a pandemic of "Spanish" flu, thought to have originated in China, while in 1957 Asian flu killed 9m. An outbreak in 1968 of Hong Kong flu affected over 1% of the British population.

Manufacturers begin developing new vaccines to combat the strains as soon as they are identified, and the first consignments of vaccine generally arrive in British GPs' surgeries in October. By the time the bug arrives, however, it may have changed its protein "coat" and defeat the vaccine.

Vaccination reduces the pressure on GPs' surgeries, and many buy the vaccine and administer it to patients for free, before being refunded by the NHS at a profit of around £1 per jab.

Laurence Buckman, of the British Medical Association's general practitioners' committee, said that despite the unpredicability of the virus, vaccination was the best course of action open to GPs and patients alike.

"The vaccines are not wonder cures ... but they do stop an awful lot of people going down with the virus," he said.

"I would recommend any old person, any child, anyone with bronchial complaints, asthma or other respiratory problems to have a vaccine."

The widespread nature of the present outbreak has less to do with the strength of the Sydney strain than the collective immunity of the population, said Dr Buckman.

"What is important is herd immunity," he said. "If the herd has a low immunity to a strain, and it occurs at a time that doctors and nurses get it to, then the virus will potentially affect millions."

A big problem faced by doctors attempting to prescribe effective treatment is that patients tend to bundle together a number of symptoms under the lay-heading flu, when in fact they may be suffering from other viruses.

"The term flu is misused regularly and in both directions. People say they have flu when they just have a common cold, and similarly I have had patients who have dismissed pneumonia or meningitis as flu," said Dr Buckman.

"Flu is rather distinct in its symptoms. The sufferer will have a dry cough, a high fever and muscular aches and pains. However, flu does not give you a runny nose and it doesn't give a sore throat ... Flu is a profound malaise, people feel truly awful - if you've genuinely had flu there is no danger of you mistaking it for a cold."

To get well...

Do:

Get vaccinated

Maintain a 'comfortable' temperature. You shouldn't be cold but overheating is as dangerous

Drink plenty of liquid. You're going to sweat a lot so replace the fluid

Take two paracetamol every four hours

Try to keep temperature under 102F. Take regular cool showers to stem the fever

Don't:

Go to work. Flu sufferers are unproductive and succeed only in giving the rest of the office the bug

Expect miracles. There is no cure for flu

webTitle: Bishop calls on Pope to retire

fields.headline: Bishop calls on Pope to retire
fields.trailText: A leading German bishop sparked outrage in Italy today by suggesting that the Pope should retire if his health deteriorates further.
fields.body:
A leading German bishop sparked outrage in Italy today by suggesting that the Pope should retire if his health deteriorates further.

Bishop Karl Lehmann, president of the German bishops conference, was speaking on the Cologne-based Deutschlandfunk radio station when he made the comments about John Paul II, who is believed to have Parkinson's disease.

"I have confidence in the Pope that when he feels he is no longer capable of leading the Church with responsibility, he will have the strength and the courage to say: 'I cannot fulfil this (charge) as is required'," he said.

Although his comments were heavily qualified, they were carried in big headlines in most Italian newspapers.

Bishop Lehmann's remarks are even more controversial because, while the Pope's critics inside the church have made such remarks in the past, it was the first time it came from a powerful figure in an important European bishops conference.

Popes usually reign for life. The last Pope to resign willingly was Celestine V, who stepped down in 1294. Gregory XII reluctantly abdicated in 1415 in order to resolve a dispute when there was more than one Pope reigning at the same time.

"It is naturally difficult to imagine such a situation. Nobody is used to the idea of a Pope stepping down. Nonetheless with Celestine V we have someone who has done that," Bishop Lehmann added.

He said that even if an incapacitated Pope tried to step down, his aides probably would try to resist the idea.

"But if the Pope wanted to do that (retire), I am not sure whether the climate is right, and whether all those that give advice would agree and think it better that he should step down. It is still a sensitive time for the church," he said.

The bishop noted that despite what is believed to be Parkinson's disease the Pope always displays an "unbelievable presence of mind" and there was no question at the moment that he was not fulfilling his Papal duties.

The 79-year-old Pope, elected in 1978, last dismissed suggestions that he should resign in 1995, when he turned 75, the age at which Roman Catholic bishops usually hand in their resignation.

"I renew before Christ my willingness to serve the Church as long as he wants, abandoning myself completely to his holy will. I leave to him to decide when and how he wants to relieve me of this service," the Pope said at the time.

Lehmann's words were met with incredulity in some Vatican quarters.

"No-one has the right to say that the Pope should step down for any reason," Cardinal Alfons Stickler, a Vatican-based Austrian, was quoted as saying in Monday's La Repubblica newspaper.

Italian Cardinal Ersilio Tonini told La Stampa newspaper: "I can't believe this, if it is true. I think the Pope is in full command of his functions. Above all, his mind is still totally free, totally unencumbered. The decisions still are all his."

According to Canon 332 of church law, a Pope can resign, but since he is supreme pontiff, no one has to accept the resignation.

The Canon reads: "If it should happen that the Roman Pontiff resigns his office, it is required for validity that he makes the resignation freely and that it be duly manifested, but not that it be accepted by anyone."

webTitle: Court to rule on boy's return to Cuba

fields.headline: Court to rule on boy's return to Cuba
fields.trailText: A US court is to decide this week whether intervention by a Republican politician should delay the return to Cuba of a six-year-old boy at the centre of an immigration row.
fields.body:
A US court is to decide this week whether intervention by a Republican politician should delay the return to Cuba of a six-year-old boy at the centre of an immigration row.

The intervention comes amid mounting political tension over the case, which began seven weeks ago when fishermen found Elian Gonzalez clinging to an inner tube off Florida. His mother and nine other refugees drowned when their boat capsized while trying to reach the US from Cuba.

Immigration officials have ruled that Elian should be returned to Cuba, where his father lives, by this Friday.

Juan Miguel Gonzalez has been lobbying for his son's return, but relatives in Miami insist he should stay in the US. Elian's great-uncle has filed a petition to be named his guardian.

The Republican congressman Dan Burton intervened on Friday when he filed a subpoena calling for Elian to testify before the US congress in February and delaying his repatriation until after then.

The move has cheered anti-Castro Cubans in Florida who have campaigned to keep the child in the US. On Saturday, Elian was paraded in front of cameras in Florida and was encouraged by relatives to offer the victory sign. The boy has also been the subject of mass protests in Cuba.

A poll in this week's Time magazine reveals 56% of Americans believe that Elian should be returned to his father, with 35% opposed to the move. The poll also suggests that anti-Castro feeling has waned in the US, with 53% of those polled supporting open diplomatic relations with Cuba, a marked rise over the past two years.

The magazine reveals that Mr Gonzalez, Elian's father, sold his car to help pay for the calls he is making to his son in Miami. He also easily passed two interviews with US immigration officials designed to test his intimacy with his son.

Bob Smith, a Republican member of the senate judiciary committee, which oversees immigration issues, met the boy's relatives on Friday and said that Elian wanted to stay in the US. He indicated that Elian's father may have wanted his son to come to America and is being prevented from saying so by Cuba's leader, Fidel Castro.

The US president, Bill Clinton, has backed the decision by the immigration department but presidential contenders have been more ambiguous.

fields.headline: Novelist Nigel Tranter dies
fields.trailText: Tributes are being paid to novelist and historian Nigel Tranter, who has died at the age of 90 at his home in Scotland. One of Britain's most prolific writers, he had more than 130 works published, mainly novels and historical works.
fields.body:
Tributes are being paid to novelist and historian Nigel Tranter, who has died at the age of 90 at his home in Scotland.

One of Britain's most prolific writers, he had more than 130 works published, mainly novels and historical works.

His family said he died peacefully at his home in Gullane, East Lothian. Among those who paid tribute was Mike Russell, SNP shadow minister for culture in the Scottish Parliament, who said: "Nigel Tranter was a story-teller of rare power, whose genius was his ability to excite new audiences with imaginative and detailed tales of Scotland's past.

"He brought Scottish history to life, and made it accessible to all."

Mr Tranter visited the Scottish Parliament for the first time in December, as a guest of SNP MSP Richard Lochhead.

"As a long-standing supporter of a Scottish Parliament, he was thrilled with developments in Scotland, and full of hope for the country's future," said Mr Russell.

"It is sad that he is no longer with us to witness them."

Born in Glasgow, Tranter was educated in Edinburgh, trained as an accountant, and worked for an Edinburgh insurance company until 1939 when he joined the Royal Artillery.

His first novel, Trespass, was published in 1937, and by the time he became a full-time writer in 1946 he already had 10 books to his name.

He had more than 100 novels published, some under the pen-name Nye Tredgold, and also wrote children's books and Westerns.

He described his earliest novels as "ordinary adventure and romance".

His biographer, Ray Bradfield, said today "He had a rare gift of imagination and a vivid visual imagination which lasted throughout his life.

"It is an extraordinary record. He wrote novels for 60 years and never suffered from writer's block.

"The reason he was so successful was he saw himself as a storyteller and entertainer, combined with a passionate love of country which he put at the service of the common people of Scotland."

webTitle: Russia's northern cities die as people leave

fields.headline: Russia's northern cities die as people leave
fields.standfirst:
With no more communist state perks for those living in harsh regions, workers are streaming away in search of jobs and warm weather

Russia: special report
fields.trailText: A gargantuan Soviet monument to the unknown soldier dominates the terraces of high-rise flats above the dockyards in Murmansk at the head of the Kola fiord - but his descendants have begun deserting Russia's frozen, far north.
fields.body:
A gargantuan Soviet monument to the unknown soldier dominates the terraces of high-rise flats above the dockyards in Murmansk at the head of the Kola fiord - but his descendants have begun deserting Russia's frozen, far north.

The largest city within the Arctic circle is emptying. The collapse of the communist command economy is dispersing the population south to warmer housing estates and better job opportunities. Some residents are slipping across the border into Scandinavia.

Founded in 1915, Murmansk is Russia's only year-round, ice-free port on the Barents sea. It survived Hitler's panzer divisions in the second world war and by the time Mikhail Gorbachev became the Soviet president in 1988 it was home to more than 500,000 people.

They were drawn in by the higher wages, longer holidays and lower pensionable age, granted for working in harsh conditions.

Since the fall of the Berlin wall in 1989, 100,000 people have gone, discouraged by the end of the privileges and the breakdown of municipal central heating systems.

Emigration, plus with spiralling rates of alcoholism, a falling birthrate and shorter life expectancy, are driving down Russia's population. In 1990 it stood at 148m. By October it was 145.7m.

With the nouveaux super-rich exporting their wealth to the safety of hard currency accounts in the west, there are few signs of investment for economic recovery in cities such as Murmansk. The private kiosks may be full of food but secondhand Volkswagens and Ford Sierras mingle with elderly Ladas, Trabants and Fiat Polskas on the roads. The average wage is only 1,000 roubles (£23) a month.

Prostitutes mill around near large hotels. The smell of incinerated oil hangs in the cold air.

"People used to receive all sorts of special benefits for working here," explains Otto Mamelund, Norway's consul-general, who deals with the rapid rise in visa applications. "In the past, people came to the Arctic for 10 or 15 years for the extra cash. Many of them are going now. Most consider themselves to be from somewhere else in Russia."

The trend is pronounced across Russia's north-west. The region's second city, Archangel, has seen its population bleed away to below 400,000. "After perestroika this place began to die," said one discouraged official. "Moscow is a separate country." In nearby Severodvinsk, where the Soviet Union built most of its nuclear submarines, the number of inhabitants has dropped from 270,000 in 1990 to an estimated 200,000 this year.

Archangel was built on the principle of state intervention. Peter the Great decreed it should be a naval base. The canals linking the city to St Petersburg in the south were built by slave labour in Stalin's days. Memories of state oppression linger. A tower block looms over the surrounding buildings and a local joke asks: What is the tallest building in Archangel? The three-storey courthouse, the answer goes - because from there you get to see Siberia.

While most Russians head south, to Moscow or villages in central Russia warm enough for them to augment low wages with freshly grown food, many seek work in the west. Ten years ago the border between the Norwegian town of Kirkenes and Russia was a cold-war frontier where Nato faced the might of the Soviet Union across a sterile military zone. This year 100,000 people are expected to cross.

The prosperity of Norway, the world's second largest exporter of oil after Saudi Arabia, gleams like a welcoming beacon for those trapped in a bankrupt Russia. Local Norwegian women, traditionally less enamoured than their menfolk with the rigours of Arctic life, with its six weeks of total darkness every winter, have been leaving for Oslo. Russian women have provided replacements, boosting the number of mixed nationality marriages in Finnmark, Norway's most northerly province.

But the opening of the border has prompted Norway to step up customs inspections and military patrols to counter illegal immigration, alcohol smuggling and prostitution.

"Prisoners in Norway are paid a small, weekly allowance," explains one Norwegian official. "That sum is double the industrial wage paid in Russia. People are coming across the border and if they get caught committing a crime they know they will be jailed somewhere safe and warm - and get paid for it. It's a great deal."

fields.headline: Fighting the soggy centre
fields.standfirst: Proportional representation: special report
fields.trailText: The close connection is obvious and undeniable. Most Labour enthusiasts for what they impertinently call "electoral reform" support the introduction of proportional representation because they know that it would lead - irrevocably and unavoidably - to coalition government. No other outcome is possible. The interesting question is whether the proponents of PR welcome that result or accept it as a regrettable necessity. "Fair votes" - another arrogant attempt to end the argument before it begins - would certainly give the Liberal party a share of power. For Labour it would only mean the loss of what remains of its socialist identity.
fields.body:
The close connection is obvious and undeniable. Most Labour enthusiasts for what they impertinently call "electoral reform" support the introduction of proportional representation because they know that it would lead - irrevocably and unavoidably - to coalition government. No other outcome is possible. The interesting question is whether the proponents of PR welcome that result or accept it as a regrettable necessity. "Fair votes" - another arrogant attempt to end the argument before it begins - would certainly give the Liberal party a share of power. For Labour it would only mean the loss of what remains of its socialist identity.

I cite, in support of my warning, a letter written last week to the Guardian by the admirable Oona King, member of parliament for Bow and Bethnal Green. Electoral reform, she wrote, "will benefit the Labour party... The current system allowed the Conservatives to dominate the 20th century". How does Ms King imagine proportional representation would have broken that stranglehold?

It would not have produced majority Labour governments. Indeed full-blown PR would have left Labour in a minority after both the 1945 and 1997 election landslides. Clement Attlee would have governed courtesy of Archibald Sinclair, Tony Blair by grace of Paddy Ashdown.

We know that the prime minister would welcome a marriage of the two true centrist minds - the patrol leaders of politics united in the same Scout troop. But does Ms King think that Clement Davies, Jo Grimond or Jeremy Thorpe would have promoted progress towards the sort of society she wants to see? My abiding memory of Mr Thorpe - apart from his wit and charm - is a speech in defence of stag hunting.

The one ideological justification for PR is the courage and confidence it might give to a genuinely radical but pathologically timorous Labour leader. If the 1997 parliament had been elected by proportional representation, Tony Blair (the argument runs) would have begun the campaign confident of leading the largest party in the subsequent coalition. In consequence he would not have thought it necessary to leap so far to the right.

Whatever else Tony Blair may be, timorous he is not. Nor does he lack principle. He leapt to the right because the middle ground of politics is where he wants to be. What is called "fair votes" - the meaningless insistence that democracy requires the House of Commons to be an arithmetical reflection of national voting patterns - would keep Labour in the soggy centre for ever.

That is not what Labour's grassroots want. Nor do they believe that it is the inevitable consequence of New Labour's modernisation.

In the long term, their optimism can still be justified. In the short run, it is important for socialists not to lose their nerve. Ten years ago, Labour opposition to coalition was based on the belief that Liberals would act as a sheet anchor, holding back a genuinely democratic socialist government from the creation of a more equal society. Now (despite Charles Kennedy's disavowal of any ambition to outflank Labour on the left) much of his programme is significantly more radical than the government's alternative. The Liberal's education policy is what Labour policy ought to be. Its proposals for freedom of information are what Labour proposals once were.

Last week on radio, Bill Rodgers, the Liberal Democrat leader in the House of Lords, expressed his general sympathy with the aims of Tony Blair's project, but - to my shame and embarrassment - regretted that under New Labour, the gap between rich and poor was widening. Bill Rodgers remains true to his Labour roots. I doubt if the Liberals of Bath and Newbury - with parliamentary victories to their credit - share his views on the overwhelming need to help the urban poor.

The temporary radicalism of a party which has been elbowed out of the middle ground is certainly no reason for abandoning New Labour - a point I make each week to the dozen or so Labour party members who write to me about their despair and disenchantment.

Because of the real but subdued beliefs of the constituency parties, Labour remains the best chance there is of building a more equal society in Britain. But socialists who still cling to that belief have to fight for its resurrection.

This year we mount no more than a rearguard action. But at least we can - and it seems we will - prevent the institutional change which would extinguish all hope of a democratic socialist government ever being elected.

webTitle: We're just lousy organisers, however much we spend

fields.headline: We're just lousy organisers, however much we spend
fields.standfirst: The Dome, the health service, machine guns in Kosovo - all go wrongThe Millennium: special report
fields.trailText: The most relevant thing about the Dome, these past 10 days, has nothing to do with going there. It is, rather, a text on what money can - and can't - buy.
fields.body:
This is not, you may be relieved to learn, another of those articles in which Our Hero ruptures a tendon at Stratford station, catches flu whilst queuing for five hours and thereupon succumbs to a heart attack in the body zone. No: the most relevant thing about the Dome, these past 10 days, has nothing to do with going there. It is, rather, a text on what money can - and can't - buy.

We all know, because regularly so informed, that the NHS is on its knees again for lack of cash. Lack of nurses, lack of beds. The ruptured tendon will take weeks to treat. The flu epidemic brings the service itself close to collapse. The heart attack victim will die somewhere in an ambulance looking for intensive care. Only more money can bandage the wounds.

We also know that Britain's troops in Kosovo had light support weapons which did not fire, radios that kept breaking down and a command and control system so "confused and fractured" that our boys would have been in the soup if the Serbs had wanted to make a fight of it. More money, please. Cut out the cuts.

The litany - from schools to railway signalling to urban regeneration - is constant. Very little works as it should because we choose to spend too little on it. The root of most modern evil is governmental parsimony. The magic formula for success is billions extra. Right? Now let's get back to the Dome.

Many unpleasing analyses have been written about it already, with assorted theses bearing blame. But, whether for prosecution or defence, no one has so far sung the otherwise universal British anthem. No one has said £750m wasn't enough and that maybe another £250m would have made all the difference.

That unique lack of pleading, moreover, touches every aspect of the debacle. No one has claimed there weren't enough staff sending out opening night tickets (merely that they forgot about the Christmas post). No one has claimed that there weren't enough police on duty (merely that the Met's serried legions got in the way).

The alleged culprits, in short, aren't the usual suspects. They are disorganisation, profligacy, botched planning and absence of imagination/flair/creativity/vision. Debate, in its potty way, revolves around whether Jennie Page should get her bonus a year hence. She had every resource apart from unlimited time. Could she have done better?

But start asking such questions, even in a narrow Greenwich context, and they spread wider of their own malign accord. Was it really lack of money which left the Kosovo battalions too remote from KFor headquarters? Of course not. It was people who couldn't get organised, who didn't communicate. Was it really MoD policy to buy cheap machine guns which jammed too easily? Of course not. We paid full whack in true Whitehall fashion, but the kit we bought - like some Dome exhibits - wasn't up to mechanical snuff.

And don't forget, of course, to ask yourself the question behind the question. How on earth did two such secret and damaging military inquests come to land last week on a BBC reporter's desk rather than atop the secretary of state's in-tray? Where are the accustomed rituals of ministerial denunciation and leak inquiries? What's the message behind the message? No prizes there. The treasury knows the game all too well. Crisis, real or confected, opens closed purses. Give them the money, Gordie.

Nobody, by contrast, could remotely argue that enough cash pours into the national health service. We spend £946 per head per year on health, around £650 less than most of our European neighbours - and £1,500 less than America. Whether those shortfalls need making good by taxation or insurance doesn't matter here. They are too gaping for comfort. But the same old background questions do matter.

Take intensive care beds. There will never be enough - whatever the spend - to deal with every conceivable regional emergency. Nor will every hospital be able to deliver the same level of medical expertise. Moving some patients between hospitals, therefore, has to be part of any system, coordinated nationally: and thus, at once, we are back to talking Kosovo-style control operations again.

Will real availability, for instance, be faithfully notified? It isn't always so at the moment. Hospitals with tired nurses and doctors and unpredictable local demand aren't invariably going to put their hands up to take a patient from 70 miles away when (apart from anything else) the costs of caring for that transferred case have to come from their own budgets. They work harder and they lose out as a result. The system doesn't fit with natural human instincts: and a related, deeply ingrained instinct, of course, is to win more money generally. Crisis rings treasury bells.

Cash, in sum, is part of the answer: but it isn't the only answer. The lesson of the Dome is that you need much, much more than that. Cash won't tell some random copper that the man he's stopped driving along in his car is Stephen Lawrence's dad and due care needs to be exercised. Cash won't stop every train driver from dozing in his cab. Cash won't hand the BBC a glowing digital future. Cash didn't make the millennium wheel turn on time. Cash won't exalt Covent Garden. Cash may have "saved" us from the Y2K bug - but its almost total absence does not seem to have brought Ukraine to its knees.

The true horror story of the turning century, as happens, runs straight to Greenwich's door. When the prospective Jubilee Line was costed 10 years ago, it looked like a £900m touch. When it was started in October 1993, that had swelled to £1.9bn. The current closing cost - years late and still struggling for completion around Westminster - is £3.3bn.

That is £330m per mile of track. More expensive than the Channel tunnel at £320m a mile. Hugely more expensive than the new line 14 on the Paris Metro: £120m a mile. And the bitter query of the enterprise's struggling mastermind, Roland Paoletti, has stayed in my notebook over the years. Why is it that, in Britain, "civil engineering projects will always come in behind time and over budget?"

Getting the money is only the start. It is what you do with it which counts - and we are, on our record, pretty lousy at that. No wonder Mr Blair and Lord Falconer were originally loud in Jennie Page's praises. She delivered, managerially, on time and on budget. She just didn't happen to deliver much showbusiness - more the kind of Cliff Richard musical the critics love to hate - but she might be a wow on London Underground.

Then we could all fall silent for a time, snuffle off to bed with a packet of paracetamol, and add a few ends to our means.

Many unpleasing analyses have been written about it already, with assorted theses bearing blame. But, whether for prosecution or defence, no one has so far sung the otherwise universal British anthem. No one has said £750m wasn't enough and that maybe another £250m would have made all the difference. That unique lack of pleading, moreover, touches every aspect of the debacle. No one has claimed there weren't enough staff sending out opening night tickets (merely that they forgot about the Christmas post). No one has claimed that there weren't enough police on duty (merely that the Met's serried legions got in the way). The alleged culprits, in short, aren't the usual suspects. They are disorganisation, profligacy, botched planning and absence of imagination/flair/creativity/vision. Debate, in its potty way, revolves around whether Jennie Page should get her bonus a year hence. She had every resource apart from unlimited time. Could she have done better? But start asking such questions, even in a narrow Greenwich context, and they spread wider of their own malign accord. Was it really lack of money which left the Kosovo battalions too remote from KFor headquarters? Of course not. It was people who couldn't get organised, who didn't communicate. Was it really MoD policy to buy cheap machine guns which jammed too easily? Of course not. We paid full whack in true Whitehall fashion, but the kit we bought - like some Dome exhibits - wasn't up to mechanical snuff. And don't forget, of course, to ask yourself the question behind the question. How on earth did two such secret and damaging military inquests come to land last week on a BBC reporter's desk rather than atop the secretary of state's in-tray? Where are the accustomed rituals of ministerial denunciation and leak inquiries? What's the message behind the message? No prizes there. The treasury knows the game all too well. Crisis, real or confected, opens closed purses. Give them the money, Gordie. Nobody, by contrast, could remotely argue that enough cash pours into the national health service. We spend £946 per head per year on health, around £650 less than most of our European neighbours - and £1,500 less than America. Whether those shortfalls need making good by taxation or insurance doesn't matter here. They are too gaping for comfort. But the same old background questions do matter. Take intensive care beds. There will never be enough - whatever the spend - to deal with every conceivable regional emergency. Nor will every hospital be able to deliver the same level of medical expertise. Moving some patients between hospitals, therefore, has to be part of any system, coordinated nationally: and thus, at once, we are back to talking Kosovo-style control operations again. Will real availability, for instance, be faithfully notified? It isn't always so at the moment. Hospitals with tired nurses and doctors and unpredictable local demand aren't invariably going to put their hands up to take a patient from 70 miles away when (apart from anything else) the costs of caring for that transferred case have to come from their own budgets. They work harder and they lose out as a result. The system doesn't fit with natural human instincts: and a related, deeply ingrained instinct, of course, is to win more money generally. Crisis rings treasury bells. Cash, in sum, is part of the answer: but it isn't the only answer. The lesson of the Dome is that you need much, much more than that. Cash won't tell some random copper that the man he's stopped driving along in his car is Stephen Lawrence's dad and due care needs to be exercised. Cash won't stop every train driver from dozing in his cab. Cash won't hand the BBC a glowing digital future. Cash didn't make the millennium wheel turn on time. Cash won't exalt Covent Garden. Cash may have "saved" us from the Y2K bug - but its almost total absence does not seem to have brought Ukraine to its knees. The true horror story of the turning century, as happens, runs straight to Greenwich's door. When the prospective Jubilee Line was costed 10 years ago, it looked like a £900m touch. When it was started in October 1993, that had swelled to £1.9bn. The current closing cost - years late and still struggling for completion around Westminster - is £3.3bn. That is £330m per mile of track. More expensive than the Channel tunnel at £320m a mile. Hugely more expensive than the new line 14 on the Paris Metro: £120m a mile. And the bitter query of the enterprise's struggling mastermind, Roland Paoletti, has stayed in my notebook over the years. Why is it that, in Britain, "civil engineering projects will always come in behind time and over budget?" Getting the money is only the start. It is what you do with it which counts - and we are, on our record, pretty lousy at that. No wonder Mr Blair and Lord Falconer were originally loud in Jennie Page's praises. She delivered, managerially, on time and on budget. She just didn't happen to deliver much showbusiness - more the kind of Cliff Richard musical the critics love to hate - but she might be a wow on London Underground. Then we could all fall silent for a time, snuffle off to bed with a packet of paracetamol, and add a few ends to our means.

fields.headline: The politics of the Dome
fields.standfirst:
Some on the right would like it to fail

The Millennium: special report
fields.trailText: Some people think it is wonderful; some think it a waste of money and time. Simon Hoggart and family (Saturday's Guardian) voted their day at the dome a big success. Polly Toynbee (Wednesday's Guardian), though once a fan of the project, now calls it a lemon. Clearly the Greenwich experience is not the thumping world-class achievement that government propagandists, distorting prisms clamped to their eyes, are inviting us to believe.
fields.body:
Some people think it is wonderful; some think it a waste of money and time. Simon Hoggart and family (Saturday's Guardian) voted their day at the dome a big success. Polly Toynbee (Wednesday's Guardian), though once a fan of the project, now calls it a lemon. Clearly the Greenwich experience is not the thumping world-class achievement that government propagandists, distorting prisms clamped to their eyes, are inviting us to believe.

But neither is it the 100% certified fiasco now being acclaimed on the political right. "Sponsors are appalled by dome chaos"; "Dome tickets flop forces big relaunch", the Telegraph proudly proclaims on successive days on page one. On inside pages, columnists get to work. "The orphan dome, the Oliver Twist of architectural disasters, will go down in posterity as one of the great bad jokes of British history, along with King Canute's failure to halt the tide, King John's loss of his baggage in the Wash, and the South Sea bubble", burbles one overwrought soul in the Daily Mail. Two pages later, another writes of a "criminal" waste of resources. Yesterday, a fresh allegation emerged: the cash to meet the looming shortfall, up to £23m, will be snatched from lottery money which would otherwise go to charities and other good causes.

There is a hidden agenda here, of which those tempted to credit this kind of analysis ought to be made aware. The troubles with the Dome, the failures in organisation, the unhappiness of the sponsors, the fact that some of the punters are coming away disappointed, has come as a heaven-sent chance for the right, at a time when such chances are rare, to get back at all-conquering Labour. Persuade people, not just that this enterprise is a fiasco, but that is also somehow emblematic of the whole New Labour approach, and you might just begin to roll back some of that huge Labour lead which threatens an even bigger Blair majority in May 2001 or whenever. But what makes it even more juicy is the second dimension to this attack. If the Dome becomes established as a disaster, the blame will fall not only on Tony Blair and specifically on his first "dome secretary", Peter Mandelson, but on someone the Tory right tends to regard with even more venomous loathing: the great Europhile and assassin of Margaret Thatcher, Michael Heseltine. One could note on Saturday morning how the two columnists of the Mail carefully bracketed Messrs Mandelson and Heseltine together as what one of them called "the Dome's putative fathers". "This monument to his vanity," said the other of Mr Heseltine, "is the last entry on his list of failures, and just about the biggest." A Times leader made the same telling conjunction, nailing Mr Heseltine as the project's "prime progenitor", "a long-time giganticist whose interest in size for its own sake was the hallmark of his career."

The special joy of their campaign is that it may become self-fulfilling: by trumpeting it as a recognised fiasco from which the public is staying away, it is much more likely the project will fail. The certainty with which they condemn it seems all the more bogus in the light of a poll of more than 1,000 visitors to the Dome carried out (in circumstances inadequately specified) by the Sunday Times. Asked "Did you enjoy it?" 85% said they did. Was it good value for money? 62% said that it was. Would you recommend it to friends? 74% said they would. That hardly makes it a triumph, but it does underline how much of the rightwing comment now proceeds from political calculation, and malevolent and unscrupulous calculation at that.

fields.headline: Fairer fares
fields.standfirst:
Inner city transport is a political hot potato. Cutting fares may have worked in the past, but congestion charges are much more important

Transport in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Today London Transport's average fares go up by 1.5%, the 16th successive year of above-inflation increases, albeit the smallest rise since 1984. Then, of course, fares were the responsibility of the Greater London Council (GLC) led by one Ken Livingstone. The would-be mayor's time is remembered for Fares Fair: in October 1981, the GLC cut fares across the board by 31%. This was paid for by a supplementary rate, extra tax on London homes and businesses. The policy has entered leftwing mythology as an example of popular socialism. But how successful was it? The answer is relevant to getting around in all conurbations but has special resonance in the race for London mayor.
fields.body:
Today London Transport's average fares go up by 1.5%, the 16th successive year of above-inflation increases, albeit the smallest rise since 1984. Then, of course, fares were the responsibility of the Greater London Council (GLC) led by one Ken Livingstone. The would-be mayor's time is remembered for Fares Fair: in October 1981, the GLC cut fares across the board by 31%. This was paid for by a supplementary rate, extra tax on London homes and businesses. The policy has entered leftwing mythology as an example of popular socialism. But how successful was it? The answer is relevant to getting around in all conurbations but has special resonance in the race for London mayor.

Fare reductions were short-lived. In December 1981, the policy was ruled illegal. Tory-controlled Bromley challenged the policy on the grounds that it was unfair to residents of the outer London borough who paid rates but did not benefit from the tube fare cuts - there are no underground stations in Beckenham. But the law lords went a step further and ruled that the GLC had been acting beyond its powers in subsidising fares at all.

As a result, in March 1982 fares were doubled. High fares continued for a year until, after a friendly high court action between London Transport (LT) and the GLC, a legal way was found to cut fares again. A new package was introduced in May 1983, cutting fares by 23%. This left average bus fares about 10% lower in real terms and tube fares 20% lower than they had been in October 1980.

Traffic levels and public transport use were monitored throughout. When fares were cut, bus and tube use increased and car commuting decreased. When fares were raised, these trends were reversed. Following the final May 1983 package, bus and tube use increased by 11% and car commuting to central London decreased by 9%. Travel zones and the Travelcard, a ticket valid on both buses and tube, were also introduced at this time.

An analysis by LT suggested that the benefits of the scheme outweighed the costs by more than two to one, with much of the passenger increase attributed to fares simplification. The cityscape has, of course, changed. In 1984, the Tory government took control of LT and the GLC was abolished in 1986. Fares have increased in real terms by nearly 50%. Traffic congestion has got worse and public transport use has increased.

What would be the impact of a general cut in fares today? We used a model developed for the department of transport and it suggests an across-the-board reduction in the style of Livingstone's Fares Fair would not provide good value for money. This is because there is little spare capacity on the tube. To reduce fares by 25% would cost £300m a year; tube use would increase by only about 5% as a result. It is on the buses that a fares cut would work - it would be better targeted and help people on low incomes, who use buses the most.

But there has to be a lot more to effective transport policy than fares. Providing priority bus routes, enforcing them and putting on additional bus services would yield high dividends. An ambitious network of routes where buses came first, combined with extra services, could increase bus use in London by as much as 18%, without requiring the mayor to budget for extra subsidies. We estimate that journey-time savings to transport users from this package would be worth over £200m a year.

The capital costs of completing the London bus priority network and installing cameras on buses for enforcement purposes have been estimated at £60m. These are modest in comparison with the potential benefits. The revenue costs of an effective enforcement programme have been estimated at £20m a year. Enforcement could be self-financing from the penalty charges for bus lane infringements.

An independent study of congestion charging in London shows that a scheme based on a £5-a-day charge for cars in central London would cut traffic by about 10% and raise about £250m a year. We used the model to evaluate the impact of congestion charging combined with the bus improvements described above, plus a cut in bus fares and extra bus services. This could increase bus use by nearly 40%, help to cut traffic congestion and relieve crowding on the tube, at a subsidy cost to the mayor of about £80m a year.

That would leave money over from the congestion charges. Some two thirds of the revenue would be available for free travel for children under 16 (cost £30m a year) and capital investment projects. In London, pensioners already travel free. The net benefits of this package to transport users in London would be worth about £500m a year, including journey-time savings and the revenue from congestion charging.

The key is charging motorists for congesting central London: money generated from charges would allow a mayor to introduce free travel for children, a 70p flat bus fare and to freeze tube fares. But the package also depends on a network of priority bus routes. Remaining revenue from congestion charging could provide extra bus services and capital investment in new tube lines.

 Tony Grayling is a transport specialist at the Institute for Public Policy Research. A new fares contract for London, written by Grayling and Stephen Glaister, is available from Central Books (0181-986 5488)

fields.headline: Chechens launch counter-attack
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: Chechen guerrilla forces, growing bolder as the savage Russian campaign in the north Caucasus stalls, counter-attacked on several fronts at the weekend while Moscow's political and military leadership appeared confused.
fields.body:
Chechen guerrilla forces, growing bolder as the savage Russian campaign in the north Caucasus stalls, counter-attacked on several fronts at the weekend while Moscow's political and military leadership appeared confused.

After Moscow ordered an abrupt suspension of its offensive to capture Grozny, the Chechen capital, and fired two of its most senior commanders, Chechen rebels staged counter-attacks in and around Grozny, ambushed Russian checkpoints further south, and claimed to have retaken a town and village from the Russians.

The Russian consensus behind the war, meanwhile, showed signs of eroding amid mounting Russian casualties and questioning of Moscow's tactics and strategy.

In two northern districts of Grozny which the Russians said they controlled last week, the city's defenders struck back, sparking fierce fighting and causing the Russians to call in air support from helicopter gunships.

Fifteen miles to the south, outside the village of Shali, the Russians confirmed losing at least two men in an attack on a checkpoint. The Itar-Tass news agency said that Chechen gunmen drove a bus to the checkpoint and when Russian interior ministry troops asked to see documents, the Chechens opened fire.

A four-hour gun battle ensued during which two Russians were killed and one wounded.

NTV, Russia's largest private television station, reported yesterday that the Chechens had retaken Shali. The station played a key role in turning public opinion against the last Chechen war in 1994-96 and is slowly becoming more critical this time.

Movladi Udugov, a Chechen spokesman, said battles were raging at Shali after the rebels launched an attempt to recapture it. He claimed the town of Argun and the village of Mersky-Yurt a few miles east of Grozny had also been recaptured by the Chechens.

Through the past two weeks of Russia's ground assault on Grozny, the Russians have been seeking to pin the guerrilla fighters down and pen them in the city centre. The weekend developments suggested this had failed and that Chechen forces were breaking out of the city to launch counter-attacks.

The last few days have also seen the rebels stage ambushes and counter-attacks behind the Russian lines at Gudermes, Chechnya's second biggest city, and at Chervlennaya north of the capital.

The Russians said they were using the suspension of the air and artillery assault on Grozny to regroup under new commanders. The Russians said they had surrounded the southern mountain town of Vedeno, a rebel stronghold, and that officers were seeking to negotiate the town's surrender.

Moscow media speculated that the Russians might be preparing an even bigger assault on the battered capital where some 20,000 civilians, many of them elderly Russians, are at their wits' end after four months of bombardment.

Some Russian media which have hitherto supported the war and the hawkish line of the acting president, Vladimir Putin, are beginning to undermine official confidence by highlighting the funerals of dead soldiers, and interviewing combatants who make two points unwelcome to the government and military leadership: that the war will not be over quickly and that the Russian casualties are inexorably mounting.

Anatoly Kulikov, a former Russian interior minister who was one of the commanders in the 1994-96 war, predicted a long slog despite repeated official claims that the war will be over quickly.

While the government continued to insist that the two generals commanding the eastern and western fronts were removed as a matter of routine "rotation" in order to give other officers the chance to show their mettle in battle, Mr Kulikov said: "When you're talking of a decisive stage, you don't change the leadership."

fields.headline: Dome cash crisis 'utter nonsense'
fields.standfirst: The Millennium: special report
fields.trailText: The organisers of the Millennium Dome yesterday denied that it is facing a massive financial shortfall which could force them to seek funds from the treasury unless visitor numbers improve dramatically.
fields.body:
The organisers of the Millennium Dome yesterday denied that it is facing a massive financial shortfall which could force them to seek funds from the treasury unless visitor numbers improve dramatically.

Amid renewed attacks on its running of the dome, the New Millennium Experience Company dismissed as "utter nonsense" reports that it will be forced to ask for taxpayers' money or to remain open for an extra eight months to attract enough visitors to break even.

It is due to close at the end of December, although there is an option to remain open for an extra month if there is substantial public demand.

But the company refused to rule out the option of seeking extra funding from the National Lottery if more cash is required during the year.

As the campaign to turn around the attraction's beleaguered image took on a new intensity, Peter Mandelson accused the press of a vendetta against the £758m project in Greenwich, south-east London.

With little sign of a warming in the organisers' relationship with newspaper editors, Mr Mandelson, formerly the minister responsible for the dome, said: "If this is because they and other opinion-formers were unfortunately inconvenienced in travelling to the dome on opening night, this is not just high-handed but a misuse of their position. I think we are getting two quite distinct judgments: one from the public and the other from a section of the media who want to see the dome fail."

The organisers' business plan sets a target of 12m visitors by the end of the year, the equivalent of 33,000 a day. But the dome would reach its break-even figure of £184m revenue with 8.8m visitors, or 24,000 a day.

Attendance figures are due to be released at the end of the month, but reports yesterday claimed that the numbers so far have averaged around 10,000 a day.

If that remained the average for the year, the organisers would be left with a £113m hole in their finances.

But Gez Sagar, the dome's spokesman, insisted the organisers were confident that the 12m target would be reached and there would be no financial shortfall. Both visitor numbers and income during the first week were well ahead of the business plan's forecasts, he said.

"We are first and foremost a tourist attraction and that means our attendance figures will follow the rest of the UK leisure industry, with January and February the slower months. But in the summer we expect to be getting up to 55,000 visitors a day."

Amid renewed attacks on its running of the dome, the New Millennium Experience Company dismissed as "utter nonsense" reports that it will be forced to ask for taxpayers' money or to remain open for an extra eight months to attract enough visitors to break even. It is due to close at the end of December, although there is an option to remain open for an extra month if there is substantial public demand. But the company refused to rule out the option of seeking extra funding from the National Lottery if more cash is required during the year. As the campaign to turn around the attraction's beleaguered image took on a new intensity, Peter Mandelson accused the press of a vendetta against the £758m project in Greenwich, south-east London. With little sign of a warming in the organisers' relationship with newspaper editors, Mr Mandelson, formerly the minister responsible for the dome, said: "If this is because they and other opinion-formers were unfortunately inconvenienced in travelling to the dome on opening night, this is not just high-handed but a misuse of their position. I think we are getting two quite distinct judgments: one from the public and the other from a section of the media who want to see the dome fail." The organisers' business plan sets a target of 12m visitors by the end of the year, the equivalent of 33,000 a day. But the dome would reach its break-even figure of £184m revenue with 8.8m visitors, or 24,000 a day. Attendance figures are due to be released at the end of the month, but reports yesterday claimed that the numbers so far have averaged around 10,000 a day. If that remained the average for the year, the organisers would be left with a £113m hole in their finances. But Gez Sagar, the dome's spokesman, insisted the organisers were confident that the 12m target would be reached and there would be no financial shortfall. Both visitor numbers and income during the first week were well ahead of the business plan's forecasts, he said. "We are first and foremost a tourist attraction and that means our attendance figures will follow the rest of the UK leisure industry, with January and February the slower months. But in the summer we expect to be getting up to 55,000 visitors a day."

fields.headline: Fury over rail crash 'immunity'
fields.standfirst: Paddington disaster firms set to escape prosecutionPaddington train crash: special report
fields.trailText: Police conducting the criminal investigation into the Paddington rail crash yesterday said there was virtually no chance of anyone ever standing trial in connection with the disaster.
fields.body:
Police conducting the criminal investigation into the Paddington rail crash yesterday said there was virtually no chance of anyone ever standing trial in connection with the disaster.

Officers say that the attorney general's decision to offer immunity to all evidence presented to a public inquiry means that rail company bosses - if suspected of corporate manslaughter - could be free from prosecution.

The immunity undertaking is so wide that it means that there is almost certain to be no documents left that could be used to support a case.

Louise Christian, a solicitor representing eight of the bereaved families, accused the government of taking a political decision to block prosecutions. She said there could be a legal challenge to narrow the scope of the immunity.

British transport police launched an investigation after the crash which killed 31 people and injured 250 in October last year. Two trains crashed close to Paddington station in London after one ploughed through a partially obscured red danger signal.

Officers were searching for evidence to bring a charge of manslaughter against the companies involved or individual employees.

Such a case would rely heavily on internal documents from any company charged, but they would be covered by immunity if presented to the inquiry by the firm concerned.

Within the last week officers have been in talks with the director of public prosecutions, David Calvert-Smith, over the impact of the immunity granted by Lord Williams, the attorney general.

Railtrack and the two train companies, Great Western and Thames, face the possibility of charges. The Guardian has also learned that the health and safety executive is also under criminal investigation.

Superintendent Tony Thompson of British transport police said: "If certain key documents aren't admissible, it tears the heart out of any potential prosecution."

He added: "A lot of the stuff we will be relying on for a prosecution is going to be looked at by the inquiry. Once it's admitted and subject to immunity, there is virtually nothing left to base a case on."

Lord Cullen, chairman of the public inquiry, asked for the immunity to help establish the full truth.

To speed up his delivery of recommendations on rail safety, Lord Cullen's inquiry will start even if decisions over prosecutions have not been made, also raising the risk that a prosecution could founder because of prejudicial material emerging at the inquiry.

Robin Kellow, who lost his daughter Elaine, 24, in the crash, said: "It's an utter disgrace. People who do wrong should be punished. In this case there is absolutely no doubt that criminal acts were done. Nobody takes a blind bit of notice of what happens. A criminal prosecution makes them stand up and be shown to have done wrong.

Louise Christian said: "This means there has been a decision by the government not to prosecute and that is very disturbing. On something as political as the railways and the crash, the decision to prosecute or not should be taken by a wholly independent prosecuting authority and not the government."

A spokesman for the attorney general said: "The logical conclusion is that an internal document admitted can't be used against an individual or an organisation [admitting it] unless there is another copy with another organisation.

"Any evidence people give will not be used against them."

webTitle: Freed cleric calls for holy war in Kashmir

fields.headline: Freed cleric calls for holy war in Kashmir
fields.standfirst:
More about the Indian Airlines hijacking
The India-Pakistan conflict: special report
fields.trailText: A Pakistani Muslim cleric released last month by India in return for hostages on a hijacked plane threatened yesterday to recruit half a million men to fight a holy war against Indian rule in the disputed territory of Kashmir.
fields.body:
A Pakistani Muslim cleric released last month by India in return for hostages on a hijacked plane threatened yesterday to recruit half a million men to fight a holy war against Indian rule in the disputed territory of Kashmir.

"We are going to organise a 500,000 [strong] mojahedin force to fight against the Indians," Mohammed Massoud Azhar told thousands during an address in Bhawalpur, Punjab province. He said the force would be recruited from all over Pakistan, but gave no details.

Last week, in an address outside a mosque in a Karachi suburb, Mr Azhar called for a holy war in Kashmir. He has denied reports of his Karachi speech that quoted him calling for aggression against the US.

Mr Azhar was freed from an Indian jail along with two other militants on December 31 and traded for 155 hostages held on a hijacked Indian Airlines plane.

Relations between India and Pakistan, which fought over Kashmir this summer, have deteriorated since the hijacking, with India accusing Pakistan of being involved in the drama which began on Christmas Eve when the plane was hijacked on its way to New Delhi from the Nepal. Pakistan has denied any involvement.

Another of the freed militants, Mushtaq Ahmed Zargar, a Kashmiri, is said to have returned to Pakistan-controlled Kashmir but has not been seen. The third, Syed Ahmed Sheikh, who holds a British passport, is thought to be in Pakistan. The whereabouts of the five hijackers is not known.

webTitle: Universal man must take responsibility for slaying Beveridge's five giants

fields.headline: Universal man must take responsibility for slaying Beveridge's five giants
fields.standfirst: The Millennium Bug: special report
fields.trailText: On the dot of midnight, as 1999 became 2000, all sorts of bad things were supposed to happen. Computers would malfunction, planes would fall out of the sky and cities would be plunged into darkness. None did. The first few days of the new century - if such it is - have all been about grappling with older and rather more tangible problems, such as finding hospital beds for intensive care patients and enough staff to treat them.
fields.body:
On the dot of midnight, as 1999 became 2000, all sorts of bad things were supposed to happen. Computers would malfunction, planes would fall out of the sky and cities would be plunged into darkness. None did. The millennium bug didn't bite, and the first few days of the new century - if such it is - have all been about grappling with older and rather more tangible problems, such as finding hospital beds for intensive care patients and enough staff to treat them.

This is salutary lesson about getting too hung up about arbitrary dates. When you get down to it, the task of politicians has changed very little since Beveridge said there were five giants barring the way to a better world, and named them want, idleness, ignorance, disease and squalor. Across the globe, there is a need to ensure that everybody can enjoy the basics of a decent life - a job, a roof over their head, an education, protection from preventable illness and an adequate diet.

The importance of the millennium celebrations, however, is that it has focused attention on what has been achieved in the past and what remains to be done in the future. There is no intrinsic reason why Beveridge's giants should not be slain in the 21st century, no real excuses for putting up with the death of 5m children under five during the next 12 months.

At the crossroads

When people died young in the middle ages, it was because of a lack of knowledge; they die in Africa today because they are poor, and don't have proper sanitation and the right drugs. The cost of providing universal primary education would be $8bn (£4.8bn) a year - about four days' worth of global military spending. So when pessimists say we are condemned to famine, ecological disaster and ever greater inequality, they are wrong. This is not a question of inevitability, it is a question of choice and will.

As Oxfam said at the end of last year, we stand at a crossroads. "A new world is taking shape at the end of the millennium that has two possible futures. If current trends continue we will have a world divided by immense inequality, with the poorest regions falling further behind. Our children will face a world of environmental collapse, international resentment and insecurity and uncontrolled international crime. Vast swaths of humanity will be excluded from great wealth created by a global economy.

"It is worth reflecting on what future generations will think when they look back. Will they see us as the first generation to build firm foundations for international peace and to rid the planet of the scourges of absolute poverty and avoidable disease? Or will they see a generation hell-bent on squandering every natural resource in a quest for material happiness and at the cost of the great majority of humanity? Will they feel pride or shame at what their fathers and mothers have done to the world they inhabit?"

Of course, a number of obstacles stand in the way of a better future. One is the giant that Beveridge had no need to mention amid the high optimism of the mid-20th century: cynicism. This is no longer the age of "what needs to be done", but "what can we get away with".

In retrospect, the idealism of the post-war reformers may have been misguided, even naïve, but there was a genuine belief that there was no problem too big to be solved. Today, politicians everywhere routinely renege on pledges in the belief that any problem can be solved by short-term fixes, spin-doctoring or character assassination.

Take this example highlighted by the outgoing head of the International Monetary Fund, Michel Camdessus, in Madrid recently. He reminded his audience of all the agreements signed up to by governments over the past decade or so - to reduce the number of people living in poverty by half by 2015, to ensure universal primary education, to reduce child and infant mortality by two-thirds and maternal mortality by three-quarters, to reverse the current rate of destruction of the environment and to eliminate the disparity in access to primary and secondary education for girls and boys by 2015.

"Imagine for a moment that these pledges were to be actually fulfilled: what a giant step this would be toward a better world, toward improving the lot of the most disadvantaged among the poor - women and children! But many of the world's top leaders are losing sight of these pledges. With 1.3bn people living in extreme poverty, what is needed is some thing that is also fundamental in human relations: abiding by one's word. If we allow cynicism to prevail here, we may as well give up the dream of progressing to a more fraternal society," he said.

Absolutely right. Over the past decade, rich western countries have merrily trousered their peace dividends as a result of the end of the cold war, giving them the wherewithal to meet their United Nations targets for aid. Yet, with a few honourable exceptions, countries have continued to fall further and further short of their 2000 aid targets of 0.7% of GDP.

Dog eat dog

One reason that governments have been allowed to get away with this is that the past two decades have seen the relentless denigration of the public realm. This has been true both within and between countries, with the fostering of a dog eat dog political culture and the every man for himself mentality.

All the great flowerings of civilisation - from Greece and Rome onwards - have been based on a strong sense of a public realm and public duty, not on naked individualism and atomised societies. So if the first prerequisite for progress is an end to cynicism, the second is the desperate need to protect, nurture and develop a sense of collectivism. The tremendous success of the Jubilee 2000 campaign, the outpourings of public concern over food safety and the World Trade Organisation are all signs that the mood is changing.

The public is waking up to the fact that the counterpart to ever lower taxes is a health service in a state of semi-permanent crisis - and that if they want the best graduates to teach their children they are going to have to pay for them, collectively or privately.

Similarly, it is becoming clear that solving some of the world's most pressing problems - the environment, drugs, organised crime, corruption, poverty, financial instability - cannot be left to the private sector because the private sector is part of the problem. The reason the dark ages were a dark time for civilisation was that the public realm collapsed with the demise of Rome, leading to fragmentation, lawlessness and higher rates of illiteracy. Recolonisation of the public sphere is now long overdue, with electorates tending to be ahead of governments in understanding what needs to be done.

As Mr Camdessus noted: "Humanising globalisation also means creating conditions that will enable us to better protect ourselves as a group against collective risks on a global scale, and together obtain a clearer view of our collective destiny.

"We are the first generation in history to be called upon to organise and manage the world, not from a position of power such as Alexander's or Caesar's or the Allies at the end of the second world war, but through a recognition of the universal responsibilities of all peoples, of the equal right to sustainable development, and of a universal duty of solidarity."

It's not often that I find myself in total agreement with Mr Camdessus. It is conceivable that the next 100 years could see great advance for the human race. But the process of humanising globalisation will only happen if there is a rediscovery of the virtues of governance and a willingness to accept collective responsibility for our destiny. That means redistribution of power and redistribution of wealth. But above all it means a belief that we can do it. If we believe it can't be done, it won't be.

fields.headline: In search of best tunes
fields.trailText: With reference to Geoffrey Watson's letter (January 6), it seems that vast numbers of those who lived through the second world war were so traumatised by it that (as well as acquiring a distressing tendency to wear beige cardigans) they were deprived of the ability to appreciate any music written after that time
fields.body:
With reference to Geoffrey Watson's letter (January 6), it seems that vast numbers of those who lived through the second world war were so traumatised by it that (as well as acquiring a distressing tendency to wear beige cardigans) they were deprived of the ability to appreciate any music written after that time. They have therefore never derived any pleasure from the music of the Beatles, Queen, Elton John, Oasis or Robbie Williams (to name but a few); and to compound this, their own choice of music (Red Sails in the Sunset, Run Rabbit, etc) has been regarded by succeeding generations as unbelievably dreary and awful. Another tragic consequence of war, I'm afraid.
S Saxby
Wrexham, Clwyd

 I sympathise with Geoffrey Watson about current music. However, as Jeremy Hardy has noted, eventually we all turn into our parents in this respect. I mean, young people's music today, it's not what it was when I were a lad - no proper tunes any more, no words you can sing along to. In my day we had the Clash and the Buzzcocks...
Ian Shuttleworth
London
shutters@cix.compulink.co.uk

 Geoffrey Watson is right on about the pleasant tunes we used to sing 50 years ago, before we dumped the big bands for hip-wriggling, arm-waving, pop stars sexually titillating their admiring fans. And it's a lot more than the singalong they're missing. In the Hammersmith Palais in the early 50s, you had hundreds of beautiful girls waiting for you to ask them to dance. On the dance floor, you had a girl you never saw before with her body pressed against yours, both of you sending out most intimate body signals as you danced and sang along with the band. There was no better way to make out. You just don't get that in the current dance scene.
Sam da Vinci
London

 Amateur operatic societies and light orchestras exist to provide audiences with music of the sort that Geoffrey Watson remembers. Our light orchestra specialises in music from 1850-1950. We still find many audiences who appreciate the older compositions that are too valuable to allow to die.
W F Daggett
Littlehampton, West Sussex

 I suggest Geoffrey Watson finds a copy of Girl/Boy Song by Aphex Twin if he wants a nice melody. One of the best pieces of advice I ever had was that if I was ever to hear a piece of music I didn't like the first thing I should do is listen to it again.
Robert Dane
Ashby-de-la-Zouch, Leics

webTitle: Some good news to go with the lemons and pears

fields.headline: Some good news to go with the lemons and pears
fields.trailText: One day last week, two coach loads of children from Camden's Edith Neville and Beckford primary schools worked from 6am to 6pm to perform their show, No Limits, on the McDonald's Our Town stage at the Dome.
fields.body:
One day last week, two coach loads of children from Camden's Edith Neville and Beckford primary schools worked from 6am to 6pm to perform their show, No Limits, on the McDonald's Our Town stage at the Dome. These children, using their own ideas and research, with help from Hampstead Theatre staff, created something inclusive and exciting; involving cooperation, commitment, joy, pride, hard work, confidence, success, learning and achieving together. Problems? Yes - the background noise and acoustics in the theatre are terrible. However, maybe in this 21st century we should do a lot more to celebrate and recognise the day-to-day endeavour and success ordinary children and adults, working in and supporting schools and other services, achieve. That would be truly innovative, exciting and different.
Andy Macgarr
London

 I'm sorry that Polly Toynbee (Comment, January 5) had a lemon-flavoured day at Greenwich recently. Citing works by Antony Gormley and others, she writes: "The lesson is that only those elements created by artists have meaning." Of course, it was good that some art was included both outside and inside the Dome. The organisers made a mistake, though, typical among commissioners of public art in Britain. This reflects the sculpture-on-a-plinth afterthought, which tends to restrict the artwork to being a discrete and isolated object, and the artist to a peripheral and ultimately decorative role. The secret is to involve artists from the start, as part of the team. On the wider cultural, social and economic front - of which the Dome is intended to be emblematic - artists are contributing in real and diverse ways to development and regeneration all over the country. Something beyond money and concrete was clearly missing in the reconfiguration of our towns and cities in the previous half-century. At least one of the missing ingredients in our present planning - as at the Dome, our supposed showcase - is the skill and imagination of artists. Without them the regeneration of our cities and our society will continue to go pear-shaped.
Robert Powell
Wakefield

 Polly Toynbee disappointingly joined the journalistic tendency to criticise the Dome. I visited the Dome with my godson the very day her article was published, and had a completely different experience.

By visiting the zones when they were less busy we avoided all queuing. We were surrounded at all times by thousands of people, of all ages, obviously enjoying themselves enormously. The Dome also offers thousands of unskilled job opportunities, providing experience in customer care, to people of all ages. At £20, where else would you find such good value for a day's entertainment in London?
Alec Reed
Reed Executive plc
Tolworth, Surrey

fields.headline: Slight loss of bearings
fields.trailText: As one of the thousands of readers bereft by the death of Patrick O'Brian, may I add to WL Webb's obituary (January 8) a fact that was also missing from a television documentary: apart from his great characters, Aubrey and Maturin, O'Brian also created a range of fascinating women.
fields.body:
As one of the thousands of readers bereft by the death of Patrick O'Brian, may I add to WL Webb's obituary (January 8) a fact that was also missing from a television documentary: apart from his great characters, Aubrey and Maturin, O'Brian also created a range of fascinating women.
Mary Benson
London
maryb@langfordcourt. demon.co.uk

 WL Webb wrote a handsome obituary for Patrick O'Brian; but I feel Jack Aubrey would have been very annoyed at the final paragraph. " 'Ushant somewhere away on the starboard bow, the Scillies to larboard,' bound for heaven knows where..."

Given the bearings quoted, they were sailing east up the Channel. I suspect Jack would have had Plymouth or Portsmouth in mind, and the doctor would have been fully aware of what was intended.
John S Preston
Winchester, Hants
jspreston@winchester126. freeserve.co.uk

fields.headline: The danger of implosion
fields.standfirst:
Indonesia's neighbours should help now

Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: The election of a new president last October and the ending of the crisis caused by East Timor's secession have brought little respite from political, ethnic and sectarian upheavals for the people of Indonesia. The latest flashpoint is centred on Ambon, the capital of the Moluccas in eastern Indonesia. An estimated 1,500 people have been killed in clashes between Muslim and Christian communities in more than a dozen islands in the past year, and perhaps 200,000 have been displaced. In contrast to East Timor, the army, which took over responsibility for security from the police last month, does not appear to be actively fuelling the conflict. But nor does it seem able to contain it. In faraway Jakarta, passions have become inflamed. Reckless calls are heard for a jihad (holy war) against the Christian minority. The potential for a serious escalation is only too clear.
fields.body:
The election of a new president last October and the ending of the crisis caused by East Timor's secession have brought little respite from political, ethnic and sectarian upheavals for the people of Indonesia. The latest flashpoint is centred on Ambon, the capital of the Moluccas in eastern Indonesia. An estimated 1,500 people have been killed in clashes between Muslim and Christian communities in more than a dozen islands in the past year, and perhaps 200,000 have been displaced. In contrast to East Timor, the army, which took over responsibility for security from the police last month, does not appear to be actively fuelling the conflict. But nor does it seem able to contain it. In faraway Jakarta, passions have become inflamed. Reckless calls are heard for a jihad (holy war) against the Christian minority. The potential for a serious escalation is only too clear.

Much the same might be said of the province of Aceh, in western Sumatra, the scene of much recent separatist violence. There seems little doubt that a majority of local people would vote for independence from Indonesia if their demand for a Timorese-style referendum were granted. So far, it has been refused. In Irian Jaya (known indigenously as Papua), in West Kalimantan, in South Sulawesi, and in Riau, in eastern Sumatra, a similar story is unfolding. While each agitation has its own particular aspects, this seemingly disparate unrest has some common causes. One is the political weakness, in the post-Suharto era, of the central government now led by President Abdurrahman Wahid and Megawati Sukarnoputri, his inexperienced deputy. Another is the economic depression that has plagued Indonesia for the past three years. Yet another is the widely-felt grievance that the natural resources of non-Javanese provinces are unfairly exploited by the Jakarta power elite.

Is Indonesia about to break into pieces, to be Balkanised like a sort of Asian Yugoslavia? Its neighbours, who have most to lose in any such implosion, would be unwise to wait and see. Members of the Association of South-East Asian Nations, Japan, and China, many of whom ducked the Timor problem, leaving it largely to Australia and the west, should move quickly to bolster Mr Wahid. Humanitarian aid should be backed up by greater economic assistance. At this time of uncertain transition, escalating violence and resultant government repression help nobody.
