fields.headline: How to make big money
fields.standfirst: Follow the City, then do the opposite
fields.trailText: City bonuses are reported to have recovered dramatically from last year and could top £1.5bn when they are finally totted up. It was thus with high expectations that we came to examine how the panel, assembled by the Financial Times, of five leading City experts performed with their predictions for the past year (ie those made in January 1999). We have done this exercise for the past two years. On the first occasion (for 1997) they were badly wrong. Among other things they forecast that shares were heading for a big fall. In fact they rose by 20%. Anyone taking their advice would have lost a lot of money.
fields.body:
City bonuses are reported to have recovered dramatically from last year and could top £1.5bn when they are finally totted up. It was thus with high expectations that we came to examine how the panel, assembled by the Financial Times, of five leading City experts performed with their predictions for the past year (ie those made in January 1999). We have done this exercise for the past two years. On the first occasion (for 1997) they were badly wrong. Among other things they forecast that shares were heading for a big fall. In fact they rose by 20%. Anyone taking their advice would have lost a lot of money.

We were looking forward to a recovery by the pundits a year ago with their predictions for 1998. Sadly we were disappointed. In the words of the FT's own reporter the pundits were "spectacularly wrong". Only one of the five panellists got the rise of the FTSE 100 index about right and the rest underestimated the gains by up to 42%. But they were even more badly wrong about Wall Street and wildly so about the trend of Japanese shares. They all totally failed to predict the 1998 slump in oil prices, or the drop in long-term interest rates.

And last year? Oh dear. The average of the panel's forecast for UK shares was for the FTSE 100 to be at 5,760 (a small fall over the year). In fact shares rose by 18% to 6,930. So, if you had been taking their advice for the past three years... no, don't even think about it. Their success on Wall Street was just as bad. They predicted a rise of 5% instead of the actual rise of 25%. For the Nikkei 225 in Tokyo, they predicted a rise of 17% compared with an actual increase of 36%. They thought the price of oil (Brent crude) would be $11.30 a barrel but it turned out to be $25.4 a barrel. Did they get anything right? Yes, the average forecast (albeit concealing some pretty wide variations) was $291 an ounce for the price of gold. Spot on. But then even a stopped clock is correct twice a day.

fields.headline: Libel no longer suits
fields.trailText: Just what purpose does our law of libel serve? It isn't just the entertaining but ludicrous Hamilton-Fayed trial that makes me ask, although those proceedings have certainly given me much ammunition. Does anybody for a moment believe that Mohamed al Fayed has been "vindicated"; or, if the decision had gone the other way, that Neil Hamilton would have had his reputation "restored"? Has anybody changed his or her opinion of the main actors in the farce? This particular jury decided in favour of Fayed; another bunch of 12, chosen equally randomly, might have taken the opposite view. So what has been proved? Indeed, how often, in all the high-profile celebrity trials of recent years, has the result been anything approaching moral justice? Big money has sometimes changed hands, but I wonder whether the supposed main aim of defamation law - to redeem a dented reputation - is achieved.
fields.body:
Just what purpose does our law of libel serve? It isn't just the entertaining but ludicrous Hamilton-Fayed trial that makes me ask, although those proceedings have certainly given me much ammunition. Does anybody for a moment believe that Mohamed al Fayed has been "vindicated"; or, if the decision had gone the other way, that Neil Hamilton would have had his reputation "restored"? Has anybody changed his or her opinion of the main actors in the farce? This particular jury decided in favour of Fayed; another bunch of 12, chosen equally randomly, might have taken the opposite view. So what has been proved? Indeed, how often, in all the high-profile celebrity trials of recent years, has the result been anything approaching moral justice? Big money has sometimes changed hands, but I wonder whether the supposed main aim of defamation law - to redeem a dented reputation - is achieved.

The real sufferers from defamation are those people, unknown to the outside world, who are libelled within their own small communities, where the effects can be devastating, where the defamation has caused them to be shunned or avoided, or harmed in their business, trade or profession. They are precisely the people who can't afford to go to law because there is no legal aid for libel. Yes, I know that cases can now be brought through a lawyer acting on a no-win, no-fee basis and that the law has been streamlined to make it easier to bring proceedings. But these changes won't have more than a marginal effect. Tinkering with the procedure is no longer enough. What is needed is a deep new look at the principles.

For me, the most interesting peerage in the new year honours list was for Joel Joffe, described as the chairman of Oxfam, which he is. But he's been something else as well, for which he is justly revered. In 1963 Joffe, a young South African lawyer distressed by the apartheid system, was on the point of emigrating to Australia. Instead, almost by accident, he stayed to take on the defence of some important members of a banned revolutionary organisation who had been arrested at a farm in Rivonia, near Johannesburg. Not long afterwards, the police detained a fugitive called Nelson Mandela, who joined the other liberation leaders in the dock, charged with offences against the state for which the punishment could be death. Joffe was the main defence attorney throughout the Rivonia trial, which ended, of course, with Mandela on Robben Island. Joffe still has the handwritten original of Mandela's famous speech in the trial, the one with the unforgettable last words: "It is an ideal for which I am prepared to die."

The failure of the dome organisers to adopt my suggestion of an interactive Miscarriage of Justice Zone - in which, for example, innocent members of the public would be sent to prison for long periods and have to sell their homes to pay their legal bills - has had the predicted (by me) results of low attendances and poor critical notices. And how much livelier the opening ceremony would have been had the trapeze artists, as I had urged, been dressed in wigs and gowns and sung key passages from a text-book on negligence, thus symbolising the main theme of the new millennium - "More Litigation". Still, my New Year's Eve in London was not entirely shorn of legal content. As I walked past the Victorian Gothic Royal Courts of Justice in the Strand, where there's a long wall half-hidden by arches, I noticed an orderly queue and a lot of men with their backs to me. Yes, on the last night of the old millennium, one of the most important and symbolic centres of justice in the English speaking world was playing a crucial role - as a pissoir .

webTitle: Do I really need a lawyer for  accident compensation  ?

fields.headline: Do I really need a lawyer for  accident compensation  ?
fields.trailText: Unlike house conveyancing or divorce, this isn't something you can do by following a series of steps in a book. It takes know-how to work out whether your injuries were caused by someone else's negligence or breach of a statutory duty - if not, you won't be entitled to compensation - and, if so, how to prove it and how to assess whether any settlement offered  is fair.
fields.body:
Unlike house conveyancing or divorce, this isn't something you can do by following a series of steps in a book. It takes know-how to work out whether your injuries were caused by someone else's negligence or breach of a statutory duty - if not, you won't be entitled to compensation - and, if so, how to prove it and how to assess whether any settlement offered is fair.

Extracting payment from the insurers who deal with these claims is not a job for an amateur. Indeed, unless the injuries are small, it's a job for a specialist personal injury lawyer.

If the insurers refuse to settle, you will have to issue court proceedings. Reforms last year, designed to produce more settlements and simplify the law, have, paradoxically, made it harder for DIY litigants to pursue an accident claim.

Claims assessors, without legal qualifications, will negotiate settlements for accident victims, but will take a cut. There are also claims management companies which pass cases on to personal injury lawyers and won't charge anything upfront, but there is no need to go through an intermediary. Ringing 0500 192939, the Law Society's accident line, will get you a 30-minute, free, no- obligation interview with a solicitor. There is a website at www.accident-line.org.uk.

Legal aid is still available for accident victims who pass the means test. From April, it will no longer cover injury cases. Lawyers offering no-win, no-fee deals will take its place. The details of these deals are mind-boggling, but a newly updated book, No Win, No Fee, No Worries, by Kerry Underwood (CLT Professional Publishing, £28), will tell you all you need to know about funding a case. The lawyer gets nothing if the case is lost, but up to double normal fees if it's won. The extra fees are known as the "uplift" or "success fee". At present, this comes out of your damages, though it can't exceed 25%.

The second element of the deal is an insurance premium to cover the cost of losing and having to pay the other side's costs. From later this year, probably April, if you win, the other side will have to reimburse both the premium and the uplift, as well as your lawyer's normal costs. So you'll keep your damages in full. The end result is you've nothing to gain from trying to bring a claim yourself.

webTitle: Israel-Syria talks fail to reach accord

fields.headline: Israel-Syria talks fail to reach accord
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Despite five visits from President Bill Clinton, Israeli-Syrian negotiations on a land-for-peace treaty appeared to be nearing a close yesterday without even a tentative agreement.
fields.byline: Barry Schweid  in Shepherdstown, West Virginia
fields.body:
Despite five visits from President Bill Clinton, Israeli-Syrian negotiations on a land-for-peace treaty appeared to be nearing a close yesterday without even a tentative agreement.

Preparing to return home from the US today, the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, described the week-long, US-mediated talks on territory, peace, water and security as "complex and difficult".

Diplomatic sources said Syria's foreign minister, Farouk al-Shara, was likely to follow tomorrow.

On the sensitive issue of establishing a new border once Israel pulls back on the Golan Heights, Israel's foreign minister, David Levy, said: "Nothing has been agreed upon."

Yet the talks were reported to have surmounted a hurdle when a "borders" committee - on charting Israeli withdrawal - met yesterday for the first time.

Mr Clinton intervened in the talks four times before yesterday. "He's going for meetings. The process continues," a White House official said.

The state department spokesman, James Rubin, said the two sides responded positively to a statement presented by the US on Friday. fields.headline: I told my son's killer: I forgive you
fields.standfirst: A scheme designed to heal the pain of crime worked for one mother when she met the man responsible for the death of her only child. But will 'restorative justice' work for others?
fields.trailText: It was a meeting both sides had longed for and dreaded in equal measure. A go-between from the probation service had spent nine months preparing them for it. Neither Mary nor Michael could be sure what would happen. After all, she was a mother whose only son had been killed on his 21st birthday. He was the young man sentenced to six years in prison for his manslaughter.
fields.body:
It was a meeting both sides had longed for and dreaded in equal measure. A go-between from the probation service had spent nine months preparing them for it. Neither Mary nor Michael could be sure what would happen. After all, she was a mother whose only son had been killed on his 21st birthday. He was the young man sentenced to six years in prison for his manslaughter.

Mary was the one who had asked for the meeting but, as she waited to face the man who had taken her son's life, she was, in her own words, a nervous wreck.

Michael felt afraid. He was taken to the church, where the meeting took place, from his cell. "It was like going to court again, only worse. There were about five steps to climb. It seemed like 200. I could not lift my legs up the steps."

The idea that such meetings can help to heal the damage done by a crime is not a new one but the basic concept has been expanded and incorporated into a radical approach known as "restorative justice". Some believe that the traditional structure of crime and punishment could be replaced by a restorative system based on group meetings and agreed reparation.

For Mary and Michael, the meeting was an opportunity to deal with a legacy of bitterness and misunderstanding which, in different ways, had blighted their lives.

Mary had been horrified when the police told her who had been arrested for her son's murder. Her son had been bullied at school by a boy with the same unusual surname and she drew the wrong conclusion. Michael's plea of guilty to manslaughter meant that there was no trial and nothing was said in court about the motive for the attack or the circumstances surrounding it.

Mary believed, wrongly, that her son had been hounded and killed by someone who had tormented and terrified him for years. One newspaper picked up on the bullying element and made a big story out of it. In fact, the bully had not been Michael but one of his brothers; Michael had left home at 14 to live with his grandparents. His version of how Mary's son had died was very different from the one in the papers. He and his friends had been drinking, as had Mary's son. They had all gone off to look for a party in a block of flats. There was a row during which a punch was thrown. Mary's son ran away and fell from the roof.

Michael pleaded guilty to manslaughter because he felt, and still feels, responsible. He was ready to accept his punishment but he could not believe what the papers said about him. He felt he had been branded an "animal" and a "psychopath". No one wanted to listen to his side of the story.

After two years in prison, bottling up his feelings, he met Barbara Tudor of the West Midlands probation service. She is a victim-offender development officer and had been approached by Mary, who was worried about what would happen if she chanced to meet Michael in the street after his release.

Tudor and a colleague, Lynn Ferron, spent nine months working separately with Mary and Michael. Eventually they arranged the meeting. Mary recalls: "I just stood there and waited for him to come in. When they brought him in, he looked so smart, a really nice young man.

"I thought, how could anybody hate him? I couldn't hate him because I didn't know him. I hated what he'd done but I couldn't hate the young man himself. So I just went up to him and I put my arms around him and I said, 'I'm not here to hurt you, I'm here to help you'."

Michael says: "I was expecting to sit down and get a punch, a scratch, have my hair pulled. I thought I probably deserved it. I was gobsmacked. She was just so calm. She made me feel at ease. I thought, it should be me trying to help her. I'm the one in the wrong here."

Mary remembers: "All of a sudden he got up and asked if he could sit on the other side of the table. He sat next to me and he held my hand as he was telling me everything. And the story he was giving me wasn't anything like the one the police had told me or what I had assumed."

Mary believed that her son had been picked on because of his small size and unconventional appearance. Michael told her that was not the case. When they first met up, they had been laughing and joking.

"I wanted her to hear my side of the story, then she could make her own mind up," he says. "It wasn't just a question of being sorry. I was sorry, but that wouldn't bring her son back. I wanted her to see what sort of person I was. Not this psychopath that the papers had made out. You can look into somebody's eyes and you can tell what sort of person somebody is."

One of the strongest supporters of restorative justice is Baroness Stern of the International Centre for Prison Studies. She says the aim is to find a more satisfying and worthwhile way of dealing with crime and conflict. "We've come on a long journey from hanging and transportation, through branding and the stocks, to prison.

"Now we're moving beyond these outdated concepts towards a system which is much more to do with the victim being at the centre of the process," she says.

The most developed programmes are in New Zealand, where they have set up victim-offender liaison groups in each town. The groups work with both parties to come up with an agreed plan for reparation. Where appropriate, the families are involved too. Whatever is decided is then put to a judge, who has the final say on whether to accept the proposed settlement. In Britain, Thames Valley police are pioneering restorative justice techniques for first and second-time offenders. Elsewhere in England and Wales, new youth justice laws are bringing in a restorative justice regime. In five pilot areas, magistrates are obliged to consider imposing a reparation order which can involve a financial deal, a period of work to benefit the victim or the community, or an apology, preferably delivered in person.

Vivien Stern says that the problem with the traditional criminal justice system is that it does not satisfy the person who has been wronged. "People ask for more and more punishment, more and more suffering to be inflicted on the offender. But still it does not give a feeling that the matter has been dealt with in a satisfactory way."

She says that victims, above all, want to feel understood. They want offenders to own up to what they have done and appreciate the suffering they have caused. Many victims also want some good to come of it and that means they want the offender to go through an experience that leads them to give up crime.

Mary says the meeting gave her an opportunity to explain what she had suffered and seek answers to questions that had been bothering her. She told Michael at the outset: "You've taken away my life and future. He was my only son. I can't have any grandchildren and it's left me so alone."

The meeting lasted several hours and included a meal together. "As we spoke, I told him: 'I forgive you and my son forgives you.'"

Michael says that meeting Mary helped him to deal with coming out of prison almost a year ago. He has a job and lives with his wife, son and baby daughter. "I don't have to put my head down to anybody. All that counts for me is I've met the lad's mother. She's seen what sort of person I am. I'm not interested in what everyone else thinks."

Tudor, who has worked in this field for the probation service for 15 years, believes Michael and Mary prove that restorative justice works. Michael has found a new confidence and determination to make something of his life. Mary, on the morning of the meeting, had been urged by a friend to pull out because it might leave her in pieces. She ignored the advice and says: "I'm more together now than I have been in years."

Charles Sigler is the producer of BBC Radio 4's Law in Action.

fields.headline: The women the world forgot
fields.standfirst: Thirty years ago, American women soldiers entered the combat zone for the first time ever, yet their story has never been heard ... until now.  Sharon Krum reports on the meeting in Washington that could see Vietnam's history rewritten
fields.trailText: When US army officer Claire Starnes returned from Vietnam after serving two years as a military photojournalist, she sought help for her trauma in a group therapy session. Everyone in the room was a Vietnam vet, she recalls, but she was the only woman.
fields.body:
When US army officer Claire Starnes returned from Vietnam after serving two years as a military photojournalist, she sought help for her trauma in a group therapy session. Everyone in the room was a Vietnam vet, she recalls, but she was the only woman.

Within minutes, the verbal punches were rolling and by the end of the hour, Starnes felt emotionally black and blue. "They said: 'What are you doing here? How dare you come? You weren't in combat. You were in a safe area.' And I tried to explain that in Vietnam there was no safe area, everybody who served was in combat. But they didn't want to hear me."

Shamed and hurt, Starnes, now 55, attempted to move on with her life, working as an assistant newspaper editor and raising two sons in suburban Maryland. She never sought help again and hardly told anyone she had been in the war. "When we came back, initially America treated the vets terribly. I remember arriving home and being jeered at the airport when people saw my uniform. If I didn't tell anyone I served, they couldn't criticise me."

But despite Starnes' efforts to erase Vietnam from her life story, it wouldn't go away. There were nightmares and depression, tics and quirks that persist to this day. She still chooses to stand with her back against a wall. Even sitting, she will place a pillow between her back and the chair. "In Vietnam, you never wanted to have your back exposed because you could get shot. Once you live like that, it never leaves you. My husband knows not to turn lights on while I'm asleep because I think it is a flash of gunfire and I go berserk. Loud noises make me jump. I feel very foolish when it happens in public, but I can't help it."

Neither can the other estimated one thousand women who served in Vietnam in non-nursing roles, as stenographers, intelligence officers, advisers and flight controllers. Unlike Vietnam's nurses, who on their return were celebrated as angels of mercy, enlisted female officers like Starnes were treated as pariahs. Ignored by a US Veterans Administration overwhelmed by the return of over two million men, they buried themselves and their experiences behind a white picket fence in suburban America.

"What we found when we finally came together," Starnes says, "was that we had all taken the same route. We hid. We went into our shells and dealt with the pain privately."

Two years ago, Starnes was at a women's military memorial dedication (for women who served in all wars) when she ran into 12 women who had served with her in Vietnam. By day's end, they had resolved to track down all non-nursing female vets and hold a conference. Of the 709 tracked down, 139 turned up in November at a hotel in Olympia, Washington for three days of discussion about post-traumatic stress disorder, depression, broken relationships, miscarriages, birth defects and Agent Orange.

"It was incredibly emotional," says Starnes, who co-ordinated the event. "We had never been acknowledged by the government the way men had because we weren't in combat. Nobody came looking for us for 30 years. We had to do it ourselves."

The theme of the first Vietnam Women Veterans conference was We Remember because, Starnes explains, so many had blocked out their experiences. It was also the first time in three decades many women vets had spoken openly about life post-Vietnam and the revelations were devastating. There was the vet who talked of five broken marriages, blamed on the demons of Vietnam. There were those who spoke of multiple miscarriages or of delivering babies with birth defects. Then there was the woman who recounted how, as a general's secretary in Saigon, she took dictation about plans for a bombing raid, then suffered depression for years after realising she had typed up a death warrant for a village. All spoke of recurring dreams of being captured and tortured.

"What came up continually," Starnes says, "was how these women had spoken to so few people about their pain. Some hid it even from their spouses. I think it's because women were told if we weren't in combat, we weren't allowed to suffer."

But Starnes did see combat, through the lens of a camera. She enlisted for the US army at 18 and volunteered for Vietnam at 25. (US army women were not drafted but could volunteer for non-combat duty.) Stationed in Saigon, Starnes was the only woman in the Office of Information. She worked in composing, then as a photojournalist for a command newspaper, shooting everything from bloody battles to hospital units.

"I wanted to serve my country," she explains. "And when I got there, I said please don't give me special treatment because I'm a woman. I'll go anywhere, photograph anything."

And she did. "I had no idea how bad it would be. When I took the pictures, I never let myself feel anything. You had to tune out emotionally. It was only when I got home that I started to realise what I'd seen."

When her tour ended, Starnes quit the army, married, had children and worked in newspapers, then with troubled teens in high school. She has rarely spoken about Vietnam to her sons, now 21 and 24. "Eventually I'll sit down with them and talk about it, but right now it's still too hard."

She felt no such fear at the conference: "You didn't have to explain yourself. There was no shame about breaking down." But while the reunion was a success (many women left vowing to seek treatment for trauma), Starnes is nowhere near satisfied. The conference, she says, was just the beginning of a push for recognition of the contribution of Vietnam's non-nursing women. "We need more government services to seek out these women and help them." Later this month, Starnes will meet officers of the Vietnam Veterans Association in Washington DC for the first time to discuss women veterans' issues. Almost a year on from its inception, her group is starting to be recognised as a valid organisation.

Then there is the history book she wants written. Despite thousands of tomes that chronicle the male experience in Vietnam, there is barely a word on women. "Vietnam was the first time in the history of the US army that there was actually a Women's Army Corps detachment set up in a combat zone. Our history is not known."

Starnes invited military historians from the Veterans Administration to the reunion to take oral histories from attendees. Though many vets were reluctant to talk to strangers, Starnes prodded and pushed until every single one spoke up. "I said, this is our history, ladies, we have to do this. We have a duty to tell the world that women were in Vietnam."

fields.headline: Sex and the seventysomething
fields.standfirst: Age, according to a new survey, is no bar to wanting love. But how do we negotiate new relationships as we get older, asks  Lynne Segal
fields.trailText: Word is out. There is no escape. Even at the ripe old age of 90, it is new relationships that matter most to us. So revealed the British Household Panel Study last week, having recorded the most valued aspirations and achievements of thousands of adults over the past decade.
fields.body:
Word is out. There is no escape. Even at the ripe old age of 90, it is new relationships that matter most to us. So revealed the British Household Panel Study last week, having recorded the most valued aspirations and achievements of thousands of adults over the past decade.

This contradicts what we usually hear. Both Eva Figes and Germaine Greer have celebrated their own lives as older women in terms of freedom from the compulsions to seek out sex and relationships. As esteemed mentors of women's pathway to fulfilment in a world devised to obstruct it, their views are discouraging. In reality, we almost never lose the need for love and gratification we acquire at the beginnings of our lives. For some, it merely gets harder to seek them out; longings are silenced once the affirmation of our personal significance to others begins to diminish.

It is the 60s generation, of course, that is held responsible for placing sexual freedom and happiness at the core of life. The prostitutes teeming in every metropolis a century ago - indicative of male sexual profligacy rather than continence - had served to underwrite rather than undermine ideas of sexual freedom as immoral. And indeed it was only when women joined in the conversations about sexual freedom at the close of the 60s that the merde really hit the fan.

We are still dealing with its fallout. Today many a feminist joins the cultural conservatives in naming sexual freedom as always being against women's interests - at least if men are present in the equation. Those 90-year-olds seeking new relationships - most of whom, given contemporary demographics, must be female - should know better than to seek out pleasure with a man!

Pleasure, sex, love ... I will not presume to clarify the multiplicity of meanings such words evoke. But I will insist that, at least in fantasy, the one rarely comes without associations of the other, for a woman or a man. So how do older women negotiate new relationships today? What aspirations, if any, survive in those erstwhile cultural radicals who once hoped to negotiate freer, more equal relationships with others?

After feminism, it was clear that sexual freedom has to confront a symbolic landscape of phallic entitlement and female subjugation, as well as fight to eliminate the predatory practices such entitlement condoned. But whatever the hold of the dominant iconography of sex, few women or men report experiencing only its routine literalisation in actual sexual encounters. A sense of female affirmation and power, of male vulnerability and need, are not uncommon experiences.

Women's attempt to put sexual pleasure and freedom at the centre of our own lives has been, and remains, crucial in the struggle to subvert a cultural edifice once primarily expressive of men's control of women.

But the confidence that once enabled more women to embark on this voyage can be hard to sustain once ageism adds its noxious spray to a stage still inhabited by sexism. "There is an instinct, magnet or aerial which seeks the unsuitable," Hanif Kureishi writes about men's abandonment of their existing loved ones to pursue younger female flesh, more flattering to their attempts to stay forever young. His tales are compelling, the tales of male sexual radicals, writing guiltily of their current abandonment of older women. Many a woman of my generation, who has tried to turn the tables on the power relations of old, is currently facing the worst fears of abandonment, just when she feels least confident about her own emotional resources. At a time when collective life of any sort continues to dwindle, it can be terrifying not to feel at the very centre of another's love and desire.

Consummating the desires of every backlash moralist, are women still to be punished for any failure to conform to the norms of old? Not quite. For women are even more likely to suffer from strict adherence to the rules of the game. And older women, like younger women today, have more personal resources than ever before - above all their own rich relations with each other.

Used to the obstacles life throws at us, many of us will not give up on any of our former dreams, whether for meaningful work, political solidarities or equal and loving relationships. Honed through long years of love and struggle, the wily ways of the older woman can be hard to spurn. Whatever Hollywood allows, as we all live longer, cultural objects of desire are going to have to stray further from the image of the babe.

So revealed the British Household Panel Study last week, having recorded the most valued aspirations and achievements of thousands of adults over the past decade. This contradicts what we usually hear. Both Eva Figes and Germaine Greer have celebrated their own lives as older women in terms of freedom from the compulsions to seek out sex and relationships. As esteemed mentors of women's pathway to fulfilment in a world devised to obstruct it, their views are discouraging. In reality, we almost never lose the need for love and gratification we acquire at the beginnings of our lives. For some, it merely gets harder to seek them out; longings are silenced once the affirmation of our personal significance to others begins to diminish. It is the 60s generation, of course, that is held responsible for placing sexual freedom and happiness at the core of life. The prostitutes teeming in every metropolis a century ago - indicative of male sexual profligacy rather than continence - had served to underwrite rather than undermine ideas of sexual freedom as immoral. webTitle: Charity in clash over child abuse claims

fields.headline: Charity in clash over child abuse claims
fields.standfirst: Social services leaders accuse NSPCC of exaggerating problems of children in care in order to promote its own role
fields.trailText: Children in care are still suffering abuse at the hands of those who are supposedly looking after them despite efforts to clean up the system, the NSPCC says today.
fields.body:
Children in care are still suffering abuse at the hands of those who are supposedly looking after them despite efforts to clean up the system, the NSPCC says today.

The child protection charity is warning against such abuse being seen as a thing of the past when the long-awaited Waterhouse report on scandals in north Wales children's homes is published shortly.

But the charity's intervention has angered social services leaders, who accuse it of exaggerating problems in order to promote its own role at the expense of existing child protection arrangements.

Jo Williams, president of the Association of Directors of Social Services, said the NSPCC was mixing the messages of the importance of protecting children with its aspirations to increase the number of its own investigation teams.

The clash is a foretaste of the potentially acrimonious fallout from the Waterhouse report, which will deal mainly with abuse cases in the 1970s and 1980s.

Ministers will respond in part to the report by citing the care standards bill, which seeks to tighten safeguards for children in care. But the NSPCC says the government needs to go further.

The charity says abuse is still occurring and the care system needs to be opened to more independent scrutiny to ensure that children in both residential and foster placements get "five star" protection.

In the 12 months to last October, NSPCC workers conducted 82 investigations into alleged physical and sexual abuse of children in the care of more than 60 local authorities.

Forty-five of the investigations related to alleged events within the previous two years.

The investigations as a whole involved more than 200 allegations against 138 individuals and, the charity says, have so far resulted in charges against 53 care workers and others in positions of trust.

One abuser, already convicted and sent to prison for six years, subjected a young girl to sex assaults over a period of three years while he was her foster carer. Inquiries established that he had cared for 15 other children, two of whom also alleged abuse.

The charity says that in recent years, it has investigated allegations of children in care as young as five being kicked, slapped, thrown against walls, forced to perform oral sex and made to pose for pornographic photography.

Neil Hunt, the charity's child protection director, said: "The number of children involved in these investigations represents a small minority of the 55,000 children in care. However, the NSPCC believes that one child abused in the care system is one too many."

The charity is calling for all allegations of abuse in the care system to be referred for investigation by independent teams of specialist child protection officers, working with the police.

At present, the NSPCC runs 11 such teams. As a result of its Full Stop campaign, which has been seeking to raise £250m towards a goal of ending child abuse, it intends to establish another five.

The charity is also pressing for the creation of a children's commissioner, with stronger powers and a wider remit than the "director of children's rights" proposed in the care standards bill.

All children in care should have a statutory right to independent advocacy services and access to a safe, adult friend trained as an independent visitor, the charity says.

Ms Williams said five years of building added precautions and tightening checks was ensuring that abusers were being wrung out of the care system.

The NSPCC carried out important work, but was involved in only a tiny minority of abuse investigations, she added. Most were conducted by social workers and the police, and the charity's idea of independent investigation "could undermine" such arrangements.

One social services director went further, privately saying: "Directors everywhere will be disappointed and in many cases resent the fact that the NSPCC should use its information at such a sensitive time to promote the services it wishes local authorities to buy."

In a statement, the department of health said new guidance made it clear that investigations should involve an independent person.

webTitle: Family who fostered abuser take their case to Lords

fields.headline: Family who fostered abuser take their case to Lords
fields.trailText: In 1992 an Essex couple with four children of their own decided to become specialist adolescent foster carers - a decision that had disastrous consequences for the family.
fields.body:
In 1992 an Essex couple with four children of their own decided to become specialist adolescent foster carers - a decision that had disastrous consequences for the family.

The couple, who can be named only as the Ws, are now divorced. Both suffer from depression and can no longer work. The children, three girls and a boy, have had to undergo extensive psychiatric counselling.

In April 1993 the family accepted G, a boy aged 15, into their home. He was there for only a month, but he systematically physically and sexually abused all four children, then aged between seven and 12.

What the Ws didn't know - though Essex county council, which placed him, did - was that G was a known abuser who had been cautioned and taken into care at age 12 for an indecent assault on his sister, seven.

Tomorrow the parents will go to the House of Lords to try to overturn refusals by the high court and court of appeal to let them sue the council for compensation. After a five-year battle, the appeal court agreed last year that the children could claim damages, but not the parents.

The council has fought the case strenuously, although it admits that the abuse took place and that it was aware of the teenager's background. When the family issued their writ, the council applied to the court for the claim to be struck out.

It was relying on a House of Lords ruling in 1994 which confirmed that councils are normally immune from negligence actions over the way they carry out their statutory child care duties.

The council argued in the high court that it would be immune even if it knowingly placed an adolescent convicted of rape or robbery with a family, and even if a social worker had deliberately lied to the parents.

But the case was so extreme that Mr Justice Hooper refused to strike out the children's claim, making it the first such case to be allowed to go ahead in the courts.

However, the parents' claim was struck out because the judge held that they were secondary, not primary, victims since they played no personal part in the events.

The House of Lords has held in a number of cases, especially those brought by families of fans killed in the Hillsborough football ground disaster, that secondary victims can claim compensation only if they witnessed the traumatic event in person.

The appeal court, by a two to one majority, agreed that the W children's claims could go ahead but not the parents'. Both sides appealed to the House of Lords, but the council has now dropped its appeal against the ruling in the children's favour.

However, it is still strongly contesting the parents' claim.

Allan Levy, the family's QC, will argue that the parents were primary victims who participated in the traumatic events as unknowing or unwitting agents in bringing the teenager into their home.

Both parents were plunged into severe depression, blaming themselves for their children's trauma, and their marriage disintegrated.

Lord Justice Judge, one of the appeal court judges who gave the go-ahead to the children's claims, said: "For all the members of the family these were catastrophic events."

The parents, who underwent an assessment and training course for caring for adolescents, claim they sought and were given assurances by the council that no teenager suspected of sexual abuse would be placed with them. The agreement they signed stated that foster parents would be fully informed about any problem relating to a foster child's background.

They claim they were told only that the boy could be a bully and a liar and that his father, a convicted paedophile, had abused him. Had they known his history, they say, they would never have taken him into their home and endangered their children.

Within a month they noticed that their four had become fearful and withdrawn. One day the teenager allegedly said casually that he had been accused of raping a girl in a children's home. The parents asked for him to be removed.

Soon afterwards their two youngest daughters revealed that he had abused them and threatened them that they would be taken away from home if they told anyone.

Later the Ws discovered that he had performed humiliating acts on their elder son and daughter.

The psychiatrist who treated the children sent her file to the police. The teenager pleaded guilty to indecent assault and was sent to a young offender institution.

fields.headline: Reach for the sky
fields.standfirst:
He's a war hero who has a problem with authority, a conservative who doesn't believe in tax cuts. And a victory in the New Hampshire primary might, just might, see this Republican maverick becoming the next US president. Martin Kettle watches John McCain win over the public and the political pundits

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: He's a war hero who has a problem with authority, a conservative who doesn't believe in tax cuts. And a victory in the New Hampshire primary might, just might, see this Republican maverick becoming the next US president.  Martin Kettle watches John McCain win over the public and the political pundits
fields.body:
Two glossy campaign hand-outs, each piled high on the table at the entrance of every meeting he addresses here in New Hampshire, go straight to the heart of why a lot of romantics and even some realists think John McCain may become the next president of the United States in November.

The first consists of a black and white picture. It shows a young pilot posing by his fighter aircraft, cocky and cool. The second shows an older man, white-haired now and a little chubbier, but with the same knowing and confident smile. Under the picture the words just say The John McCain Story.

And what a story it is. Grandfather and father both US admirals. A testosterone-charged, roustabout youth. Nearly fails to graduate from the US naval academy at Annapolis. Sent to Vietnam as a pilot. Shot down over Haiphong in 1967. Pulled from the sea, body broken, and interned in the prison the GIs called the Hanoi Hilton. Tortured. Beaten. Repeatedly offered a preferential early release, which he refuses. Spends five-and-a-half years as a prisoner of war.

He returns, still on crutches, when a peace deal is signed. His marriage cannot stand the strain. He remarries, to Cindy Hensley. Stands for congress as a Republican. Succeeds Barry Goldwater in the senate. Now running for president. Ladies and gentlemen, the John McCain story.

Contrast McCain's story with that of his principal Republican rival, George W Bush, another likeable man with an agreeably misspent youth. But there the resemblance ends. Where McCain's adulthood has been seared by death and war, Bush's has been gifted to him by privilege and his presidential dad. When McCain published his autobiography last year, he called it Faith of My Fathers. If Bush wrote a similar life story, one reviewer suggested, he would have to call it Friends of My Father's.

As McCain campaigned last week in New Hampshire, where the polls show him ahead in that state's all important first-in-the-nation February 1 primary, people arrive at McCain's meeting in Franklin bearing copies of his book.

"I see some of you have my book," McCain says, as he begins to warm up the packed crowd. "I wouldn't want to hype it. It costs $24.95; it's 16 weeks on the bestsellers; it's available from Amazon.com." McCain grins and the audience laughs at his cheek.

If McCain was just a conservative military man with a brave war record running for office, he would be easy to pigeonhole. But it's not that simple. McCain appeals to conservatives and radicals alike, not just to the ageing veterans whose welfare he constantly champions but also to the young first-time voters who find the other candidates too boring and cautious to hold their attention.

McCain is a Republican independent. For someone who has lived so much of his life under service discipline, his record is liberally littered with rebellion and insubordination. A prankster and hustler at the academy, he is now the most iconoclastic member of the 55-strong Republican majority in the US senate. On two issues in particular, tobacco and campaign finance reform, he has set himself apart from the Republican establishment. No candidate in this year's race has more powerful enemies within his own party than McCain.

This audacity is delivered with a charm, humour and confidence which delights his supporters and infuriates his enemies. McCain's campaign hallmark is his informality and accessibility. In town hall meetings around New Hampshire, he chats and answers any question. His minders do not mind - that's his style, and the media and his supporters love it.

"I find that brief remarks are the most popular," he tells his audience in Franklin, cracking a few jokes before taking questions on a bewildering range of topics. It's hard to think of a politician who appears more at ease for so much of the time. Certainly not Bush, nor the two Democratic presidential hopefuls, Al Gore and Bill Bradley.

They ask him about everything from pollution to Russia, from health to pornography, and most of the time he has something interesting to say. He is brilliant at excoriating the Clinton administration's foreign policy. "A photo-op, poll-driven foreign policy," he often dubs it. Other times, he calls it "foreign policy as social work".

Not surprisingly, he is hot on military issues. Though he supported Clinton over Kosovo, he is scathing about the administration's tactics there. "Planes dropping bombs from 15,000ft, killing innocent people. There's something fundamentally immoral about that."

During the Kosovo crisis, he says, the US moved an aircraft carrier from the Pacific to that theatre. "That was the first time since 1945 that we didn't have an aircraft carrier in the Pacific. Suppose that North Korea had chosen that moment to do something."

Foreign policy, though, won't win or lose him the race for the nomination. Taxes might. While Bush offers a massive tax-cutting programme of half a trillion dollars over five years - promising "tax cuts, so help me God" in last week's New Hampshire debate - McCain remains steadfastly in the mainstream with most Democrats, in favour of some tax cuts, but not for the rich, an astonishing piece of audacity for a Republican.

"I believe that rather than spending the surplus on tax cuts we have to make sure that social security is solvent," he tells the Franklin audience. "To use it all in tax cuts is a risky business. I know it sounds populist, but I'm not sure that millionaires and billionaires need a tax cut."

He stands on a small platform in the middle of the hall holding a microphone. He never explicitly exploits his suffering, but everyone in the hall knows he cannot raise his arms above the shoulder because of his wounds, left untreated and neglected in Hanoi. Whenever a veteran speaks, McCain is visibly moved. Tears glisten more than once.

Behind him is a banner that says Restoring Respect - McCain. He travels in a bus that he calls the Straight Talk Express. His television ads say The Character To Do Things Right. Though he has a legendary temper, he is unfailingly courteous on the stump. When anyone tells him about their own military experience - and lots of older voters do, often showing him photographs of themselves in their uniformed days - he always says "Thank you for serving".

"Look at that man," says an awestruck staffer. "This guy is not stressed. He's having such a good time." More seasoned heads have been turned by McCain too. Bill Bennett, Ronald Reagan's education secretary and former "drugs tsar", told me in New Hampshire: "He brings back to the Oval Office what people have been missing. When he comes on TV, instead of people changing the channel they'll turn up the volume."

McCain's openness to the press is counter-cultural in these times of limited access, over-anxious staffers, and ubiquitous security details. On the ride back from Franklin, 10 of us sit around in the back of the bus shooting the breeze with the candidate, while he talks at length about the campaign and the world.

He tells us that he is confident about his opposition to massive tax cuts. "People don't press for them. That tells me that they want to pay down the debt, to protect social security. Most people are doing well. They feel a responsibility to those who might not be."

All this has inevitably bred doubts in parts of the media. "It is a cliche in journalism circles these days to grouse that the media, in their coverage of McCain, are acting like schoolgirls at a Ricky Martin concert," wrote Eron Shosteck in the prestigious National Journal last week.

"But the near-unanimity with which the media seem to have fallen in love with McCain is unprecedented in modern presidential politics.

"His strategy of giving the media unlimited access has to be having an effect on his coverage. Indeed, some have even speculated that, in return for being so open, McCain has benefited from smitten reporters who have not reported potentially damaging comments an unguarded McCain has made in interviews."

For there is another McCain that the world rarely sees. The Arizona Republic has repeatedly claimed that "it is time the rest of the nation learned about the John McCain we know in Arizona", and said there was "reason to seriously question whether he has the temperament, and the political approach and skills, we want in the next president".

Two years ago, the Phoenix New Times went even further, calling McCain "a mean-spirited, hot-tempered, opportunistic, philandering, hypocritical political climber who married a comely beer heiress and used her daddy's money to get elected to congress in a state he can hardly call home".

Last week, as if on cue, the McCain campaign hit a potentially serious glitch. The Boston Globe reported that McCain had used his position on a senate committee to press the federal communications commission to expedite its approval of a television station purchase by Paxson Communications, owned by a McCain supporter, Lowell Paxson. McCain has made four campaign trips in Paxson's private jet in recent months.

McCain tried to brush the allegation off, but last Thursday's debate with Bush, held at the University of New Hampshire, hung on how McCain handled the issue under the television lights. Wasn't this hypocrisy, or at least poor judgment, the debate moderator asked McCain. His response was, by his standards, wary and long-winded, betraying an uncharacteristic anxiety not to say anything either glib or off-message.

Rather than drive home his advantage, Bush said he was more concerned by McCain's preoccupation with campaign finance reform than this issue, but it had still been a difficult day for a man who presents himself as Mr Clean. "If you're explaining you're losing," said Bush's media strategist after the debate.

In a bar afterwards, McCain reviews his performance with supporters. He cracks jokes, pumps up his team. "There's only 26 days, four hours and six minutes before the polls open," McCain tells them. "We'll be entertaining and informative and we'll be able to take the positions that we believe in. Let me just give you an example. Cindy has asked me to give a 45-minute speech on the North Korean nuclear build-up." The campaign workers collapse in laughter and applause, as they always do.

Can McCain win? It's definitely an outside bet. He is ahead in New Hampshire, one of those states where independents, who love McCain, can vote in the primary.

Bush's cash juggernaut and superior organisation give him the advantage almost everywhere else. If McCain wins New Hampshire, though, he'll be on a roll that could change everything. Yet the party establishment, lined up behind Bush, is prepared in states where McCain has hardly campaigned yet.

The toughest fight for McCain is the one for the nomination. If he wins at the Republican convention in July, his broad appeal could make him a very plausible candidate against the Democrats in November.

President McCain? A First Lady called Cindy? As Bill Bradley likes to say of his own insurgent campaign, it can happen.

But there the resemblance ends. Where McCain's adulthood has been seared by death and war, Bush's has been gifted to him by privilege and his presidential dad. When McCain published his autobiography last year, he called it Faith of My Fathers. If Bush wrote a similar life story, one reviewer suggested, he would have to call it Friends of My Father's. As McCain campaigned last week in New Hampshire, where the polls show him ahead in that state's all important first-in-the-nation February 1 primary, people arrive at McCain's meeting in Franklin bearing copies of his book. "I see some of you have my book," McCain says, as he begins to warm up the packed crowd. "I wouldn't want to hype it. It costs $24.95; it's 16 weeks on the bestsellers; it's available from Amazon.com." McCain grins and the audience laughs at his cheek. If McCain was just a conservative military man with a brave war record running for office, he would be easy to pigeonhole. But it's not that simple. McCain appeals to conservatives and radicals alike, not just to the ageing veterans whose welfare he constantly champions but also to the young first-time voters who find the other candidates too boring and cautious to hold their attention. McCain is a Republican independent. For someone who has lived so much of his life under service discipline, his record is liberally littered with rebellion and insubordination. A prankster and hustler at the academy, he is now the most iconoclastic member of the 55-strong Republican majority in the US senate. On two issues in particular, tobacco and campaign finance reform, he has set himself apart from the Republican establishment. No candidate in this year's race has more powerful enemies within his own party than McCain. This audacity is delivered with a charm, humour and confidence which delights his supporters and infuriates his enemies. McCain's campaign hallmark is his informality and accessibility. In town hall meetings around New Hampshire, he chats and answers any question. His minders do not mind - that's his style, and the media and his supporters love it. "I find that brief remarks are the most popular," he tells his audience in Franklin, cracking a few jokes before taking questions on a bewildering range of topics. It's hard to think of a politician who appears more at ease for so much of the time. Certainly not Bush, nor the two Democratic presidential hopefuls, Al Gore and Bill Bradley. They ask him about everything from pollution to Russia, from health to pornography, and most of the time he has something interesting to say. He is brilliant at excoriating the Clinton administration's foreign policy. "A photo-op, poll-driven foreign policy," he often dubs it. Other times, he calls it "foreign policy as social work". Not surprisingly, he is hot on military issues. Though he supported Clinton over Kosovo, he is scathing about the administration's tactics there. "Planes dropping bombs from 15,000ft, killing innocent people. There's something fundamentally immoral about that." During the Kosovo crisis, he says, the US moved an aircraft carrier from the Pacific to that theatre. "That was the first time since 1945 that we didn't have an aircraft carrier in the Pacific. Suppose that North Korea had chosen that moment to do something." Foreign policy, though, won't win or lose him the race for the nomination. Taxes might. While Bush offers a massive tax-cutting programme of half a trillion dollars over five years - promising "tax cuts, so help me God" in last week's New Hampshire debate - McCain remains steadfastly in the mainstream with most Democrats, in favour of some tax cuts, but not for the rich, an astonishing piece of audacity for a Republican. "I believe that rather than spending the surplus on tax cuts we have to make sure that social security is solvent," he tells the Franklin audience. "To use it all in tax cuts is a risky business. I know it sounds populist, but I'm not sure that millionaires and billionaires need a tax cut." He stands on a small platform in the middle of the hall holding a microphone. He never explicitly exploits his suffering, but everyone in the hall knows he cannot raise his arms above the shoulder because of his wounds, left untreated and neglected in Hanoi. Whenever a veteran speaks, McCain is visibly moved. Tears glisten more than once. Behind him is a banner that says Restoring Respect - McCain. He travels in a bus that he calls the Straight Talk Express. His television ads say The Character To Do Things Right. Though he has a legendary temper, he is unfailingly courteous on the stump. When anyone tells him about their own military experience - and lots of older voters do, often showing him photographs of themselves in their uniformed days - he always says "Thank you for serving". "Look at that man," says an awestruck staffer. "This guy is not stressed. He's having such a good time." More seasoned heads have been turned by McCain too. Bill Bennett, Ronald Reagan's education secretary and former "drugs tsar", told me in New Hampshire: "He brings back to the Oval Office what people have been missing. When he comes on TV, instead of people changing the channel they'll turn up the volume." McCain's openness to the press is counter-cultural in these times of limited access, over-anxious staffers, and ubiquitous security details. On the ride back from Franklin, 10 of us sit around in the back of the bus shooting the breeze with the candidate, while he talks at length about the campaign and the world. He tells us that he is confident about his opposition to massive tax cuts. "People don't press for them. That tells me that they want to pay down the debt, to protect social security. Most people are doing well. They feel a responsibility to those who might not be." All this has inevitably bred doubts in parts of the media. "It is a cliche in journalism circles these days to grouse that the media, in their coverage of McCain, are acting like schoolgirls at a Ricky Martin concert," wrote Eron Shosteck in the prestigious National Journal last week. "But the near-unanimity with which the media seem to have fallen in love with McCain is unprecedented in modern presidential politics. "His strategy of giving the media unlimited access has to be having an effect on his coverage. Indeed, some have even speculated that, in return for being so open, McCain has benefited from smitten reporters who have not reported potentially damaging comments an unguarded McCain has made in interviews." For there is another McCain that the world rarely sees. The Arizona Republic has repeatedly claimed that "it is time the rest of the nation learned about the John McCain we know in Arizona", and said there was "reason to seriously question whether he has the temperament, and the political approach and skills, we want in the next president". Two years ago, the Phoenix New Times went even further, calling McCain "a mean-spirited, hot-tempered, opportunistic, philandering, hypocritical political climber who married a comely beer heiress and used her daddy's money to get elected to congress in a state he can hardly call home". Last week, as if on cue, the McCain campaign hit a potentially serious glitch. The Boston Globe reported that McCain had used his position on a senate committee to press the federal communications commission to expedite its approval of a television station purchase by Paxson Communications, owned by a McCain supporter, Lowell Paxson. McCain has made four campaign trips in Paxson's private jet in recent months. McCain tried to brush the allegation off, but last Thursday's debate with Bush, held at the University of New Hampshire, hung on how McCain handled the issue under the television lights. Wasn't this hypocrisy, or at least poor judgment, the debate moderator asked McCain. His response was, by his standards, wary and long-winded, betraying an uncharacteristic anxiety not to say anything either glib or off-message. Rather than drive home his advantage, Bush said he was more concerned by McCain's preoccupation with campaign finance reform than this issue, but it had still been a difficult day for a man who presents himself as Mr Clean. "If you're explaining you're losing," said Bush's media strategist after the debate. In a bar afterwards, McCain reviews his performance with supporters. He cracks jokes, pumps up his team. "There's only 26 days, four hours and six minutes before the polls open," McCain tells them. "We'll be entertaining and informative and we'll be able to take the positions that we believe in. Let me just give you an example. Cindy has asked me to give a 45-minute speech on the North Korean nuclear build-up." The campaign workers collapse in laughter and applause, as they always do. Can McCain win? It's definitely an outside bet. He is ahead in New Hampshire, one of those states where independents, who love McCain, can vote in the primary. Bush's cash juggernaut and superior organisation give him the advantage almost everywhere else. If McCain wins New Hampshire, though, he'll be on a roll that could change everything. Yet the party establishment, lined up behind Bush, is prepared in states where McCain has hardly campaigned yet. The toughest fight for McCain is the one for the nomination. If he wins at the Republican convention in July, his broad appeal could make him a very plausible candidate against the Democrats in November. President McCain? A First Lady called Cindy? As Bill Bradley likes to say of his own insurgent campaign, it can happen.

webTitle: Protest at Libyan missile parts find

fields.headline: Protest at Libyan missile parts find
fields.trailText: Britain is to lodge a protest with Colonel Muammar Gadafy's government after an illegal consignment of Scud missile parts bound for Libya was seized at Gatwick.
fields.body:
Britain is to lodge a protest with Colonel Muammar Gadafy's government after an illegal consignment of Scud missile parts bound for Libya was seized at Gatwick.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, has instructed Britain's ambassador in Libya, Richard Dalton, to express deep concern over the incident.

"He will emphasise that this clear breach of the EU arms embargo is unacceptable and that there must be no repetition," Mr Cook said.

But Britain will not take punitive action against Libya such as breaking off relations again. Negotiations on the appointment of a Libyan ambassador to Britain will continue.

Parts for the missiles, which are capable of carrying chemical or biological warheads, were found on a flight bound for Tripoli on November 24. They were disguised as car spares and hidden in 32 crates.

The parts, believed to have originated in Taiwan, could have helped Libya increase its missile range, possibly to as far as parts of southern Italy.

No protest was lodged at the time by the foreign office because customs and excise officers immediately began an investigation and had not wanted to alert the Libyans.

MI5, which has targeted Libyans in the UK to gather intelligence about the spread of weapons of mass destruction, was involved in the operation.

"Our investigations are continuing and no further details are being released at the moment," a customs and excise spokesman said yesterday.

Britain restored diplomatic ties with Libya last July. They were cut 15 years earlier, following the shooting of PC Yvonne Fletcher outside the Libyan embassy in London. Mr Dalton took up his post last month.

Mr Cook was unrepentant yesterday about the restoration of ties. Defending the decision, he said that at the time Britain recommended the EU arms embargo on Libya be maintained. "This latest incident demonstrates that we were right not to relax our controls. We will remain vigilant."

The shadow foreign secretary, John Maples, said he would be pressing Mr Cook on reports that other missile parts had been smuggled through Britain to Libya.

Libya is a relatively wealthy country, despite the UN trade embargo imposed after the 1988 Lockerbie bombing, but it has no technological base to improve the range of its arsenal of some 100 Soviet-built Scud missiles, which can travel only 200 miles.

According to western intelligence, China, North Korea, Iran, Iraq, Russia and Serbia have all offered technical help as well as hardware.

Libya has had its eye on North Korea's No Dong missile which has a 600-mile range.

webTitle: Holidaymakers to help toad in a hole

fields.headline: Holidaymakers to help toad in a hole
fields.trailText: The National Trust has announced a range of working holidays to raise awareness of Britain's threatened environments and offer an alternative to "boring" beach holidays.
fields.body:
Holidaymakers are to be offered the chance to swap the natural habitat of the beach bum for that of the endangered natterjack toad and a week of hard graft this summer.

The National Trust has announced a range of working holidays to raise awareness of Britain's threatened environments and offer an alternative to "boring" beach holidays.

Launching the trust's working holidays programme, David Bellamy, the botanist and TV presenter, said the holidays offered an unparalleled opportunity to learn more about the environment.

"Not only will you learn the age-old skills of landscape management, but you will be in the company of local experts who will open your eyes to the living wonders of our coastline," he said.

"If you are tempted to say 'I am too old, or not fit enough', I can assure you that there is a whole range of important jobs to be done. I can also guarantee that you will be fitter at the end of your working holiday, whether it's beside the seaside or in deep countryside."

Among the holidays on offer is a week at Formby, Merseyside, where wardens will instruct volunteers how to develop habitats for the natterjack toad and a tiny population of red squirrels that persists along this stretch of the west coast.

At Lacock abbey in Wiltshire there will be a chance to join in an archaeological excavation of a lost garden, while in April at Dolaucothi, Carmarthenshire, volunteers can spend their Easter break improving footpaths and access to goldmines above the Cothi valley.

Other schemes include replanting the formal gardens at Waddesdon manor, Buckinghamshire, goat-herding on the Isle of Wight, beachcombing at Chyvarloe in Cornwall, and, for those of an excitable disposition, counting sheep on Lundy Island (selected dates between March and September).

Finally, in a scheme that may reveal more about the economic realities facing the National Trust than the environment it works to protect, volunteers can work unpaid as stewards at a concert by the Queen tribute band Magic at Bodiam castle in Kent.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Novelist Tranter dies aged 90
fields.body:
Novelist Tranter dies aged 90

The Scottish author, Nigel Tranter, has died peacefully at the age of 90 at his home in Gullane, East Lothian, his family said. He had more than 130 works published, mainly novels and historical works.

Delia boosts Swiss powder

Distributors of Marigold Swiss bouillon vegetable powder are preparing to step up production after TV cook Delia Smith named it as a "first prize" essential in a store cupboard.

Giles leaves BBC job
Weatherman Bill Giles, who was cleared last year of allegations of bullying, is to step down from his job as head of the BBC team when his contract expires at the end of the month and take up a consultancy post.

Caesarean plea to save babies

Babies' lives could be saved if more doctors were willing to carry out an emergency caesarean section on a dead or dying woman in late pregnancy, according to a study for the Royal Society of Medicine by Laurie Irvine and Melissa Whitten of Watford general hospital.

Sea search scaled down

An air and sea search for Daniel Kebble, 22, of Polperro, Cornwall, was scaled down yesterday 24 hours after he was last seen on his 24ft craft Harbour Lights which later sank.

Double rollover

There will be a double rollover jackpot on Wednesday as none matched numbers 13, 18, 32, 34, 39 and 41 for the £23.3m on offer on Saturday. The bonus was 2. There were no Thunderball winners, when balls 4, 8, 9 and 16 and 17 with Thunderball 4, were drawn.

webTitle: Historians scorn claims over Thomas More's cell

fields.headline: Historians scorn claims over Thomas More's cell
fields.standfirst: 'No basis' for assertion made to tourists at Tower of London
fields.trailText: Historians have demolished the claim that a small white-washed cell at the Tower of London, which opens to the public for the first time today, was the last prison of Sir Thomas More.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, Arts and Heritage Correspondent
fields.body:
Historians have demolished the claim that a small white-washed cell at the Tower of London, which opens to the public for the first time today, was the last prison of Sir Thomas More.

To mark the millennium, Historic Royal Palaces, which manages the tower, will launch guided tours of the cell, and a display of historical material including the hairshirt worn by More, one of the most likeable figures in English history.

Visitors will be told the room is where More was held prisoner for 14 months, and that he walked from there to his death on Tower Green on July 6 1535. However the official Tower historian, Geoffrey Parnell, said: "There isn't a shred of evidence that More was ever held there."

More, who was canonised a Roman Catholic saint in 1935, was beheaded after he fell out with his patron Henry VIII over the act of supremacy, introduced in Henry's determination to break with Rome, divorce his first wife and marry Anne Boleyn.

More, who had been chief justice and lord chancellor, made his last jokes as he mounted the scaffold. He asked the tower governor: "I pray you, see me safe up, and for my coming down let me shift for myself."

There has been a tradition that the lower cell in the Bell Tower was More's prison. It was furnished earlier this century to resemble a chapel, with a kneeler, candle holders, and a portrait of More. A former governor, Chris Tyler, regularly invited a local order of nuns to pray in the cell.

It has never been open to the public because it can only be reached through the Queen's House, the private residence of the governor in More's time and now. It is now being opened to celebrate the millennium, as part of the London String of Pearls festival of riverside institutions.

However Dr Parnell, and the historical researcher Stephen Priestley, an expert on early manuscripts, have been tracking More through reams of documents on Tower history, and can find no evidence that he was ever in the cell, though he was certainly in the Tower of London. "There is no evidence at all that he was held in the Bell Tower, and some reasons why he was not likely to have been," Dr Parnell said.

Mr Priestley said: "It is really very frustrating because there is so much documentation about his imprisonment, his letters, details of his visitors, details of his interrogation, and you would think one of them would mention where he was held. But there is nothing."

The mystery deepened when Mr Priestley found an inventory of prisoners, tower by tower, taken on the day of More's execution, which does not mention his name. It is known that he was a prisoner there, because an earlier inventory mentions the cost maintaining him and his servant.

Thomas More was born in 1478, son of a London lawyer. When he became lord chancellor, the highest office in the land, he was renowned for his piety as well as his erudition and wit. With his head on the block, More moved his long grey beard out of the way, saying: "It were a pity it should be cut off, it has done no treason."

Henry commuted the original sentence of being hanged, drawn and quartered to beheading, and when he heard news of the execution, is said to have broken off playing cards and berated Anne for causing the death of a good man.

Dr Parnell and Mr Priestley believe the origin of the belief that he was held in the Bell Tower is because More's confidant, Archbishop John Fisher, executed on the same day, is known to have been held in the upper chamber.

"There is a record of More going up stairs to visit him, and I think people just assumed he was in the cell downstairs," Dr Parnell said. He believes the stairs connecting the two had already been demolished. He has already established that the chamber displayed as Anne Boleyn's was not built until two years after her beheading.

He thinks it is more likely that such an important prisoner would have been held, like Anne's daughter the young Princess Elizabeth, in the decaying and long since demolished medieval palace. He can only trace the Bell Tower tradition back to the 19th century and it seems likely the veneration of the cell as a shrine began in 1885 when More was beatified by Rome.

Mr Priestley said the documents showed the authorities were anxious to keep More and Fisher apart. More's pens and ink were confiscated when he persisted in writing to Fisher, and he wrote his last letters, including a moving one to his favourite daughter, Margaret, on the eve of his death, with a stub of burned stick.

A Historic Royal Palaces spokeswoman admitted: "We cannot be 100% sure that More was held in the Bell Tower, but it seems very likely"

Dr Parnell said: "It is the sort of story that everyone wanted to believe, but I think they just made an inspired guess."

fields.headline: Aids jab brings new hope
fields.trailText: A radically new Aids vaccine which could be the only hope for millions in Africa is to be tested in a government-backed research unit to be launched in Oxford today.
fields.body:
A radically new Aids vaccine which could be the only hope for millions in Africa is to be tested in a government-backed research unit to be launched in Oxford today.

The Oxford approach is the latest in a score of attempts to find a vaccine for a virus which is infecting 16,000 people a day. One or two are still in trials, but most have been disappointments. But Andrew McMichael, head of the new medical research council unit, believes the latest vaccine has a "better than 50-50 chance" - higher than any other so far.

The council's human immunology unit at Oxford university is about to try the new HIV vaccine on volunteers in Britain. The team will then work with scientists in Nairobi on larger trials in groups most at risk later this year.

Most vaccines work by promoting antibodies which recognise an invading virus and summon up the resources of the immune system to destroy it. But the HIV virus has for two decades proved a bewildering enemy. It changes its coat with astonishing rapidity, disguising itself from antibody recognition. And it targets the immune system, invading the killer T-lymphocytes, or white blood cells that normally destroy viruses, and using them to replicate itself. The Oxford group has been working, with partners in Kenya, on a vaccine that kicks the T-cells into action at the first sign of the virus.

"The hope is that the immune system will get in ahead of the virus so that it never really gets established," said Professor McMichael. "The immune system is very big, it involves billions of cells, so you can afford to have a few thousand or even a few million infected - and if they can be dealt with, you won't damage the immune system."

Since its first identification, the HIV virus has infected 50m people, and so far killed 16m. Although infection in Britain and the US has been concentrated among drug-users and the gay community, most of the infection in the developing world has been among heterosexuals. There is no cure - but recently a cocktail of specially developed drugs has, in the west, restored health to many who had expected to die. But the treatment costs up to £10,000 a year per patient - far beyond the reach of most people in Africa or Asia.

The new approach was inspired by a study of a number of prostitutes in Kenya who have puzzlingly resisted infection, even though they have been most at risk - as if they were equipped with natural resistance to a virus which in parts of Africa infects more than one in five adults.

The new vaccine is made from the tiny segment of DNA from the HIV virus that stimulates a response in the T-cells, delivered with the oldest weapon in the vaccine arsenal, the vaccinia virus that 200 years ago opened the scientific war against smallpox. It is proven safe, but the first safety trials will, in any case, be on UK volunteers.

"There is always this accusation just under the surface that we are using Africans as guinea pigs," said Prof McMichael. "We are using our volunteers here as guinea pigs."

But Andrew McMichael, head of the new medical research council unit, believes the latest vaccine has a "better than 50-50 chance" - higher than any other so far. The council's human immunology unit at Oxford university is about to try the new HIV vaccine on volunteers in Britain. The team will then work with scientists in Nairobi on larger trials in groups most at risk later this year.
