fields.headline: Dover soul
fields.standfirst: White cliffs to get a facelift
fields.trailText: It's over half a century since Dame Vera Lynn stirred the hearts of the British with a tale of bluebirds over the White Cliffs of Dover. Since then things have gone rather downhill at this symbol of British resistance to would-be continental invaders from Napoleon to Hitler.
fields.body:
It's over half a century since Dame Vera Lynn stirred the hearts of the British with a tale of bluebirds over the White Cliffs of Dover.

Since then things have gone rather downhill at this symbol of British resistance to would-be continental invaders from Napoleon to Hitler.

Visitors to the town and those arriving by ferry from the continent have long been disappointed if they wanted to take in the attractions of the cliffs.

Although there is Grand Shaft staircase - a triple spiral inside the cliffs, open to the public in the summer - most of the cliff area is derelict.

The staircase is a remarkable leftover from a series of military forts begun in 1780 and extended until the end of the second world war. These were demolished in 1965 and piles of masonry were left on site. The area has since become a rubbish tip, and home to drug dealers, bootleggers and vandals.

But now Dover council has stepped in with a £250,000 plan to restore the cliffs (pictured above) to their glorious best so they can be used as a picnic spot and as a tourist attraction. The rubbish will be cleared, the trees and bushes covering the area cut down, and the meadows restored at the top of the cliffs.

Nigel Rembridge, chief architect at Dover council, said: "There never were any bluebirds as far as I know but the Western Heights, as they are known, are designated a site of national heritage importance.

"The area is a disgrace at the moment, a place of crime which is badly overgrown with trees and shrubs. There are pits where the fortifications used to be which are frankly dangerous. We are going to clean the area up so that ordinary people can enjoy it again. We will rope it off and make it safe so people don't fall off the cliffs or down the holes. It will be a splendid place again."

webTitle: Adams faces US pressure on arms deadlock

fields.headline: Adams faces US pressure on arms deadlock
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams, will meet Bill Clinton on Wednesday as controversy over IRA decommissioning returns to the boil after a six-week honeymoon period for Northern Ireland's power-sharing government.
fields.body:
The Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams, will meet Bill Clinton on Wednesday as controversy over IRA decommissioning returns to the boil after a six-week honeymoon period for Northern Ireland's power-sharing government.

Weapons are likely to top the agenda at the White House. Mr Clinton is insistent that republicans fulfil their obligations on decommissioning just as the Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble did on backing devolution, despite party reluctance, two months ago.

However, Sinn Fein did not anticipate Mr Clinton laying down the law.

During a six-day trip to the United States, Mr Adams and Martin McGuinness, Sinn Fein's two Westminster MPs, and Caoimhghin O Caolain, its sole representative in the Dail, will address supporters in the Irish-American lobby.

The last such visit was just before Sinn Fein signalled a switch in policy and joined the negotiations leading to the Good Friday agreement.

Mr Trimble, the first minister, has said that he and his three ministers will quit the Northern Ireland government next month if there has been no start to IRA weapons decommissioning. Such a move would cause the fledgling executive to collapse.

Mr McGuinness said it was "inconceivable" that the executive could fall over the weapons issue. Criticising Mr Trimble's demand for decommissioning, he said that for him to walk away now would be to take a more extreme position than that of Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionist party.

Mr McGuinness told BBC Radio Ulster: "We're all on board the same boat now. We're still in the harbour, but we're moving forward. I think anyone who jumps off at this stage will be drowned."

His comments jarred with newspaper reports yesterday claiming that the IRA was poised to begin decommissioning this month. The stories appeared to emanate from Downing Street.

But sources close to General John de Chastelain's international commission on decommissioning indicated that it had received no evidence yet that the IRA was about to decommission. The arms body feels that raising expectations at this stage is unhelpful.

The reports claimed the IRA had asked the general to witness an explosion in which a few guns would be destroyed in a symbolic gesture.

They also suggested that the IRA would then be prepared to have the remainder of its arsenal sealed in underground bunkers in the Irish Republic.

But the commission has received no such invitation.

The commission's mandate is to verify weapons destruction, and the British and Irish governments would have to alter it to make sealed bunkers an option. Many Unionists would find it unacceptable.

Yesterday's rash of articles was the second time in a month that correspondents on Sunday broadsheets had written about the imminence of IRA decommissioning. The thrust last time was that it would have begun next week. That baffled the arms body.

The commission is due to issue a critical report by the end of this month. Last month it hinted at frustration, suggesting it would put forward its own decommissioning timetable if the IRA failed to do so.

The IRA's intentions are unclear. Recent statements have clouded its approach, with Mr Trimble accusing it of dragging its feet.

The IRA has called on Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, to begin scaling down military operations in the province. Government officials believe that could tempt the IRA to decommission, but Mr Mandelson's spokesman denied speculation yesterday that a move to cut troop levels hugely was imminent.

webTitle: GP on misconduct charge over 'at risk' inmate

fields.headline: GP on misconduct charge over 'at risk' inmate
fields.standfirst: More about the NHS
fields.trailText: A GP will be accused at the General Medical Council today of falsely certifying that he had found fit a prisoner about to be transferred from Guernsey to Winchester jail and who, two days later, hanged himself.
fields.body:
A GP will be accused at the General Medical Council today of falsely certifying that he had found fit a prisoner about to be transferred from Guernsey to Winchester jail and who, two days later, hanged himself.

Marilyn Vidamour, the mother of Philip Webb, 25, has been campaigning for an inquiry into the death of her son, who had a history of drug problems.

She and her husband heard that Webb, who was in jail for attempted theft, was to be moved from Guernsey hours before he was put on a flight to the mainland.

"I pleaded with Guernsey not to send him," she said. "We - and he - had only three hours' notice that he was being sent away. He knew he could not handle it. He said: 'Mum, what have I done? I have been doing all right'. I kissed him goodbye and told him I loved him."

The meeting, on July 14 1998, was the last time Mrs Vidamour saw her son alive.

Prison records show that the visiting GP, Simon Bodkin, saw Webb that day and signed a paper which stated he was fit for transfer. But he did not see him. Webb was to be "ghosted" out of the prison - moved without his prior knowledge.

He was viewed by the governor as a troublemaker after he smashed up his cell and incited others to do the same. It was a mini-riot and he was held responsible. The governor wanted him transferred, for control reasons and to set an example to others.

But staff were worried that he might cause trouble if he knew he was to be sent from Guernsey, where he had lived all his life.

The senior hospital medical officer told the assistant governor, Richard Rouillard, that Webb must be seen by a doctor and certified fit. But Mr Rouillard said he did not want Webb alerted.

Dr Bodkin was asked to sign the form without visiting the prisoner. He looked at Webb's medical records, heard from the senior medical officer that the prisoner seemed fine, and then, with some reluctance and anxiety, he will tell the GMC, he signed.

Webb was seen by a doctor at Winchester. "He said Philip did not give any indication he was going to harm himself," said Mrs Vidamour.

"But you know your own children. He wouldn't have told that to anybody he didn't know."

Dr Bodkin will appear before the GMC's disciplinary committee accused of gross professional misconduct.

fields.headline: Composer's West End coup
fields.standfirst: Lloyd-Webber buys 10 more theatres for £87m
fields.trailText: For 20 years his musicals have made him master of London's West End. Now Andrew Lloyd-Webber is the owner of most of it as well.
fields.body:
For 20 years his musicals have made him master of London's West End. Now Andrew Lloyd-Webber is the owner of most of it as well.

The composer of such mega musical hits as Evita, Jesus Christ Superstar, Cats and Phantom of the Opera - which has taken twice as much in box office receipts worldwide as Titanic - has bought London's biggest theatre empire for £87.5m.

Lloyd-Webber quickly denied he was buying up the West End so he could fill it with his own work. "My God, I hope I'm not," he joked.

His spokesman, Daniel Bee, said not even a composer of Lloyd-Webber's prolific and "prodigious talents" could possibly fill 13 theatres at once.

The deal for Stoll Moss - which owns such renowned West End theatres as the London Palladium, the Garrick and the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane - was finally sealed yesterday following a long drawn-out auction over the new year.

It makes Lord Lloyd Webber - who famously threatened to quit the country if Labour won the last election - the undisputed king of theatreland and one of the world's most powerful impresarios.

It also sees off the looming American threat to the West End after the Apollo Group and its 23, mostly regional, theatres and arenas were swallowed up last year by the US entertainment giant SFX for £157m.

With the box offices booming, and London property prices soaring, SFX had been eyeing some of Stoll Moss's 10 large West End houses - though monopoly laws would probably have prevented their buying them all up.

Even so, with their subsidiary, the Ambassadors Group, bidding for the eight-strong chain of smaller Crescent theatres, there had been fears that US domination would at best water down the West End's unique diversity of drama, and at worst turn it into the kind of theatrical theme park that many claim New York's Broadway has become since the advent of Disney's Beauty and the Beast and The Lion King.

Lloyd-Webber said he was worried that, if he did not act, London's theatres would fall into the hands of conglomerates "who wouldn't necessarily understand [that] the thing about the theatre is you have got to take risks".

His spokesman said the composer did not step in purely out of the goodness of his heart. "It has to be very good news for London, with so many theatres being snapped up by the Americans. It's very important such historic names stay in British ownership," Mr Bee said.

"There is no danger whatsoever of just putting on musicals. These are commercial theatres - they all have to make money - and you can't just do one thing."

Lloyd-Webber's Really Useful Group, which already owns the Palace and New London theatres and has a half share in the Adelphi theatre, will control the theatres' artistic output - though most of the cash for the deal came from Nat West Equity Partners, which will hold a 50% stake.

Stoll Moss's chief executive, Richard Johnson, will stay on, and widespread redundancies are not expected.

Lloyd-Webber himself will not take a seat on the board, but will "do what I do best, which is the creative side".

He is midway through writing a musical about the Northern Irish Troubles with the comedian Ben Elton, based on the experiences of a west Belfast Gaelic football team. He is also working on an Indian-themed musical.

Lloyd-Webber bought back his Really Useful Group after a disastrous flotation on the stock market. With the company holding the rights to most of his work, he was fearful it would fall into the hands of others.

He bought his first theatre, the Palace - home of Cameron Mackintosh's Les Misérables - in 1983 and has never made a secret of yearning for more.

"He's very proud indeed of this deal," said Mr Bee. "His love for the theatre, its history and architecture, is well known. It is a dream come true for him."

Under the mercurial Janet Holmes à Court, Stoll Moss led a West End revival with a mix of comedies, populist musicals, starry revivals of the odd classic and some new dramas. However, after years of wrangling, she was forced to sell up by banks owed millions by her late husband's Australian company, Heytesbury.

Her son, Peter Holmes à Court, now a producer in New York, tried unsuccessfully to buy the group with the media magnate Kerry Packer. Meanwhile, the former Channel 4 chief Michael Grade led another consortium of bidders backed by a City investment fund.

The impresario Mackintosh, who has lately been investing in bricks and mortar from the proceeds of Miss Saigon and Les Misérables, is due to hold the lease on two Stoll Moss theatres from 2006 - the Queens and the Gielgud.

fields.headline: The eyes have it
fields.trailText: In my lifetime the cop show has moved from the "Evening, all" comforts of Dixon Of Dock Green to the disturbing honesty of Cops. We have all probably seen enough of them to last us several lifetimes, but the TV factories have to keep turning them out to meet the specifications of commisioning editors. We have seen so many crime scenes and watched so many investigations that we imagine we could run a murder inquiry as well most TV detectives. We should, then, spare a thought for the writers who have to find some new twist to keep us interested.
fields.body:
In my lifetime the cop show has moved from the "Evening, all" comforts of Dixon Of Dock Green to the disturbing honesty of Cops. We have all probably seen enough of them to last us several lifetimes, but the TV factories have to keep turning them out to meet the specifications of commisioning editors. We have seen so many crime scenes and watched so many investigations that we imagine we could run a murder inquiry as well most TV detectives. We should, then, spare a thought for the writers who have to find some new twist to keep us interested.

Second Sight (BBC1) quickly establishes itself as a bog-standard cop show. Clive Owen plays DCI Ross Tanner, a competent, macho cop, prone to tell his female colleage, DI Catherine Tully, that "we carry no passengers, take no prisoners". Or telling her, when she gets too intuitive and psychological, that "there's time for psychobabble when we've got the big picture". He must, of course, have some background and it turns out to be of a rather Nick Hornby/Tony Parsons kind. Ross is separated from his wife, doesn't have enough time to watch the match with his son. With all this predictable stuff, there must be something new to catch our interest. What will it be?

Oddly enough the interest turns out to be optometric - DCI Ross Tanner is going blind, his retina is being attacked by a virus. There is no treatment for this rare disease and, being a macho cop, Tanner is ill prepared to cope with this disaster. He smashes up a toilet in a nightclub to show us his inner turmoil but we also get to see the world through his failing eyes, and watch as he tries to learn little tricks that will prevent his colleagues from noticing that his sight is going.

Who should be first to notice but DI Catherine Tully (Claire Skinner), the most touchy-feely cop in the force. Tanner asks her to watch every gesture of a murder suspect in a press conference. "Be your eyes, you mean?" she says, not yet knowing about his eyesight problems. Before long she is stroking his face (so there's our love interest), being rejected and finally offering Tanner a deal. She will be his second pair of eyes if he lets her have a fair chance to contribute to their new murder inquiry, keeps his macho colleagues off her back and lets her have the credit, in writing, for any successes she may have.

Tanner is is no position to refuse. Can he compensate for his failing sight by feeling his way into the minds of his suspects? Just as the X Files plays with gender reversal - male agent has a feminine faith in what he sees, female agent turns out to be sceptical in a rather masculine kind of way - so Second Sight has a macho cop learning to empathise and a female cop showing how professionally male she can be.

Second Sight is, then, rather promising (a second series has already been commisioned) and is nicely acted, filmed and directed. The only drawback to the interest we feel in Tanner's dilemma is that it is rather hard to give a damn about the case he is working on. Perhaps we will warm to that next week.

Second Sight was a good bit of entertainment in a dull weekend's television. I really couldn't get interested in seeing what happened to the army cadets in Soldiers To Be (BBC1). Who cares if a female cadet fails (or passes) her driving test? So what if bayonet practice is tough. One series was plenty.

I had hoped to tell you about Bubble Trouble on BBC2, which tells of speculative fever in Japan, but the preview tape arrived too late. In one of those unfortunate clashes, Channel 4 chose the same time slot to start a very promising new series called British Empires , telling stories of British businesses that reflect the troubles of the British economy over the last 100 years. One of the best programmes of last year was The Mayfair Set, which told us of the exploits of Jimmy Goldsmith and friends. The Mayfair Set convinced us that for most of the last 50 years British governments, investors and financial journalists didn't have a clue what was going on in the economy. How gullible most of us are when it comes to economics. There is something of the same flavour to British Empires. As we followed the messy history of Nat West, the same thoughts came back to us: Do the people who run the country know what they are doing? No. Like poor DCI Tanner they are groping in the dark. Still, Gordon Brown has cracked it, hasn't he?
fields.bodyText: In my lifetime the cop show has moved from the "Evening, all" comforts of Dixon Of Dock Green to the disturbing honesty of Cops. We have all probably seen enough of them to last us several lifetimes, but the TV factories have to keep turning them out to meet the specifications of commisioning editors. We have seen so many crime scenes and watched so many investigations that we imagine we could run a murder inquiry as well most TV detectives. We should, then, spare a thought for the writers who have to find some new twist to keep us interested. Second Sight (BBC1) quickly establishes itself as a bog-standard cop show. Clive Owen plays DCI Ross Tanner, a competent, macho cop, prone to tell his female colleage, DI Catherine Tully, that "we carry no passengers, take no prisoners". Or telling her, when she gets too intuitive and psychological, that "there's time for psychobabble when we've got the big picture". He must, of course, have some background and it turns out to be of a rather Nick Hornby/Tony Parsons kind. Ross is separated from his wife, doesn't have enough time to watch the match with his son. With all this predictable stuff, there must be something new to catch our interest. What will it be? Oddly enough the interest turns out to be optometric - DCI Ross Tanner is going blind, his retina is being attacked by a virus. There is no treatment for this rare disease and, being a macho cop, Tanner is ill prepared to cope with this disaster. He smashes up a toilet in a nightclub to show us his inner turmoil but we also get to see the world through his failing eyes, and watch as he tries to learn little tricks that will prevent his colleagues from noticing that his sight is going. Who should be first to notice but DI Catherine Tully (Claire Skinner), the most touchy-feely cop in the force. Tanner asks her to watch every gesture of a murder suspect in a press conference. "Be your eyes, you mean?" she says, not yet knowing about his eyesight problems. Before long she is stroking his face (so there's our love interest), being rejected and finally offering Tanner a deal. She will be his second pair of eyes if he lets her have a fair chance to contribute to their new murder inquiry, keeps his macho colleagues off her back and lets her have the credit, in writing, for any successes she may have. Tanner is is no position to refuse. Can he compensate for his failing sight by feeling his way into the minds of his suspects? Just as the X Files plays with gender reversal - male agent has a feminine faith in what he sees, female agent turns out to be sceptical in a rather masculine kind of way - so Second Sight has a macho cop learning to empathise and a female cop showing how professionally male she can be. Second Sight is, then, rather promising (a second series has already been commisioned) and is nicely acted, filmed and directed. The only drawback to the interest we feel in Tanner's dilemma is that it is rather hard to give a damn about the case he is working on. Perhaps we will warm to that next week. Second Sight was a good bit of entertainment in a dull weekend's television. I really couldn't get interested in seeing what happened to the army cadets in Soldiers To Be (BBC1). Who cares if a female cadet fails (or passes) her driving test? So what if bayonet practice is tough. One series was plenty. I had hoped to tell you about Bubble Trouble on BBC2, which tells of speculative fever in Japan, but the preview tape arrived too late. In one of those unfortunate clashes, Channel 4 chose the same time slot to start a very promising new series called British Empires , telling stories of British businesses that reflect the troubles of the British economy over the last 100 years. One of the best programmes of last year was The Mayfair Set, which told us of the exploits of Jimmy Goldsmith and friends. The Mayfair Set convinced us that for most of the last 50 years British governments, investors and financial journalists didn't have a clue what was going on in the economy. How gullible most of us are when it comes to economics. There is something of the same flavour to British Empires. As we followed the messy history of Nat West, the same thoughts came back to us: Do the people who run the country know what they are doing? No. Like poor DCI Tanner they are groping in the dark. Still, Gordon Brown has cracked it, hasn't he?

fields.headline: The life of spice
fields.standfirst: It was a terrible idea, but Channel 4's Victoria's Secrets - where Posh Spice dons the mantle of interviewer - is still compelling TV. Even so,  Mark Lawson  has doubts about the future for celebrity presenters
fields.trailText: Channel 4 has had many different ambitions over the years - including to be daring, distinctive, multi-cultural and movie-making - but few can have imagined that one of its prime functions would be to reveal the bleak inner life of the Spice Girls.
fields.body:
Channel 4 has had many different ambitions over the years - including to be daring, distinctive, multi-cultural and movie-making - but few can have imagined that one of its prime functions would be to reveal the bleak inner life of the Spice Girls.

But after Molly Dineen's devastating documentary, Geri, last year, which showed the coldness and loneliness of Ginger's existence - the network now screens Victoria's Secrets (10pm, Tuesday), a one-off chat-show hosted by Victoria Adams Beckham, better known as Posh.

Whatever you may think of Channel 4's judgement in making this programme, it certainly has luck. A film with a title which puns on a lingerie shop is now transmitted the week after Posh admitted (on another Channel 4 programme, The Big Breakfast) that David Beckham liked to wear her thongs, thus causing him to prove his machismo against transvestite references from the terraces with a brutal flying tackle which earned another sending-off.

But, if the chief executive of Channel 4 sends a card to Posh after this programme, it should certainly be a red one. The chat show in which both presenter and guests are celebrities has long been a TV chimera. Harold Wilson's biggest humiliation apart from the devaluation of the pound was his post-premiership stint as host of BBC2's Friday Night, Saturday Morning. The Duchess of York's talk-show was a low-spot even in the schedules of Sky One.

Perhaps because Wilson and Fergie and other celeb presenters failed in a studio setting - where tyros are more likely to be exposed by ignorance of the technology - Victoria's Secrets is a curious travelling chat-show in which the hostess is seen in limos or on aeroplanes going to meet guests including Vinnie Jones, the designer Valentino, Mirror editor Piers Morgan and actor Richard E Grant. During these interludes, the would-be presenter is herself interviewed by a disembodied voice.

As her main follow-up question is "Really?" - and her central theme is the irritations of the celebrity lifestyle - Posh as an interviewer makes Harold Wilson look like his fellow Yorkshireman Michael Parkinson. Rapidly realising this, producer Gillian Wilson and director Sue Hills increasingly edge the piece towards documentary. Indeed - rather in the way that people helping police with their inquiries are suspects rather than witnesses - it may be that the programme-makers encouraged Posh's vain and hopeless ambition to be an interviewer in order to covertly make a film about her.

Certainly a programme which gets nothing from the guests is genuinely revelatory about the presenter. Woody Allen has devoted two whole movies (Stardust Memories and Celebrity) to attempting to depict the seductive but destructive chamber which is fame but Channel 4 has said far more about the nature of stardom in these two slices of Spice life: Geri and Victoria's Secrets.

In one bizarre sequence, the film-makers persuade their hostess to go shopping in Sainsbury's with a camera concealed in her armpit. Genuinely unsure whether it would be better to be recognised or not recognised - because celebrities fear privacy although they claim to crave it - she is finally approached by an evangelist who has had a dream revealing that the Spice Girls need Jesus in their life. Meanwhile, a burly minder hovers nervously nearby.

In a few scenes like these - which genuinely give viewers that rare view from inside the smoked-glass limo windows - a really bad idea for a programme becomes a compelling one. There is an electrifying sequence in which Posh goes shopping in a Virgin Megastore with Elton John. Grabbing CDs in triplicate - one for the South of France, one for Atlanta, one for here - he contributes the only decent interview of the film, although it is conducted in reverse.

What do you think of Geri's album?, he wonders. Um, replies Posh. How do you get on with the manager of Manchester United?, he follows up. Not having seen the rest of the programme, Elton can't know that he is giving her a cruel lesson in how to be a celebrity interviewer but the dismissal of her prospects is as final as a footballer's sending off.

In the programme's final interview, Posh attempts to interrogate her husband in a dressing room. He is stubbornly wearing a bandana indoors, exposing again the paradox that a man who is clearly so thin-skinned should offer so many provocations to mocking. The gurgles of baby Brooklyn float spookily upwards, as they spasmodically do in the film because his parents have clearly ordered the cameras to ignore him. Because of lust and love and gaucheness, Posh is unable to ask any questions.

This serious weakness in a would-be interviewer should logically be the end of television's flirtation with celebrity presenters. London viewers might also make a note to avoid the return of Edward Windsor with Crown And Country (Tuesday, 10.30pm, Thames). But a failed chat-show becomes another fascinating film about fame. Two Spice Girls, though, should be enough for Channel 4. No Mel: A Documentary or Sporty's Secrets please.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: From 1863 successive headmasters of Chalfont St Peter's Church of England Middle School maintained a journal not only of events in the school but of those affecting its pupils and their families. Throughout the week in The Village School (3.45pm, Radio 4) Michael Williams reads excerpts to paint a picture of 100 years of social change in one community. Dr Katherine Bailey, an educational historian, rounds it out with assessments of the school by visiting government and church inspectors.
fields.body:
From 1863 successive headmasters of Chalfont St Peter's Church of England Middle School maintained a journal not only of events in the school but of those affecting its pupils and their families. Throughout the week in The Village School (3.45pm, Radio 4) Michael Williams reads excerpts to paint a picture of 100 years of social change in one community. Dr Katherine Bailey, an educational historian, rounds it out with assessments of the school by visiting government and church inspectors.

When farmer Gary Coomber first tilled his Kentish fields 35 years ago he could manage easily with a 35hp tractor. Now it takes a 100hp engine to turn over their densely compacted soils, and the cost of fertilisers threatens to exceed the value of the resulting crops. Not surprisingly, he is planning to adopt organic methods in the hope of rehabilitating the land. In Costing The Earth (9.0pm, Radio 4) Alex Kirby investigates Britain's alarming decline in soil productivity.

fields.headline: Marion Sarafis
fields.standfirst: A love affair with Greece and with a hero of its resistance in war and peace
fields.trailText: The Philhelline, editor and writer, Marion Sarafis, who has died aged 86, was the widow of the Greek Popular Liberation Army (ELAS) second world war commander, General Stefanos Sarafis.
fields.body:
The Philhelline, editor and writer, Marion Sarafis, who has died aged 86, was the widow of the Greek Popular Liberation Army (ELAS) second world war commander, General Stefanos Sarafis.

She was the only child of an Anglo-Austrian family, born in its substantial family house, Bracken Hill, in Woking. It remained her lifelong haven. She was educated at home and convent school, and read classics at Oxford university.

Following a Cambridge postgraduate archaeology course, she travelled to Athens in 1936, and joined the British School of Archaeology. From 1937-39, she worked and wrote on excavations at Lasithi in Crete, uncovering two statues now in the Heraklion museum.

While researching in Milos, she met Sarafis, a leading leftist republican in internal exile for his part in the 1935 coup, which opposed the monarchical restoration. A romantic attachment slowly developed during walks on the island's hills within sight of the supervising gendarme in the café below. But their friendship was broken off by the second world war.

In 1939, she offered her services to the British embassy in Athens, but was turned down, she believed, because of her friendship with Sarafis. Back in England she worked tirelessly for Greek relief efforts. During the civil war which followed the German defeat, she was a founder member of the League for Democracy in Greece, which campaigned for the release of imprisoned resistance fighters and for those, like Sarafis, in internal exile. It also lobbied for human rights in Greece.

In 1951, she edited an English edition of his book, Greek Resistance Army: The Story of ELAS. Work on the text meant correspondence throughout the late 40s and their affection grew. Back in Greece, a mutual friend told her that "the general", as she called him, reciprocated her love, but given his reticence would never articulate it. Marion proposed. They married in 1952.

Five intensely happy years followed in the Athenian seaside suburb of Alimos. Self-effacingly, she supported his campaigning for the United Democratic Left party. Then, in 1957, they were hit by a vehicle driven by an American serviceman. The general was killed and Marion's right leg was shattered and ineptly set; it bowed outwards, leaving her with what she referred to as "hammer and sickle legs".

She returned to England, where she devoted much of her time to keeping up Bracken Hill, pursuing interests, from reading English, French, German, Modern Greek and Latin to music, theatre and gallery going. She maintained her interest in Greece, retained her Greek citizenship and was an active campaigner during the 1967-74 colonels' dictatorship. With the downfall of that junta, she paid brief visits to Greece, but concentrated on new editions of her husband's writings and also works about the resistance, working with the late Martin Eve of Merlin Press and the University of North London. There was a new Greek edition of Greek Resistance Army in 1980, conference proceedings (Greece: From Resistance to Civil War), a memoir (General Sarafis As I Knew Him) and joint editorship of Background to Contemporary Greece, essays by a new generation of academics. She donated the league's archives to King's College, London and catalogued them. She also worked for the British committee for the restitution of the Parthenon marbles.

Her forbidding manner masked her shyness. To those who knew her well, she had a great sense of humour and compassion. She could not abide pomposity or self-importance. A technophobe, she refused to have a telephone in the house. Television and computers overwhelmed her and she hammered out her correspondence on an ancient typewriter, using every inch of space on her pale blue Army and Navy stationery.

 Marion Sarafis (Pascoe), archaeologist, editor, activist, born December 8 1913; died December 10 1999

fields.headline: Mick Gillies
fields.standfirst: Nemesis of malarial mosquitoes
fields.trailText: Mick Gillies, who has died aged 79, devoted most of his life to research on African malaria mosquitoes, among them one described as "the most dangerous animal in the world". By transmitting the causative agent of malignant malaria,  Anopheles gambiae is responsible for more than 1m deaths in Africa each year.
fields.body:
Mick Gillies, who has died aged 79, devoted most of his life to research on African malaria mosquitoes, among them one described as "the most dangerous animal in the world". By transmitting the causative agent of malignant malaria, Anopheles gambiae is responsible for more than 1m deaths in Africa each year.

At Winchester College, Gillies already had a fondness for natural history. He was taught fly fishing by his father, and at 15 took up his father's suggestion that he study mayflies, a part of the diet of fish. He retained a lifelong fascination with these aquatic insects. Gillies followed his father into medicine, and in 1945-47 served as an army medical officer in India, Malaya and Hong Kong (also indulging his passion for natural history).

He completed his medical training in England in 1948, and then spent a year as the medical officer of the British embassy in Moscow. This was a critical time for Gillies; his love of natural history and fascination with the tropics led him to forsake medicine.

In 1950, after training, he joined the East African Institute of Malaria as an entomologist, and for 12 years worked in Tanganyika's coastal foothills, where malaria was rife. Following the birth of independent Tanzania, Gillies spent two years working on mosquito taxonomy at the British Museum (natural history). In 1966, supported by the Medical Research Council, he set up a mosquito behaviour unit, with laboratories at Sussex university and a field station in the Gambia. His research projects involved months or years of work, always preceded by careful planning.

When it was important to know how far Anopheles mosquitoes could fly, Gillies reared 132,000 mosquitoes in the laboratory and marked them, either individually with a paint spot or in batches with radioactivity. They were released in the field and as many as possible recaptured in 110 trapping stations. He found that the average distance flown before capture was just under a mile, while some flew over two miles; the direction of movement was governed by the distribution of human settlements.

Mathematical modelling had shown that for mosquitoes to transmit malaria, they must live for a number of weeks, first feeding on an infected person to acquire the parasite, then surviving for 10-14 days while the parasite develops, and finally feeding again on an uninfected person to transmit the parasite.

It was not known how long mosquitoes lived in nature. Hearing of a Russian technique to establish the age of wild mosquitoes, Gillies traced the source to a Moscow library and translated it into English (he had learned Russian in his embassy years). The formidably difficult technique involved examining a female mosquito's ovaries for minute dilations that accumulated each time she had fed and produced eggs. Fortunately, in 1958 Gillies was joined by TJ "Tony" Wilkes, one of three or four people in the world with the skill to apply this technique consistently.

His analyses of more than 10,000 females, of three mosquito species, showed that approximately 80% of infections were transmitted by a small percentage of long-lived mosquitoes. This indicated that if mosquito life spans could be shortened by insecticide application malaria could be controlled. Control has been achieved in some parts of the world, but not in tropical Africa, where the numbers of mosquitoes are overwhelming.

In West Africa, Gillies and Wilkes undertook field experiments on practical problems. At what speed do mosquitoes fly, and how is their flight affected by wind? At what height above ground do they fly, and can their approach be blocked by high fences? Over what distance can they detect and fly to their human or animal hosts? That these studies produced much useful information was due as much to Gillies's exceptional experimental skills as to his patience and willingness to persist until success was achieved.

On first acquaintance, Gillies might have appeared shy or reserved, because he always thought carefully before speaking. To those who knew him better, he was a very warm person, wise with a fine sense of humour. He is survived by his wife, Eva, and two daughters.

 Michael Thomas Gillies, medical entomologist; born September 15 1920; died December 10 1999

fields.headline: Richard Lamb
fields.standfirst: Editor of the Liberal paper New Outlook, farmer and historian
fields.trailText: Richard Lamb, who has died aged 88, was a writer, editor, farmer and Liberal candidate for Lichfield in 1945 and Dorset North in 1964 and 1966. He was an uncomfortably provocative companion for some Liberal and Liberal Democrat colleagues. Liberal in his social and political outlook, he was a free-market right-winger in his economic views, like the 50s Liberal leader, Clement Davies. In 1950, Lamb unsuccessfully fought Stockton-on-Tees for the Tories before returning to the Liberals.
fields.body:
Richard Lamb, who has died aged 88, was a writer, editor, farmer and Liberal candidate for Lichfield in 1945 and Dorset North in 1964 and 1966. He was an uncomfortably provocative companion for some Liberal and Liberal Democrat colleagues. Liberal in his social and political outlook, he was a free-market right-winger in his economic views, like the 50s Liberal leader, Clement Davies. In 1950, Lamb unsuccessfully fought Stockton-on-Tees for the Tories before returning to the Liberals.

I knew him best when he was editing the Liberal paper New Outlook, throwing it open to outside contributors, including Sir Oswald Mosley. Once, he asked me to interview Robert Maxwell, then the Labour MP for Buckingham. I was happy to do so because Maxwell came from the same sort of orthodox Jewish family in Hungarian-minority Slovakia that my father had run away from. The interview went badly because I soon discovered he was a lying psychopath. I protested when Richard sent me back to interview him about a forthcoming budget. fields.headline: Dennis Severs
fields.standfirst: Creator of a three-dimensional historical novel, written in brick and candlelight in Spitalfields
fields.trailText: Dennis Severs, who has died aged 51, tried to bring the past alive in the dark and strange living house museum he created inside 18 Folgate Street, Spitalfields, on the edge of London's East End.
fields.body:
Dennis Severs, who has died aged 51, tried to bring the past alive in the dark and strange living house museum he created inside 18 Folgate Street, Spitalfields, on the edge of London's East End.

It became, as he described it, "a famous time-machine" in which those prepared to enter his empathetic historical imagination and to suspend disbelief (never mind mundane considerations of historical fact, conventional museum practice or conservation philosophy) could find themselves transported into a dream which illuminated the complicated and poignant social history of that ancient part of London.

Although sneered at by many who suffer from what he would have dismissed as "pigeonholed styles of intelligence" inhibiting creativity, Severs was a true original, an artist of perverse genius who created a three-dimensional historical novel out of bricks and mortar and timber and the objects he picked up for a song on countless stalls.

The social historian Raphael Samuel considered it "a magical mystery tour which dazzles the visitor with a succession of scenes more crowded with memorable incident than the mere facsimile of what passes in the museums as a period room".

Dennis was one of those Americans in England who seemed to have arrived from nowhere, to have no past, no roots and who, so irritatingly, could not be placed socially. I first encountered him in the late 60s as the exotic friend of a Cambridge friend; he was then running horse-drawn open carriage tours around Hyde Park and the West End ("See Something Different Graciously") and seemed, even for me then, a little too starry-eyed about the charm of Victorian England. But Dennis was not a blazer and Brooks Brothers stereotype American Anglophile; he was humorous, generous, passionate, altogether unpretentious and engagingly camp.

I now know that he was a Californian, the son of Earl and Helen Severs, then of Escondito, who already had four sons between them by different marriages. In an unpublished guide to his house entitled The Space Between, Severs recalled that, as a dreamy and imaginative child, he was regarded at one of his several schools as somewhere between "exceptional" and "mentally retarded."

Storytelling earned him the respect of his peers, while the mania to collect began early. "Down deep," he recalled, "I always believed that one day I would travel past picture frames and into the marinated glow of a warmer, more mellow and more romantic light. There was one such light in particular, one that I saw in the combination of old varnish and paint, and that appealed to me as my ideal. By the age of 11, it was identified as English."

Severs visited England in 1965 and moved to London two years later, after high school graduation. He abandoned plans to become a barrister in favour of carriage tours, but then his stable, near Gloucester Road, was demolished by a developer. He bought the brick George I terraced house, to which he devoted the rest of his life, in 1979.

It was the right time: the campaign to restore Hawksmoor's great church nearby had begun, while the Spitalfields Historic Buildings Trust was fighting to prevent the erosion of that run-down, but mysterious, inner suburb. The artists Gilbert and George had already moved into Fournier Street while, more significantly perhaps, another pioneering resident was the late Raphael Samuel, whose analysis of the contemporary phenomenon of "retrochic" in his book, Theatres of Memory, celebrated that restorative sympathy for the artefacts of the past that so moved Dennis.

As he put it, he did not want so much to "restore" the house with its panelled rooms, "but to bring it to life as my home. With a candle, a chamber pot and a bedroll, I began sleeping in each of the house's 10 rooms so that I might arouse my intuition in the quest for each room's soul.

"Then, having neared it, I worked inside out from there to create what turned out to be a collection of atmospheres: moods that harbour the light and the spirit of various ages in Time."

The Spitalfields inhabited by Dennis was that of the novelist Peter Ackroyd rather than that of the historian John Summerson. And to illuminate these atmospheres for his paying visitors, Severs invented a family called Jervis who had lived there over the centuries and whose members had apparently just left each of the rooms entered.

With that openness and lack of prejudice which is America at its best, he cleverly combined low and high tech: real guttering candles co-existed with concealed taped sound-effects in settings which he constantly refined. Nor was this frivolous or cynical: visitors who giggled or who were otherwise unable to enter into the spirit of the enterprise would be summarily ejected.

Nothing could be less New Labour than Severs's achievement; for him, emotionally understanding the past was vital and his vision was holistic and therapeutic, almost spiritual. He felt able to summon up past eras not through history books, but through empathy with objects and places, to tell a fictional, true story "aimed at those who want to make sense of the whole picture of being alive".

Shortly before he died two days after Christmas, ravaged by cancer, bravely borne, after long being HIV-positive, his house was bought by the Spitalfields Trust, but it is hard to see how his creation can be sustained.

"Sadly," Dennis wrote, "I have recently come to accept what I refused to accept for so long: that the house is only ephemeral. That no one can put a preservation order on atmosphere." Certainly not now Dennis Severs has gone to join the Jervises.

webTitle: Brown denies wrongdoing over buying Maxwell flat

fields.headline: Brown denies wrongdoing over buying Maxwell flat
fields.trailText: The future chancellor Gordon Brown knew his Westminster flat belonged to a failed company of Robert Maxwell's when he bought it in 1992, while the controversy over the drowned tycoon's plundered pension funds was still raging, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
The future chancellor Gordon Brown knew his Westminster flat belonged to a failed company of Robert Maxwell's when he bought it in 1992, while the controversy over the drowned tycoon's plundered pension funds was still raging, it emerged last night.

But Mr Brown, his allies and City accountants, insisted yesterday that "no impropriety" had occurred over the £130,000 purchase and that Geoffrey Robinson, the former treasury minister and multi-millionaire who is an ex-director of the company, neither tipped Mr Brown off about the flat nor helped him buy it.

The rising Labour star, newly appointed as shadow chancellor by John Smith, found the third-floor flat behind Westminster Abbey in 1992 through estate agents, it was said. The Maxwell link via the TV polling firm AGB Research - which owned the property - was pure coincidence, aides insisted.

But Labour MPs wondered if yesterday's claim in the Sunday Times - that Mr Brown had secured a "bargain price" of at least £30,000 less than the alleged 1992 market price - heralded a new round of tit-for-tat ministerial infighting like that around Peter Mandelson a year ago.

It emerged that Mr Brown had asked his brothers, Andrew, a Channel 4 TV producer, and John, for second opinions on the flat in 1992. He decided to sell his larger Kennington flat - worth £80,000 - to be five minutes' walk from the Commons.

"I'm not sure when we knew it was anything to do with the Maxwell receivers. It was only a marginal factor... but we knew pretty early on," one source familiar with the transaction confirmed last night.

Tony Blair will stand by his chancellor, whose air of rectitude will help him weather the storm. But his purchase may appear uncharacteristically naive when he was demanding "top-level inquiries" into the Maxwell affair from the then Tory government.

Yesterday the shadow treasury minister, David Heathcoat-Amory, leapt on a fresh chance to embarrass Labour ministers over the Maxwell-Robinson connection.

He wrote to Mr Brown, asking if the flat had been "sold cheaply"; why his earlier complaints about AGB International (of which Mr Robinson was once a director) had not been answered; and how Mr Brown, then on a backbench salary, had put up to £100,000 in cash into the purchase, on top of the £210,000 spent on his North Queenferry home two years earlier.

Although MPs have London housing allowances worth £10,000 a year, some Labour MPs were also puzzled. But aides of Mr Brown, who last night remained incommunicado at his Scottish home near Edinburgh, said the money came from flat sales in both London and Edinburgh.

The City accountants who administered the sale of Maxwell assets to raise cash for pensioners and other defrauded creditors, also backed the chancellor's defence.

In a statement which followed the Sunday Times claim, Andersons insisted the flat had been sold on the open market at "the best availible price... at a time of serious property depression".

fields.headline: Buddhist leader sent into hiding
fields.standfirst: Young lama secluded from media after Tibet escape
fields.trailText: Urgyen Trinley Dorje, the teenage head of one of the main orders of Tibetan Buddhism, was hidden away yesterday by Tibetan exile leaders to recover from his 900-mile escape last week across the Himalayas to India - and from a frenzy of media interest.
fields.body:
Urgyen Trinley Dorje, the teenage head of one of the main orders of Tibetan Buddhism, was hidden away yesterday by Tibetan exile leaders to recover from his 900-mile escape last week across the Himalayas to India - and from a frenzy of media interest.

As the 14-year-old lama was driven away from his guesthouse before dawn in Dharamsala, north India, the darkness was illuminated by television lights. Reporters and photographers jostled to get close to the boy who carries the title of 17th Karmapa Lama, leader of the Kagyu order.

He was taken off with his sister and two monks who escaped with him from Chinese-ruled Tibet on December 28, arriving in northern India on January 5.

The media scrum was a new experience for the boy born into a nomad family and brought up in seclusion at Tsurphu monastery in central Tibet. Tashi Wangdi, minister for religion and culture in the Tibetan exile government, said: "The Karmapa has been taken to another location to keep him away from the public eye so that he can rest and recuperate."

The location has not been revealed, but sources close to the Kagyu hierarchy say it is probably Sherab Ling, the monastery of the Karmapa's guru, who is Tai Situ Rinpoche. It is about four hours' drive from Dharamsala, near the town of Palampur in the Kangra valley. It has modern guesthouse facilities and is said to be "very securely protected" against unwanted visitors.

The defection of the Karmapa has delighted Tibetan exiles and westerners who practise Tibetan Buddhism. He was the highest Tibetan lama whose authority was recognised by both Beijing and by Tibetan leaders in exile.

But his arrival poses a problem for India, which has to balance support for the Dalai Lama and the Tibetan government-in-exile against its desire to improve relations with China.

Experts say it is almost certain the young Karmapa will be granted full residential status in India if he wants it. His predecessor, the 16th Karmapa, lived in the Indian state of Sikkim from 1959 to his death in 1981 - despite the fact that India and China are in dispute over the territory. A rival claimant to the Kagyu leadership now lives in Sikkim.

"The prestige of having the 17th Karmapa in India is enormous," said Norma Levine, an expert on the Kagyu tradition and author of The Blessing Power of the Buddhas.

"His spiritual authority equals that of the Dalai Lama,", she maintains, and it was significant that he "went straight to Dharamsala to meet the Dalai Lama after his escape, rather than going to one of his own monasteries first".

webTitle: Sailors arrested over Argentina's missing babies

fields.headline: Sailors arrested over Argentina's missing babies
fields.trailText: A group of retired Argentine naval officers were yesterday being questioned over the alleged kidnapping of children born to political prisoners during the 1976-83 dictatorship.
fields.body:
A group of retired Argentine naval officers were yesterday being questioned over the alleged kidnapping of children born to political prisoners during the 1976-83 dictatorship.

Local news reports said that up to nine officers were arrested late Friday in the coastal city of Mar del Plata, 250 miles south of Buenos Aires.

The arrests followed a raid on Thursday on a naval base in Mar del Plata, the site of one of several detention centres set up during the military dictatorship. The arrests took place on the orders of a federal judge, Maria Servini.

The former officers are suspected of taking 12 babies from political prisoners held at the base. Several officers are accused of illegally adopting some of the babies.

Federal judges are investigating whether there was a systematic plan for the illicit adoption of more than 200 children born to dissidents held captive during the military junta's campaign against leftwingers and political opponents.

The children's mothers are among at least 9,000 Argentines who vanished during the "dirty war". Human rights groups say the figure is closer to 30,000.

The judicial investigation was prompted by a report from the Grandmothers of the Plaza de Mayo, a human rights group which has identified about 60 children born to dissidents who disappeared during the military regime.

Nine of the junta's most senior leaders are already being held, including Jorge Videla, the general who became the regime's first president, and a former chief admiral, Emilio Massera - both leaders of the military group that overthrew President Isabel Peron in 1976 and ruled until 1983.

Many of the senior members of the dictatorship were sentenced to life in prison in 1985 for human rights abuses. But five years later President Carlos Menem pardoned those in jail along with all middle- and senior-ranking officers.

That move outraged human rights groups, which have since searched for ways to bring the former officers to justice. Charges of child kidnapping are not covered by the presidential pardon.

fields.headline: Jungle orchestra lures eastern talent
fields.trailText: As a child growing up in St Petersburg, Kirill Bogatyrev believed that the Amazonian city of Manaus was a wild place where anaconda snakes slithered down the streets.
fields.body:
As a child growing up in St Petersburg, Kirill Bogatyrev believed that the Amazonian city of Manaus was a wild place where anaconda snakes slithered down the streets.

Little did the young musician realise that he would one day swap cold Russian winters for the humid swelter of the Brazilian rainforest - and that he would do so for the sake of his orchestral career.

In October last year, the 25-year-old cellist left the renowned Kirov Opera to join the new Amazon Philharmonic, based in Manaus.

He is not the only good east European musician now living in the jungle. Since the orchestra was founded two years ago it has become the focus of perhaps the most bizarre migration in the classical music world. At the last count the 54-member orchestra included 16 Bulgarians, 15 Belarussians and seven Russians. At least a dozen more east Europeans are expected to join this year.

"There's a very good outlook for me here," says Mr Bogatyrev, whose pale features are sunburned and sweaty. "In Russia there is a war with Chechnya; I may be called up. It is civilised here. It is clean. I really like this town."

A thousand miles upriver

Manaus, population 1.2m, is one of the most remote cities in the world, 1,000 miles up the Amazon with no proper road links to the rest of Brazil.

When the rubber tree was first commercialised 100 years ago, the sudden influx of money turned Manaus into a place of opulence almost overnight. Despite its location and the challenges of the Amazonian climate, it was the first Brazilian city to have trams and the second to have electric street lighting.

If anything symbolises Manaus's heyday it is the opera house, built in neoclassical style with Scottish iron, Italian stone and French tiles. The building was immortalised in the 1982 film Fitzcarraldo, Werner Herzog's fictional account of an Irishman who dreams of Caruso performing in the jungle.

But when the rubber industry moved to east Asia, Manaus's fall was as swift as its rise. The opera house was used to store petrol and the stage was at one time used for five-a-side football.

Almost a century later Manaus's neglected cultural life is re-emerging with a Slavic twist. webTitle: Christians and Muslims keep killers at bay

fields.headline: Christians and Muslims keep killers at bay
fields.standfirst: Community shows rest of Moluccas how to live in peace
fields.trailText: The sound of church music played by a lone trumpeter mixed with the recorded voice of the imam earnestly calling the faithful to prayer in the nearby mosque.
fields.byline: John Aglionby  in Wayame, the Moluccas, Indonesia
fields.body:
The sound of church music played by a lone trumpeter mixed with the recorded voice of the imam earnestly calling the faithful to prayer in the nearby mosque.

This is Wayame, where nothing is as one might expect. For this village on the northern coast of Ambon bay is one of the few oases of peace in the Moluccas, the Indonesian island group where Muslims and Christians have been fighting a vicious war for 12 months.

Most other communities in the hundreds of islands that make up the Moluccas - a mini-archipelago 1,500 miles east of Jakarta and famous for its spices - have been torn apart by the fighting.

Some have become purely Muslim enclaves; in others the Christians have triumphed; many have become segregated, the two sides kept apart only by the Indonesian military. The intensity and destruction have been frightening.

Not so in Wayame. Despite being sandwiched between a Muslim village to the east and an equally militant Christian settlement to the west, Wayame has no burned-out houses, no piles of rubble where a church or mosque once stood and no graves of the victims of the conflict.

The secret is trust, cooperation and dialogue.

"From the start, last January, we all got together - from all religions and sections of the community - and promised not to get involved in what was happening elsewhere," said the village's head, Daniel Hunihua. "People have kept their word."

Underpinning the villagers' efforts to remain above the fighting is Team 20, a committee of 10 representatives from each religion who meet at least twice a week to discuss problems and threats to the village.

"We alternate between the church and the mosque," said the chairman, Johannes Amanupungo, a Christian. "We organise programmes to help each other and to bring the people closer together." It has not been easy in the face of constant provocation.

"We get threatening calls several times a week but we do not react to them," said Dirk Pietersz, a Muslim member of Team 20.

Numerous other villages have tried to set up similar teams, but failed, becoming engulfed by the fighting that has claimed at least 1,500 lives. Some estimates say the figure could be as high as 5,000.

"Other villages often had teams for each religion that only met together rarely," Mr Pietersz said. "But we talk all the time, and if there is a major threat then we will call a meeting straight away."

"A lot of the credit must go to the religious leaders, who work tirelessly."

It has also helped that there are few migrants in the village. Along with central government neglect of the region, local resentment at forced migration to the Moluccas - mainly of Muslims - is one of the main causes of the conflict.

Mr Amanupungo said that the fighting had actually made the village more united. "We have seen what is happening elsewhere and we are determined not to let that happen here. We don't want to become refugees and we don't want to see our lives destroyed," he said.

More than 100,000 people out of the Moluccas' 2m have been driven from their homes by the fighting, and a similar number have left of their own accord.

Among the latter group are more than half of Wayame's 1,700 families. "Some have lost their nerve while others have gone because they want to ensure their children can complete their education," said Mr Pietersz.

The village has a primary school, which is fully mixed. But the nearest secondary schools are in a Christian area along the bay. "It can get very nasty for the Muslim pupils there," said Mr Hunihua.

Wayame villagers have also established close links with the military, who in other areas have taken sides and even shot at each other.

Even the graffiti are reassuringly normal in Wayame. Scrawled under a heavily laden jackfruit tree in bright yellow paint is "Billy and Alvi". Across the water in the provincial capital, Ambon, common slogans include "Jesus was born from a dog" and "All Muslims deserve to burn in hell."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Firm denies it knew of bug
The French food company Coudray yesterday denied a report in the provincial daily Ouest France that it knew a potentially deadly listeria bacteria had infected its products but had kept quiet.

Firm denies it knew of bug
The French food company Coudray yesterday denied a report in the provincial daily Ouest France that it knew a potentially deadly listeria bacteria had infected its products but had kept quiet.

Thousands of Coudray products, including pté, were withdrawn after a pensioner and a baby died.
Reuters, Paris

Grandmother has triplets
US farmworker Arcelia Garcia, 54, who already has eight children and 15 grandchildren, has given birth to healthy triplets without having used fertility drugs.
AP, Yakima, Washington state

China accused of organ trade
A hospital in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou was yesterday accused of selling livers from executed prisoners for transplants, at £23,500 each.

Hong Kong's South China Morning Post said China was profiting from its frequent use of the death penalty.
AP, Hong Kong

Tale of torment on the tube
A forsaken lover has rented advertising space in 105 carriages on Prague's underground train system to print a public letter begging his former partner to return to him.

"I think of you all the time... how you were preparing eggs or pancakes in the morning, wearing my white T-shirt," said the message addressed to "M" and signed "A".
AP, Prague

webTitle: Champion of apartheid plans to join ANC

fields.headline: Champion of apartheid plans to join ANC
fields.trailText: Pik Botha, the former South African foreign minister best known for spending nearly two decades defending apartheid against a hostile world, plans to join the ruling African National Congress.
fields.body:
Pik Botha, the former South African foreign minister best known for spending nearly two decades defending apartheid against a hostile world, plans to join the ruling African National Congress.

In an interview with a black Sunday newspaper, Mr Botha described Nelson Mandela as a better leader than South Africa's last white president, FW de Klerk. And he attacked those whites who have failed to adapt to the new order.

"Mandela succeeded in his bid to reach out to whites without bitterness. De Klerk did not manage to reach out to blacks," he said.

"Whites, especially the Afrikaners, must get down from their pedestals. They should rather help uplift poor South Africans of other population groups. Afrikaners cannot flourish when things are not going well for other South Africans," he added.

Mr Botha would be the first former National party cabinet minister to join the ANC, although it is not certain that he will be welcome after the party said it will "cross that bridge" when he submits his application.

The 67-year-old former minister said he identified with the ANC's "fundamental values" of "freedom of speech, freedom of religion and protection of private property". He called on other Afrikaners to join the party to bring about a real change in political alignments in South Africa. He denied that he was signing up with the ANC "just to be on the side of the governing party".

Mr Botha has long had a taste for the dramatic. He outraged other members of the apartheid government in 1986 when he famously suggested the country might one day have a black president.

Towards the end of his stint as the world's longest serving foreign minister - from 1977 to 1994 - Mr Botha briefly harboured the illusion that Nelson Mandela might keep him on in the post. But after South Africa's first all-race elections in 1994, Mr Botha was made minerals minister in the coalition government.

"The standard of debate in the Mandela cabinet was at any time just as high if not higher than in former president De Klerk's cabinet," he said.

Mr Botha's call on whites to join the ANC implicitly endorsed a warning by President Thabo Mbeki that the "cancer of racism" still plagues South Africa. In a speech to mark the ANC's 88th birthday, Mr Mbeki said he is considering calling a national congress to combat the problem.

"We have not won the struggle against racism - a defining element of the problem of the colour line which the 20th century failed to solve," he said.

 Mr Mbeki's office was baffled yesterday when Margaret Thatcher insisted on paying him a "courtesy call". Mrs Thatcher is in South Africa to see her son, Mark.

Mr Mandela once said "let bygones be bygones" when asked about the former prime minister's description of the ANC as terrorists.

An official in the president's office, Tasneem Carrim, said Mr Mbeki is not quite as forgiving. "I don't think the president would say 'let bygones be bygones'. But Mrs Thatcher is not prime minister anymore, and I don't think the president sees much harm in meeting with her."

webTitle: Lost files let Italy's criminals off the hook

fields.headline: Lost files let Italy's criminals off the hook
fields.standfirst: Justice officials plan inquiry into why 700,000 forgotten court cases languished in basement for years
fields.trailText: The much-vilified Italian justice system has sunk to new depths with the discovery of 700,000 court cases filed away in a Rome basement and forgotten for over a decade.
fields.body:
The much-vilified Italian justice system has sunk to new depths with the discovery of 700,000 court cases filed away in a Rome basement and forgotten for over a decade.

An inquiry into the bureaucratic bungle - which has mortified officials and deepened the sense of crisis surrounding Italy's fight against crime - is expected this week. Officials said it could take years to sort out.

The files went missing in 1989 when one department, the instruction office, was being phased out. The transfer of files to the preliminary hearings office was botched when there was a last minute decision to keep open a branch of the instruction office until its director, Judge Rosario Priore, returned to Rome from investigating an air crash. It left the files in limbo and no action was ever taken on these cases.

The caseload remained undisturbed in a court basement in Piazza Adriana until last year when Rome's tribunal office, tipped off by Judge Priore, started sifting through the boxes. The news leaked out at the weekend and pressure has mounted on the justice minister, Oliviero Diliberto, to investigate.

Luigi Scotti, president of the Rome tribunal, said the situation was "grave". The small sample examined so far suggested many of the cases were petty theft, carried out between 1975 and 1989, but thousands of more serious crimes are expected to emerge.

Mario Cicala, president of the national association of magistrates, said: "If there was something really important in there maybe someone would have already asked for the cases to be called up."

But he added: "With efficiency levels like this we'll keep exporting civil justice [to the European court] and importing criminal justice."

Legal experts agreed that a series of judicial fiascos were threatening to turn Italy into a haven for criminals.

A long-awaited reform to speed up the system by merging small claims courts with other courts has backfired by creating new bottlenecks. Antonio Guttadauro, a prosecutor in Florence, said hundreds of hearings and trials risked cancellation because of the confusion. Outdated computer systems and the failure to help judges to implement the reforms were adding to the chaos.

Recent cases have shredded the judiciary's reputation for championing ordinary people's rights against the corruption of the mafia and political elites. A grindingly slow appeals process, which often expires, has allowed many well-connected convicts to escape jail, including Silvio Berlusconi, the media magnate and leader of the centre-right coalition. No one expects him to serve his two years and nine months for bribery and false accounting.

The collapse of two trials against the former prime minister Giulio Andreotti has fuelled accusations that corruption investigations were witch-hunts carried out by leftwing magistrates.

The use of pentiti, mafia supergrasses, is being reviewed by a parliamentary committee after a spate of scandals in which the turncoats contradicted their own evidence and committed crimes while under state protection.

The crisis of faith in the system was highlighted at the weekend by the plight of Antonella Ronghi, a housewife from Foggia convicted of stealing olives. Originally sentenced to five years, a six-year judicial odyssey of appeals cut the sentence in half.

She served six-and-a-half months in prison and was allowed to finish the sentence under house arrest. That ended last week when she was re-arrested because she was sitting in her garden.

webTitle: Theatrical agent to lead German Jews

fields.headline: Theatrical agent to lead German Jews
fields.trailText: A Jewish theatrical agent who spent his childhood hiding from Nazis in the cellar of a Belgian farmhouse was elected to lead Germany's burgeoning Jewish community yesterday.
fields.body:
A Jewish theatrical agent who spent his childhood hiding from Nazis in the cellar of a Belgian farmhouse was elected to lead Germany's burgeoning Jewish community yesterday.

Paul Spiegel, who is already leader of the Jewish community in Düsseldorf, was elected by six votes to three to the post of president of the central council of German Jews by the body's executive board. The remaining votes went to Charlotte Knobloch of Munich.

His predecessor, Ignatz Bubis, died last August.

Mr Spiegel, 62, who is considered a liberal by his contemporaries, is the first central council president not to have experienced the Nazi death camps first hand. Both Mr Bubis and his predecessor, Heinz Galinski, survived Auschwitz.

Mr Spiegel fled Germany with his mother in 1939, finding refuge in Belgium. But his sister was killed and his father spent five years in a concentration camp.

In a recent interview, he said: "I have often been asked why on earth German Jews should have chosen to go back to Germany after the war. The answer is simply that most wanted to go home."

After the election, the new president, who calls himself an "enlightened, traditional Jew", said: "My main task will be to further integration of Jews in Germany." He added that he aimed to continue in the spirit of his forerunner who saw himself as a "guardian" of German democracy.

Germany's Jewish community has trebled to more than 80,000 since reunification, with many young Jews arriving from the former Soviet Union.

fields.headline: Belgium restores frontier curbs
fields.standfirst: Dream of common EU border recedes as two countries resurrect barriers to curb illegal migration
fields.trailText: The dream of a passport-free European Union will be seriously undermined today when Belgium and Luxembourg reimpose border controls to help prevent a feared influx of illegal immigrants.
fields.body:
The dream of a passport-free European Union will be seriously undermined today when Belgium and Luxembourg reimpose border controls to help prevent a feared influx of illegal immigrants.

The move has exposed the fragility of the Schengen agreement under which nine EU countries removed border controls in 1995. Britain has refused to participate.

The Belgian decision dismayed European commission officials and MEPs. One official expressed disbelief, given that Belgium is far from Europe's external frontier.

The Belgian interior minister, Antoine Duquesne, said the move was temporary and designed to dissuade anyone tempted to gain entry to take advantage of a three-week amnesty this month for illegal immigrants already in the country.

"These controls are necessary to dissuade illegal arrivals in our country and to combat effectively the mafia-style networks that exploit these unfortunate people," he said, in a reference to smuggling of migrants by criminal gangs.

But the Belgian decision had an immediate knock-on effect. The Luxembourg government said it, too, would reimpose its border controls from today.

Delays are predicted for travellers arriving by plane, train or car in both countries, since passports will be checked.

There is no sign that France or Germany will follow suit. Such a move by either would effectively scupper the accord.

Belgium is not in breach of the agreement: a clause allows members to opt out for short periods if special circumstances are invoked. But the decision amounts to a tacit admission that the policy of a common EU border is failing to control illegal immigration.

The other participants in Schengen are Austria, Italy, the Netherlands, Portugal and Spain.

Britain and Ireland have resisted pressure to join, claiming Schengen is for countries with land borders, and that islands have different problems in dealing with illegal immigrants. Both Conservative and Labour governments also feared igniting a row over loss of sovereignty.

The hope of pro-Europeans has been that Britain and Ireland will eventually join, to create free movement across an area from Ireland to the Finnish border with Russia. But Belgium has dented that ambition.

Claude Moraes, Labour MEP for London and legal affairs spokesman for the European Labour party, expressed disappointment last night: "It has the potential to start a trend towards other countries closing their borders. Belgium, though a small country, is symbolically important because it is home to the European institutions."

He questioned the value of an agreement when countries could unilaterally reimpose controls: "Schengen is riddled with inconsistencies."

John Maples, the shadow foreign secretary, said: "This shows it was sensible to stay out." He added: "It is about more than Schengen breaking down. It is the way our European partners pick and choose whether to abide by agreements."

The foreign office stood aloof. A spokesman said that since Britain had not signed the agreement, it was a matter for Belgium and the others.

Mr Duquesne, referring to the flow of illegal immigrants - estimated to be well in excess of 60,000 in Belgium - said: "They think Belgium is a paradise."
