webTitle: Last supper for boy killer on death row

fields.headline: Last supper for boy killer on death row
fields.trailText: Like lots of other people, Chris Thomas will settle down tonight in front of a dinner of fried chicken, French fries and apple pie. Unlike the others, though, Thomas does so knowing it is only a few hours until $86.06 worth of chemicals are injected into his veins to stop his heart.
fields.body:
Like lots of other people, Chris Thomas will settle down tonight in front of a dinner of fried chicken, French fries and apple pie. Unlike the others, though, Thomas does so knowing it is only a few hours until $86.06 worth of chemicals are injected into his veins to stop his heart.

"I've seen the [prison] officers eating fried chicken," he said yesterday, dressed in regulation orange jumpsuit and sitting 20ft from the execution chamber in Greenville prison, Virginia. "I acquired a taste for the smell of it."

Thomas was 17, still at school and too young to vote when he was convicted of murdering his girlfriend's mother and father because they wanted to keep the couple apart. Had he been born in almost any other country in the world he would not be facing death at 9pm (Eastern Time) near the heart of the Old South.

"I can't blame the United States; I can't blame Virginia," said Thomas. "In a sense, I put myself here. It was a childish decision. I was a child. I'm not a victim of my environment, I'm not a victim of drugs. In the US we live under a democracy with freedom of speech, freedom of choice. Unfortunately, I made a bad choice."

He is by no means the only one to have done so. About 70 death row inmates have been sentenced as juveniles in the US in the past 24 years and on Thursday Steve Roach is due to be executed in Virginia for murdering a neighbour when he too was 17. In Texas two more are soon to die.

"This would mark the first time since the death penalty was reinstated [in 1976] that so many juvenile offenders would be executed in so short a period," William Paul, president of the American Bar Association, wrote to Virginia's governor, Jim Gilmore. "In our view, the execution of people for crimes they committed while children is unacceptable in a civilised society."

Only Iran, Nigeria, Saudi Arabia, Pakistan and Yemen appeared with the US on a list of countries that have executed juvenile offenders in the past 10 years.

Thirty-eight of the 50 states have the death penalty. It can be imposed at the age of 16 in 18 states, including Virginia; at 17 in five states, including Texas; and at 18 in 15 more.

Spoiled child

Mr Gilmore is the only person left who can prevent Thomas from dying tonight, by granting clemency. There is no reason to suppose that he will.

"I think Monday will be a glorious day, whatever way it goes," said Thomas, now 26. "If it's commuted, I get some sort of life back. If it's not commuted, then I move on to another life. I believe death is only the beginning."

He was raised by his grandparents in Chesterfield, about 100 miles from Richmond, the state capitol, where his mother Margaret lived, and he had no contact with his father until last summer.

"It was a pretty great childhood," said Thomas, allowing himself to laugh at how he believes his case confounds the stereotype of the criminal shaped by his miserable early years. "I was a spoilt kid. Anything I wanted, they gave me: toys, motorcycles, all the normal kid things."

He did pretty well at school and played baseball, basketball and soccer. But his grandparents died when he was 12 and he had to go to Richmond to live with his mother. "I was moving in with someone I knew was my mother but I didn't know her as a person. I was moving from my home town."

There were other changes: at 14, he was caught stealing music tapes from a shop; at 15, it was breaking and entering, possessing drugs, and then alcohol and trespass, which earned him three months in a special school for boys; at 16, he stole a car and spent four days in jail.

"Nothing violent - I never exhibited any violence to anyone." Not, at any rate, until he was 17 and back home, as he thinks of it, in Chesterfield. There he took up with 14-year-old Jessica Wiseman, whose parents disapproved of the relationship. The teenagers plotted to kill Kathy and James Wiseman, both 33, and they saw it through with a shotgun.

Jessica was tried and convicted as a juvenile, held in a correctional centre until she was 21 and released three years ago. Thomas was charged as a juvenile, tried as an adult and sentenced to death.

Search for identity

"She pulled the trigger," he said yesterday. "I should have said it during my trial. I told her I would take full responsibility." Two women came forward last summer to say they had heard Jessica say she killed her mother.

"I don't hold any animosity towards her," said Thomas. "At 17 I was impulsive. I was gullible, I was still searching for my identity, I was being who everyone wanted me to be. Now I've grown up. I've changed."

He has spent his years in jail reading, watching television, working out, listening to music from opera to rap, anything that would take his mind off where he was. "I like Frederick Forsyth. I read Andrew Morton's book about Princess Diana, but I'm a sceptical about Morton. She took her celebrity and made a difference."

Not much can make a difference now for Chris Thomas, though he has been here before, last June, when a stay of execution was granted five hours before he was due to die. He had fried chicken for dinner that night, too.

600 executed

Since 1976, when the US supreme court reinstated the death penalty, 600 people have been put to death. There are 3,600 on death row.

Two died this year: Malcolm Johnson by lethal injection in Oklahoma and David Duren by electrocution in Alabama.

Texas has been responsible for 199 of those executed since 1976. Virginia has put to death 73 people, Florida 44 and Missouri 41. Colorado, Idaho, Ohio and Wyoming have executed one each.

webTitle: Crying all the way to the bank

fields.headline: Crying all the way to the bank
fields.standfirst: He's huge in open-air music spectaculars and big on sharing his feelings about tax, drugs, rock'n'roll - and his ex-partner, Charlotte Rampling.
fields.trailText: To the cynical English ear, Jean Michel Jarre, the 51-year-old French musician, talks enough rot to sink a cross-channel ferry. He spent Millennium night in Egypt, lighting up the Pyramids with "an electronic opera" entitled the Twelve Dreams of the Sun, at which he and his audience were not "trapped by their day-to-day life, with tools around their arms", but "in front of themselves, not just in front of the past, but in front of time", and also "in front of timelessness". It was "a physical experience, a bit painful". They felt "the rust, the dust". It was, despite the multi-million-dollar equipment, 100%"organic".
fields.body:
To the cynical English ear, Jean Michel Jarre, the 51-year-old French musician, talks enough rot to sink a cross-channel ferry. He spent Millennium night in Egypt, lighting up the Pyramids with "an electronic opera" entitled the Twelve Dreams of the Sun, at which he and his audience were not "trapped by their day-to-day life, with tools around their arms", but "in front of themselves, not just in front of the past, but in front of time", and also "in front of timelessness". It was "a physical experience, a bit painful". They felt "the rust, the dust". It was, despite the multi-million-dollar equipment, 100%"organic".

He has a new album out this month, Metamorphoses, "a blank page, a new chapter", in which for the first time in his career he has fully "experimented" with the voice, his own and others, using it naturally "as an instrument", the words as "audio-pictograms". It has an Oriental feel this album (it is also "organic"), and Jarre believes more and more that the next metamorphoses of Europe, in which "we grow up enough to succeed as Europeans", may come not from inside but from outside, from this Oriental connection, "this glue", we all share: "The Turkish connection for Germans, the north African connection for France, Pakistani or Indian for Britain."

He has a sensitive nature, he says. "At the end of the day the saddest thing for me was clowns. I used to cry. The more the other children around me were laughing, the more I was crying."

But Jarre is French after all. And handsome. And so charming. And so tiny. He sits in a recording studio in Paris, surrounded by crates ("Pink Floyd World Tour") and boys in Hard Rock cafe T-shirts, and all the wires and chrome and leads and cables and titanic speakers that attend his career as the man who brought the musical extravaganza, the techno tirade, to your local city centre (Paris, Beijing, Houston, Moscow... Docklands), like a Gallic Wizard of Oz.

He looks like a spaniel, with his puppydog brown eyes and dark hair falling around his line-free face like two floppy ears, a lean Dudley Moore with his easy grin and shiny school boy trousers. His hands are pale and slim and a bit damp looking and always on the move, scratching his eyebrows, tweaking the flies of his trousers.

"Oh, you English women, you are so cheeky," he says. "The guys in England are more cynical. It's funny, in France it is the reverse. English woman is more open and much less cynical, less knowing is the word, than the French woman. On my side I have this love affair with the UK..."

He has, however, separated from his wife, the English actress Charlotte Rampling; newspaper reports in 1997 said he'd left her for a 31-year-old French civil servant called Odile Froment. But he says he and Charlotte "are like twins. Really, we are closer than ever. Really, she is the woman of my life." So you are living together again? "Er, not really. We have separate lives but we will live together forever. Life is a long way..."

Jarre, who was born in Lyon, has been around almost as long as the Pyramids. He was experimenting at the Paris Conservatoire in 1966. Oxygene, his first international hit, was released in 1976, the same year he was voted Personality of the Year by People magazine. His first open air concert was on Bastille Day in Paris in 1979. (He fell into the whole outdoor scene by accident - in an attempt to make the performance of music based around a synthesiser interesting: "the instruments were not so sexy," he says.)

He's sold more than 50m albums along the way, but he found the 80s a bit lonely: "I followed my way more or less by myself." But the raves of the 90s have caught him up. "A lot of people joined the boat." He says he is a regular fixture on the rave scene. Does he take ecstasy when he's there?

"Er, no. But you know it is unfair to trap a movement with drugs. It is a never-ending story. Every movement has been linked with drugs, the beginning of jazz, the beginning of rock'n'roll, the beginning of heavy metal, punk, grunge, techno. Drug dealers have an impact when people are just starting a new way of expression, when they are fragile and vulnerable, but what is most interesting in the rave scene is the attempt to find an alternative to rock'n'roll."

He could never have been a rock'n'roll star himself. He's adamant about that. He uses painting or writing analogies for what he does, not musical. It's a question of humility. "I know that I'm a bit odd, or eccentric. But I never consider myself a pop star obsessed by my image. This image problem is a very 80s attitude, linked with a certain cynicism, that the image is more important than whoever you are. But mine is a more humble approach, to be part of a big picture, rather than going into a small theatre just with your guitar with a spotlight on yourself, thinking you are going to excite an audience for two hours."

Jarre is not short of theories, and he's generous with them too. He has a complicated family - he and Rampling have a son; she had a son from a previous marriage, he had a daughter (he had custody of her from the time she was 18 months). They're all in their 20s now - a magician, a graphic designer, the movie business: a perfect division of the family talent - but he's happy to share his tips for domestic harmony. "The 60s generated this silly attitude to leaving the kids to do whatever they want, which created a big mess.

"Charlotte and I always considered that you should give a framework where they could be as free as possible and then enlarge the framework as long as they are growing up. We are all very close, even among these mad crazy schedules. Yesterday I was with David. We had dinner at one in the morning until three. I had no other time and he was the same." As for he and Rampling: "We will never divorce. The whole family is very close."

There is one exception: his father, Maurice Jarre, who wrote the soundtrack to Dr Zhivago and lives in Los Angeles, "trying... I mean continuing to do his work". His son thinks he has met him about 20 times. "As long as you can count the number of contacts with one member of your family, it is not a good thing. I am only now starting to cope with this. A blank space instead of a father is not a good thing. It means nothing. It's sad because apart from the personal things, it is quite unusual from a professional point of view when a French person is internationally successful in music, but to have two in the same family, it is crazy not to share that."

His father has another son from a more recent relationship. "I think it's even worse with this one than with me." Have you met him? "No. Er, yes... I've met him, but, you know, I have enough responsibility with my own children. I'm not taking care of children from my father!"

For most of our encounter, Jarre fits easily into the role of the ageless celebrity, one of the most successful post-Beatles musicians. Everyone around him bangs on about how wonderful he looks for his age ("Fit, 50 and not a firework in sight!" begins his press pack). And he does. He was on "a silly" French version of This Is Your Life recently, and "suddenly you are in front of your mates of when you were 14 and they were these old, established people. I had the feeling they belonged to the generation of my father."

But, after talking for a while, he begins to act his age, giving a nice rant at the French tax system when I asked how rich he was (he and Rampling brought their children up in a 14-bedroom chateau at Versailles; he still lives nearby). "I am not at all like these English pop stars who are not paying taxes by having these big tours and avoiding any traps with the tax," he said crossly. "I am a victim of the highest tax in Europe.

"It's a joke in France. If you have so many people unemployed it's because people are living on this system, working to just the limit and getting paid in black [economy] money, while a small percentage of people are working day and night for really the rest of the country."

He's gone off America: "It's an old-new concept. It's a dated country." He's fed up with being associated with lasers. "I don't like lasers. I think it's very disco. I'm not a fan." He's against cosmetic surgery. "All these silly things people are doing. Charlotte thinks exactly the same. It's too much." And he gets a bit hot under the collar about cigarettes too. "Really I am fed up. In record institutions you have four people smoking around you, it's really affecting. I really hate this more and more." He screwed up his nose.

"But what I hate the most, I must say, particularly in London, is noisy restaurants. I can't stand that any more. More and more restaurants are like gymnasiums. This Conran is like a railway station.

"I was in this restaurant the other day and I looked around and it was like people were having arguments with one another and I thought to myself we should organise intercoms for people to talk to one another at lunch!"

By now he had completely forgotten himself. "The next step, the next luxury," he said, "will be to have a quiet place, and to shoot the pianist."

It's sad because apart from the personal things, it is quite unusual from a professional point of view when a French person is internationally successful in music, but to have two in the same family, it is crazy not to share that." His father has another son from a more recent relationship. "I think it's even worse with this one than with me." Have you met him? "No. Er, yes... I've met him, but, you know, I have enough responsibility with my own children. I'm not taking care of children from my father!" For most of our encounter, Jarre fits easily into the role of the ageless celebrity, one of the most successful post-Beatles musicians. Everyone around him bangs on about how wonderful he looks for his age ("Fit, 50 and not a firework in sight!" begins his press pack). And he does. He was on "a silly" French version of This Is Your Life recently, and "suddenly you are in front of your mates of when you were 14 and they were these old, established people. I had the feeling they belonged to the generation of my father." But, after talking for a while, he begins to act his age, giving a nice rant at the French tax system when I asked how rich he was (he and Rampling brought their children up in a 14-bedroom chateau at Versailles; he still lives nearby). "I am not at all like these English pop stars who are not paying taxes by having these big tours and avoiding any traps with the tax," he said crossly. "I am a victim of the highest tax in Europe. "It's a joke in France. If you have so many people unemployed it's because people are living on this system, working to just the limit and getting paid in black [economy] money, while a small percentage of people are working day and night for really the rest of the country." He's gone off America: "It's an old-new concept. It's a dated country." He's fed up with being associated with lasers. "I don't like lasers. I think it's very disco. I'm not a fan." He's against cosmetic surgery. "All these silly things people are doing. Charlotte thinks exactly the same. It's too much." And he gets a bit hot under the collar about cigarettes too. "Really I am fed up. In record institutions you have four people smoking around you, it's really affecting. I really hate this more and more." He screwed up his nose. "But what I hate the most, I must say, particularly in London, is noisy restaurants. I can't stand that any more. More and more restaurants are like gymnasiums. This Conran is like a railway station. "I was in this restaurant the other day and I looked around and it was like people were having arguments with one another and I thought to myself we should organise intercoms for people to talk to one another at lunch!" By now he had completely forgotten himself. "The next step, the next luxury," he said, "will be to have a quiet place, and to shoot the pianist."

fields.headline: No: 1558 Frank McCourt
fields.trailText: Age: Top of the morning to you.
fields.body:
Age: Top of the morning to you.

No, how old is he? Ah, begorrah, you'll be after his age, will you?

That's the long and short of it. B'jasus, if only I could remember. It's so long since he's lived in these parts. He emigrated to the US when he was 19, y'know.

Well, have a guess: Holy Mary, etc, etc, he must be 70 if he's a day.

Good. Look, we may have to speed things up a bit. Now, don't be hurrying me. Will you be having a few jars?

Perhaps later. Appearance: Well, he was in Dublin for a book signing the other week.

No, what does he look like? Pensive.

Surely not. His first book, Angela's Ashes, was an international bestseller; the sequel, 'Tis, is doing very nicely; and this week sees the release of the film of Angela's Ashes, starring Emily Watson and Robert Carlyle. This is not by way of being a commercial, is it?

Of course not: . . . Because Frank isn't too popular here in Limerick.

Why's that? Well, there's a feeling that his book was unfair to his mammy, to the Catholic church, and to the plain folk of Ireland; that he exaggerated the suffering and twisted the truth. Local DJ Gerry Hannon is publishing a riposte to 'Tis called 'Tis In Me Ass.

But McCourt's childhood was appalling: alcoholic father, downtrodden mother, dying siblings; ceaseless suffering, hunger and humiliation; sleeping in flea-ridden beds, begging for food, eating out of jam jars . . . To be sure, but think of the spirit of the place, man. Will you be sinking some black?

No thanks, not in this dump. Begob! You're as bad as he is.

Not to be confused with: The even more miserable Frank Dobson.

Do say: "These ridiculous Oirish expressions serve only to perpetuate an outmoded view of a rapidly changing society."

Don't say: "There was a poor Limerick lad / Whose family history was sad / Nothing to eat / No shoes on his feet / Hey, get me an agent!"

fields.headline: Sorry, you don't exist
fields.trailText: Do not mess,  cher lecteur , with French bureaucracy. I say this having spoken to one Pascal Weber, who is without job, unemployment benefit or chequebook - and all because another Pascal Weber, born on the same day of the same month of the same year, did not pay a tax bill.
fields.body:
Do not mess, cher lecteur , with French bureaucracy. I say this having spoken to one Pascal Weber, who is without job, unemployment benefit or chequebook - and all because another Pascal Weber, born on the same day of the same month of the same year, did not pay a tax bill.

The story of Weber (the right Weber, that is, the one now being hounded simultaneously by the tax authorities, health insurance inspector, dole office, bank and bailiff) is straight out of Kafka: in other words, an object lesson in the ways of Gallic officialdom.

On July 4, 1996, Pascal, an electrician in the Moselle, was made redundant. Signing on for benefit, he was surprised to be told he already had. Look, said the clerk: Pascal Weber, born March 14, 1964, in Haut-Rhin.

Ah, said Pascal, but that's not me: I was born in Luxembourg.

"And I thought that was that," he said. "More fool me. A week later, I go to withdraw some cash from the building society and am told my account's blocked. I tell them they have the wrong person; they won't listen. Then comes a tax demand, for £11,500. I show them I've already paid; they won't listen."

Slowly, but surely, the wrong Weber - an unemployed drifter whom the right Weber has never succeeded in tracking down - takes over. Hospital bills start arriving from Colmar, credit card bills from Strasbourg, social security and health insurance cards from Mulhouse.

Despairing that even his bank can't get it right, Weber tries to change; the new one says sorry, you're on a blacklist.

Weber (the right Weber) has tried everything. He has written to the Luxembourg consul, the public prosecutor, Jacques Chirac, Lionel Jospin, his Royal Highness the Grand Duke Jean of Luxembourg. He has hired expensive lawyers, appeared on television. To no avail. The word bureaucracy is not of French origin for nothing.

Take, for example, the process of applying for a residence permit. It goes something like this: first, you spend about five hours in an over-crowded room clutching a number. Of the dozen or so booths, only three are open. When your turn comes, you are given a list of the dozen or so documents you need, of which you possess only three.

Then you return and repeat the process. Dimly, as if from many miles away, you hear the words: "Désolé, monsieur, mais vous avez oublié votre certificat d'assurance/contrat d'emploi/carte de sécurité sociale."

In vain, you protest that you are unable to obtain the above without a residence permit. So you are given a piece of paper. But it is only valid for six months, after which you must return with what you think are the right documents but aren't.

All this, of course, is kindergarten stuff compared to what Pascal Weber has been through. But someone, somewhere in government seems to have seen it.

A remarkable report on the residence permit situation for the interior minister last week slammed "interminable queues, repetitive and redundant appointments, a lack of information and clarity on what papers are needed and an aggressiveness on the part of certain employees".

It said that 50% of the entire procedure should be scrapped immediately. There's the immigration service dealt with, then.

That just leaves social security, unemployment, most banks, health insurance, the gas, the electricity and the woman from France Telecom who wouldn't sell me a new mobile phone last week without seeing my passport, residence permit and contract of employment. Shouldn't be too hard.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: Ann Robinson has been appointed chairman of the Gas Consumers' Council and the Electricity Consumers' Committee (ECC) for London, and not for a wider area as our City briefing, page 22, January 6, may have suggested. Hers is one of 14 regional ECCs. The chairmanship of the other regional ECCs and the National Electricity Consumers' Council is not affected by Ann Robinson's appointments.
fields.body:
Ann Robinson has been appointed chairman of the Gas Consumers' Council and the Electricity Consumers' Committee (ECC) for London, and not for a wider area as our City briefing, page 22, January 6, may have suggested. Hers is one of 14 regional ECCs. The chairmanship of the other regional ECCs and the National Electricity Consumers' Council is not affected by Ann Robinson's appointments.

Andrew Boff has asked us to say that, contrary to an assertion in a report on our front page, December 29, he is not intending to run as an independent in the election for mayor of London. He remains a candidate for the Conservative party nomination.

A caption on page 15, January 5, was wrong to describe those shown as "Followers of the New York-based Rabbi Lubavitch..." They were fol lowers of the New York-based Lubavitch Hasidic movement, led for 44 years until his death in 1994 by Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson.

We misspelt the name of Anita Gale, wrongly calling her Gayle throughout a piece about her and others in Women, page 6, G2, January 4. Apologies.

The cartoonist to whom Kenneth Baker referred in an article about British views of the French was Hogarth, not Hoggart, page 6, The Editor, January 7. We were misquoting from the Daily Telegraph where the full article appeared, naming him correctly.

A letter from Barbara Matthews, page 27, December 11, associated her with The Society of London Theatre. In fact, she is the president of Theatrical Management Association (TMA). The president of The Society of London Theatre (SOLT) is Martin McCallum. Apologies to both.

A trail on Page 5, January 7, wrongly attributed the film Angela's Ashes to Neil Jordan. We should have credited Alan Parker.

Reinhold Messner, the mountaineer and explorer, is not German, as we said he was on page 16, January 7. He is Italian, born in 1944 at Bressanone in Trentino-Alto Adige.

fields.headline: Wheel of progress
fields.standfirst: Raleigh driven to new site
fields.trailText: Bike manufacturer Raleigh is looking for a new home in a move that will end more than 100 years of production on its present Nottingham site.
fields.body:
Bike manufacturer Raleigh is looking for a new home in a move that will end more than 100 years of production on its present Nottingham site.

The 600 workers have been told the factory is to be sold and that the company is looking for another site near the city. Senior management said the move would not result in job losses and would lead to a production increase.

The company is looking for a brownfield site ready for clearance rather than following the example of car makers such as Honda and Nissan, which have built on greenfield sites.

The announcement was being seen as an attempt by new managing director Phillip Darnton, who took over on Tuesday, to halt the company's decline in the face of tough competition from overseas. "This will allow us to become more cost-effective and more competitive," said Mr Darnton. "This is not a job-shedding exercise by any means.

"Old buildings such as those we have occupied for decades are no longer appropriate in today's production processes."

He said the company, which now assembles and paints bikes from imported parts, wants to increase production from its present 520,000 a year.

The new site has not been identified but Raleigh has four years to move after agreeing to sell its land to Nottingham university to extend its Jubilee campus.

Raleigh began making bikes at the Radford factory, then just seven and a half acres, in 1896 after relocating from Russell Street in Nottingham. At the time it was the world's biggest cycle factory.

webTitle: City expects MPC to raise loan rates

fields.headline: City expects MPC to raise loan rates
fields.trailText: Business leaders yesterday appealed to the Bank of England's monetary policy committee to spare industry an interest rate rise when it holds its first meeting of the new year this week. But with house prices rising rapidly and earnings growth drifting upwards, the City expects the appeal to go unheeded.
fields.body:
Business leaders yesterday appealed to the Bank of England's monetary policy committee to spare industry an interest rate rise when it holds its first meeting of the new year this week. But with house prices rising rapidly and earnings growth drifting upwards, the City expects the appeal to go unheeded.

Most analysts are anticipating a quarter-point increase in the cost of borrowing to 5.75% on Thursday, with a few opting for a bigger 0.5% point rise.

In an interview on GMTV's Sunday Programme, Digby Jones, the new director general of the Confederation of British Industry, said he did not want a return to boom and bust. But he added that the MPC should give growth a chance before raising rates, already increased twice since September, again.

"Look at it again in February, and look at it again in March, but no interest rate rise would be very good news for the UK economy," said Mr Jones.

The City regards a rate rise from 5.5% as almost inevitable after a raft of data in the past few weeks showing house prices rising at the fastest rate since the late 1980s boom, earnings growth accelerating towards 5% and a surge in high street spending over Christmas.

At the last MPC meeting in December, three out of the nine MPC members voted for a rise and a majority of the others agreed that it was likely that a further tightening of policy would be needed to ensure the government hits it 2.5% inflation target.

The latest figures are likely to convince the committee waverers that now is the time to act, say economists.

In its World Outlook 2000, published today, the Economist Intelligence Unit predicts British rates will peak at 6.25%, compared to 7.5% during the previous cycle.

It says sub-Saharan Africa, one of the world's poorest regions, will be the fastest growing area this year followed by the Middle East and north Africa, Latin America and north America.

"Higher commodity prices will benefit sub-Saharan Africa, which is forecast to grow by 4% in 2000, the best performance of any region," says the unit. "Mozambique will be the fastest growing country in 2000, based on strong growth in mining."

webTitle: Business rivals plan joint spin for industry

fields.headline: Business rivals plan joint spin for industry
fields.trailText: The war is over. Britain's two premier and rival business organisations, the Confederation of British Industry and the Institute of Directors, are burying the hatchet and joining forces to launch a campaign to improve industry's image in the community.
fields.body:
The war is over. Britain's two premier and rival business organisations, the Confederation of British Industry and the Institute of Directors, are burying the hatchet and joining forces to launch a campaign to improve industry's image in the community.

Due to be officially announced in the next few weeks, the initiative is seen as heralding a warming of relations between the CBI and IoD, which have been at loggerheads over the business approach to New Labour in power.

Leading directors have accused the CBI of being far too cosy with the government, and have been especially critical of the softly-softly approach adopted by Adair Turner, the rival body's director general until the end of last month.

The IoD believes that business organisations as a whole - including the CBI - should have taken a far more robust and public stance towards the increased regulations which have been imposed by government via policies such as the minimum wage and the working time directive.

George Cox, who has been the IoD's director general for the past four months, is understood to have approached Digby Jones, his new opposite number at the CBI, suggesting that the two groups and the British Chambers of Commerce join forces to run the campaign - and Mr Jones instantly agreed.

The initiative embracing the BCC is designed to encourage a "risk culture" and to promote a sizeable increase the numbers of entrepreneurs in Britain over the next decade.

The BCC, CBI and IoD are now proposing to lead the national enterprise campaign on a rolling basis to prevent it being dissipated in a variety of well-meaning but ultimately ineffective initiatives.

The IoD argues that while earlier campaigns such as Business in the Community and the Prince's Trust have achieved much, the culture and attitudes of a large proportion of the population remain hostile and negative towards business.

A crucial aim is to build on the IoD's Hub programme and send 1,000 business ambassadors into the community, including schools, to promote greater trust in industry and commerce and counter the widespread view that business leaders care not a fig for their local communities.

Mr Cox said: "Altering the attitude towards business is a huge task; if we are to make any impression it is an area where the major organisations concerned with representing business - albeit from their different standpoints - have to join forces."

webTitle: RMC warns fine will put 10% dent in profits

fields.headline: RMC warns fine will put 10% dent in profits
fields.trailText: Concrete group RMC will warn shareholders on Thursday that a multi-million pound fine from Germany's anti-monopoly authorities is likely to wipe out more than 10% of 1999 profits, a bigger than expected dent in earnings. The group is appealing to Berlin's tax authorities for a rebate but has accepted the fine is fair.
fields.body:
Concrete group RMC will warn shareholders on Thursday that a multi-million pound fine from Germany's anti-monopoly authorities is likely to wipe out more than 10% of 1999 profits, a bigger than expected dent in earnings. The group is appealing to Berlin's tax authorities for a rebate but has accepted the fine is fair.

It follows a price fixing scandal that resulted in three German local managers being fined between £8,300 and £33,000 by Germany's federal cartel office. All three have since left the group. It is thought the price-rigging was organised at plant level in minutes, making the cartel office's job relatively easy.

Last year, it emerged the office was investigating 56 concrete firms, including RMC, operating in the Brandenburg region between the old iron curtain and Berlin. RMC - nearly 30% of whose profits come from Germany - warned shareholders that any fine was likely to be "material" in terms of 1999 profits.

But the company played down suggestions the office would be likely to levy a fine of 10% or more of profits. Now, it seems, the penalty is in the region of £34m, against expected pre-tax profits for the whole group of £300m for 1999.

RMC is appealing not against the findings but against its German tax bill, which, it argues, ought to be reduced on the ground that it ought not to pay taxes on profits effectively being confiscated.

Should the tax appeal succeed - and the chances are not thought to be great - RMC's total bill for the price-fixing affair will shrink from about £34m to about £22m.

Two senior officials from RMC's German operation who have seats on the company's main board are to remain with the company. fields.headline: M&S hires top image consultant
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer is planning to revamp its image with the help of the prestigious design consultancy, Interbrand Gerstman+Meyers.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer is planning to revamp its image with the help of the prestigious design consultancy, Interbrand Gerstman+Meyers.

The struggling high street retailer, which has seen sales fall dramatically over the past 18 months, confirmed yesterday that it had hired the consultancy to help it make the M&S brand more productive.

The decision to overhaul the company's image comes almost eight months after executives signalled that a revival was needed to haul the group out of a slump. Last year the company was the subject of bid speculation amid accusations of poor management.

A spokeswoman admitted the stores group had failed to make the most of its prominent position on the high street. "There's a recognition that it is a world class brand and there is a recognition that it is perhaps something we have not pushed as hard as we could have done. We are looking at that," she said.

News of the revamp emerged ahead of publication of M&S's crucial Christmas sales figures, due for publication on Wednesday.

However, the retailer is unlikely ever to return to its halcyon days as Britain's top retailer because "more nimble" competitors - including those from the United States and mainland Europe - were rushing to offer shoppers more choice, consultancy Retail Index said yesterday.

Sunday papers carried contradictory reports about how M&S had performed at Christmas: the Mail on Sunday said it had suffered a 10% slump in sales but the Observer insisted business had been better than predicted. M&S shares closed at 307.75p on Friday, up from November's low of 227p but still less than half peak value.

webTitle: Express sale key to Granada bid

fields.headline: Express sale key to Granada bid
fields.trailText: An early demerger of its hotels and media businesses combined with the sale of Express Newspapers emerged yesterday as two likely outcomes of a successful bid by Granada for United News & Media or Carlton Communications.
fields.body:
An early demerger of its hotels and media businesses combined with the sale of Express Newspapers emerged yesterday as two likely outcomes of a successful bid by Granada for United News & Media or Carlton Communications.

The potential moves came to light as investors pondered the implications of Friday's announcement by Granada that it may gatecrash Carlton and UN&M's merger plans by making a rival offer for one or other of the media groups.

Although Granada declined to comment yesterday on speculation about its bid tactics sources confirmed the group was likely to consider demerging its hotels and media businesses once it had made a bid.

Granada chairman Gerry Robinson has made it clear in the past that he is ready to consider a demerger - but only after weighing up the benefits of sharper focus that such a move would bring against the possible disadvantage of loss of size.

Were Granada to buy either Carlton or UN&M, Granada's media businesses would be large enough to stand alone.

However it is unlikely that Mr Robinson and chief executive Charles Allen would be rushed into a demerger, and they are likely to reassure investors that the move would only take place if it were to benefit shareholders.

City sources also expect Granada to sell Express Newspapers if the group bids for UN&M rather than Carlton. The newspapers have been identified as a cornerstone of Lord Hollick's strategy for UN&M and Carlton should they be allowed to merge.

On Thursday the first deadline for shareholder acceptances for the Carlton-UN&M merger will pass.

Advisers to UN&M and Carlton are expecting few shareholders to respond by that date - given that the bid appears likely to be referred to the competition commission.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
RBS renews offensive
Royal Bank of Scotland is this week expected to relaunch its assault on NatWest. Brandishing "proof" from Deloitte Consulting, RBS will try to prove that bank mergers can and do work, despite claims to the contrary during the four-month £25bn battle.
fields.body:
RBS renews offensive
Royal Bank of Scotland is this week expected to relaunch its assault on NatWest. Brandishing "proof" from Deloitte Consulting, RBS will try to prove that bank mergers can and do work, despite claims to the contrary during the four-month £25bn battle.

The City believes that RBS hopes to improve its share price at the expense of NatWest and counter-bidder Bank of Scotland in the weeks before the Valentine's day deadline in the battle - and therefore avoid having to raise its bid for NatWest.

Ellis & Everard trades on site
A specialist chemicals company is claiming to be the first British public limited company to offer investors the opportunity of buying shares through its own website. The move is a further indication of how seriously private investors are being taken by quoted companies.

Chemical distribution company Ellis & Everard has a website which offers a direct link to xest.com, the online brokerage service operated by stockbroker Charles Stanley. Website visitors can browse a portal for private or professional investors.

White collar dispute at Ford
Thousands of engineers and other professional staff at Ford are threatening their first national strike in a dispute over pay and conditions. The staff, at plants throughout Britain including the factories at Dagenham in Essex and Halewood on Merseyside, are seeking a deal similar to one agreed with manual employees. Union leaders said Ford's final offer to salaried staff was worth 11% over three years - compared with a deal with hourly paid workers worth 15%.

Hopes dip for Transtec
Hopes that Transtec, the engineering firm which collapsed last year with debts in excess of £70m, would survive a period in administration before potential buyers could be lined up looked increasingly improbable over the weekend.

Government sources indicated that a £6.9m grant to build a factory in Northern Ireland could be claimed back, making the firm less attractive to buyers. Two former directors were also accused of knowing about the existence of a £10.9m claim by Ford against Transtec, without informing other board members.

webTitle: How Emu rides roughshod over social concerns

fields.headline: How Emu rides roughshod over social concerns
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: If you are against the single currency, it seems you have to get used to being caricatured as an antediluvian "little Englander". After all, the argument goes, surely anybody who is on the same side of the debate as Rupert Murdoch must be reactionary, xenophobic, and "anti-European". Well, no, actually.
fields.body:
If you are against the single currency, it seems you have to get used to being caricatured as an antediluvian "little Englander". After all, the argument goes, surely anybody who is on the same side of the debate as Rupert Murdoch must be reactionary, xenophobic, and "anti-European". Well, no, actually.

While it is true that opposition to the euro brings with it some strange and often questionable bed-fellows, it is perfectly possible - and urgent -for progressive internationalists to oppose the single currency. That is why British Greens are supporting New Europe - a group of people from all political backgrounds who share our opposition.

That does not make us anti-European. Far from it. It is precisely because we have a wider vision about the role of Europe that we are so critical of the narrowly defined economic objectives of the European Union, of which Emu is now becoming such a key part.

The debate about the single currency goes to the heart of the wider discussion about what kind of Europe we want. We can sign up to an EU of ever more open markets, dominated by big business interests. Or we can work towards a more inspiring vision, where the EU takes the lead on issues of peace and democracy; where it is in the vanguard of progressive policies to rebuild local communities, and to further social justice and human rights; and where its environmental understanding and policy-making set an example for the world.

British Greens believe that, if the EU is to have social and environmental justice at the heart of its domestic and international policies, it must develop and promote strong, self-reliant regional economies rather than ever greater economic centralisation. We therefore oppose the single currency, not for narrow nationalistic reasons, but because we oppose one of its overriding aims: to accelerate economic globalisation by increasing international trade and to create an economic superpower able to compete more efficiently with the United States and Japan. In this dubious economic experiment, not only is the economic logic faulty, but it rides roughshod over important social and environmental concerns.

There is plenty of evidence to suggest that a single currency will increase regional disparities, add to unemployment across Europe and undermine local economies.

For Greens, the task of shifting local and national economies on to more sustainable foundations will be set back if key levers of eco nomic decision making are handed to an undemocratic, unaccountable central bank.

This centralisation of economic decision-making cannot possibly meet the needs of 370m Europeans: each region in Europe differs too greatly, and their economies, histories, and cultures are too diverse.

Even within Britain, the effects of having one currency -and one interest rate - may be to increase divisions. We are already witnessing interest rate rises stifling the north of England because of "overheating" in the south-east. That situation is likely to be even more pronounced under the euro.

Emu proponents invariably point to how it will improve the EU's international competitiveness through reduced transaction costs and lower inflation rates.

But being "internationally competitive" is fast becoming the problem, not the solution, for Europe. It is no exaggeration to say that Emu, and the rush to the single market, with its reduction of protective barriers between countries, is cor roding the social, employment and environmental structure of our continent.

The Green Party is proposing a very different approach which would enable national and local governments to take back control of their economies, increasing their diversity in order to rebuild security and stability.

Over time, goods and services would be provided more locally wherever feasible and appropriate, greatly reducing the volume of long distance trade.

Import and export controls, local competition policy, regulation of transnational corporations, and the reorientation of the goals of aid and trade policies so that they contribute to the rebuilding of local and regional economies worldwide would be among the measures needed to achieve this.

Before dismissing this as unworkable, it is worth recalling the absurdity that a huge proportion of international trade involves the simultaneous import and export of almost identical products.

The debate about the euro ought to be an opportunity to consider proposals such as these, to reassess our vision of Europe and to debate how we will rise to the vital challenge of enlarging to the east and south.

The present level of debate represents a tragedy of lost opportunity for, in the facile exchanges taking place between the Europhobes and the Europhiles, such fundamental issues never seem to be touched upon.

Yet not to do so brings high risks: the EU faces a crisis of confidence, as the pitifully low turn-out in the European elections recently demonstrated, which no amount of spin-doctoring will address.

People will only engage with a Europe that is relevant to their everyday lives and which they feel is democratic and accountable. Economic and monetary union is moving in precisely the opposite direction.

Caroline Lucas is a Green MEP: www.greenparty.org.uk www.new-europe.co.uk

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Observer
fields.body:
Observer

Computer experts in Russia believe that the west overreacted to the millennium bug . The Russian government and business sector spent only £200m preparing for the date change, and one analyst said the US might have wasted up to $40bn preparing for the bug. In all, spending on the bug worldwide is estimated to have reached $400bn.

The two directors who resigned from Transtec, the collapsed engineering company amid accusations of accounting irregularities, knew about an £11.2m claim agreed with Ford Motors but failed to disclose it to their board, the paper claims.

Sunday Times

BT is to bid for Irish telecoms company Esat Telecom, at present the subject of a hostile bid by Norway's Telenor. BT has sought clearance from competition officials in Brussels.

The number of women in UK boardrooms is on the increase. Research reveals that women make up one third of all directors in the UK. According to research by Experian, the information solutions company, women make up one third of of all directors in the UK. Most reach senior positions in the service sector, with 44% of all female directors working in banking, finance or insurance.

The paper also said that cost-cutting by Ford Motors is to centre on its Belgian plant in Genk.

Sunday Telegraph

The Post Office is to install 3,000 cash machines in villages around the UK in co-operation with high street banks and building socities. The plan will also involve the installation of a secure national network for transactions, which the Post Office said it would like to offer free unless forced to charge by the banks.

Bus and train company Arriva is in talks aimed at a £70m bid for Merseyside rival MTL.

Insurance group CGU is to sell its mortgage portfolio to Skipton Building Society for £160m, while anglo-Swiss Zurich Financial is said to have hired Morgan Stanley to advise on its £7bn bid for Royal & Sun Alliance.

IoS

The National Audit Office is to investigate whether ministers wasted public money preparing for the millennium bug. Its report, to be published in the spring, will be followed by a further inquiry by the Public Accounts Committee.

Channel 5 has accepted stakes in a series of internet companies in return for allowing them air time to advertise their businesses.

The government is considering claiming back a £6.9m it gave to Geoffrey Robinson's failed engineering company Transtec. It said the grant, which was used to build a factory in Northern Ireland, could be claimed back from administrators Arthur Andersen if it is stripped by a trade buyer or put to a different use. The grant was made based on assurances that Ford Motors had increased its demand for Transtec motor parts when it was subsequently discovered Ford had lodged a claim for £10.9m for the late delivery of parts.

Mail on Sunday

Kevin Maxwell, son of the disgraced tycoon Robert Maxwell, plans to set up a trust fund of at least £1m to help victims of the Mirror newspapers pension scandal. The size of the fund will depend on the success of his telecoms company, Telemonde.

Walt Disney chief Michael Eisner is in danger of losing his title as the world's best paid boss after a dismal year at the entertainment firm. Last year Forbes magazine calculated that Eisner earned £360m.

Sunday Business

Japanese finance house Nomura has been shortlisted to buy the controversial Millennium Dome at Greenwich. The government will announce the offer this week. Nomura is leading a consortium masterminded by Guy Hands, managing director of the bank's principal finance division.

British Airways is heading for a damaging showdown with pilot unions over plans to hand European routes to CityFlyer Express, one of the airline's low cost subsidiaries. The pilots are worried about job security.

The Queen has joined the internet gold-rush by ordering the stockbroker to the privy purse to buy shares worth £100,000 in the Millennium Mapping Company, a private group which is assembling a complete aerial photograph of the UK.

Reports out this week Today

Interims Pace Micro Technology. Finals Hacas Group, Ward Holdings. AGMs Greenalls, BGI Endowment Fund II. EGMs Orchard Furniture.

Tuesday

Interims Anite Group, Ellis & Everard, Jurys Doyle Hotel, Osmetech, Precoat International, Savills. Finals Chemring Group. AGMs Majedie Investments, Minorplanet. EGMs Newcastle United, Card Clear, eVestment Co, Whitecroft.

Wednesday

Interims Dixons Group, Reg Vardy. AGMs Diploma, MJ Gleeson, Wigmore Property. EGMs Towry Law.

Thursday

Interims Abbey, Capital Bars, Kleeneze. Finals Greenwich Resources. AGMs Carr's Milling, Royal Bank of Scotland. EGMs PNC Tele.com, United News & Media.

Friday

Interims The Old Monk Company. Finals WF Electrical. AGMs Get Group. EGMs Enterprise Capital, National Westminster Bank.

Indicators this week Today

UK CBI financial services survey (Jan).

Tuesday

UK BRC retail sales (Dec). UK EEF business trends survey (Q4).

Wednesday

UK BoE MPC meeting. UK BDO monthly business trends survey. US Treasury auction of 10 year inflation-indexed notes. GER 1999 GDP. FR Provisional CPI (Dec).

Thursday

UK BoE interest rate decision. US Producer prices (Dec).

Friday

US Consumer prices (Dec). UK Halifax house price survey (Q4).

fields.headline: Worm's eye
fields.trailText: In a season of landmark dates and important anniversaries there is one birthday that shouldn't pass without notice; Selsdon Man is 30 this month.
fields.body:
In a season of landmark dates and important anniversaries there is one birthday that shouldn't pass without notice; Selsdon Man is 30 this month.

Three decades back, he emerged blinking into frosty sunshine outside the eponymous Croydon hotel in the aftermath of a weekend "strategy meeting" of the Conservative Party, then - as now - in opposition. Proud midwives stood around in self-consciously casual pullovers: a youthful Peter Walker, an unchanged Geoffrey Howe, a beaming ERGH.

At the time, Selsdon was seen as the original "lurch to the right", the ditching of the paternalistic Tory tradition in favour of what the party leader described as "a new economic order based on the disciplines of a market economy".

Conventional wisdom has it that the Selsdon programme - with its declaration that "lame ducks" in industry would no longer receive government support - collapsed at the first sign of picket line trouble and the first hint of rising unemployment. Not for another decade did a Tory leader have the "guts" to give Selsdon Man his head.

In fact, nothing could be further from the truth. Twelve months after Selsdon, with the Conservatives in government, Bank of England governor Lord O'Brien used a dinner with chancellor Anthony Barber to reveal proposals for the mendaciously named "competition and credit control" (CCC).

The package was implemented later in 1971 and involved the large scale deregulation of British banking. Despite at least two catastrophic periods of credit inflation consequent on CCC - 1972/3 and 1987/9 - the liberation of the banks has never seriously been challenged.

In his excellent book Prawn Cocktail Party (Vision: 1998), Robin Ramsay gives the best and pithiest summary of CCC: "It was simply the old order being re-imposed on the British economy. This was the climax of all those attempts since the post-war era to get rid of government controls.

"Under the new system the banks could lend what they liked and, when it was decided that there was too much credit in the system, they would put the interest rates up. What a truly wonderful racket!"

Thanks to Selsdon Man the asset-stripping of British industry and the destruction of its employ ment base could begin in earnest not, as is popularly supposed in 1979, or 1992, but 29 years ago this month, the date of the fateful O'Brien dinner.

Perhaps someone this past weekend has been hosting a sort of reverse Selsdon summit in which a few foolhardy souls discuss ways and means of bringing the banks back under control. But surveying the political scene, it would be foolish to bet on it.

So many unhappy returns to Selsdon Man and, more to the point, to the rest of us as well.

webTitle: Just three quid, and lots of change

fields.headline: Just three quid, and lots of change
fields.standfirst: The once shabby Pompidou Centre has been transformed into an airy, almost elegant cultural treasure trove. And what's more, writes  Jonathan Glancey  , it's cheap to get in
fields.trailText: The signs are silly, the staff surly, some of the new displays potty, the lavatories unspeakably filthy... At this point, criticism begins to trail off. The refitted and repainted Pompidou Centre is something of a wonder. Go there as soon as you can, for here, in the heart of Paris, you will see for yourself how the broadest possible public can be offered culture without compromise - "the right twigs for an eagle's nest" as Yeats put it - in a building that remains as striking, if not quite as controversial, as it was when Richard Rogers and Renzo Piano's original design was attacked for looking too much like a gasworks back in 1977.
fields.body:
The signs are silly, the staff surly, some of the new displays potty, the lavatories unspeakably filthy... At this point, criticism begins to trail off. The refitted and repainted Pompidou Centre is something of a wonder. Go there as soon as you can, for here, in the heart of Paris, you will see for yourself how the broadest possible public can be offered culture without compromise - "the right twigs for an eagle's nest" as Yeats put it - in a building that remains as striking, if not quite as controversial, as it was when Richard Rogers and Renzo Piano's original design was attacked for looking too much like a gasworks back in 1977.

Experience the fast-moving queue in the capacious piazza that fronts the building to the west, and see just how many people can't wait to get inside one of the world's finest cultural centres. Unlike some overhyped cultural attractions that have opened this year, visitors would be lying if they said they were disappointed by the exhibits, or thought that 30 francs (£3) was too much to pay to see as much Picasso, Braque, Ernst, Tinguely, Klein and Calder as you can manage without suffering visual indigestion. And these are before attempting to tackle the delightful displays of modern architecture, graphics, photography and design. Stuff all this nonsense about "virtual" exhibitions, the decline of the "object" and cyberspace: people from all walks of life, all ages and all corners of the world love to see the range and quality of the very real things - paintings, sculpture, furniture, architectural models - the Pompidou has on display. It offers a truly "fantastic" day out and demands not just one return visit, but many.

The centre had been closed until January 1 for 27 long months. Under the direction of Piano, but without Rogers on a formal basis, other firms of architects have been involved in bringing the Pompidou up to date and enabling it to cope with the tidal wave of visitors that had crashed and rolled through its steely interiors since its opening by Valéry Giscard-d'Estaing on January 31, 1977.

During that time no fewer than 145m visitors came to ride the external escalators with their cinematic views of central Paris and to shoulder their way through great exhibitions devoted to Dali (the most popular of all, in 1980), Matisse and Derain. That's an average of 23,000 a day, and this for a cultural centre designed for an optimistic capacity of 5,000 a day. No wonder the Pompidou was looking shabby and threadbare by the mid-90s. But who now remembers the cavernous lobby with its soiled grey carpet, the tons of grime accumulated on the building's prominently displayed (or "Bowellist") ductwork and the lack of proper cafes, bookshop and spaces to unwind? Today the building looks and feels light, airy, almost elegant. This is not just because it sparkles like a liner out of dry dock after a major refit, but also because the west front has been painted a convincing shade of white (with subtle yellow bands behind windows and the undersides of the escalator tubes painted a handsome red), leaving the less visited east front in the toy-like reds and blues that, fashionable among architects back in the mid-70s, seem hard on the retina today.

The building has been much modified internally. The admin offices have gone, clearing a whole floor for more art. The vast entrance lobby is much lighter and more welcoming. On opposed mezzanines, north and south, Piano has added an open cafe, and, more controversially, an open shop, the first museum shop of its kind, in fact - no doors, no windows and best of all, no tat.

In this franchise from the department store Printemps, the "designer" merchandise, arranged like a street market, has been selected by Yves Marbrier, the stylist who has brought intelligent new design to many Parisian outlets. Below shop and cafe are a childrens' rumpus room (the sort of mimsy you expect to find in Ikea) and a bookshop twice as big as before.

At the centre of this space is a stunted tree growing from a huge cube of earth rising from the basement (where four new performance and lecture spaces, including a second cinema, have been shaped) and a shoulder-shrugging information desk. (Don't try to speak a foreign language and, whatever you do, don't attempt your school French; this will only make matters all the more degrading for you, rosbif .)

Smooth-running external escalators lead up to a new library designed by Jean-François Bodin, who has also re-dressed the Museum of Modern Art above it. The museum is on two levels, connected by a rather temporary-looking stair. The sub-John Pawson, white-painted minimalist joinery here is scarcely a match for the breathtaking collection of 20th-century art on the upper level, nor does it come anywhere near matching the superb new exterior lake terraces Piano has added to punctuate the generously spaced, if near relentless sequence of masterpieces.

These terraces are an inspiring touch. From inside the museum, surrounded by the works of Giacometti, of Picabia and Delaunay, visitors can gaze over watery terraces animated by Miro, Ernst and Calder sculptures and through the cat's cradle of Piano + Rogers' structure to famous Parisian monuments of earlier heroic moments. At one point, they can see the mount of artistic Montmartre and its crown, the Sacré Coeur basilica, framed by the legs of a hefty Calder sculpture: the artworld caught in the leghold of a major artwork.

The museum is neatly ordered, with paintings and sculpture housed in small-scale white pavilions (none is exhausting; museum fatigue sets in slowly) leading off a main internal "street" on both levels. On both of these, pre- and post-1950, the pavilions of painting and sculpture lead into others displaying design and architecture. This is a controversial decision in curatorial circles, but it works pretty well, because the selection of architectural drawings and models, of chairs and cameras and even computers (it's fun to see one of those faddish iMacs, dated 1998, already preserved in a display case) has been rigorous. For anyone keen on architecture, the sight of Tchernikov's fantasies, Le Corbusier's early sketches and presentation drawings of the Villa Savoye and rare designs by Pierre Chareau (of the Paris "Glass House" fame), the Museum of Modern Art is more than enticing.

Downstairs, the relationship between pop and post-pop art, design and architecture is often as close as the Pompidou curators suggest it is. In one gallery, I found myself surrounded by the architecture and design, wrapped around with the art, that I first published as an assistant editor on the Architectural Review. It was like being surrounded by old friends. There were provocative designs for buildings and furniture by those Italian "Rationalists" (Aldo Rossi chief among them) and irrationalists of the 80s - Gaetano Pesce, Andrea Branzi, Michelle de Lucchi, Ettorre Sottsass - that made me smile and which my then editor frowned on with undisguised contempt. They looked great in the magazine, though, and are just as much fun today. And in between, there's a delightful silvery model with red and blue ductwork, au Pompidou, of an unrealised hospital "module" made by Piano + Rogers in 1970, a year before work began on the cultural centre.

Above the museum is a gallery of contemporary art. The interior architecture, by Bodin, is much as the museum below. On level 6 there's a zooty, curvy 350-seater terrace restaurant (not open on my visit) designed by the young architects Dominique Jakob and Brendan MacFarlane.

There is truly something for everyone in the new-look Pompidou, although Rogers and Piano are upset that the introduction of a vertical loft and stair shaft into the core of the building has destroyed the once seamless flow of the interiors, and neither agrees with the idea of visitors having to pay to ride the escalators. Yet, as the architects agree, the Pompidou was designed for change;they meant that when they were the extremely unlikely winners of the design competition for the Pompidou Centre at the end of the 60s (there were more than 600 entries) and the building really can cope with change now - as it no doubt will again, and again, in the future.

webTitle: Work experience: The stars before they were famous

fields.headline: Work experience: The stars before they were famous
fields.standfirst: Helen Hunt in Project X  (Jonathan Kaplan, 1987)
fields.trailText: What Helen Hunt did before she was a film star
fields.body:
Who? Whey-faced star of the immensely popular sitcom Mad About You, and Oscar-winner for her role alongside Jack Nicholson in As Good As It Gets. Hunt, and her Mad About You co-star Paul Reiser, received a record-breaking $1,000,000 per episode for the 1999 season, an episode of which she also directed. Next up, after her recent marriage to fellow actor Hank Azaria, is a role in Robert Altman's gynaecologically-themed Doctor T And The Women.

The role: Teri McDonald, a psychology graduate whose research project is teaching a chimp, Virgil, sign language. When he's taken away, thanks to lack of funding for her work, he ends up in a US Airforce base where they teach him to fly. Sadly, however, pilot Jimmy Garrett (Matthew Broderick) discovers there are men at the base who want to do nasty things to the cute little monkeys (boo).

Best Line: When she finds out Virgil has to leave, Hunt pleads "But I raised him. He doesn't know anybody but me - he's not going to understand what's happening."

Cringe factor: Low, other than being out-acted by a chimp.

Other wannabes: William Sadler, who plays the titular project's evil head, Doctor Carroll, also appeared as Death in Bill And Ted's Bogus Journey, and stars in the forthcoming Stephen King adaptation, The Green Mile.

Critical judgement: Desson Howe in The Washington Post was ambivalent: "The film follows the fail-safe formula of every lovable creature flick from National Velvet to ET - but Hunt brings a sweetness to what is essentially a supportive venture."

Also not starring in: Girls Just Want To Have Fun, in 1985, and as Kathleen Turner's daughter in Peggy Sue Got Married the following year.

Project X, Sky MovieMax, Tuesday January 11, 7.0am

fields.headline: Fixing it at the lastminute
fields.standfirst: Ros Hollingworth went into the job with no internet skills. Now she's running the office at one of Britain's most exciting online businesses. Eve Vamvas reports
fields.trailText: Ros Hollingworth went into the job with no internet skills. Now she's running the office at one of Britain's most exciting online businesses. Eve Vamvas reports
fields.body:
Talk about success stories. In April 1998, two friends set up an internet company, lastminute.com, to offer late holiday deals online. Less than two years later, the site has more than 500,000 regular users and 80,000 daily browsers. Plans to float next year have valued the company at £400m, netting its founders Brent Hoberman, 31, and Martha Lane Fox, 26, a combined fortune of around £150m.

Ros Hollingworth's rise to PA to the two directors has been not quite as spectacular, but is no less a success story. She joined the company in August, her first job after graduating from Nottingham university. Originally fancying a career in TV production, her plan to study media was abandoned for a degree in classical civilisation after a year backpacking across Thailand. Her secretarial skills were minimal when she moved to London and began temping. "I didn't have any office experience so temping was a good way to get started. My typing skills are non-existent, but I was very comfortable with computers after researching and writing my thesis. I had a few interviews for receptionist posts, but when I heard about the job here, I really wanted it."

Fortunately, Hoberman and Lane Fox were not looking for an experienced, corporate PA. "I didn't know much about e-commerce or the internet and I was completely honest about my lack of experience. But I managed to show that I have the energy and the willingness to learn. I think the interview established that I would fit in here and have the potential to grow with the company."

Hollingworth coordinates both directors' diaries, and handles frantic media interest, but in general, she says, they are very self-sufficient. This frees Hollingworth's time to oversee the day-to-day running of lastminute.com alongside the office manager. A major part of this is handling the logistics of a rapid recruitment programme: Hollingworth started as the 40th employee, but over the past five months the staff has increased to 150. Going through online applications on the website's JobBox is a priority. "Martha was on Question Time recently and mentioned that lastminute.com is always looking for good, energetic people," she says. "I knew that the rest of my week would be taken over with CV sorting but even I was surprised by the overwhelming response."

It can seem that there is a new face everyday, and Hollingworth is the first port of call. "I suppose I am seen as the 'office fixer', particularly for new members of staff, but I like that role. I am responsible for getting them set up as quickly as possible in the office with their equipment and stationery and making sure they appear on our website. Everybody answers a fun questionnaire about themselves and gets featured on our 'About Us' page." She has had to learn just enough of the programming language HTML to ensure the website is kept up to date. Lastminute.com puts a big emphasis on communication, and on Fridays Hollingworth organises an informal staff lunch for everyone to air their news and views. With an average employee age of 27, there is also plenty of socialising going on and Hollingworth often finds herself arranging these events too. "It is a very electric, buzzing environment with a real community spirit but you need some serious energy to be able to keep up with the workload and the extra curricular activities. I love the informal atmosphere - there's no dress code and the organisation is truly merit-based - but I have spent quite a few weekends recovering from the previous week in time to regroup for next one."

But there are two big bonuses in her job: "No letter typing - everything is done via email and I like that immediacy. I also find working for Martha and Brent inspirational because they are hugely successful but are still sensible human beings. Martha recently spent the day having her photo taken for an Elle feature on inspirational women and was reeling from the shock of hanging around a studio with Claudia Schiffer. I can't really relate to Martha's success, but at times I don't think she can either!"

All employees will be offered stock options when the company floats and Hollingworth says this is an added incentive to contribute to the company.

"Essentially, this is where it's at. Aside from the fact that I love what I do, I am working for the leading lights in e-commerce, developing the most revolutionary industry around. I'm pretty pleased with the first job of my career."

fields.headline: Songs of innocence
fields.standfirst:
Angelika Kirchschlager and Helmut Deutsch
Wigmore Hall
***
fields.trailText: In a supposedly post-feminist age, it is hard to stifle a chuckle (or a grimace) at the sentiments expressed in the poetry to which much of the romantic lieder repertoire for female voice is set. Many of the texts in the first half of this recital were no exception, and it is to Angelika Kirchschlager's credit that she could make an audience armed with translations believe fully in these wonderful settings.
fields.body:
In a supposedly post-feminist age, it is hard to stifle a chuckle (or a grimace) at the sentiments expressed in the poetry to which much of the romantic lieder repertoire for female voice is set. Many of the texts in the first half of this recital were no exception, and it is to Angelika Kirchschlager's credit that she could make an audience armed with translations believe fully in these wonderful settings. Of the five Schubert songs that opened the recital, only Vom Mitleiden Maria avoided the scene of submissive love. Back on the usual subject, Gretchen am Spinnrade found Kirchschlager and her accompanist Helmut Deutsch recreating vividly the tension and unrest that plagues the narrator.

Kirchschlager's rich tone, polished and even, suited Schumann's cycle Frauenliebe und-leben well. The central song, Süsser Freund, was poised and radiant; while she may not have the lightness of touch and variety of expression that, say, Anne-Sophie von Otter can bring to the song, her nuances of colour are thoughtful and can be really special. A tendency to sing just under the note was Kirchschlager's only real weakness. Ensemble between singer and accompanist was always tight, but, as was the case throughout the recital, a little more presence from Deutsch was needed.

Alma Mahler suffered the sharp end of these 19th century fantasies about a woman's calling. The five songs Kirchschlager chose spring from the old lieder tradition, but seemed to occupy a different sound world, darkly chromatic, both evocative and inventive.

fields.headline: UK 'could join euro at DM3'
fields.standfirst:
Sterling's entry into single currency is inevitable, says Nobel economist

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The so-called godfather of the euro, Nobel prize-winning economist Robert Mundell, yesterday predicted that Britain could safely join the currency at an exchange rate of almost three marks without flattening the economy.
fields.body:
The so-called godfather of the euro, Nobel prize-winning economist Robert Mundell, yesterday predicted that Britain could safely join the currency at an exchange rate of almost three marks without flattening the economy.

In an interview with the Guardian he said it was inevitable that sterling would be replaced by the single currency within four years and that productivity improvements meant the economy could cope with an exchange rate of DM2.95 - the level at which the pound crashed out of the exchange rate mechanism in 1992.

Mr Mundell - regarded by many as the world's leading expert on currencies - said Britain and the other countries outside the euro zone - Greece, Denmark and Sweden - would realise very soon that they had no alternative but to become part of monetary union. "It is a fait accompli. Whatever the UK says about [the euro] it isn't going to go away. It's going to succeed."

If Britain stayed out the euro, it would pay the price in higher interest rates because it had proved in the past that it was not able to operate its economy independently without inflationary pressures building up, Mr Mundell said. "That's a big cost to British industry."

Mr Mundell won the Nobel prize last year for his work on exchange rates and currency areas. He was one of the first to propose monetary union in Europe more than 30 years ago and is a strong advocate of fixed-rate exchange systems.

At a meeting on challenges for the new millennium at the foreign office-financed conference centre Wilton Park in Sussex, Mr Mundell predicted that within a decade the world would split up into three currency areas: the euro zone, a dollar zone and a yen zone.

The euro zone would include at least 28 countries and have a larger combined annual income than the United States.

The Nobel Prize winner believes improvements in productivity - particularly in the services sector - mean Britain could join the euro zone with the pound valued at the equivalent to DM2.95, even though that is the rate which is considered to have crippled manufacturing when Britain tied itself into the ERM 10 years ago.

Mr Mundell said Britain's time in the ERM, which caused unemployment to soar to nearly 3m and ended with the pound being blown out of the pegged rate system by speculators in September 1992, had been good for the economy because it squeezed inflation out of the system.

"The common view is that the ERM was a disaster. But by going in Britain stopped its inflation, which was 8%."

Hostility to the single currency was partly based on the experience of the ERM, he said, but people had drawn the wrong lessons from the episode. Public opinion had turned against it because British politicians blamed Germany for failing to defend the pound when it was under attack by speculators. "I think Britain gained from that experience but learned the wrong lessons from it."

Mr Mundell said that choosing the right rate for the pound's value against other currencies when it joined would be critical.

Because of improvements in the economy's performance since 1992 it was now possible for it to withstand a pound fixed at the equivalent of Dm2.95, and entering at a lower level would be inflationary.

The Nobel prize-winner's advice on the appropriate value for sterling will not be welcomed by the manufacturing sector, which believes the strength of the pound is pricing their goods out of world markets.

Sterling has been trading above DM3 for much of the last three years, but Mr Mundell said the decision on an entry rate should not be dictated by industry.

"The exchange rate which might appear to be right for manufacturing is not right for financial services. To let manufacturing call the tune with respect to the exchange rate is misguided. The economy is now dominated by the service sector - as with all advanced economies."
