fields.headline: Lunch hour - what lunch hour?
fields.standfirst: Many workers are made to feel they are shirking if they stop for a break. But, says Annabelle Thorpe, staff work better if they take time to eat properly and relax
fields.trailText: Many workers are made to feel they are shirking if they stop for a break. But, says Annabelle Thorpe, staff work better if they take time to eat properly and relax
fields.body:
'Lunch is for wimps," growled Michael Douglas's grotesque creation Gordon Gecko in the film Wall Street. Supposedly a portrayal of eighties excess and corporate greed at its most extreme, this attitude is still mirrored across office life. Taking time out to eat during the day is for slackers and subordinates - basically a privilege of those not busy enough, or conscientious enough, to know better. For those who have any ambition to get ahead, there is no such thing as a free lunch hour.

"I can't remember the last time I took an hour for lunch," says Bernadette Carmen, who works as a PA. "Usually it's about half an hour - I always try to go and get some fresh air even if it's just to buy a paper, but my boss rarely stops for lunch and he seems to expect the same of me. In my contract it says I should take an hour for lunch each day, but realistically, no one does that."

Depressingly, this appears to be the norm. According to a survey carried out by catering company Eurest, which manages staff canteens and corporate dining rooms from military bases to Mayfair property companies, the concept of an hour for lunch is ridiculously outdated - only one in three people take more than half an hour's break.

"For some reason we feel as if taking a break for lunch is a bit of a cheek," says business consultant Simon Marks. "In fact it's essential - both for health and work reasons. Most of us are tied to computer screens all day and it is imperative to give your eyes a break and to take your mind off work, even if it's only for 20 minutes or so. Otherwise you'll get to four in the afternoon and not be able to concentrate, which is totally counterproductive."

There is some evidence that workers are realising that they have to stop for a while and eat if they want to be able to work through the afternoon. In 1997, 42% of workers in the south claimed never to take a lunch break: a year later this had fallen to 18%. This is particularly important since many of us have done away with breakfast. "I never eat breakfast," says legal secretary Sara Lambert, "and when things used to get really busy here I often wouldn't eat lunch. I'd stuff back chocolate in the afternoon which would lift me for an hour, but then I'd feel really weird. I nearly fainted on the tube on the way home one night, and decided enough was enough. Even if all I do for lunch is nip out and get a sandwich, I always make sure I eat." The health and safety executive says all employers have a responsibility to encourage workers to take proper breaks, and to provide a suitable seating area for them to use. This should be clean, say the guidelines, and provide a means of heating food and making hot drinks. But employers who go further have seen the benefit of creating a proper lunch space on site - more than half those workers who have a workplace canteen use it four times a week or more and over a fifth believe that socialising with colleagues at lunch boosts their performance.

"Everything changed here when the canteen opened," says Jeanne Lawrence, secretary in a large consulting firm. "The pressure here is very high and my lunch hour used to consist of making a list of what everyone wanted for lunch and spending half an hour queuing in the sandwich bar. But when the canteen opened, lunch became much easier. Most people go down and sit for at least 15 minutes. Somehow, because you're still in the building, it doesn't really feel like taking lunch."

In spite of the fact that many of us still work under intense pressure, it does seem that the pendulum is swinging back a little from the harsh long hours of the late eighties, when recession-hit companies insisted on squeezing every last minute out of their employees. Although the hedonistic liquid lunches have never made a return (85% of workers say they never touch alcohol at lunch), taking the opportunity to head off down to the pub for a ploughman's, or to a local cafe for a plate of pasta is increasingly common.

"The office isn't all about work," says Marks. "The social aspects of working life are also important - and lunchtime is the main chance we get to chat with colleagues about other things, to relax and be ourselves. Having a laugh or sharing a moan is hugely healthy and it helps to combat stress. Everyone, to a greater or lesser degree, adopts a persona in the workplace and a lunchbreak is the only chance to shrug it off for a while."

Perhaps surprisingly, there is no legal requirement for your boss to give you an hour off at lunch, says Mike Emmett of the IPD. "A lunch 'hour' can be whatever length is defined in your contract, so it's important to pay attention to that particular clause." But with the Department of Health estimating that 6m working days are lost each year due to stress, it makes sense for companies to encourage employees to take a breather. "It is important to get some relaxation in your working day," says an NHS spokesman. "Even if it is just 10 minutes. If you close your eyes, breathe deeply and think about something totally different, you can really calm yourself down."

Of course it can be extremely difficult to take breaks if your boss consistently works through his or her lunch hour, but workers should be expected to compromise their health because of their boss's habits. It's always a good idea to check that there is nothing urgent to do before you leave for lunch, and give an estimated time for how long you'll be gone. Then head for the pub, the park, the sandwich bar, and even if only for 20 minutes, switch off. And enjoy it.

fields.headline: You'll hear from my lawyer
fields.standfirst: Finola Lynch on the trend for workers to go to court to solve office grievances
fields.trailText: Finola Lynch on the trend for workers to go to court to solve office grievances
fields.body:
Everyone gets fed up with work from time to time. We all moan about being overworked and underpaid, but generally have to grin and bear it. What happens, though, when a meeting with your manager doesn't sort out office problems? How bad does it have to get before you stop moaning to colleagues and start talking to your lawyer?

Record numbers of workers are now turning to the law to sort out their workplace grievances. In 1998, the Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service (Acas) reported its biggest ever employment tribunal caseload, a 6% rise to 112,000 claims in just one year. Ten years ago the figure was 50,000.

Acas argues that these figures show employees have become more politicised and less complacent. "People are more aware of their individual rights and are more willing to do something about their grievances," says chairman John Hougham.

But a glance at the latest report from the TUC suggests another motive - compensation. The trade union umbrella body announced last month that in 1998 it won more than £308m in compensation from employers for members either injured or made ill at work, an increase of 10% on the previous year and its second highest figure ever. Compensation claims for stress alone soared by 70%.

Last year's landmark case of a secretary who successfully sued her employer for stress has crystallised the belief that a compensation culture is beginning to bite in the workplace. Beverley Lancaster, a former Birmingham city council employee, won more than £67,000 for the mental anguish she suffered after being switched from a clerical job to a much more demanding role in a neighbourhood housing office. The Institute of Directors was worried enough to warn its members to expect a tidal wave of copycat compensation claims.

So is the workplace becoming more stressful, unhealthy and dangerous, or are we greedier? Certainly high-profile cases with huge awards do encourage others to sue, says Ronnie Fox, an employment law specialist with City law firm Fox Williams. "We've seen a huge increase in the number of employment disputes of any nature, particularly those involving industrial tribunals, because of the compensatory element."

But the boom in litigation is not just down to greed, he stresses. Changes in government legislation have given tribunals much greater power to compensate in sex and disability discrimination cases, and have made access to the courts much easier for ordinary workers. One of the most significant changes, for example, is a reduction in the time workers must have been with a firm before being able to claim unfair dismissal - now one year instead of two. Adverts from law firms are now appearing on television offering "no win, no fee" representation, while trade unions are quickly expanding their legal services departments to match the new climate.

The white collar union MSF (manufacturing, science and finance) is planning to set up a 24-hour call centre for members seeking legal advice. But spokesman Richard O'Brien denies trade unions are actively encouraging workers to sue. "In most cases you still find that people don't know the system until they find themselves in the situation. We are the first point of call because they need to find out what their rights are."

Marjorie Mair, head of secretarial and administrative development at the Industrial Society, recently came across the case of a woman who needed to go on a course for her job, but whose manager wouldn't meet the course fees. "The poor woman rang us to ask if she could pay the £350 herself in instalments," she says. "The manager refused to discuss the matter and the woman said the incident had upset her enough to make her leave. Potentially she could sue for constructive dismissal."

The TUC wants to formalise workplace rights even further and is lobbying for a new code of practice on managing stress at work, as well as tougher regulations on working time. But, says Mair, the responsibility for avoiding litigation at work really lies with employers. "They have got to be both supportive and involving, whatever the scenario, and come up with ways of improving things for the secretary."

The workplace revolution has seen some secretaries assuming what are effectively managerial roles, while others find themselves marginalised and offered limited opportunities. In both cases, say the experts, changing roles demand a commitment to training and support if bosses want to avoid turning an unhappy support worker into a litigious one.

fields.headline: Here to stay
fields.standfirst: Temping is no longer a stopgap job. A new breed are bonding with their employers. Bill Saunders reports
fields.trailText: Temping is no longer a stopgap job. A new breed are bonding with their employers. Bill Saunders reports
fields.body:
The 1990s was the decade of the temp. And as the growth of temp vacancies outgrew the creation of permanent jobs, often dramatically so, there was much debate as to whether this was a good or bad thing. For some this was "the age of anxiety" as job security became a thing of the past. More recently economists have suggested that the flexibility (and, it must be said, the lower labour costs) of temps were the secret of what has become known as the "goldilocks" economy - not too hot, not too cold, but just right.

Theory aside, at the sharp end of the business on the first working day of the new decade, things were much the same as the start of the last. It seems that for many employers the temp is still for emergencies only. At temp specialists Tate Appointments last week, one client was seeking a temp for maternity cover. Hadn't they noticed their full-time employee was pregnant before?

None the less this demonstrates the flexibility and convenience of the temping system. Tate's managing director Julia Robertson says, "If it wasn't for temps the economy would grind to a halt."

But behind the rush things have changed. For many temps, temping is no longer a stopgap between jobs. In a survey last year 70% of Tate's secretaries said they expected to be temping for at least a year - "as long as one might spend in a permanent job," says Robertson. Typical of the new breed of temp is Camilla Pettit, an actor by profession and a successful temp by day (in November she was Tate's temp of the month, incidentally). For Pettit, her principal relationship is with her agency. She began temping in 1996 during a break from drama school.

"It is as if I had been with the same employer all the time. They know me and are very understanding about things such as time off for auditions." Like many professional temps, she works for a small portfolio of firms, many of which ask for her by name.

Robertson says this is not unusual. Many Tate temps work for three or four companies. It is an arrangement that benefits all parties because it makes for fewer cold starts. The temps build knowledge as they go, says Robertson, and employers have the advantage of calling in temps who understand how they work.

As an actor, Pettit understands the nature of job insecurity better than most. But, she stresses, she has never experienced it in her day job. "The only days I don't work are bank holidays and my own holidays". It is a better position than most of her drama school contemporaries have found themselves in. "Secretarial skills were compulsory at my school," she says, "and I'm so glad they were." She agrees that many people are reluctant to acquire them because of the image problem attached. "People don't like the thought of being stuck in an office all day." But, certainly for an actor, it is much better to be based in an office during the day than have to work in the evening, as is demanded by most other casual work. Pettit has just finished a short run in fringe theatre during which she was still able to earn a wage during the day. She describes the experience as "exhausting" but at least it was possible. Her friends from drama school who support themselves through bar and restaurant work watched enviously. Many of them, she says, are saving up for secretarial courses.

Temp rates in London

 A team secretary, with the basic skills such as Word and Excel, can expect to earn between £9.50 and £10.50 an hour.

 A temporary PA can earn between £10 and 11.50 per hour, or between £11 and £12 if they have shorthand.

 Junior admin assistants and receptionists generally earn between £8 and £9.

(Information supplied by MaineTucker Recruitment)

fields.headline: Learn shorthand
fields.trailText: "When I started learning shorthand it was for the girls who were not going to university," says Jenny Smith. Now 54 and a PA at the north-east London probation service, she has been using her shorthand for more than 30 years, and in the past worked specifically as a shorthand secretary in various jobs. "It took me a while to appreciate that it is a skill," she says. "It would have been better marketed as a second written language."
fields.body:
"When I started learning shorthand it was for the girls who were not going to university," says Jenny Smith. Now 54 and a PA at the north-east London probation service, she has been using her shorthand for more than 30 years, and in the past worked specifically as a shorthand secretary in various jobs. "It took me a while to appreciate that it is a skill," she says. "It would have been better marketed as a second written language."

Invented by Isaac Pitman in the 1800s, by the 1960s many regarded his "new era" shorthand system - with its complicated grammalogues, shortforms and contractions - as too much like hard work; a new version of Pitman and the Teeline system were introduced. Most colleges now offer Teeline, which is based on the alphabet rather than phonetics, and is quicker and easier to learn.

Despite dictaphones and voice-activated technology, shorthand skills are still much in demand. Employment agencies report a constant call for shorthand secretaries, and Jean Newland of the London chamber of commerce and industry estimates that shorthand skills can add £2,000 to a PA's salary. Its sweetness may be in its simplicity - once you've got it down, no computer blip or system crash is going to get in the way. Shorthand notes are often the only practical way to minute large meetings, tribunals and court hearings.

And, of course, it looks very impressive. "Once you've done it, there is something about it that makes you feel really smug," smiles Smith.

 How do I learn? Adult education centres, FE colleges and private secretarial colleges offer courses, or you can teach yourself. For Pitman courses, call Pitman's Qualifications Customer Inquiry Unit on 0171 294 2800. Books include Teeline Shorthand Made Simple by Harry Butler (Butterworth Heinemann, £9.99) and Teach Yourself Pitman 2000 (Hodder & Stoughton, £9.99).

 How long will it take? With dedication, you can reach a speed of 100 words per minute in Teeline after 36 weeks. To reach the same speed in Pitman can take up to two years. Oh, and you'll have to take exams.

 How much will it cost? Self-teaching is the cheapest, evening classes cost £80-£100 a term depending on where you live, and private tuition could run into hundreds of pounds.

 Is it like riding a bike? Keeping your shorthand alive and well does require practice - perhaps by transcribing voices from the radio. For the truly dedicated, there are novels in shorthand - Anna Karenina in Teeline, anyone?

fields.headline: Boom and gloom
fields.standfirst: More jobs, higher wages, bigger bonuses - it promises to be a bumper year. But, reports Esther Addley, it's not all good news
fields.trailText: More jobs, higher wages, bigger bonuses - it promises to be a bumper year. But, reports Esther Addley, it's not all good news
fields.body:
The future's bright - you've probably heard that once or twice in the past couple of weeks. But millennial hype aside, it does indeed seem that for administrative and support staff, 2000 looks set to be a bumper year in terms of career opportunities. A new report by employment agency Gordon Yates and the Guardian, which surveyed secretarial employers and employees, has taken a snapshot of the secretarial sector at the turn of the century - and reveals a picture of an industry in bouncing good health.

"A year ago widespread press coverage speculated on the possibility of an economic downturn in the UK," says Richard Grace, managing director of Gordon Yates. "In the event, this didn't happen, and this year's survey suggests that optimism about prospects has strengthened." The principal reason for cheer among administrative and support staff is that employment opportunities are booming, which puts skilled secretarial staff at an extremely high premium. Secretarial appointments have been growing healthily for the past five years, but predictions for this year are even rosier - a quarter of firms say they will be hiring more admin staff.

Salaries are also up: 1999 saw a 4.4% increase in wage packets, the highest rise in real terms for 10 years. More than half of companies now offer bonuses to their staff, at an average value of £1,648 per employee. And companies are spending an average of £721 a year to train each of their staff, well up on the previous year. Never had it so good? The figures are certainly persuasive.

The increasing emphasis on bonuses and perks is one of the most significant features of the changing secretarial landscape, according to Grace. "It used to be that a quarter of the workforce got a little extra at Christmas, but now a significant proportion of employers will pay a reasonably chunky bonus. It's a material part of the package that started two or three years ago."

But this is not necessarily all good news for the milliennial secretary. The increasing popularity of bonuses is partly a way for employers to make jobs more attractive without committing themselves to a salary increase. Wages may be up, but the really high rates witnessed during the last big boom in the late 80s have not, in the main, materialised.

And there are other blots on the apparently blossoming landscape. While talented secretaries and PAs are much in demand, a quarter of firms say it is increasingly difficult to find good staff. "We have a huge influx of jobs but extremely good candidates aren't walking through our doors at a rate of knots," says Jane Littlefield, manager of the secretarial division at employment agency Joslin Rowe. "To find a good calibre candidate with good skills and shorthand seems to be asking the earth these days."

This might be because employers are becoming more demanding. Aside from shorthand, the skills employers nominate as being in short supply centre almost entirely on attitude, the so-called "soft skills". Initiative is the ability believed to be rarest in candidates, followed by commitment, a positive attitude, common sense and flexibility. You may type and file like a wizard, but it's not necessarily enough.

Mike Cannell, training and development adviser at the Institute of Personnel and Development, does not think this trend is confined to the secretarial industry. "More and more companies are saying, 'Everybody has access to the same technology - what differentiates us from the rest? It's the people.' You are looking for people who have that little bit extra.

Of course, "that little bit extra" is often what secretarial staff are itching to demonstrate. Asked what changes they would make to their current role, respondents said more responsibility, less tedious tasks such as basic typing and administration, and more opportunity for career development. And what's most important in a job? Not pay, which ranked a lowly sixth place, but simply recognition.

A more flexible employment market may have made the secretarial role less easily defined, but for those prepared to take their career into their own hands, the opportunities are impressive. "There's more going on, and more variety than there was in the past," says Grace. "It has complicated everyone's role, but it's more fun these days."

fields.headline: Only in America?
fields.standfirst:
Spin
White Bear, London
***
fields.trailText: In an Iowa hotel room during the state primary to elect a candidate for the presidential race, two opposing campaign managers square up. Jerry has every reason to be confident knowing that his man, Henry, is 15 points ahead in the polls. But Mary has a gleam in her eye that suggests that, like an ace poker-player, she has something up her sleeve.
fields.body:
In an Iowa hotel room during the state primary to elect a candidate for the presidential race, two opposing campaign managers square up. Jerry has every reason to be confident knowing that his man, Henry, is 15 points ahead in the polls. But Mary has a gleam in her eye that suggests that, like an ace poker-player, she has something up her sleeve.

So it proves: in an American election in which it is the candidates' personalities, not their policies that count, Henry's wife, Alex, and her past are about to prove a liability. Or are they? In the world of political spin, the bad can be turned to your advantage just as easily as the good.

Now that we in Britain are all so familiar with Alastair Campbell, the moment for Robert William Sherwood's play may have passed. But while its cynicism about the political process is probably somewhat less than the audience's, it is still extremely watchable and funny. "Alex can you cry? Don't worry, we can teach you," is the spin-doctors' response to the painful revelations about her life, oblivious to the fact that she may be genuinely hurting.

There is a schematic feel to the play that lessens its impact. But its wit and its jaundiced view of human nature is spot on, the production is sharp and in the bilious Jerry, a man who so believes his own press releases he has lost all touch with reality, Sherwood has created one of the most memorable stage monsters of recent years.

Until January 30. Box office: 0171-793 9193
